2390752.text:
Today is the last day to buy formal tickets for the formal TOMORROW! You
can pick up your ticket during dinner tonight in the Gold Room if you have
already bought it. If you would prefer to pay by cash or card, we will be
selling tickets during dinner as well!

From: Adams HoCo Publicity <adamshocoannounce@gmail.com>

but there is still time left to *purchase *and *pick up *yours.
and if seeing *Indigo* and DJ *Brenda Ceja* isn't incentive enough,

SO GET READY AND PSYCHED FOR

3217707.subject: [ADAMS] üíõüíôLAST DAY TO APPLY TO ECHO!! APPLICATIONS DUE 11:59PM TONIGHT! Sign-Up NOW! Be an ECHO Peer Counselor! üíôüíõ
3217707.text:
Start your application HERE
<https://streaklinks.com/BerfTcUZGXP-EPm1RAWHPzWD/https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSeWntw92peY0clFqAmS3SZMiufnpW5R6MYlrqRBabORQKd1OA%2Fviewform%3Fusp%3Dsf_link>
.


ECHO is interviewing for new Fall 2023 staffers!

Are you concerned about body, eating, and exercise issues on campus?

Would you like to support those around you?

Are you a good listener?


You can become an ECHO (Eating Concerns Hotline and Outreach)

 peer counselor ‚Äî no experience needed!

Start your application HERE
<https://streaklinks.com/BerfTo86us_yaD_bvwrJLyTS/https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSeWntw92peY0clFqAmS3SZMiufnpW5R6MYlrqRBabORQKd1OA%2Fviewform%3Fusp%3Dsf_link>
.

The application includes a short-answer Google form questionnaire and a
follow up Zoom interview. We would love to have you apply.

The Zoom link is below.

You will log on with the Zoom link here
<https://streaklinks.com/BerfTcQKSi9PWcxLkwVheMdy/https%3A%2F%2Fharvard.zoom.us%2Fj%2F96698486573>(and
below) at the time of your interview.

Complete the online form here
<https://streaklinks.com/BerfTcYsLEADoNfjVAqTRkJ4/https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSeWntw92peY0clFqAmS3SZMiufnpW5R6MYlrqRBabORQKd1OA%2Fviewform%3Fusp%3Dsf_link>
.

Sign up for your interview slot here
<https://streaklinks.com/BerfTc8gYMpmjXitxgyGEnF6/https%3A%2F%2Fcalendly.com%2Fharvardecho%2Fnew-staffer-interviews-s2023%3Fmonth%3D2023-04>
.

Once you sign-up for a slot, the Zoom link will be: bit.ly/echof23interviews
.

You can also find the link, the application, and any other relevant material on
our website
<https://streaklinks.com/BerfTcY5eb4Sv19q9ANIo4hG/http%3A%2F%2Fharvardecho.crd.co>
.

*All applications are due at midnight on Sunday, April 23rd.*

ECHO is a peer counseling group that provides a confidential,
non-judgmental, non-directive space for undergraduate students to receive
support about any concern. ECHO specializes in addressing concerns about
exercising, body image, food, eating, and eating disorders.

****

ECHO is committed to training and maintaining a staff that reflects the
diversity of the people who struggle with eating concerns and/or body image
issues on campus. People of color have historically been underrepresented
in ECHO as an organization. In this and as in recent semesters, we are
reaching out to people of as many different backgrounds and experiences as
possible.

No concern is too big or too small.

14776860.subject: Summer Storage, Financial Aid Fair, Senior Week, and more!
14776860.text:
View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/21442008b4f2/welcome-to-the-hua-13544447?e=471a08c560)
https://www.thehua.org


** Hi Eelaaf!
------------------------------------------------------------

Happy Spring! Yardfest is behind us and the semester is nearly over, but the HUA is still hard at work delivering for you. This email includes important updates about the Summer Storage Program, Senior Week, Intersectional Earth Week, and a financial aid fair organized by the Inclusion Team!


** Senior Week
------------------------------------------------------------

For the first time ever, the HUA will be providing $5,000 in funding to Senior Week! The Senior Week planning committee starts with a budget of $0 and has had to raise event ticket prices every year. We want to ensure that every senior can enjoy the week‚Äôs events, and hope to set a lasting precedent for future years. Stay tuned for more updates from the Class Marshals about Senior Week events!


** Financial Aid Fair
------------------------------------------------------------

The HUA Inclusion Team is hosting a Financial Aid Fair!

What: The Financial Aid Fair is an opportunity for students to get together and have a designated space and time to work on their financial aid applications. As the due date for financial aid materials approaches (May 1st), this fair will also be a time for students to get support and assistance from Financial Aid Officers throughout this process. We will provide food (Raising Canes) and drinks for participants.

When: Thursday, April 20th ( 5pm- 6:45pm)

Where: Science Center Hall C


** Summer Storage
------------------------------------------------------------
Register for the 2023 Summer Storage Program (https://airtable.com/shr1hvx0yR2LIFquz)

Registration

Claim your spot in the Summer Storage Program by clicking the above button!

The Harvard Undergraduate Association will partner with Five Stars Movers to provide a Summer Storage Program by renting a warehouse for students to store their belongings until they return to campus in Fall 2023. To store until Fall 2023, the cost will be $15 per box which is significantly cheaper than Olympia and CollegeBoxes. With your Student Activities Fee (SAF), we were able to successfully negotiate a cheap alternative. This is an excellent example of using SAF funds to benefit students. Additionally, this year‚Äôs storage program is protected by a legally-binding contract that was approved by Harvard and the storage company. This will ensure financial protection for students and establish clear expectations for everyone to avoid some past issues.

Logistics

We have altered the drop-off dates by pushing them one day later. Additionally, we successfully negotiated a drop-off site accessible to freshmen in the Yard that will live in the Quad Fall 2023.

River Drop-off and Pick-up:

The Drop-off and Pick-up location for the River Houses (Fall 2023) will be located at Beren Hall at the corner of Mill and Plympton Street by Winthrop (River Location (https://goo.gl/maps/osvXt2ASWzCmGme9A) ). All days will operate between 10:00am to 5:00pm. These are the finalized corresponding Drop-off and Pick-up Dates:

1. Drop-off May 6th and Pick-up Sept. 4th

2. Drop-off May 9th and Pick-up Aug. 30th

3. Drop-off May 11th and Pick-up Sept. 3rd

4. Drop-off May 12th and Pick-up Sept. 2nd

Quad Drop-off and Pick-up:

The Drop-off and Pick-up location for the Quad Houses (Fall 2023) will be located at the Quad Main Lot between Bertram and Eliot Halls (Quad Location (https://goo.gl/maps/LRcxWD8zj2K9jp9k7) ). All days will operate between 11:00am to 3:00pm. These are the finalized corresponding Drop-off and Pick-up Dates:

1. Drop-off May 9th and Pick-up Aug. 30th

2. Drop-off May 11th and Pick-up Sept. 3rd

3. Drop-off May 12th and Pick-up Sept. 2nd

Littauer Drop-off for Quadded Freshman:

The Storage Program successfully negotiated an additional location for freshman in the Yard that will live in the Quad Fall 2023 (Littauer Parking Lot Location (https://goo.gl/maps/QdA2mKjBV1qsY5ue9) ). Drop-off will operate will operate between 11:00am to 3:00pm.

1. Drop-off May 6th at Littauer Parking Lot and Pick-up Sept. 4th at the Quad location.

Additional Key Information
1. We expect to close form submissions on May 3rd at 11:59pm or when we reach our 6000 box limit, whatever comes first.
2. The storage company has agreed to sell boxes before the scheduled drop-off dates at $8/box. Time and location are still being discussed, but are aimed to be during Reading Period. You may find other options elsewhere like FedEx or UPS stores.
3. Box dimensions are 18‚Äù by 18‚Äù by 24‚Äù. Medium-sized luggage with approximately the same volume is acceptable as a box. If oversized, please consult this sheet (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uhkjn864yTWudy0n5IS85ihwADrWxhTftGt6NLouE2U/edit?usp=sharing) .
4. Friends are allowed to drop off other boxes. They are required to display proof of payment and have all of their boxes in the name of the owner.
5. Do not leave any important documents or items you may need during the storage window. The storage company will charge $200.00 fee to the student for rummaging through the boxes‚Äô contents at the warehouse.
6. Maximum cap of 10 boxes per student.
7. Any oversized items will be charged on-the-site by the storage company. For example, if you have 7 items (3 oversized, 4 regular), you still pay 7 items * $15/item = $105. Extra charges will be made by the company with their discretion.
8. Do not worry about overpaying us. We will have a refund system set up after the completion of the drop-off dates to address this.
9. You may split up your boxes between drop-off dates. However, you will then expect to pick up different boxes on the different corresponding pick-up dates in the Fall.

The Team

Leading the team is Corbin Lubianski as Overall Program Head, Jerelyn Fernandez as On-the-Day Captain, and Autumn Dorsey as Communication Head. We also want to note the Residential Life Officer Hamza Masoud for also leading this program with us.

We desperately rely on volunteers to make sure questions are answered by monitoring our email and helping out on-the-day. If you are interested in helping out, please fill out this form (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSecGqOkVCv9SFdCdTR-oc7qxRBJAZWdHWeKeQYK4fY-ovY5Ow/viewform) if you have the time to help out. We anticipate giving volunteers a discounted rate of $5/box for 10 boxes per volunteer.

Contact

Please reach out to thehuastorage@gmail.com (mailto:thehuastorage@gmail.com) if you have any questions or concerns. Please remember that for very specific questions, especially with oversized fees, can be addressed directly to Five Stars Movers at (617) 787-2801.
Volunteer to help run the Storage Program! (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSecGqOkVCv9SFdCdTR-oc7qxRBJAZWdHWeKeQYK4fY-ovY5Ow/viewform)


** Check out Intersectional Earth Week!
------------------------------------------------------------


** The HUA is cosponsoring these events alongside Harvard Climate Coalition! Explore and celebrate the intersection between climate change and our lived experiences, identities, and interests. RSVP here.
------------------------------------------------------------
RSVP for events here! (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdXxePqji01XGqy6K67q3bGbBYz_mXuqNEA-mvs2HHvNR88wg/viewform)


** HUA Resources
------------------------------------------------------------

1. To become involved and stay updated about ongoing projects, please join the HUA Slack (https://join.slack.com/t/hua-dc68696/shared_invite/zt-18i4ouuhs-yYKcqdeK3GNjOi7SFTEX0g) !
2. Our website is www.thehua.org. Here, you can find information about the teams, our initiatives, and all of our sources of funding!
3. The HUA hosts weekly general meetings on Sundays 5-6 pm at Riverview Commons on Smith Campus Center 10th Floor. The meetings are open to all students, and every student has voting power!

Additionally, please fill out this form (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1SXVmM_lAYbLPVQAAW57EquKx6m_vUBUW1dMFxNJI4_Q/edit) if you want to join any of the HUA teams! You can read about each of the teams here (https://docs.google.com/document/d/14-5Y3KNm7k4uJny_LUa9scPujIHBz-XtaHXOF4xEsgg/edit?usp=sharing) .

Please use this form (https://forms.gle/2rjwdL4fTxQjNZ6M7) (linked below) to send us any ideas, thoughts, or feedback concerning our initiatives! We are looking forward to hearing from you.

Send us ideas! (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSc4PaOCYsLFfla43iFAP024n0lrMlXoQJtdz0veQTr06aweXg/viewform)

Thanks for reading! As always, If there is any way we can help you or your student organization, please do not hesitate to reach out.

Making Harvard Home,

John and Shikoh

HUA Co-Presidents
https://facebook.com/ https://instagram.com/ https://twitter.com/
Logo

Hi Eelaaf,

Google I/O is just around the corner and we thought you‚Äôd be interested in two Google Maps Platform technical sessions where you will learn about new capabilities to create next-gen immersive maps and to use data-driven styling and advanced markers to provide richer user experiences. Register for this live streaming event and join developers from around the world for networking, meetups, collaboration, and more.

Tech Sessions:

57382487.subject: [wics-chatter] Introducing the 2023-2024 WiCS Directors!
57382487.text:
[image: pasted image 0.png]

HI WiCS

We are so excited to introduce the 2023-24 WiCS Board. Please join us in
congratulating them!

[image: Screen Shot 2023-04-29 at 5.06.34 PM.png]



Thank you again to everyone who applied to be a WiCS Director ‚Äî WiCS is
lucky to have every single one of you. We will be sending out applications
soon to lead our annual Projects, so keep an eye out for that. All
directors are here to make your CS experience at Harvard the best that it
can be, so please don't hesitate to reach out to any of us to share any
ideas, voice concerns, or if you just want to talk. Always happy to involve
this community as much as possible!


We cannot wait for this upcoming year and hope that you are excited as
well! If you have any questions, shoot us a message :)



Best,

Karen & Rachna

-- 
www.harvardwics.com
With questions/concerns/anything at all we can help with, reach out to Rachna or Karen! (rachnagupta / karen_li @ college.harvard.edu)
---

61910431.subject: [Fyre] Justice Served for #JamesPennington ~ A Midnight Ray of Sunshine
61910431.text:
Good evening Members of the Harvard Community,

I'm writing to share *jubilant news* that on Monday, April 24, 2023, the *Yale
Board of Trustees* conferred *Dr. James W.C. Pennington**, the first Black
student ever at Yale University, *his Masters of Divinity after nearly *200
years* of institutional erasure and discriminatory denial of this degree.

[image: image.png]

*The Story*
James Pennington was born into slavery 1809 in Maryland, and after
courageously and craftily escaping slavery at 19 years old, he attended and
crafted awe-inspiring work through classes at Yale though he was not
allowed to even speak in class or access library resources.

Despite these undoubtedly soul-wearing injustices and the quality of his
labor, Pennington was never granted his degree. Throughout the past two
years, Noah Humphrey <https://www.instagram.com/knowaknow/> '23, M.Div.,
Yale University, has led student activism through co-founding the
Pennington Legacy Group to actualize action in support of this Degree
Conferral
<https://yaledailynews.com/blog/2023/04/24/yale-to-award-first-black-student-a-posthumous-degree/>,
and throughout the past two weeks, I was elated to partner
<https://www.instagram.com/p/CrjPKxvP_2W/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link> with
Noah and the Group to water the luminous fruits comprising this Letter with
the words of encouragement Dr. Cornel West
<https://utsnyc.edu/faculty/cornel-west/#:~:text=BIOgraphy,Dr.> shared with
me earlier this month which I shared with Yale.

*To Take Home*
Although some earnestly believed this Degree Conferral may not come to pass
& others actively labored to withhold it for as long as possible, it is my
joy tonight to share this celebration-worthy bit of Black History with you
all this evening as we simultaneously tenderly remember the injustices
inflicted upon Ralph Yarl, George Floyd, and innumerable other Black and
Brown bodies throughout the colonialist history and present of this country
in which we study.

It is my hope that this concrete moment of historical triumph inspires each
of you to continue pursuing the worthy, even and especially silently,
solitarily witnessed efforts that keep your heart pumping.

Your dream is *not* too big or too good for you, and it is my hope that you
return to this or my story when you need a reminder as well as for next
steps to become involved with this and similar future projects!


Wishing you all wellness, safety, and prosperity in these times!

Have a wonderful Summer Recess, and, to the Class of 2023, especially Dr.
Pennington, congratulations!!

Selah & Grace,
Jayla-Whitney
-----------------------

Jayla-Whitney Spidell

Harvard College | Class of 2023

A.B. Candidate in Psychology

Secondary, African-American Studies

IG <https://www.instagram.com/soleil.1689/>, FB
<https://www.facebook.com/jwspidell/>, LinkedIn

<jspidell@college.harvard.edu>

101497457.subject: [HUES] HUES Board elections happening TOMORROW 1 P.M
101497457.text:
Hey engineers!

Candidacy statements for 2023-2024 HUES Board positions are attached below!

*The election will take place TOMORROW on Friday**, April 28th *from
12:00PM - 3:00PM EDT*, but will likely not take the entire allocated time.* We
will be meeting in *Sever Hall, room 102. * Everyone is invited to join us!
Please take part in choosing the individuals who will be representing our
engineers in this board next year.


Because the meeting is relatively long, voters can come and go, but *if
you're running for a position please try to stay the whole time. **If you
are running for a position, but are unable to attend
the election deliberations, please email mwieczorek@college.harvard.edu
<gracekim@college.harvard.edu>** as soon as possible.*


*Please email me (mwieczorek@college.harvard.edu
<gracekim@college.harvard.edu>) or Molly (mollybosworth@college.harvard.edu
<mollybosworth@college.harvard.edu>) with any questions!*

A reminder about voting/election procedures is below.

*Voting/Election:*


   - *The election is open to all members of the hues-open list who would
   like to come for deliberations and voting.*
   - Because the meeting is relatively long, voters can come and go, but *if
   you're running for a position please try to stay the whole time (please let
   us know if you can only stay part of the time.)*
   -  Please keep speeches to under 3 minutes.
   - You may not take part in the deliberations for any position you are
   running for; you will be in a different room while deliberations happen
   among voters.
   - For each position, the candidate with the most votes will be elected -
   for positions with 2 chairs, the candidates with the top 2 most votes will
   be elected.

Please let me or Molly <mollybosworth@college.harvard.edu> know if you have
any questions, and I hope to see lots of you tomorrow!
-- 
Maycee Wieczorek
Harvard College Class of 2024
S.B Candidate in Mechanical Engineering

--

114923218.subject: [wics-chatter] Bridgewater Associated Investment Engineering Info Session
114923218.text:
Bridgewater Associates will be on campus next Thursday, April 27th at
12:30pm in the Smith Collaboration Commons Isaacson Room, with two of our
Investment Engineers to host an information session to learn more about
what we do at Bridgewater as well as the role Investment Engineers hold in
the organization.



We are currently recruiting for our summer 2024 internship programs, and we
thought members of your club might be interested in stopping by to learn
more! If you think others in your club might be interested, please send
this flyer along!




*What is Investment Engineering?*As an Investment Engineer, your mission is
to understand how the world‚Äôs markets and economies work and codify this
understanding. You will spend your time designing and building the
algorithms which are used to generate Bridgewater's views on markets,
translate those views into portfolios, and trade those portfolios. Every
piece of investment logic is owned by an Engineer who:

   - Is an expert in their investment domain and can hold the whole model
   of the investment system in their head.
   - Designs systems that beautifully express and run our investment logic
   and evolves with our investment understanding.
   - Runs and develops a team of engineers to build and maintain the
   investment system.



We also shape how Bridgewater does investment research: we deeply
understand how exploration is done and evolve the methods and tools to more
rapidly develop breakthrough insights.



*Explore more information about Bridgewater‚Äôs culture on our website **here*
<https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/www.bridgewater.com/principles-and-culture__;!!IBzWLUs!Rn0EllmoiBk7uMQf1ViaFdv_Ewz7_cDdPEDOXrfmxR3J9aNITucOl1W9NmZ7oeTJ0ZI8aix9G2JPaiYbEYpGiPd-vw$>
*.What is the opportunity for summer intern hires?*

   - We are looking for undergraduate and graduate students who have a high
   affinity for building well-engineered solutions to complex problems
   pertaining to economics, markets, portfolio management and trading.
   - Summer interns will work on a challenging investment engineering
   project throughout the course of their internship with the potential to
   have real impact in our investment process and to shape how we do work.
   - Interns will also participate in a summer-long Investment Engineering
   class which will give each participant a well-rounded experience that
   covers the gamut of the problems we face, and the thinking required to
   solve them
   - Top summer interns will receive full time offers to join the team
   following the successful completion of their degree.



Spots are limited, and I wanted to reach out to you first with a link to
RSVP <https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/7NBZVZ9>. We hire from a diversity of
backgrounds ‚Äì and don‚Äôt require any prior finance, econ, or markets
knowledge to join our investment community. We‚Äôd love to have members of
your org at the chat. If you know someone who is a creative thinker with an
interest in exploring complex problems, please feel free to share this
invite to them as a version of a ‚Äúplus one‚Äù!



We are also hosting 1:1 coffee chats with current Investment Engineers! If
you would like to sign up for a chat, please use this link
<https://calendly.com/evajoycespivey/harvard-coffee-chats>.

-- 
www.harvardwics.com
With questions/concerns/anything at all we can help with, reach out to Rachna or Karen! (rachnagupta / karen_li @ college.harvard.edu)
---

137257816.subject: [Fyre] Humanitarian Relief for Sudan
137257816.text:
*TLDR: Support humanitarian relief efforts in Sudan by Venmo‚Äôing
@sasharvard.*


Dear FYRE,


We hope this email finds you well!


As you might be aware, a war broke out in Sudan between the national armed
forces and a paramilitary group on April 15th, 2023. The situation has now
become what the UN has termed a *humanitarian catastrophe*.


   - It is mainly civilians being targeted. Water and electricity have been
   cut off since the beginning of the conflict.
   - Over 70% of the capital Khartoum's hospitals are now out of
   commission, with only 19 remaining servicing a population of 6.3 million.
   - The majority of international relief organizations have stopped
   operations in the country and most nations have evacuated their personnel.


Given the dire nature of the situation, the Harvard Society of Arab
Students, the African Students Association, and the Islamic Society are
raising funds for medical relief in the nation. We humbly request that you
consider contributing a donation of any size to support the relief effort.
You can do so through *SAS's Venmo: @sasharvard*.

All collected funds will support the Sudanese American Physicians'
Association (SAPA), Fill-a-Heart (FaH), and the Sudan Doctors' Union - UK
(SDU-UK). We are grateful for any support you can provide and would love it
if you can forward this email to others.

Sincerely,

Aisha Abdelhamid

-- 
Aisha Abdelhamid (she/her)
A.B. Candidate in Sociology
Harvard College | Class of 2023

141595280.subject: The Slowdown for April 20, 2023
141595280.text:
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=e545481fa707b124c07062df9a024918905e84e6bdfeaf35d0e13a4ba6c8ec6c9dca877170c842e406230769767bf61dd847d4a41719f80e 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=e545481fa707b12479277f1337e64a5e1d21089123c0ea6d26450a346bc450b662eea53e61e6eb69a722b171ff6f2061b6cd8ec03854d31a 
Give Now 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=e545481fa707b124fe5e8475aa8f152ee077cc343471fabca0c79f507081ac49d1f1b92016cbf441858aa9ad96b3357208e43a947ed37f07 
“I read the daily poems from The Slowdown with my morning coffee. These poems are a gift.” - Richarda E. 





 Today‚Äôs ingenious poem calls attention to the lived realities of financial literacy, how it‚Äôs touch and go, and how it‚Äôs thrust upon us if we are not fortunate to receive those lessons in our home.       

   
— Major

Learning Money in Reverse
 by Stephanie Niu



My mother can still afford to retire.

She withdraws her offer on the foreclosed house.


My drunken signature vanishes from a receipt.

Friends dodge disappearing plates of sushi.
The word bitcoin has never buzzed in my brain.

Boxes of takeout repackage themselves.

 

I return my first pair of full-priced boots.

I un-sign my first lease. I go home.

 

My parents remarry. I have not yet chosen

the school that will cost their life savings.

 

I close and seal the scholarship rejections.

My first paystub folds back into the letter.


My forehead unkisses the floor and I pass

the red envelope back to my mother.

 

We move into a smaller, more crowded house,

where I fry sesame seeds with Lao Lao, and the HOA


reprimands us for growing winter melon on the porch.

I pedal backwards on my sister’s bike. I hand back

 

her worn clothes. We put coins from our palms

back into our father’s coat, having just told him good job

 

because we think this is what he earns in a day,

and it is enough. He’s about to come home.
"Learning Money in Reverse" by Stephanie Niu. Used by permission of the poet.

>    each position.
>    - To run, you must be planning to be an enrolled student for the
>    entirety of the 2023-2024 academic year and you must have attended at least
>    two meetings over the past two semesters.
>    - The co-presidents reach out to guest speakers, communicate with the
>    club, plan events, and generally oversee things. The treasurer gets funding
>    from the HUA, buys stuff, and keeps a record of financial transactions. The
>    secretary controls media and outreach activities.
>    - You're encouraged to run for anything you're interested in!
>    - Please feel free to contact anyone on the board if you have
>    questions.
>    - If you're free at our meeting tomorrow, feel free to do some light
>    campaigning :)
>
> *April 29 - May 1: Voting period*
>
>    - Once the candidacy declaration period is over, we will email out the
>    candidates' statements to the whole club.
>    - All members will then be able to read the statements and vote on the
>    new board. Each member may, of course, only vote once.
>
> *May 2: Election results*
>
>    - On May 2, we will make the results public and announce our board for
>    next year.
>    - If there is a tie, we will have a run-off election.
>
> Best,
> Joanna (the only graduating board member, and therefore your impartial
> parliamentarian)
>

171012027.subject: [ADAMS] Visitas 2023: Mini Tabling+Boba and Board Games TOMORROW!
171012027.text:
You already know the vibes. Visitas 2023 at PBHA is officially TOMORROW!!

YOU+mini tabling+boba+board games=an amazing Sunday!


Our annual Visitas event is around the corner, please RSVP here
<https://forms.gle/tndYHhZn46vw441HA> and we hope you can make it! We'd
like to welcome incoming first years, their families, volunteers,
directors, and any other Harvard students who are interested in public
service. This is a great opportunity to meet our wonderful directors,
volunteers, and leaders while getting to learn about PBHA‚Äôs wide range of
programs.

Join us in front of PBHA for a mini tabling info session from
4:30-5:30 pm! PBHA
runs over 60 programs throughout the year that you can get involved with so
spend this hour mingling with other students, walking around program
tables, and asking any questions you have about PBHA! Then head inside our
historic building for a delicious and fun Boba and Board Games event from
5-7pm! We will have various boba flavors, games to play, raffle prizes, and
even more people to meet!



-- 
*Elizabeth Ogolo*
She/Her/Hers
Harvard College | Class of 2024
A.B. Candidate in Neurobiology

Plus, Harry Belafonte‚Äôs obituary.
View in browser
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/SE7bHPOdo5YfsBHWSFCyJg~~/AAAAAQA~-Q_9IZPtcO81SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]|nytimes.com
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/J8-c5l5-r6dOh-ML9nkkuA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4RDP0StaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vP2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjYmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwODUmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTM3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD5D_0hk-1w7zVIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]

[https://liveintent.newyorktimesinfo.com/imp?s=859181&li=NN&m=ba2ff69ed6e9fec6f31f322ce534bd15&p=NN_20230426]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/DZPyP1vDSqCEbUnSkKohbg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4RDP0SWaHR0cHM6Ly9saXZlaW50ZW50Lm5ld3lvcmt0aW1lc2luZm8uY29tL2NsaWNrP3M9ODU5MTgxJmxpPU5OJm09YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTUmcD1OTl8yMDIzMDQyNiZ0ZT0xJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDI2VwNueXRCCmQ-Q_9IZPtcO81SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~

[https://static.nytimes.com/email-images/N-TheMorning%402x.png]

April 26, 2023

Author Headshot
[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/01/multimedia/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning-blogSmallThumb-v3.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/1vntmtSzz0JinLApMpkybA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4RDP0S_aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZGF2aWQtbGVvbmhhcmR0P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjYmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwODUmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTM3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD5D_0hk-1w7zVIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~

By David Leonhardt
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/1vntmtSzz0JinLApMpkybA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4RDP0S_aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZGF2aWQtbGVvbmhhcmR0P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjYmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwODUmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTM3NSZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD5D_0hk-1w7zVIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]

Good morning. As Biden starts his campaign, we ask why he doesn‚Äôt spend more
time in the public eye.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/25/multimedia/26themorning-lede/26themorning-lede-jumbo.jpg]President
BidenDoug Mills/The New York Times


MINIMIZING CONVERSATION¬†

The biggest reason that many Democratic officials are nervous about President
Biden‚Äôs age is not his ability to do the job in a second term.

Strange as it may sound, the American government can function without a healthy
president. The U.S. marched toward victory in World War II while Franklin
Roosevelt was ailing in 1944 and 1945. Four decades later, the government
managed its relationship with a teetering Soviet Union while Ronald Reagan‚Äôs
mental capacities slipped. In each case, White House aides, Cabinet secretaries
and military leaders performed well despite the lack of a fully engaged leader.

The issue that makes many Democrats even more anxious than Biden‚Äôs second-term
capabilities is whether his age will prevent him from winning a second term. If
enough voters are turned off by the idea of a president who would turn 86 in
office, Republicans might win full control of the federal government in 2024 ‚Äî
and Donald Trump might return to the White House.

I know that it may seem crass for Democrats to worry more about partisan
politics than the mental acuity of the country‚Äôs most powerful person. But it‚Äôs
not entirely irrational. Today, I will look at the biggest question about
Biden‚Äôs re-election campaign ‚Äî which he formally announced yesterday
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ahX63mkVCfO4qVVuVKHImA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4RDP0TiaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vbGl2ZS8yMDIzLzAxLzIwL3VzL2JpZGVuLTIwMjQtcHJlc2lkZW50LWVsZWN0aW9uLW5ld3M_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTA4NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMzc1JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPkP_SGT7XDvNUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
‚Äî and how he might address that question.


A GAFFE MACHINE

At 80, Biden can be an unsteady public performer. He occasionally uses the wrong
word or fails to summon a name. Some of these habits are not new, to be sure.
Biden has a stutter
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/qdXd7WsYDUrtmpkrB26vkg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4RDP0ToaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMi8wOC8yOS9icmllZmluZy9zdHV0dGVyaW5nLXN0aWdtYS1iaWRlbi1kaXNhYmlsaXR5Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTA4NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMzc1JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPkP_SGT7XDvNUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
which can make it seem as if he can‚Äôt remember words when in fact he is
struggling to enunciate them. He has also long been known for saying things that
he probably shouldn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúBiden living up to his gaffe-prone reputation,‚Äù read a Times headline in 2008
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/4P3kM6HL3DDD4GtOn9NYwQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4RDP0TiaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAwOC8wOS8xMS93b3JsZC9hbWVyaWNhcy8xMWlodC1iaWRlbi40LjE2MDgxNTE1Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTA4NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMzc1JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPkP_SGT7XDvNUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
when he was only 65. That same year, Slate magazine wrote
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/pgnUZ5T_F4sScppZSi9ahQ~~/AAAAAQA~-Q_9IZPtcO81SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~],
‚ÄúHe misspeaks so often, it‚Äôs hardly news ‚Äî and hardly damaging.‚Äù

But aging does seem to have exacerbated these issues. In the upcoming campaign,
you can imagine that¬†a verbal misstep could cause some swing voters to wonder
whether Biden is up for a second term.

These concerns help explain why polls show that roughly three-quarters of
Democratic voters approve of Biden‚Äôs performance but slightly less than half
want him to run for a second term.

Of course, there would be a simple way for Biden to address the concerns: He
could spend more time speaking in public now and demonstrate his vigor. Instead,
he and his aides have chosen the opposite approach.


THE QUIET STRATEGY

Biden has held fewer news conferences per year than any president since Reagan.
Biden gave¬†fewer interviews during his first two years in office¬†than any
president in even longer:

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/25/briefing/oakImage-1682455059225/oakImage-1682455059225-jumbo.png]Sources:
The American Presidency Project; Martha Joynt Kumar | By The New York Times

Michael Shear, a White House correspondent for The Times, says that Biden‚Äôs
aides are unapologetic about avoiding interviews and news conferences. ‚ÄúThey see
these traditions as outdated and unimportant,‚Äù Michael told me. ‚ÄúThey say that
traditional media don‚Äôt have clout, and they think that there are many other
ways that he can better present himself.‚Äù

But Biden has not¬†replaced media conversations with other means of engaging with
the public. He does not hold regular town-hall meetings, for example. And the
statistics on interviews in the chart above include Biden‚Äôs recent conversations
with people other than journalists, like Drew Barrymore and Jason Bateman, both
actors, and Manny MUA, a YouTube beauty expert.

Biden‚Äôs strategy of minimizing unscripted public appearances suggests that his
staff believes the risk often isn‚Äôt worth the reward.


‚ÄòWATCH ME‚Äô

Biden and his aides have said that his age is a legitimate issue for debate but
that he has demonstrated he is up to the job. ‚ÄúThe only thing I can say is,
‚ÄòWatch me,‚Äô‚Äù Biden likes to say.

There certainly are reasons to think that Biden is up for both the substantive
and performative parts of the job. He looked sharp during his State of the Union
address this year, trading verbal volleys with congressional Republicans ‚Äî and
winning the exchange
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/qxm8jA77auqd9jiC6f73yQ~~/AAAAAQA~-Q_9IZPtcO81SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].
I have spoken with Biden a couple of times since he was elected and found him to
be sharp, able to discuss policy and politics in the same discursive style he
had in prior years.

He has also had a successful presidency by many measures. He passed a blizzard
of legislation, including more bipartisan bills than almost anybody expected,
and managed both the pandemic and the West‚Äôs pro-Ukraine alliance. Democrats
fared much better in the midterms than during Barack Obama‚Äôs first term or Bill
Clinton‚Äôs. As I‚Äôve written before
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ZiBM_FO3R8WG2lZ3P60hJA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmK4RDP0TQaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wMi8yMC9icmllZmluZy9iaWRlbi0yMDI0Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTA4NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMzc1JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPkP_SGT7XDvNUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
Biden ‚Äî unlike many other top Democrats, who have drifted to the left of most
voters ‚Äî seems to understand where public opinion really is: left of center on
economic issues, more moderate on many social issues.

I can imagine a scenario in which the age worries prove overblown. Maybe voters
care less about Biden‚Äôs age than political pundits do and will re-elect him for
the same reasons they elected him: He conveys an aura of moderation and
competence when many other parts of the American political system do not. His
opponent, whether it is Trump (who‚Äôs 76) or somebody else, seems likely to
embody the Republican Party‚Äôs recent shift toward extremism.

‚ÄúThe man has done a good job,‚Äù Elaine Kamarck, a political scientist and
Democratic Party official recently said on The Run-Up, a Times politics podcast
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/tnfD71DyXCTgoAh39SB7Iw~~/AAAAAQA~-Q_9IZPtcO81SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].
‚ÄúSo everybody‚Äôs sort of saying, ‚ÄòOkay, yeah, he‚Äôs old. Big deal.‚Äô There are
advantages that come with age, as well as the downsides.‚Äù

Still, a question looms: If Biden is as energetic and effective as his aides
insist, why does he spend so little time publicly engaging with other people?


MORE ELECTION NEWS

base, the part that hasn‚Äôt yet finished middle school,‚Äù he writes, ‚ÄúI expect it
will simply be, like so much else at the museum, awesome.‚Äù

221393554.subject: [slims] Fwd: [Wcstaff-list]  Join us for WoCC x Saheli!
221393554.text:
Join us for WoCC x Saheli!
> Join the Women of Color Collective (WoCC) in partnership with Saheli Boston for SAAM (Sexual Assault Awareness Month), Thursday 4/20 at 5 PM in the Smith Riverview Commons (Smith Campus Center, Floor 10)!
> 
> Come for Nine Tastes, and conversations revolving around sexual assault awareness and intersectional experiences on campus. All identities welcome!
> 
> RSVP form: https://forms.gle/Mz5j5NpC5ghjuGtBA <https://forms.gle/Mz5j5NpC5ghjuGtBA>
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> Wcstaff-list mailing list -- wcstaff-list@lists.fas.harvard.edu
> To unsubscribe send an email to wcstaff-list-leave@lists.fas.harvard.edu

245932634.subject: [HoCo-announce] Adams Formal Ticket Purchase and Pickup
245932634.text:
*DEAREST ADAMSIANS,*
formal tickets are still available
& must be picked up this week
*purchase here
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdU9wUBajblt3leBiH6VtZas31kaHJgpP6qmB1qCwV-EpvEzA/viewform?usp=sf_link>*
*:* $20 for 1 & $35 for 2
formal tickets are SEF-able - if your SEF funds have run out,
please email *adams@fas.harvard.edu <adams@fas.harvard.edu>*
*pick up your ticket *in the Adams Gold Room 5:30-7:00pm on
Tuesday 4/25, Wednesday 4/26, Thursday 4/27
and get excited for
*Happily Ever Adams*
Friday April 28th, 10pm - 2am

BREAKING NEWS


JERRY SPRINGER, THE TALK SHOW HOST WHO MEDIATED ROCKY RELATIONSHIPS AND FAMILY
FEUDS OVER DECADES, IS DEAD AT 79.
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/x6Qiht5G7g8vecsXgVRp4Q~~/AAAAAQA~~]

Thursday, April 27, 2023 10:53 AM ET

His raucous and often confrontational show, ‚ÄúThe Jerry Springer Show,‚Äù ran for
nearly three decades and became a cultural phenomenon.

256452144.subject: [Fyre] Fwd: Strides in Solidarity Recap!
256452144.text:
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: amielkatz <amielkatz@college.harvard.edu>
Date: Sun, Apr 23, 2023 at 11:43‚ÄØAM
Subject: Strides in Solidarity Recap!
To: Harvard PIH Engage <harvard-pih-engage@googlegroups.com>


Hello everyone,

Strides in Solidarity was a great success! Thank you to everyone who could
make it. Strides in Solidarity, an annual 5k that PIHE chapters across the
nation organize, is meant to express the distance many of the PIHE
community health workers walk everyday to accompany their patients. PIHE's
mission would not be carried out if not for the community health workers,
so Strides in Solidarity shows our appreciation for them. This year we
fundraised for the University of Global Health Equity in Rwanda, which will
be training the next generation of doctors and medical professionals!

If you would like to donate please feel free to use this link:
https://pih-ughe.donorsupport.co/-/NTVCZJDE
Or, spread the word by forwarding this email!

In solidarity,
Harvard PIHE Board

-- 
You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups
"Harvard PIH Engage" group.
To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an
email to harvard-pih-engage+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.
To view this discussion on the web visit
https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/harvard-pih-engage/578844c8-b341-434c-8711-5be556fa859dn%40googlegroups.com
<https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/harvard-pih-engage/578844c8-b341-434c-8711-5be556fa859dn%40googlegroups.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer>
.

FYRE@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/fyre

259058639.subject: The Morning: The fight over the debt limit
259058639.text:
[https://nl.nytimes.com/q/4Iwuk2WBI6ztA5J5NaRlEg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmLNaRPVcDbnl0QgpkSJFRSmQ7W8uzUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
Republicans are trying to force a negotiation.
View in browser
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/sxWkqLWY5iGN5c-r3ixEPA~~/AAAAAQA~~]|nytimes.com
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/6iDRsQJS8HzdLqlc_AR9pg~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
[https://static.nytimes.com/email-images/N-TheMorning%402x.png]

April 27, 2023

Continue reading the main story

SUPPORTED BY Masterworks
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/ZrwfZPTzswNKb002zHofKQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmLNaRP4Q_AWh0dHBzOi8vd3d3Lm1hc3RlcndvcmtzLmNvbS8_~~]

Author Headshot
[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/01/13/reader-center/author-german-lopez/author-german-lopez-blogSmallThumb-v2.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ZAaYgAdK-ff3WTXaBtz1sg~~/AAAAAQA~~~

By German Lopez
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ZAaYgAdK-ff3WTXaBtz1sg~~/AAAAAQA~~~]

Good morning. House Republicans are putting the economy at risk to¬†push spending
cuts.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/27/multimedia/27themorning-lead-ljqt/27themorning-lead-ljqt-jumbo.jpg]Kevin
McCarthy, the House speaker.Kenny Holston/The New York Times


CAPITAL SHOWDOWN

Since they won a majority in the midterm elections, House Republicans have
promised to use a debt-limit bill as leverage to achieve their policy
priorities. But it was not until yesterday that they confirmed what those
priorities are, passing legislation that they plan to use in debt-limit
negotiations.

The House approved the bill in a close vote, 217-215
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/3htg2yYdm9my-h-X8kZWQQ~~/AAAAAQA~~],
with no Democratic support. The legislation, championed by House Speaker Kevin
McCarthy, would raise the limit on money the government can borrow through next
year, reel back President Biden‚Äôs climate agenda and force sweeping, unspecified
spending cuts. The bill is dead on arrival in the Senate, which Democrats
control, and Biden has already said he would not sign it. But Republicans hope
it will push Democrats to negotiate. ‚ÄúWe lifted the debt limit; we‚Äôve sent it to
the Senate; we‚Äôve done our job,‚Äù McCarthy said.

The stakes are high. If the U.S. breaches the debt limit, it could be forced to
default on its debts. A default could set off global economic calamity because
U.S. debt, which underpins much of the financial system,¬†would collapse in value
(as I‚Äôve explained before
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/3Q9-zjtGhuzUvjQpwtI44w~~/AAAAAQA~~]).
The U.S. hit the debt limit in January, but the Treasury Department has used
so-called extraordinary measures to keep the government from defaulting. Those
measures will run out in the coming months.

Republicans are leaning on the economic threat to try to force Democrats to
negotiate. Today‚Äôs newsletter will look at why Republicans are pursuing this
strategy and why Democrats see it as reckless.


WHAT REPUBLICANS WANT

Republicans say the U.S. government has grown too large, that it spends too much
and that its debt and deficits are unsustainable. More recently, Republicans
have argued that spending cuts will ease inflation. Reducing spending would also
give Republicans more leeway in the future to extend tax cuts passed under
Donald Trump, which disproportionately benefited wealthy Americans.

But Republicans have failed to act on a smaller-government vision when they have
been in power. When they controlled the House, Senate and White House in 2017
and 2018, they increased federal spending and deficits. Pointing to that
history, some liberals have argued
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/OH7Kkys0oa93g004f6h2hw~~/AAAAAQA~~]
that House Republicans are simply trying to undercut Biden even at the cost of
damaging the economy.

Republicans also face difficult politics. In the debt-limit showdown, they have
promised to shield Social Security, Medicare and military spending from cuts.
Those programs make up the bulk of federal spending. Without them, balancing the
budget or even just reducing spending would require steep cuts to other
policies, potentially including Medicaid, food stamps, border security and
grants to local police departments.

Some of those programs are popular, and slashing them could upset constituents
who rely on them to make ends meet.

The political reality has prompted Republicans to take smaller steps.
Originally, McCarthy said he wanted to put the U.S. ‚Äúon a path towards a
balanced budget‚Äù within 10 years. His current proposal
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/MEu3mGCNgYFouOx-UWj44A~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
falls short of that goal. But it would cap some federal spending,
reclaim¬†unspent Covid relief funds, roll back the Biden administration‚Äôs efforts
to boost clean energy, block student loan forgiveness and impose more stringent
work requirements for food stamps and Medicaid.


WHY DEMOCRATS REFUSE

Democrats have largely resisted negotiating over the debt limit. They have
likened Republicans‚Äô tactics to hostage taking, arguing that McCarthy and his
allies are using the threat of economic catastrophe to force Biden to agree to
draconian spending cuts. Democrats warn that negotiating would set a bad
precedent ‚Äî one that could ultimately hurt Republican administrations, too.
Democrats could, for example, refuse to raise the debt limit to try to force a
Republican president to agree to increase the minimum wage.

But there is already precedent. Barack Obama‚Äôs administration negotiated with
Republicans during similar debt-limit showdowns. Some Democrats, including
then-Senator Biden, also voted against increasing the debt limit in 2006 to
protest the costs of the Iraq war and tax cuts.

Biden and his allies argue that it is time to break that cycle. They say they
will negotiate with Republicans on spending after they increase the debt limit,
but not before. This matches what other countries do. (Denmark is the only other
country with a similar debt limit, but it raises its cap well in advance of
reaching it.)

Democrats also object to Republicans‚Äô proposed cuts, which they say would
particularly hurt poor and middle-class Americans. They also point out that some
proposals, like reducing funding for the I.R.S.
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/l449Gc3DrbDfzxa3kEUasg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmLNaRP0TlaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMi8wOC8yNi9icmllZmluZy9jb25zcGlyYWN5LWlycy10YXgtYWdlbmN5LWZyYXVkLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNyZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTE3NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxNDY5JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkSJFRSmQ7W8uzUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
would increase the deficit.

Still, Democrats may be forced to negotiate. As long as Republicans control the
House, there may be no other way out of a potential economic crisis.

A REASON TO DREAM

In India, where cricket is by far the most popular sport, a women‚Äôs league
arrived last month with a splash. Investors poured hundreds of millions of
dollars into the league, delivering big paydays for the sport‚Äôs biggest female
stars, and crowds swarmed the inaugural tournament.

The Times‚Äôs Mujib Mashal visited Dharoki, a village in the wheat fields of the
Punjab region, where the league‚Äôs success has inspired a generation of girls
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/d4-WuDyE-dh6YmRyxCNgyQ~~/AAAAAQA~~]
to dream of becoming cricket stars.

263691529.subject: New in GitBook: Multi-block selection & private content ‚ú®
263691529.text:
A product update from GitBook

¬†

View in browser ( http://track.customer.io/deliveries/dgT4iQcDALnLhwO4y4cDAYfD7Ljh3MzwcFimaDNqbQ== )

¬†

¬†

GitBook logo ( https://www.gitbook.com/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

GitBook logo white ( https://www.gitbook.com/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

Block selection hero image ( https://blog.gitbook.com/product-updates/new-in-gitbook-better-block-manipulation-and-private-documents/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

*****************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************
New in GitBook: Better block manipulation and private content ( https://blog.gitbook.com/product-updates/new-in-gitbook-better-block-manipulation-and-private-documents/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )
*****************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************

This month, we‚Äôve made it easier to select, move, copy and delete blocks within your content. All you have to do is highlight any content within the blocks you want and hit Esc to select the blocks themselves.

We‚Äôve also added a section for private content within your organizations ‚Äî¬†perfect for ideas, drafts or work-in-progress that isn‚Äôt ready to share. You‚Äôll find it at the top of your GitBook sidebar.

Find out more ( https://blog.gitbook.com/product-updates/new-in-gitbook-better-block-manipulation-and-private-documents/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

Lens image ( https://www.gitbook.com/solutions/ai/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

*********************************************************************************************************************************************************
ICYMI: GitBook Lens is available now ( https://www.gitbook.com/solutions/ai/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )
*********************************************************************************************************************************************************

Have you tried GitBook Lens yet? If not, now‚Äôs the time to switch it on for your published documentation or internal knowledge base. Lens uses AI to scan your documentation, then answers your questions with simple, semantic answers ‚Äî with clickable references and follow-up questions if you want to dive deeper.

Discover Lens ( https://www.gitbook.com/solutions/ai/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

*********************
Featured integrations
*********************

Arcade logo ( https://www.gitbook.com/integrations/arcade/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Arcade ( https://www.gitbook.com/integrations/arcade/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Create interactive product demos in minutes, then embed them directly into your GitBook content.

Learn more ( https://www.gitbook.com/integrations/arcade/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

Jira logo ( https://www.gitbook.com/integrations/jira/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Jira ( https://www.gitbook.com/integrations/jira/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Embed Jira issues right in your GitBook documentation and make it easier to track all your projects.

Learn more ( https://www.gitbook.com/integrations/jira/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

*********
Resources
*********

GitBook Library ( https://www.gitbook.com/gitbook-library/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
GitBook Library ( https://www.gitbook.com/gitbook-library/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We‚Äôve rounded up the best GitBook content ( https://www.gitbook.com/gitbook-library/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 ) in one place ‚Äî¬†an all-new Library. And now you can submit your own work ( https://forms.gle/cmkuQqrHNNjCxyvX8 ), too!

Documents icon ( https://developer.gitbook.com/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Developer docs ( https://developer.gitbook.com/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We‚Äôve been hard at work building a developer platform, and it‚Äôs almost ready ‚Äî take an early look at our progress ( https://developer.gitbook.com/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 ) right now.

Lens icon ( https://docs.gitbook.com/product-tour/searching-your-content/lens/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Enable GitBook Lens ( https://docs.gitbook.com/product-tour/searching-your-content/lens/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 )
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Make your readers‚Äô lives easier. Find out how to enable GitBook Lens ( https://docs.gitbook.com/product-tour/searching-your-content/lens/?utm_source=product&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=product_newsletter_202304 ) for public and private documentation with our quick guide.

284146389.subject: The Slowdown for April 25, 2023
284146389.text:
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=151ae6d9a8dad2243f386be79bcc9f454d9400e41f77e1c9ca77fbff3a8cc43b8075a2943074cbc12ef2e1ded7a8bde7058111a9d778d73b 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=151ae6d9a8dad224b0cc35c0773ad9f5e7c3b8bc1aa521e9e25c0be946eb4f4f11d2213b2b38c72b80cf17a0d698015f18959d81e94af047 
Give Now 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=151ae6d9a8dad2245fd7c9a3f2ecc9ed18c062fff643e33cb392df2eafe82e833c112e6fba2a87e197ce6d9870140320c65bd607ea3aa503 
“I read the daily poems from The Slowdown with my morning coffee. These poems are a gift.” - Richarda E. 





 Today‚Äôs poem states a truth about turbulent times. After sadness, fear, and uncertainty, we will inevitably feel that distinct sense of having surmounted some great hardship. This suffering makes life precious, and above all, makes our friends treasured. And may I suggest, that to follow this episode, you might queue up Destiny‚Äôs Child‚Äôs iconic song ‚ÄúSurvivor.‚Äù        

   
— Major

La Peste
 by Marilyn Nelson



In the era of raining boys, a steady downpour

all shapes and sizes of Africans, Asians;

in the era of suicidal pleasure, of shooting-up

oblivion; in the era of handwringing research,

of children exing out father, mother, older sister,

neighbor, teacher, friend; in this era, they will say,

the worst epidemic by far was the gallop of evil

that overtook our kind like the virus from hell.

Its dragon breath passed from heart to heart,

engulfing whole continents with superiority, unwise

knowledge, and despair. It walked roughshod; it left

a black swath. But here we are, they will say,

shaking their heads with humble awe as others did

after the Black Death, after the Holocaust: Survivors.

“La Peste” by Marilyn Nelson from 
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=151ae6d9a8dad224a3dbeb24544cda4897bf53931269c29f82ceb0f584cb88a4a4c21fddc4a5da689445a6496402da90c60c30be72cd545a

288257448.subject: "Eating the Moon in Cotulla, TX" by Analicia Sotelo
288257448.text:
A trip to Laredo is like breaking open the sky.

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 20, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** Eating the Moon in Cotulla, TX (http://poets.org/poem/eating-moon-cotulla-tx?mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
Analicia Sotelo (https://poets.org/poet/analicia-sotelo?mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID)

A trip to Laredo is like breaking open the sky.

Each long row of wheat meets the eye

before it sloughs into desert, where the occasional hawk,

in a few concentric turns, identifies a weak movement.

I know this place. The place in between.

I have seen limbs of prickly pear hovering in the still, hot air,

clustered and distorted like a reef in reverse.

I have seen the hay bales lead me to ranch houses

with tin foil winks on every window

and a museum of appliances on every porch,

sliding from one world to another,

where there are trucks without wheels,

willows without spirits, and mesquites with nothing to lose.


I have seen the sun own the land. I have seen it bake

into our hands. And I have seen it sleep in a dark coverlet

while the sky opens loose, and the coyotes, in their constellation,

propose a trick. A star crosses with intelligence.

A rabbit becomes an antique. At the gas station in Cotulla,

I eat the moon in the form of a pie. A real U.F.O. in cellophane,

a chemically unctuous sweet. Each bite, with the physics of an asteroid,

crumbles onto the asphalt where purpling black spheres of gum

have each staked a claim on the cosmos. There is no claim

that cannot be shifted. There is no orbit that cannot be redone.

I have a stepfather who I call a father, who believes other life forms

are out there, far beyond our boastful sun. And I have seen

this moon pie has no bloodline. I have seen it orbit from

one home to another, a pre-made kindness at a pit stop

where something in the brush is changing up its cry.
Copyright ¬© 2023 by Analicia Sotelo. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on April 20, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS1150165788.mp3?updated=1681505295&mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID

‚ÄúI wrote this poem about the stretch of land between San Antonio and Laredo, my nostalgia for Moon Pies, and the mysteries of our origins. It‚Äôs also dedicated to road trips with my dad.‚Äù
‚ÄîAnalicia Sotelo
https://poets.org/poet/analicia-sotelo?mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID

Analicia Sotelo (https://poets.org/poet/analicia-sotelo?mc_cid=e438f579db&mc_eid=UNIQID)  is the author of Virgin (Milkweed Editions, 2018), the inaugural winner of the Jake Adam York Prize. She is a CantoMundo Fellow and the recipient of the 2016 Disquiet International Literary Prize.

BREAKING NEWS


THE AIRMAN ACCUSED OF LEAKING CLASSIFIED DOCUMENTS HAD POSTED INTELLIGENCE ON
ANOTHER, LARGER CHAT GROUP MONTHS EARLIER THAN PREVIOUSLY KNOWN.
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/KEMf-vdN5kOsptMGBJfkKg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJaYhP0TyaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yMS91cy9wb2xpdGljcy9qYWNrLXRlaXhlaXJhLWxlYWtzLXJ1c3NpYS11a3JhaW5lLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9NjAmZW1jPWVkaXRfbmFfMjAyMzA0MjEmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9MCZubD1icmVha2luZy1uZXdzJnJlZj1oZWFkbGluZSZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMDY0JnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD4hIUNk7PJzJlIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]

Friday, April 21, 2023 7:48 PM ET

In February 2022, soon after the invasion of Ukraine, a user profile matching
that of Airman Jack Teixeira began posting secret intelligence on the Russian
war effort on a previously undisclosed chat group on Discord.

297921969.subject: [ADAMS] Hollywood Subletting/Rooming?
297921969.text:
Hi Schmooze,

Going to be working in Hollywood this summer (June 10-August 12) and was
wondering if anyone had any leads on subletting/was also going to be living
there and looking for roommates. Would be super awesome and lovely of you
if you did!

Thanks!

-- 
*Seattle Hickey **(she/her/hers)*
*Harvard College | Class of 2025*
*AB Candidate in **History of Science and Women, Gender & Sexuality Studies*
*seattlehickey@college.harvard.edu <seattlehickey@college.harvard.edu>*

_______________________________________________

300593715.subject: [HoCo-announce] PARTY FAVORS TO THE FIRST 200 PEOPLE AT ADAMS FORMAL
300593715.text:
formal tickets are going quick and quicker,
but there is still time left to *purchase *and *pick up *yours.
and if seeing *Indigo* and DJ *Brenda Ceja* isn't incentive enough,
there will be THEMED *party favors* to the *first 200 people*
so get on this IMMEDIATELY!
YOUR TICKETS CAN BE
*purchased here
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdU9wUBajblt3leBiH6VtZas31kaHJgpP6qmB1qCwV-EpvEzA/viewform?usp=sf_link>*
*:* $20 for 1 & $35 for 2

316343416.subject: The Slowdown for April 17, 2023
316343416.text:
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=f7702b238188121e9c698e9d0329393b17aabae5cc060f17c79a9edeeb9a2ac76c023b0063517199f58d739a6bcd25f2eed590a46d93a372 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=f7702b238188121ea0cbcb48f55300bf0c555729254393d4211987e0a21249bd966c4fdeaea01aa45332c9844f94a5d5c9b9f2abcd09fbe8 
Give Now 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=f7702b238188121e9da58f05968595224f0396e98c8ced1f0dc9836c4d52703288aa134fcddfef2c3626bb1bb92c6d27150a4762a1d5496c 
“I read the daily poems from The Slowdown with my morning coffee. These poems are a gift.” - Richarda E. 





Through my many years of reading poetry, I feel as though I’ve absorbed other people’s stories and feelings. I strongly believe this has fortified me with a spirit of kindness, poetry as a daily pill of compassion. This is a grounding tenet in my belief in poetry as a communal and righteous good. We get to see through each other’s eyes and feel through each other’s hearts.       

  
— Major

And Everywhere Offering Human Sound
 by Joan Houlihan



Come here. Let me finger your hair.


I like the way you imitate weather:


a white breath, here and there,


the rush and sting of pinkened air,


a coven of crows talking briefly of home


and then the pelted tree.


By these shall I know ye,


bless yer little round mug.

 

Oh, my semi-precious, so much slow time


so much crawling and browsing


so much fascination with harmful insects


and corrosive sublimate.


As if you have as many eyes


as many eyes as the common fly,


and every one stuck open wide


to the wonderful, wonderful world.

 

So, I get up at 4 AM, finally, to put on some tea—


a soothing explanation for steam.


Children grow into themselves, then away.


We mustn’t worry when they’re gone—


or worse, not-quite-gone-yet.


The roots of things connect


where we can’t see.

 

When I was born, my mother began counting


to herself. Something in the middle 


must have gone missing.


Fortunately, I have all my faculties.


In fact, I still remember to turn 


every small thing until it gleams:


like your favorite airplane pin

 

there, riding on its own cotton wad.


Now come here so I can see


through your eyes to the sky within.

 

You are my only animal—


my animal of air.

“And Everywhere Offering Human Sound” by Joan Houlihan from 
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=f7702b238188121e194ba905830e33bcff8633ef322a66a4340814c4073b496e31fbe967532d72bde578e6c8afdbde704814799379d22e54

352378386.subject: The Morning: Clarence Thomas‚Äôs gifts and the court‚Äôs credibility
352378386.text:
[https://nl.nytimes.com/q/Squefe2cI0e1KfEXVpn7kw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIPvNPVcDbnl0QgpkIc12PmTVjHjAUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
Plus, the Ralph Yarl shooting and Crumbl cookies.
View in browser
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/_IMZtb3MBtjiyR4bMa2n7A~~/AAAAAQA~~~]|nytimes.com
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/gYfDrwE_wbqMqEGmSwdRpQ~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
Continue reading the main story

Marquee Ad
[https://liveintent.newyorktimesinfo.com/imp?s=859181&li=NN&m=ba2ff69ed6e9fec6f31f322ce534bd15&p=NN_20230418]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/NPO_GJsYox6TRvY8LQ2vUg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIPvNP0SWaHR0cHM6Ly9saXZlaW50ZW50Lm5ld3lvcmt0aW1lc2luZm8uY29tL2NsaWNrP3M9ODU5MTgxJmxpPU5OJm09YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTUmcD1OTl8yMDIzMDQxOCZ0ZT0xJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDE4VwNueXRCCmQhzXY-ZNWMeMBSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~

[https://static.nytimes.com/email-images/N-TheMorning%402x.png]

April 18, 2023

Author Headshot
[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/01/multimedia/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning-blogSmallThumb-v3.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ZKP81BkmcrGTjjklRc3KYw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIPvNP0S_~~

By David Leonhardt
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ZKP81BkmcrGTjjklRc3KYw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIPvNP0S_~~]

Good morning. There are more revelations about Clarence Thomas‚Äôs finances. We
explain.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/18/multimedia/18themorning-lede-tzwm/18themorning-lede-tzwm-jumbo.jpg]The
U.S. Supreme Court.Kenny Holston/The New York Times


UNDISCLOSED MONEY

Americans have long viewed the Supreme Court as more trustworthy and less
nakedly political than other parts of the government. Or at least Americans used
to feel that way.

In 2002, 50 percent of adults said that they had a lot of confidence in the
court, according to Gallup‚Äôs annual polls on major institutions. Last year, in
the most recent version of the poll, only 25 percent gave that answer. Other
institutions have also become less trusted over the past two decades, but the
court‚Äôs decline has been especially acute.

The Supreme Court is now less trusted than organized religion, organized labor
or public schools, as this chart from my colleague Ashley Wu shows:

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/17/briefing/oakImage-1681757098250/oakImage-1681757098250-jumbo.png]Source:
Gallup | By The New York Times

The debate over Justice Clarence Thomas‚Äôs acceptance of gifts
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ebEnW5iH4uJItwix5jwl2g~~/AAAAAQA~-ZNWMeMBSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
from a wealthy Republican donor ‚Äî and Thomas‚Äôs failure to disclose them ‚Äî is in
some ways a political Rorschach test. Many liberals who already disliked Thomas
are angry. Many conservatives who consider Thomas to be a great justice think
the controversy is overblown. And given that justices have lifetime tenure, that
the Supreme Court has a habit of protecting its own, and that Congress (which
has the power to remove justices) is gridlocked, I don‚Äôt expect that this
episode will lead to any direct consequences for Thomas.

But it may have larger political consequences.

Thomas has engaged in a yearslong pattern of behaving in ways that other
justices, and many elected politicians, do not. He has misled the public
multiple times
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/-_mG-0NTiYJkDp_UNDFlWA~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
about his finances (accidentally, he has said). His wife, Virginia, a
conservative activist, has also acted in ways that affect the court‚Äôs
credibility. She attended the Jan. 6 rally protesting the 2020 election result
and has repeated Donald Trump‚Äôs false claims about that election.

Outside legal experts aren‚Äôt the only ones worried about the court‚Äôs reputation
these days. The justices are, too.

John Roberts, the chief justice, has publicly argued that the court is not part
of the country‚Äôs ‚Äúpolarized political environment.‚Äù Amy Coney Barrett gave a
speech in which she said that she and her colleagues were not ‚Äúa bunch of
partisan hacks.‚Äù Thomas himself has said that the justices don‚Äôt decide cases
based on ‚Äúpersonal preference.‚Äù

Thomas‚Äôs own behavior, however, has made it harder for the court to argue that
it follows a loftier standard than either Congress or the executive branch does.
Many officials in those branches probably would have suffered damage to their
careers if they had repeatedly covered up ‚Äî or failed to disclose ‚Äî payments
they had received.

You have to wonder how Thomas‚Äôs colleagues, including his fellow conservatives,
feel about the continuing revelations.

In the rest of today‚Äôs newsletter, my colleague Lauren Jackson explains the
situation, including the latest developments and less recent details.


YACHT TRIPS

ProPublica has reported this month
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/y26ZAB1frf3uARp5Ic0rsQ~~/AAAAAQA~-ZNWMeMBSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
on two aspects of Thomas‚Äôs relationship with a real estate scion from Dallas
named Harlan Crow, who has spent millions of dollars on Republican causes,
including efforts to move the judiciary to the right. (Here is a Times profile
of Crow
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/jTZO0fnnanYnQStvScyvEA~~/AAAAAQA~-ZNWMeMBSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~],
including details about an art collection that includes statues of dictators.)

For more than 20 years, Thomas has accepted luxury gifts and trips from Crow.
The Los Angeles Times reported on the gifts in 2004. After that story, Thomas
continued to accept gifts but stopped disclosing them in the public forms that
Supreme Court justices file annually. More recent gifts remained unknown until
ProPublica‚Äôs reporting.

Among them: Thomas has flown on Crow‚Äôs private jet and toured a volcanic
Indonesian archipelago on his superyacht. Crow commissioned a portrait of
himself and Thomas smoking cigars in Adirondack chairs. Crow also helped finance
a documentary about Thomas and donated half a million dollars to Liberty
Central, an advocacy group Virginia Thomas founded.

Thomas has responded by saying that Crow is one of his ‚Äúdearest friends.‚Äù He has
also said he was following colleagues‚Äô advice when he declined to disclose the
gifts.

Crow called the ProPublica report a ‚Äúpolitical hit job‚Äù by a group ‚Äúfunded by
leftists.‚Äù


MISSING TRANSACTION

The second set of revelations
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/GU97pp0ytcFZmIq6Imjk6A~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
involve real estate that Crow bought from Thomas‚Äôs family. In 2014, Crow
purchased the home where Thomas‚Äôs mother lives as well as two nearby vacant lots
in Savannah, Ga., for $133,363. Thomas‚Äôs mother lives rent-free but is
responsible for paying property taxes and insurance, CNN reported
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/RFZWs3qPQf-q6ze7kNvEAQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIPvNP0T6aHR0cHM6Ly9lZGl0aW9uLmNubi5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8xNy9wb2xpdGljcy9jbGFyZW5jZS10aG9tYXMtYW1lbmQtZGlzY2xvc3VyZS1nb3AtbWVnYWRvbm9yL2luZGV4Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQxOCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDQ2MSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMwNzExJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkIc12PmTVjHjAUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
yesterday.

In a statement, Crow said he purchased the house, where Thomas spent part of his
childhood, to preserve it for a future museum.

Thomas intends to amend his financial disclosure forms to reflect the 2014 deal.

It joins a list of other transactions that he failed to disclose or that remain
mysterious:

 * Thomas failed to report $686,589 in income that his wife earned over five
   years from the Heritage Foundation as well as two years of her income from
   Hillsdale College, a Christian school in Michigan. Thomas acknowledged the
   error when he amended his filings in 2011.
 * He has reported between $50,000 and $100,000 in annual income from a real
   estate company and for years referred to it by an outdated name on disclosure
   forms, as The Washington Post reported
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/KDq1UPhBBW1XKSQhx8KtxA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIPvNP0T6aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cud2FzaGluZ3RvbnBvc3QuY29tL2ludmVzdGlnYXRpb25zLzIwMjMvMDQvMTYvY2xhcmVuY2UtdGhvbWFzLWdpbmdlci1maW5hbmNpYWwtZGlzY2xvc3VyZS8_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQxOCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDQ2MSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMwNzExJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkIc12PmTVjHjAUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
   this weekend.
 * Thomas did not report reimbursement for teaching at the University of Kansas
   and the University of Georgia several years ago. After an outside group, Fix
   the Court, pointed out the lack of disclosure, Thomas amended his filing.
 * From 1998 through 2003, Thomas accepted $42,200 in gifts, making him the top
   gift recipient on the court at the time. The justice who accepted the
   next-highest amount was Sandra Day O‚ÄôConnor, who received $5,825 in gifts.


FOR MORE

 * The Senate Judiciary Committee plans to hold a hearing about ethical
   standards on the Supreme Court.
 * The U.S. and Israel are asking: How much power should courts have?
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/wE91E6-tQ5rSFdZpzRYSgg~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
   Emily Bazelon explains in The Times Magazine.
 * Late night hosts joked about Crow‚Äôs art collection full of dictators
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/pwn9E2fYt414nW665nQ0YQ~~/AAAAAQA~-ZNWMeMBSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].

Continue reading the main story


ADVERTISEMENT

Ad
[https://liveintent.newyorktimesinfo.com/imp?s=859187&li=NN&m=ba2ff69ed6e9fec6f31f322ce534bd15&p=NN_20230418]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/m2KxCppJVTx5mFfiBTq94g~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIPvNP0SWaHR0cHM6Ly9saXZlaW50ZW50Lm5ld3lvcmt0aW1lc2luZm8uY29tL2NsaWNrP3M9ODU5MTg3JmxpPU5OJm09YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTUmcD1OTl8yMDIzMDQxOCZ0ZT0xJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDE4VwNueXRCCmQhzXY-ZNWMeMBSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~


THE LATEST NEWS

Politics

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/17/multimedia/18themorning-labor/18themorning-labor-jumbo.jpg]Three
boys from Guatemala who work full time in construction.Kirsten Luce for The New
York Times

 * The Biden administration ignored warnings that migrant children were being
   forced into work
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/GvxN1kYd6t8wBmHMoPo52A~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIPvNP0TiaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8xNy91cy9wb2xpdGljcy9taWdyYW50LWNoaWxkLWxhYm9yLWJpZGVuLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQxOCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDQ2MSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMwNzExJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkIc12PmTVjHjAUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
   a Times investigation found.
 * Kevin McCarthy, the Republican House speaker, proposed to raise the debt
   ceiling for a year
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ysO-_1RMn9-YEnEV2MeqwQ~~/AAAAAQA~-ZNWMeMBSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   in exchange for spending cuts.
 * Representative George Santos, the New York Republican who fabricated much of
   his biography, says he will run for re-election
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/umWhAIngzKIvDABMdBYA6w~~/AAAAAQA~-ZNWMeMBSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   in 2024.

Gun Violence

 * An 84-year-old man was charged with shooting Ralph Yarl
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/sxW7VMVK_ecVdAW0odq3vA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIPvNP0TfaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8xNy91cy9yYWxwaC15YXJsLWthbnNhcy1jaXR5LXNob290aW5nLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQxOCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDQ2MSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMwNzExJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkIc12PmTVjHjAUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
   a Black teenager who mistakenly came to his door in Kansas City, Mo.
