A LOOMING HOLLYWOOD STRIKE

Hollywood writers have voted in favor of a strike
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/1s73cVKdgJ4VFwZAHpQbcg~~/AAAAAQA~~~],
setting up a contract fight that could upend the entertainment industry if they
don‚Äôt reach an agreement with major studios by May 1. The unions that represent
TV and movie writers are seeking higher wages and royalties that better account
for streaming services.

If the two sides fail to reach a deal, the first shows to go off the air would
likely be late-night talk shows ‚Äî where scripts are turned around daily ‚Äî
followed by ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live‚Äù and soap operas. Studios have begun to
stockpile scripts and are preparing new unscripted entertainment, like reality
shows.

360675725.subject: [ADAMS] Another Book Giveaway
360675725.text:
Hi Schmooze,

The Library will be giving away "abandoned books" this Thursday at 7:45pm
in the Brower Room.

What's an abandoned book? It's a book that former students have left behind
when they move out in hopes that the House Library will take them. We don't
have the space to keep all the books we've been "given" the last couple of
years, so we want to give them a new home.

As an added incentive, donate to one of the Gradams boxes we'll have
available and skip the line!

As ever,
Santi

381733797.subject: [cs-undergrads] Build an (AI) Bot Workshop Sunday, 4/30/23 @ 3:30 pm
381733797.text:
Hi all,

Perhaps of interest, from Jennifer 8 Lee '99!

djm

---


*Build an (AI) Bot Workshop *
When: Sunday, April 30 ¬∑ 3:30 - 7:30pm EDT
Where Nieman Foundation's Lippman House @ Harvard 1 Francis Street
Cambridge, MA 02138

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/build-an-ai-bot-workshop-tickets-619793297437

AI is happening, and it‚Äôs easier than you think.

Join us for an (AI) Bot Building Workshop with Chinese food, instruction,
GPT4 and everything you need to walk away with an open-source bots your
friends can use and share.

If you‚Äôre looking to learn about AI or start a company from your dorm, this
workshop will leave you brimming with ideas and skills

Who It‚Äôs For
This workshop works best in programmer-poet pairs (we can pair you).
One of you should know Python.
One of you should know Poe.
Other than that, we only need you to bring your laptops, empty stomachs,
and ambitious brains.

What We‚Äôll Do

   - *Part 1: No Code? No Problem*

You‚Äôll use a web interface to create a GPT-4 based bot with a custom
personality, capable of answering questions about YouTube videos and PDF
files you care about.

   - *Part 2: Put it on your Phone*

You‚Äôll add your bot to Telegram so you and your friends can chat with it.

   - *Part 3: Extending your Bot with ‚ÄúTools‚Äù*

‚ÄúTools‚Äù are Python skills that an AI can use autonomously. A tool could be
generating a DALL-E image, remembering a grocery list, or looking up the
time of your next class.

You‚Äôll modify your bot to add basic tools and learn how to develop your own.

*WÔªøhat*
* Will We Eat?*We will feed you yummy Chinese ü•ü (and more) from Dumpling
House <https://www.dumplinghousema.com/>

<https://www.dumplinghousema.com/>


*Who‚Äôs Hosting?*Hosted by Steamship <https://steamship.com/> (Team Python)
and Plympton <https://plympton.com/> (Team Poetry) ‚Äî two companies born
from opposite ends of Mass Ave who feel very much that they are coming home
with this event!

--

383969915.subject: üöÇ Norfolk‚Äôs mess raises alarms
383969915.text:
‚Ä¶and big foodies from McD‚Äôs to Pepsi flaunt their price-hiking power
 

Norfolk Southern‚Äôs derailed freight train in East Palestine, Ohio (NTSB/Xinhua/Getty Images)

 
Yesterday‚Äôs Market Moves
 
Dow Jones
33,302 (-0.68%)		S&P 500
4,056 (-0.38%)		Nasdaq
11,854 (+0.47%)		Bitcoin
$28,634 (+1.11%)
Dow Jones
33,302 (-0.68%)		S&P 500
4,056 (-0.38%)
Nasdaq
11,854 (+0.47%)		Bitcoin
$28,634 (+1.11%)

Hey Snackers,

Sotheby‚Äôs is selling the handwritten lyrics to ‚ÄúWe Are the Champions‚Äù and other Freddie Mercury treasures in a $7.4M estate sale. Also on the auction block: his Tiffany mustache comb, rotary phone, and [checks notes] vest covered in images of cats.

The Nasdaq ticked up yesterday on better-than-feared earnings from Microsoft and Google parent Alphabet. Meta spiked after surprising investors with its first quarterly sales growth in a year. Amazon reports today.

Locomotion

Norfolk Southern puts a price on its Ohio derailment as rail safety practices come under greater scrutiny

Track record‚Ä¶ Yesterday, Norfolk Southern said that the February derailment of one of its trains ‚Äî which spilled toxic chemicals into a small Ohio town ‚Äî would likely cost the company $387M, or about 12% of its profit last year.

  • Cleaning up: The price tag includes $31M pledged to help local residents recover. So far, Norfolk said it‚Äôs spent $55M removing contaminated soil and water.

  • Lawyering up: That includes legal fees, because Norfolk faces lawsuits from the DOJ, Ohio, and shareholders, among others.

The issue runs deeper‚Ä¶ than just one spill. The National Transportation Safety Board launched a special investigation into Norfolk‚Äôs general safety practices. The company‚Äôs workforce has shrunk by almost 40% since 2012, a steeper drop than that of rivals BNSF, CSX, and Union Pacific. From 2013 to 2022, Norfolk‚Äôs accident rate spiked more than 80% ‚Äî nearly 3X the industry average. The Ohio disaster has led to greater scrutiny of the rail industry‚Äôs safety practices.

  • Accidents up: In the past decade, the seven major US freight railroad operators have had 27% more accidents. Lawmakers and safety officials point to an industry-wide strategy called Precision Scheduled Railroading, or PSR, as a reason for declining safety.

  • Profits up: PSR aims to boost profits by cutting costs and increasing efficiency through measures like lengthening trains (some up to 3 miles long), shrinking staff, and cutting inspection times.

THE TAKEAWAY

Financial efficiency can hurt operational efficiency‚Ä¶ Since 2010, rail companies have paid shareholders almost $200B through dividends and stock buybacks. While PSR has helped rail corps haul in record profits, it‚Äôs also led to widespread safety problems and worker dissatisfaction. In December, President Biden blocked a nationwide rail strike that would‚Äôve cost the US $2B/day.

Bite

Big foodies flaunt ‚Äúpricing power‚Äù as consumers stomach higher costs (for now)

From Big Macs to Kraft mac‚Ä¶ Americans aren‚Äôt giving up their comfort-food staples. Big food companies have crushed earnings expectations as consumers keep paying up to eat up, despite significant price hikes. It‚Äôs a theme:

  • McDonald‚Äôs beat estimates as US traffic grew for the third straight quarter, amid higher McMenu prices and inflated nuggets. Global same-store sales grew 13%.

  • Chipotle saw stronger-than-expected traffic and sales growth, while the burrito legend‚Äôs prices are up 10% from a year ago (guac = extra extra).

  • Nestl√©, the world's largest food company, also grew sales after hiking prices by about 10% as folks kept grabbing its Kit Kats, Hot Pockets, and "Nes" products (‚Äôpresso, ‚Äôcaf√©, ‚Äôquik).

  • Pepsi lifted its annual sales forecast as demand for products like Gatorade, Cheetos, and Doritos stayed strong ‚Äî after it raised prices by 13%.

  • Coke had bubbly results, too, as higher prices and rising demand fueled its bev sales.

I‚Äôve got the (pricing) power‚Ä¶ Pricing power = how much companies can raise prices without hurting demand. Food companies are flexing that power by showing that consumers are willing to pay more for their goodies, from brand-name sodas like Coke to affordable splurges like Egg McMuffins. Even during economic downturns, people tend to hold on to these little treats.

THE TAKEAWAY

Pricing power has its limits‚Ä¶ because budgets can stretch only so far. McD‚Äôs said that diners in some markets have pushed back more than anticipated against higher prices, and customers are ordering fewer items. Coke noted signs of shifting buying habits, and said it plans to slow price hikes this year. As US retail spending dips, corporate price bumps could flatten.

COD

Microsoft‚Äôs $69B Activision takeover is in jeopardy after UK regulators blocked the potentially historic gaming deal

Game changer‚Ä¶ Yesterday, UK regulators said they‚Äôd block Microsoft's $69B acquisition of Activision Blizzard, worsening the chances of the deal‚Äôs approval. Microsoft‚Äôs bid to buy the Call of Duty maker (which would be the largest tech deal ever) has been on ice as regulators worry the merger would hurt competition. The Xbox maker has struck deals with rivals like Nintendo and Nvidia to share its gaming treasures to win support for the Activision-quisition.

  • Stiff odds: The FTC is still evaluating the merger after suing to block it in December, and the EU is set to make a formal decision next month.

  • High stakes: Microsoft‚Äôs already planning to appeal the UK‚Äôs decision, but if it fails (or if other regulators nix it) it‚Äôll owe Activision $3B in break-up fees.

Cloud cover‚Ä¶ By some estimates, Microsoft already controls 60%+ of global cloud-gaming services, and its Xbox Game Pass has 25M+ subscribers. For reference: Sony's PSNow cloud-gaming service had just 3M subs before it was replaced last year. Now regulators argue that Microsoft's ownership of Activision's billion-dollar franchises (like: Call of Duty, World of Warcraft) would make it tougher for others to compete.

THE TAKEAWAY

Buyers, beware‚Ä¶ The UK‚Äôs decision is a rare win for supporters of Big Tech regulation, and it could prompt more crackdowns in the US, where major antitrust rulings have been scarce. As governments get tougher on protecting competition, tech biggies may have to revisit their M&A strategies, or risk losing billions if they fail.

What else we're Snackin'

  • Liked: Meta stock popped 12% after it posted unexpected sales growth thanks to more ads. But profit plunged by nearly $2B as its metaverse biz kept bleeding cash and layoffs meant high severance costs.

  • Lotus: Pack your Portia fits: Hilton beat expectations and gave sunnier guidance as vacay demand stayed strong. Hotel bookings are up 4X from last year and airlines are eyeing a summer surge.

  • Shh: To ease privacy concerns, OpenAI said it‚Äôll let ChatGPT users opt out of having their prompt history used for AI training and is working on a biz subscription that won‚Äôt study users‚Äô data (think: company secrets).

  • Pullup: Target is rolling out curbside returns, so you won‚Äôt need to pause your pod to unload impulse-bought blenders. Since the pandemic, consumers haven‚Äôt curbed their enthusiasm for parking pickup.

  • Understellar: Japanese space startup Ispace's rover ‚Äúmade a hard landing‚Äù (ahem, crashed) into the moon. It would‚Äôve been the first private company to touch down on the lunar surface.

üç™ Thanks for Snacking with us! Want to share the Snacks? Invite your friends to sign up here.

Snack Fact Of the Day
Netflix reportedly lost 1M users in Spain last quarter as it intro‚Äôd a password-sharing fee

From: Sadia Laisa <slaisa@college.harvard.edu>
Date: Wed, Apr 19, 2023 at 2:55‚ÄØPM
Subject: What do you want to see in a FGLI handbook by seniors?
To: <primus-list@googlegroups.com>
Cc: Harvard Primus <harvardprimus@gmail.com>


Hi PRIMUS!

I am so excited to be working on a project with some of our amazing seniors
to create a comprehensive handbook with questions, reflections, academics
and course recommendations, pre-professional and career pathways and more
as a gift from the graduating class to a community that we hold close to
our hearts. We would love to hear from you about what you want to see in
the handbook, any questions you want seniors to answer, and any advice for
us to document. Please fill out this google form
<https://forms.gle/RfRThatqSDhF3fui8> by *Monday, April 24* with your
inputs.

*If you are a* *senior and you want to get involved, please respond to this
email with your phone number so that we can add you to the group chat. *We
would love to have you!

All my love,
Sadia Laisa '23

430859355.subject: "Playing with Bees" by RK Fauth
430859355.text:
So the world turned / its one good eye

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 29, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** Playing with Bees (http://poets.org/poem/playing-bees?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
RK Fauth (https://poets.org/poet/rk-fauth?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID)

So the world turned
its one good eye

to watch the bees
take most of metaphor
with them.

Swarms‚Äî
in all their airborne
pointillism‚Äî
shifted on the breeze

for the last time. Of course,

the absence of bees
left behind significant holes
in ecology. Less

obvious
were the indelible holes
in poems, which would come
later:

Our vast psychic habitat
shrunk. Nothing was

like nectar
for the gods

Nobody was warned by
a deep black dahlia, and nobody

grew like a weed.

Nobody felt spry as
a daisy, or blue
and princely
as a hyacinth; was lucid as
a moon flower.            Nobody came home

and yelled   honey!   up the stairs,

And nothing in particular
by any other name would smell as sweet as‚Äî

Consider:
the verbal dearth
that is always a main ripple of extinction.

The lexicon of wilds goes on nixing its descriptions.
Slimming its index of references
for what is

super as a rhubarb, and juicy
as a peach,
or sunken as a
comb and ancient as an alder tree, or
conifer, or beech, what is royal
as jelly, dark as a wintering

hive, toxic as the jessamine vine
who weeps the way a willow does,
silently as wax
burned in the land of milk and

all the strong words in poems,
they were once

smeared on the mandible of a bee.

Copyright ¬© 2023 by RK Fauth. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on April 29, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS6037835739.mp3?updated=1682009107&mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID

About the Treehouse Climate Action Poem Prize
RK Fauth‚Äôs ‚ÄúPlaying with Bees‚Äù is the second-place winner of the 2023 Treehouse Climate Action Poem Prize. Established in 2019 with generous support from Treehouse Investments, the prize is given to honor exceptional poems that help make real for readers the gravity of the vulnerable state of our environment at present. Beginning with Earth Day, Poem-a-Day will feature this year‚Äôs three winners on consecutive weekends.

‚ÄúMaking language itself a primary concern, ‚ÄòPlaying with Bees‚Äô reminds us that we are nature, just as bees are, and the poem explores the manner in which words govern our relationship with the nonhuman world. Inside that exploration, this poem becomes a poignant meditation on how we imagine both the natural world and our place within it, while also capturing some of the mystery of what exists beyond our ability to express. ‚Äù
‚ÄîDr. Peter Kalmus and Matthew Olzmann (https://poets.org/poet/matthew-olzmann?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID)

‚ÄúThis poem is the prelude to my first collection, Playing with Bees, which catalogs moments in time as artifacts after a fictional bee extinction. The image (https://poets.org/glossary/imagery?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID) of ‚Äòthe world turning its one good eye‚Äô came to me after watching a swarm of starlings. The birds made these mesmerizing, intelligent patterns against a sunset undoubtedly made extra vibrant by light pollution. It made me wonder, what happens to my imagination, my language, my daydreams, every time a peg in the environment is removed? Without, say, bees, what of this poem would shrivel and disappear? How much of me would the bees take with them?‚Äù
‚ÄîRK Fauth
https://poets.org/poet/rk-fauth?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID

RK Fauth (https://poets.org/poet/rk-fauth?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID) is the author of A Dream in Which I Am Playing with Bees (Texas Tech University Press, 2024), winner of the Walt MacDonald First Book Prize in Poetry. The recipient of fellowships from the Lannan Foundation and the Fulbright Program, she currently lives in Asheville, North Carolina.

https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781682831960?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID

A Dream in Which I Am Playing with Bees (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781682831960?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID)
(Texas Tech University Press, 2024)
https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781682831960?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID


‚ÄúHuman Habitat‚Äù by Alison Hawthorne Deming
read more (https://poets.org/poem/human-habitat?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID)
‚ÄúUnacknowledged Pollinators‚Äù by Fady Joudah
read more (https://poets.org/poem/unacknowledged-pollinators?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID)
https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID
Thanks to U.S. poet laureate Ada Lim√≥n (https://poets.org/poet/ada-limon?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID) , author of The Hurting Kind (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781639550494?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID)  (Milkweed Editions, 2022), who curated Poem-a-Day for this month‚Äôs weekdays. As of this year, the U.S. poet laureate guest editorship during National Poetry Month (https://poets.org/library-congress-and-poem-day?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a collaboration between the Academy and the Library of Congress. Read or listen to a Q&A (https://poets.org/April-2023-poem-a-day-editor-ada-limon?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID)  about Lim√≥n‚Äôs curatorial approach and find out more about our guest editors for the year (https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID) .


http://poets.org/donate/pad?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID
‚ÄúPoem-a-Day is brilliant because it makes space in the everyday racket for something as meaningful as a poem.‚Äù ‚ÄîTracy K. Smith

If this series is meaningful to you, join the community of Poem-a-Day supporters by making a gift today (https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=88cebd421e&mc_eid=UNIQID)  in honor of National Poetry Month. Now serving more than 320,000 daily subscribers, this publication is only possible thanks to the contributions of readers like you.

449541637.subject: [cs-undergrads] George Barbastathis Talk. Thursday 4/20 - 11:15 am to 12:30 pm, SEC 1.413
449541637.text:
From: Demba Ba



Dear Colleagues,



I hope this message finds you well and in great health.

My friend and colleague George Barbastathis from MIT will speak to my class this Thursday! You may find the topic of high relevance to AI4Science! You can find details below.



Title: Adjoint sensitivities and Neural Ordinary Differential Equations (Nodes)



Room: SEC 1.413. From 11:15 am to 12:30 pm



Abstract: In March 2020, as the Covid-19 pandemic was starting, many students in the (then budding) Physics in Machine Learning class at MIT were selecting projects relating to epidemiological analysis and forecasting. One of them, Raj Dandekar, decided to look into the effect of quarantine, namely how it influences the rate of infections. At the time, he and his advisor, Chris Rackauckas, were involved in the origins of a new class of algorithms allowing the direct insertion of neural networks into differential equations for system identification, forecasting, and control. The result was one of the first-ever practical implementations of Nodes, and yielded some interesting insights into how different policies among jurisdictions affected their infection outcomes [Dandekar et al, Patterns 1:100145, 2020; Dandekar et al, Health Data Science 2021:9798302]. Since then, Nodes has been applied widely in many contexts of estimation theory, including stiff nonlinear dynamics [Suyong Kim, et al, Chaos 31:093122, 2021].



In the lecture, we will start at the motivation behind Nodes more generally and the Covid-19 work more specifically. Then we will go into the nitty-gritty of such techniques in simple dynamics such as the Malthusian and logistic population growth models, and the Lotka-Volterra predator-prey competition model. We will learn how the important concept of adjoint sensitivity arises in these models in the presence of parameter uncertainty. Finally, we will loop back into the original idea of inserting neural networks into differential equations, and how the adjoint allows the weights of these networks to be estimated, building robust and explainable models of complex phenomena.

Familiarity with nonlinear dynamics will be helpful, but not required; however, we will all have to dust up our memories of simple ordinary differential equations.

Bio: George and his groups at MIT and in Singapore are defining the role of machine learning far beyond applications in imaging and optics by elegantly weaving first principles into the AI's learning functionals. George's work demonstrates clearly how the synergies between physics, first principles, and machine learning will enable strategic research priorities in engineering and the sciences. His educational efforts model elegantly how to excite our students about the utility of first principles-enabled machine learning in science and engineering.

Familiarity with nonlinear dynamics will be helpful, but not required; however, we will all have to dust up our memories of simple ordinary differential equations.



Host: Demba Ba

Thank you very much,



[cid:image001.jpg@01D971F3.97C8EF60]
Liz Palomino (she/her/hers)
Faculty Coordinator
Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences
a: 150 Western Ave, Rm 4.404, Allston, MA 02134
p: 617-496-5027
e: lpalomino@seas.harvard.edu<mailto:lpalomino@seas.harvard.edu>
Hours: 9:00 am-5:00 pm | In-Office: Wednesday






--

590053048.subject: [ADAMS] HOW TO SAVE A LIFE WORKSHOP April 30th 8:30-9:30 pm
590053048.text:
Mark your calendars for a workshop on...

*AIRWAY MANAGEMENT*
April 30th* 8:30-9:30 pm*

We will learn how to place nasal trumpets (sounds fun!) and oral airways,
how to properly bag ventilate a patient, and how to intubate (or place a
breathing tube).
We will also cover basic CPR skills.

space limited, SIGN UP HERE <https://forms.gle/nQ8Tm5kSarpZUp989>

Snacks included


[image: Bad-Intubation.jpg]
Bonus points if you show up and can explain what is wrong with this picture
from this unnamed hallmark movie.


xoxox
Leonie

IMPT: this is not true CPR training, nor is it sponsored by the AHA. If you
want to get truly CPR certified, this is not the way.

-- 
Leonie Oostrom-Shah
(she/her/hers)
Resident Tutor, Adams House
Emergency Medicine Resident--HAEMR/BIDMC
phone: 509.987.6555

599619690.subject: "The Splendid Body" by Rebecca Lindenberg
599619690.text:
The splendid body is meat, flexor / and flesh pumping, pulling, anti-

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 27, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** The Splendid Body (http://poets.org/poem/splendid-body?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
Rebecca Lindenberg (https://poets.org/poet/rebecca-lindenberg?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID)

The splendid body is meat, flexor
and flesh pumping, pulling, anti-
gravity maverick just standing
upright all over museums and
in line for the bus and in the laundry
aisle where it‚Äôs just standing there
smelling all the detergent like
it‚Äôs no big deal. So what if a couple
of its squishy parts are suspended
within, like beach-bungled jellyfish
in a shelved jar, not doing anything?
Nothing on this side of the quantum
tunnel is perfect. The splendid body,
though, is splendid in the way
it keeps its steamy blood in, no matter
how bad it blushes. And splendid
in how it opens its mouth and
these invisible vibrations come
rippling out‚Äîif you put your wrist
right up to it when that happens
it feels somewhat like the feet
of many bees. The splendid body
loves the juniper smell of gin, loves
the warmth of printer-fresh paper,
and the sound fallen leaves make
under the wheel of a turning car.
If you touch it between the legs,
the splendid body will quicken
like bubbles in a just-on teakettle.
It knows it can‚Äôt exist forever, so
it‚Äôs collecting as many flavors as it can‚Äî
saffron, rainwater, fish-skin, chive.
Do not distract it from its purpose,
which is to feel everything it can find.

Copyright ¬© 2023 by Rebecca Lindenberg. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on April 27, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS5109763603.mp3?updated=1682008368&mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID

‚ÄúThis poem is part of a longer project called Our Splendid Failure to Do the Impossible. That project began during the Covid-19 lockdown, because, everywhere I looked, I saw the words ‚Äòdiabetes‚Äô and ‚Äòsevere outcome‚Äô within an inch of each other on page after page of news, public service announcements, medical studies, etc. As a Type 1 diabetic for over thirty years now, I found that scary and distracting. That, in turn, prompted me to write more directly about my experience growing up with an incurable, life-threatening illness and the way it‚Äôs shaped my life, my imagination, and, in turn, my art and other ways I have of knowing. I see this particular poem as examining the ways in which chronic disease prevents us from taking the body and its intersections with the world for granted. Usually, that‚Äôs one of the hardest things about living with my condition; but it can, at times, feel almost celebratory.‚Äù
‚ÄîRebecca Lindenberg
http://poets.org/poet/rebecca-lindenberg?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID

Rebecca Lindenberg (http://poets.org/poet/rebecca-lindenberg?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID) is the author of Our Splendid Failure to Do the Impossible, forthcoming in 2024 from BOA Editions. The recipient of a National Endowment for the Arts literature grant and a Dorothy Sargent Rosenberg Poetry Prize, she is an assistant professor at the University of Cincinnati, where she is also poetry editor of the Cincinnati Review.

Thanks to U.S. poet laureate Ada Lim√≥n (https://poets.org/poet/ada-limon?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID) , author of The Hurting Kind (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781639550494?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID)  (Milkweed Editions, 2022), who curated Poem-a-Day for this month‚Äôs weekdays. As of this year, the U.S. poet laureate guest editorship during National Poetry Month (https://poets.org/library-congress-and-poem-day?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a collaboration between the Academy and the Library of Congress. Read or listen to a Q&A (https://poets.org/April-2023-poem-a-day-editor-ada-limon?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID)  about Lim√≥n‚Äôs curatorial approach and find out more about our guest editors for the year (https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=21c40f16f5&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

607936505.subject: [cs-undergrads] GPT-4 - How does it work, and how do I build apps with it?
607936505.text:
Hi all,

Perhaps of interest, a lunchtime lecture on GPT-4 next Monday! RSVP at
https://forms.gle/GGniJDH4wAWG7Ca67.

djm

---

First software ate the world. Now Generative AI is eating software. Join us
for a three-piece lecture on theory, practice, and Otto's pizza.

*GPT-4 - How does it work, and how do I build apps with it?*
Monday, May 1, 2023, 12pm‚Äì1:30pm
1 Brattle Square <https://goo.gl/maps/4ad3BCzXbqEAunPj9> #204, roughly
across from Felipe's

RSVP at https://forms.gle/GGniJDH4wAWG7Ca67.

First, you‚Äôll learn how GPT-4 works and why human language turns out to
play such a critical role in computing. Next, you‚Äôll see how AI-native
software is being made. Every attendee will leave with AI know-how, a full
belly from pizza, and free credits on Steamship ‚Äî the hosting platform for
AI apps.

Taught by Ted Benson, founder of Steamship, MIT Ph.D., & Y Combinator Alum;
and Sil Hamilton, researcher of emergent AI behavior at McGill University.

This event is open to anyone at Harvard, whether taking CS50 or not!

-- 
You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "cs-undergrads" group.
To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to cs-undergrads+unsubscribe@seas.harvard.edu.
To view this discussion on the web visit https://groups.google.com/a/seas.harvard.edu/d/msgid/cs-undergrads/CAOeccsNsSHr7Jok%2Bep6JtNtp00E-yDsX9kaq%3DHjn8mrp8rV4jA%40mail.gmail.com.

612761889.subject: [hcs-d] $100,000 Xfund Xperiment Stake
612761889.text:
Hi HCS!

Are you working on a startup? Is your team looking to start your company
full-time after graduation? This is your opportunity to receive a *minimum
$100k investment* in your startup!

Xfund, an early-stage venture firm designed for university founders, is
launching Xperiment Stake. Learn more here ->
https://www.xfund.com/xperiment
The deadline to apply is *April 30th*! No team is too early and all
verticals are fair game for this Xperiment.


-- 
*Kelly Ding *(she/her/hers)
Harvard College Class of 2025

Adam

701308246.subject: New threads in COMPSCI 143
701308246.text:
Course: COMPSCI 143
Author: PK/Lauren Byunn-Rieder
Link:   https://edstem.org/us/courses/36192/discussion/3038135



Our experimentation indicates that the satellite outage only exists on the TCP flow from 221 to 220 (the original 2 ground stations). To get continuity with our third ground station, I'd like to either add the satellite outage to the other TCP flows or remove it, but I can't find where in the code base it's implemented. Staff tips/points in the rig...



Course: COMPSCI 143
Author: Anonymous
Link:   https://edstem.org/us/courses/36192/discussion/3034425



My group was wondering what the slide limit for our final presentation is. It sounded like from the answer to https://edstem.org/us/courses/36192/discussion/2968229 that it might be different from the initial 7 slides limit for the in-class presentation. but I haven't seen any additional updates on canvas that states otherwise.

737166636.subject: [ADAMS] SCR lunch talk at 12pm in the conservatory
737166636.text:
Join Adam's Arab American Heritage Month SCR lunch talk today

12pm in Adams Conservatory (grab lunch then grab a seat)

With Dr. Anas Chalah

Dr. Anas Chalah is the Assistant Dean for Teaching and Learning at the
School of Engineering, as well as a lecturer in Engineering Sciences at
Harvard University. He leads a team of engineers and collaborates with
faculty to create an environment that encourages hands-on engineering
education. As a member of the research and teaching senior executive team,
he applies new pedagogical methods in developing experimental and
design-based activities, as well as in supporting SEAS' growing presence in
Biological and Environmental Engineering. Anas received his PhD in
Chemistry from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

SCR lunch talk titled:
From Damascus to Cambridge: One way road!

Here's what's happening in tech APRIL 25, 2023

From TechTarget | 150 Editors, Objective IT Coverage

¬†¬†Featured Stories

[https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineimages/container_g1128254725.jpg]

How to create an SBOM, with example and template
[https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014726/45705094]
SBOMs help organizations inventory every component in their software. This free
template, which includes an SBOM example, can help you secure your own software
supply chain. by Rob Shapland [https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014727/45705094]
A quick look at the Carbon programming language
[https://go.techtarget.com/r/266015172/45705094]



¬†¬†In the news

[https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/email/genericContentImages/random_content_img_10_200x200.jpg]
Mandiant: 3CX breach caused by second supply chain attack
[https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014558/45705094]
Trading Technologies said in a statement it had 'not had the ability to verify
the assertions in Mandiant's report' that its software played a role in the 3CX
supply chain attack. by Alexander Culafi
[https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014513/45705094]

[https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/email/genericContentImages/random_content_img_11_200x200.jpg]
Sidecarless eBPF service mesh sparks debate
[https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014506/45705094]
As cloud-native service meshes expand beyond Kubernetes, open source community
members raise concerns about the security and suitability of eBPF in sidecarless
architectures. by Beth Pariseau [https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014507/45705094]

[https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/email/genericContentImages/random_content_img_19_200x200.jpg]
Server-side Wasm boosts K8s bonds, devx ahead of key update
[https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014606/45705094]
Early adopters await a WASI update this year before server-side Wasm can be
ready for wider production use. For now, PaaS vendors have begun to bridge some
of the gaps. by Beth Pariseau [https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014507/45705094]

[https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/email/owl.png]

Your Words
of the Day

class library (in object-oriented programming)
[https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014822/45705094]

[https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/email/icon-youTube-30px.png]https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014822/45705094¬†[WATCH
[https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014822/45705094]]

In object-oriented programming, a class library is a collection of classes and
other reusable software components, such as interfaces and value types.
tape library [https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014786/45705094]

[https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/email/icon-youTube-30px.png]https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014786/45705094¬†[WATCH
[https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014786/45705094]]

In data storage, a tape library is a collection of magnetic tape cartridges and
tape drives.
software toolchain [https://go.techtarget.com/r/266014823/45705094]
A software toolchain is a set of software development tools used simultaneously
to complete complex software development tasks or to deliver a software product.

764375343.subject: [ADAMS] Join PBHA for Visitas: Info Sessions, Boba, Board Games, Raffle Prizes, and more!
764375343.text:
Want to learn more about public service?

Love bubble tea and fun games?

Join us for Visitas 2023 at PBHA this Sunday!!

Our annual Visitas event is around the corner and we hope you can make it,
please RSVP here <https://forms.gle/tndYHhZn46vw441HA>! We'd like to
welcome incoming first years, their families, volunteers, directors, and
any other Harvard students who are interested in public service. This is a
great opportunity to meet our wonderful directors, volunteers, and leaders
while getting to learn about PBHA‚Äôs wide range of programs.

Join us in front of PBHA for a mini tabling info session from
4:30-5:30 pm! PBHA
runs over 60 programs throughout the year that you can get involved with so
spend this hour mingling with other students, walking around program
tables, and asking any questions you have about PBHA! Then head inside our
historic building for a delicious and fun Boba and Board Games event from
5-7pm! We will have various boba flavors, games to play, raffle prizes, and
even more people to meet!




-- 
*Elizabeth Ogolo*
She/Her/Hers
Harvard College | Class of 2024
A.B. Candidate in Neurobiology

771227634.subject: [Fyre] Fwd: AAWA Reading Period Care Packages!!
771227634.text:
HARVARD-RADCLIFFE ASIAN AMERICAN WOMEN‚ÄôS ASSOCIATION

READING PERIOD CARE PACKAGES !

Need yummy snacks to take your mind off studying without having to leave
your dorm? Want to send some food and love to your stressed out friends
(and yourself)? Treat yourself and your friends to reading period care
packages from AAWA!!! Each care package will contain Hi-Chews, Pocky, and
other wonderful Asian snacks! You can also add a little note to each care
package! Each care package has been created with lots of love and care by
the AAWA board. We‚Äôre sending everyone well-wishes and the best of luck~!

Small: $8

Large: $10

Place your order at https://tinyurl.com/AAWA2023Cares between 04/16 and
04/21. Payment accepted via Venmo @Harvard-AAWA

*Orders will be delivered via door drop at the beginning of Reading Period!

Questions?

Email crimson.aawa@gmail.com!


--

<https://www.facebook.com/HarvardAAWA/> | AAWA's Insta
<https://www.instagram.com/harvardaawa/>

791180544.subject: [ADAMS] Looking for a fourth suitemate to join a quad!
791180544.text:
Hi Adams,

We are a group of three incoming juniors looking for a fourth (preferably
female or non-binary) suitemate to regroup as a four-person suite before
the Priority 3 lottery round! If you happen to love wine and cheese nights
and going on berryline runs, we would love for you to join us! Here are
some short bios of the three of us:

Amanda: Hey everyone, my name‚Äôs Amanda! I‚Äôm studying econ and considering
an ed studies minor. I play on the women‚Äôs lacrosse team! I like to keep my
living space clean, and I go to bed around 11:00 and wake up around 6:30
for morning practice. I love music, being outdoors, and creative writing :)
Insta: @a_sudzy

Helen: Hey everyone, my name is Helen and I‚Äôm a rising junior concentrating
in neuro! I usually go to bed at around 12 or 1 and wake up at 9/9:30
during the weekdays. I always keep my living space organized and clean, so
messiness won‚Äôt be an issue. I love to dance, play the piano, and make yt
videos! Insta: @helenpiltner

Ann: My name is Ann and I am an (undeclared) Econ concentrator planning a
sociology secondary! I tend to go to bed around 1-2 am and wake up around
10 am and am typically a neat person. I love country music and have a
slight obsession with Gilmore Girls. Insta: @annncatt

If you're interested, please respond to this email, reach out on insta or
text 9125413367 :)

Thanks,

Ann, Helen and Amanda

[image: Screen Shot 2023-04-17 at 10.47.30 PM.png]

-- 
*Ann Nguyen*
A.B. Candidate in Economics at Harvard College
anguyen@college.harvard.edu

799603910.subject: Re: [hcs-d] HSRG: reading group on dataframe libraries
799603910.text:
Sorry: Quick correction to the above email on the date!

We're having weekly reading group at 1 PM in the Science Center (Room 109) on Sunday, April 23rd. 


> On Apr 17, 2023, at 2:12 PM, Eric Zhang <ekzhang@college.harvard.edu> wrote:
> 
> Hello from the Harvard Systems Reading Group <https://notes.ekzhang.com/events/hsrg>!
> 
> <PastedGraphic-1.png>
> 
> We're having weekly reading group at 1 PM in the Science Center (Room 109) on Saturday, April 15th. All are invited to join us, regardless of past background ‚Äî we believe that having diverse thoughts is important to learning together as a collective.
> 
> This week's topic is is dataframe libraries ‚Äî exploring how we talk to computers about data analysis & transformations, through languages and storage formats and performance optimization. Case studies on Polars and DuckDB.
> 
> To get updates please join our GroupMe at the website linked here: https://notes.ekzhang.com/events/hsrg :D
> 
> Best,
> Eric

801946491.subject: [hcs-d] Berkeley Summer Sublet for Intern/Student
801946491.text:
Forwarding for a friend!

BERKELEY SUMMER SUBLET (NEAR SAN FRANCISCO)

I'm looking for a summer subletter (female-identifying preferred) for my
furnished single bedroom in a 2bd1ba apartment close to UC Berkeley campus
and Berkeley BART station. Oakland, San Francisco, and much of the Bay Area
are accessible via public transportation. The subletter would ideally be a
student taking summer classes or completing a summer internship in the Bay
Area.

Details:
    ‚Ä¢    Apartment located in a quiet neighborhood in Berkeley Southside
    ‚Ä¢    3 min walk to Berkeley campus, 5 min walk to Telegraph Ave
(restaurants, shops), 7 min walk to Downtown Berkeley
    ‚Ä¢    Spacious bedroom w/ walk-in closet and queen bed, fully furnished
(see photo)
    ‚Ä¢    Shared access to kitchen, living room, and other apartment common
spaces
    ‚Ä¢    Other bedroom may be occupied by female-identifying Berkeley
student
    ‚Ä¢    Available June 1 - mid August
    ‚Ä¢    Rent: $1300 (negotiable)

The rent price and move-in/out dates are flexible. Please message reach out
to me at eleanorfwong@berkeley.edu (mailto:eleanorfwong@berkeley.edu) if
you‚Äôre interested and I can provide more details.

816663432.subject: May 9  Talk, "Large Language Models and the End of Programming" with Matt Welsh, CEO of Fixie.ai
816663432.text:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
May 9  Talk, "Large Language Models and the End of Programming" with Matt Welsh, CEO of Fixie.ai 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Register now for the next free ACM TechTalk, "Large Language Models and The End of Programming" (https://acm-org.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_vf0SPZY7TeWMH-5_IaloIQ), presented on Tuesday, May 9 at 12:00 PM ET/16:00 UTC by Matt Welsh, CEO of Fixie.ai. Oana Olteanu, Partner at SignalFire, will moderate the questions and answers session following the talk. 

Leave your comments and questions with our speaker now and any time before the live event on ACM's Discourse Page (https://on.acm.org/t/large-language-models-and-the-end-of-programming/2750). And check out the page after the webcast for extended discussion with your peers in the computing community, as well as further resources on large language models, generative AI, and more.

(If you'd like to attend but can't make it to the virtual event, you still need to register to receive a recording of the TechTalk when it becomes available.)

Note: You can stream this and all ACM TechTalks on your mobile device, including smartphones and tablets.


The field of Computer Science is headed for a major upheaval with the rise of large AI models, such as ChatGPT, that are capable of performing general-purpose reasoning and problem solving. We are headed for a future in which it will no longer be necessary to write computer programs. Matt believes that most software will eventually be replaced by AI models that, given an appropriate description of a task, will directly execute that task, without requiring the creation or maintenance of conventional software. In effect, large language models act as a virtual machine that is "programmed" in natural language. This talk will explore the implications of this prediction, drawing on recent research into the cognitive and task execution capabilities of large language models.  

Duration: 60 minutes (including audience Q&A)

Presenter:
Matt Welsh, CEO, Fixie.ai

Matt Welsh is the CEO and Co-founder of Fixie.ai, a Seattle-based startup developing a new computational platform with AI at the core. He was previously head of engineering at OctoML, a software engineer at Apple and Xnor.ai, engineering director at Google, and a Professor of Computer Science at Harvard University. He holds a PhD from UC Berkeley.

Moderator:
Oana Olteanu, Partner, SignalFire

Oana is a ML engineer with operating experience in enterprise software and investment experience at the Seed, Series A and Series B stages. Prior to joining SignalFire, Oana was at Scale Venture Partners where she invested in applied ML and developer tooling. She sourced Scale's investments in Observe.ai, Flatfile, and Proscia. She was part of the deal teams for Honeycomb and AllyO (acquired by HireVue). Prior to VC, Oana worked at SAP where she contributed to the development of the backend systems used by SAP for its solution portfolio.

Visit learning.acm.org/techtalks-archive for our full archive of past TechTalks.
You are subscribed with: eelaafzahid@college.harvard.edu

Unsubscribe:  https://optout.acm.org/unsubscribe.cfm?rm=trWpwdl49BCEB56B7AE1EF3E03B6D9A360B497176536B49536C57776B4A5558666E5955&ln=ACM-WEBINAR

<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSf-q336L-I-CxjcIpoGQxFMBpdokcZ5HB4dV-5IRYtKgi23PA/viewform>

Despite a City Council vote
<https://click.actionnetwork.org/ss/c/atcYNHk4Eh2YdGnwBh-YDPKoZNOpT4YMSDOIuZmc6RIOMzLp9Sxlq88HsR7Yx8p8Qsw67rY-_dz3yAoMfw09kO3JJrupG5zHHNkE6g6Ov02LsxuieDBg5bFcSVNDjnr5E4CIH3Gg8TheJWQwDoM14vuEb_KgW2XyofYVU3sBkvpJPxHuL1lyKkDvlKExQ5vppCGpMlINbO7C775jVHoG-7hA3HKgGxkFFYoLcNUo00om64XAgc_VjKJjuPTJlUDnRXKDrLqpdSuKgfj3F-2GLov_zdFVAI-fOg2Tj621qyMB30Snl7tp7X_bEVnYkcWkJ4rOWVCYQFGnBlVSYwXuNOivmTbsde1t8wmzbuLfpxIejPocX6ZdAjNLNIL4NHs1SDJ2oTOfD7tHa6m6dX07zcCf3rTgQU7sGoZKWAqRFt7pvvJUEqGjBuTQGUYqmNlF_fNby-SgX6LHzh_pocM6mvKbUbCPeWnIN41QWkupsyB3ZG9fLsjmuIJEGIlhk1iQ2vyU7A9yXgjiyB96PlbNVUv0RVmhGMpqt6_B3rertbg/3ur/-pV1r34LSPitbsXg7qs8zg/h0/t89NTGwN4FAa0zojohA6z1qTOaC0jI-2D2AU5wxCp00>
to close Memorial Drive to traffic all weekend, the Department of
Conservation and Recreation has announced that the park will only open on
Sundays. This completely ignores the park's popular support.


Every spring, Memorial Drive closes to cars
<https://www.cambridgeday.com/2022/09/11/its-time-to-make-memorial-drive-a-weekend-park-for-good/>
on weekends and becomes a park that thousands of residents use. It‚Äôs a
space where we can walk, run, bike, skate, and enjoy the breathtaking views
of the Charles River and the city skyline. It‚Äôs a space where we can
connect with our community and with ourselves.

Last year, over 4,000 people signed a petition to keep Memorial Drive open
as a park on Saturdays. Yet our state government isn‚Äôt listening to this
broadly supported proposal.

Harvard College Democracy House is fighting to reopen Mem Drive, and we
need your help.

   1.

   Sign this petition
   <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSf-q336L-I-CxjcIpoGQxFMBpdokcZ5HB4dV-5IRYtKgi23PA/viewform>
   to show that, like the rest of Cambridge, Harvard students want and deserve
   this open space.
   2.

   *Make phone calls today and tomorrow *- Urge officials to support
   opening Riverbend Park on Saturdays this year. It just takes a couple of
   minutes, and you can leave a message if you don't reach somebody. Politely
   share your personal thoughts and experiences using this open space.
   DCR Community Relations Office 617-626-1250 #3

   DCR Communications Director 617-360-1715
   Governor Healey's Office 617-725-4005
   Rep. Decker 617-722-2130
   Rep. Owens 617-299-6982‚Ä¨
   Sen. Brownsberger 617-722-1280
   Sen. DiDomenico 617-722-1650


   <https://click.actionnetwork.org/ss/c/4PfL751D8g4IfLXFw3QfXYble7GwiWawy0OAMyo2b55MEsEqfbOFMxr2zMmW_wJT290njSlMmzk9YoPG2szIb0-IBdOEA8RY_PH44DiDVR2vGhSO5lKA5x1-9nS1Wb8fnS2rhQUvmU_CgrPUAKqxz7wiKkTj1qqtyr2pd-zmLMRw5mlDy7TCU9E052ZPmUDzGgW_jKXdiDVr844yx8oPqvl6NhyRDgAuC73_qGse9YrIFgM0WcriBcB6BarteLMgW0CEegmVGCnZ967R7KFvAS422MCaI3I3-KoFKuHzKB7c582J6pCyiLmVl7DI20VnBR1-w2JBdWetNXBeigD2Ai6xFsB693F6_lGkP1ZHxz0vzl2alWpMCDYxdw9B_HhNk7ZXpDc6Q-RK1qHhTD3lA24hfma0gxUEEHG9KwFCFENJzU3sB1pYYXUK_H4OqLiMjhdncvYEwMCEvut2vUbkkwooRMhCfV0rUsbs0j7srWsUFQV120VwVYtJOeSBPyvDrcM4y1OOsgRNiUD9L_jOr1hOLCogj9fRfMfdVZ7R7T2DYmSTKBjLh-ZZsoSDtgruJ2VA4A20R-hRTZfy5Cdy2Smc7UIg1jEcrnzBonLkDnfRpM5Ph0OAHnOP5BMUIDhf54DAKO6_Wvx4TRTg8W94sMkiU2reXE7EE0ZtS2LCNLkBJoJu2v6vr83mo5-1f0Yx0e4uybAY3zF_PdjsEjbQfQ/3ur/-pV1r34LSPitbsXg7qs8zg/h2/jOx2yWekdR9kFZy5a9xgfJRpaqs9mt0wytrHSSoeOZ0>

848254779.subject: [ADAMS] Fwd: Join Harvard-Radcliffe Summer Theater!
848254779.text:
for a friend!

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Azra Haseki <ahaseki@college.harvard.edu>
Date: Wed, Apr 26, 2023 at 7:19‚ÄØPM
Subject: Join Harvard-Radcliffe Summer Theater!
To: <crmoses@college.harvard.edu>


*Tl;dr: fill out **this* <https://forms.gle/pxjUJPU4pG6ypxLVA>* interest
form to do summer on-campus theater*

Want to do theater but don‚Äôt have time during the school year? Looking to
stay in Cambridge over the summer? Love comedies featuring fake identities?
Fill out this non-binding interest form
<https://forms.gle/pxjUJPU4pG6ypxLVA> and join Harvard-Radcliffe Summer
Theater for Oscar Wilde‚Äôs hilarious play, The Importance of Being Earnest!

We plan to run HRST from the beginning of June to the end of July. Just
like term-time theater, HRST will have its rehearsals in the evenings and
on weekends, so cast and crew are welcome to take part in internships or
research in the Boston area as long as they are able to fulfil their role.
Fill out our form here: https://forms.gle/pxjUJPU4pG6ypxLVA !

We'd love for you to get involved with the show -- if you have any
questions or if you would like to learn more about the show, please reach
out to directors Azra Haseki (ahaseki@college.harvard.edu), Ellie Powell (
epowell@college.harvard.edu), or stage managers Em Barnes (
ebarnes@college.harvard.edu), Elizabeth Resner (eresner@college.harvard.edu
).





-- 
Charlotte Moses
Harvard College | Class of 2024
A.B. Candidate in Chemical and Physical Biology
Secondary in Folklore and Mythology

[US Army Corps of Engineers]

From the USACE:

"The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is one of the world's premier public engineering, design, and construction management agencies. We serve the American people, striving to provide the most effective engineering and environmental science solutions to the nation's complex problems affecting national security, the economy, and the environment in which we live. In support of our programs, we hire many environmental science professionals, biologists, physical scientists, geologists, hydrologists, and many other civilian positions. It's an exciting time to work for USACE. We offer challenging professional, technical and non-STEM assignments that include paid summer positions, student internships, developmental and mid-career opportunities, just to name a few."

- General Natural Resources Management and Biological Sciences series
- Engineering Technical series

- Realty series
- Lock and Dam Operating series

868865515.subject: [ENG-SCI 94] Help a classmate out - Startup User Research!
868865515.text:
Hi Everyone,

Hope this finds you well. One of your classmates (Yoona Kim, yoonakim@college.harvard.edu) , needs your help with a venture she‚Äôs building after being inspired by ES 94. If you can spare a minute or two please fill out the following survey -  https://forms.gle/UyjQxX1WFbiYRU2j7<https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__forms.gle_UyjQxX1WFbiYRU2j7&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=EIE15gYfUCNOtm9xR8OjX86k2-i3vdDJYc4ixDpbcbY&m=bulAr1rIdzcewP_X-3m34HTYUVghQtfqkyigXsEI7ORDess2f2a1jE_jbsyRXnw4&s=x6jMC2hpHUKid2z6-dSXFqjSJAB0tvccP9517QI5qZo&e=>. Below is a short description of her venture:

WishWise is a wishlist and personal finance service that incentivizes users to save money before making a purchase, whether it's a new article of clothing or an electronic device. The key component of WishWise is the browser extension that pops up when users add items to an online shopping cart. They'll be nudged to put the item in WishWise's cart, rather than the actual website's cart, and set a savings goal. WishWise would also have a social community aspect, where users can find friends and see each other's wishlist or saving trends. To determine the relevance and viability of this idea, I've created a survey to gain insight into potential users' spending habits, attitudes toward saving and budgeting, common pain points surrounding online shopping and spending, and interest in a service like WishWise.

Good luck with finals!

Best,
Aqdas

879119190.subject: [hcs-d] 1 more roommate in Manhattan Midtown this summer!
879119190.text:
My roommate and I found a pretty nice/cheap/convenient place in Midtown,
and are currently in the process of securing it for this summer! We'd like
to get one more person on board. The place is 401 East 50th Street #5D
<https://streeteasy.com/building/401-east-50-street-new_york/5d?utm_campaign=Agent_Contact_Consumer-Agent_HDP&utm_medium=email&utm_source=Iterable>.
Some additional details:

   - 3 bedrooms, 1 bath, 1 living room
   - Laundry in building, kitchen/fridge/dishwasher in unit
   - 2 blocks from metro station, generally close to where we/people work
   - Rent: $4,650/month total with no broker fee, so around
   *$1550/person/month*
   - Extra nice thing: My roommate's company is giving us a stipend
   specifically for moving services

Note: *Any gender* *welcome*. Khanh and I are supporters of mixed-gender
housing.

We're doing a call-in viewing of the apartment *tomorrow 5/1 at 5:30pm*--feel
free to hop on if you'd like!

The turnaround for apartments is tight, so feel free to *email or call me
at 703-899-1656* or Khanh at ‚Ä≠*(910) 713-6056*‚Ä¨ if you have any questions!

[image: image.png]

Best,
Jessica

_______________________________________________
hcs-discuss mailing list
hcs-discuss@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/hcs-discuss

903303506.subject: [HUES] Nuclear Energy Summit
903303506.text:
Hi everyone,

Interested in climate change and decarbonization? Interested in foreign
affairs and policy as they intersect with technology? Thinking about
joining HUTT next year?

*The Harvard Undergraduate Think Tank* cordially invites you to attend our
inaugural symposium this Friday, April 28th in the Fong Auditorium in *Boylston
Hall!* We will be hosting a session presented by one of our advocacy teams:


*The Future of Nuclear Energy in the United States (2:45-4pm)*

This event will include presentations by our undergraduate research teams
as well as moderated discussions and Q&A sessions with experts in the
field. And there will be *free Flour Bakery* catering for all attendees!

See attached flyer for details.

We hope to see all who are interested this Friday!

Best,
HUTT Co-Presidents
Arjun Akwei and Shelby Tzung

[image: HUTT Symposium - Nuclear.png]

-- 
*Ben Schroeder *(He/Him)
Harvard University | Class of 2024
S.B. Candidate in Mechanical Engineering
Secondary in History

--

918468415.subject: [Fyre] (Need More Responses!!!) Take this quick survey (<3 mins) on food insecurity for a chance to win an Amazon Gift Card!
918468415.text:
Hi everyone!

We're conducting research on food insecurity within the Harvard community
for GOV 51: Data Analysis for Politics. *We would like to invite you to
participate in our **short survey*
<https://streaklinks.com/BdKBCVVMzImCbCcwaA7JY0vM/https%3A%2F%2Fharvard.az1.qualtrics.com%2Fjfe%2Fform%2FSV_57GigRjCe1FTLlY>*
to help us strengthen our research*.



Your feedback will help us bring attention to the larger issue of food
insecurity on college campuses. Of course, your participation is greatly
appreciated, so after completing the survey you will have the chance to win
1 of 3 $20 Amazon Gift Cards!  (YAY!)

The survey only takes *3-5* minutes to complete! Your survey responses are
strictly confidential and will not be tied to your name or personal
information.

Here is the survey link!
<https://streaklinks.com/BdKBCVRDA_tF-9bSRgRfTSbB/https%3A%2F%2Fharvard.az1.qualtrics.com%2Fjfe%2Fform%2FSV_57GigRjCe1FTLlY>

SURVEY: https://harvard.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_57GigRjCe1FTLlY

Thank you so much!

_______________________________________________

FYRE@lists.hcs.harvard.edu

938179420.subject: [Fyre] TODAY! Indigenous Health & Harvard: Hear from Rachel Wilbur MPH PhD
938179420.text:
Interested in hearing from an Indigenous leader in healthcare? Join the
Harvard Quechua Initiative on Global Indigeneity on *Friday, April 21th at
3:00 pm in the SCC Mt. Auburn Room *to hear from Rachel Wilbur MPH, PhD.
Dr. Wilbur will be talking to us about her work addressing the impact
social determinants have on Native Americans and Alaska Native Healthcare
with a Q&A session afterwards.
[image: 47BABD9A-CAE9-4391-AF90-27AABA4DD2DF.jpeg]
*Please RSVP at https://tinyurl.com/harvardquechuawilbur
<https://tinyurl.com/harvardquechuawilbur>*

-- 

*Angie De La Cruz*

Harvard College Class of 2026

A.B. Candidate in Neuroscience

Secondary in Ethnicity, Migration and Rights

952999241.subject: [ADAMS] Fwd: [be a peer counselor!] Join INDIGO and learn to counsel on mental health, intersectionality, and identity!
952999241.text:
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Brian Zhou <brian_zhou@college.harvard.edu>
Date: Wed, Apr 19, 2023 at 4:17‚ÄØPM
Subject: [be a peer counselor!] Join INDIGO and learn to counsel on mental
health, intersectionality, and identity!
To: Indigo Peer Counseling <indigopeercounseling@gmail.com>


*Do people say you're the "therapist" friend?*
*Do your peers go to you for help?*
*Are you interested in how culture and identity affect mental health?*

*Consider interviewing to be an INDIGO* *Peer Counselor! *
Sign ups open now! 4/17-4/27!


If you would like to set up an interview, please schedule a timeslot
between 4/17-4/27 at this *LINK*
<https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/0/appointments/schedules/AcZssZ295fcLwuKZKX-cEhm_RRx39EOaYJFDGsyVX0m5dIIZN4qY2NGAEOkfIMiIgFwu7-cdAYVsmdcr>.
Please email *indigopeercounseling@gmail.com*
<https://mailto:indigopeercounseling@gmail.com> if none of the available
times work for you!

Indigo Peer Counseling is a group of undergraduates who are trained peer
counselors that  strives to foster a supportive and empathetic campus
environment for undergraduate students grappling with and addressing
concerns that lie at the *intersection of identity and mental health.* We
provide specialized services grounded in an understanding of
intersectionality, race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, socioeconomic and
immigration status. Indigo provides *confidential non-directive,
non-judgmental peer counseling,* as well as informational resources.

--

--
*Brian Zhou* (they/them)
A.B. Candidate in Social Anthropology
Harvard College | Class of 2024




-- 
Muriel Dol | Class of '24
Undergraduate Student at Harvard College
mdol@college.harvard.edu
781-732-5035

954348219.subject: "let grow more winter fat / wine-cup / western wild rose" by Camille T. Dungy
954348219.text:
so little open prairie left¬† ¬† ¬† little waves of bluestem¬† ¬† ¬† little

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 21, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** let grow more winter fat / wine-cup / western wild rose (http://poets.org/poem/let-grow-more-winter-fat-wine-cup-western-wild-rose?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
Camille T. Dungy (https://poets.org/poet/camille-t-dungy?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID)

so little open prairie left      little waves of bluestem     little

fuzzy tongue penstemon        quieter the golden currant

nodding onion quieter now as well


only a few clusters of Colorado butterfly plant still yawn into the night


where there once was prairie

a few remaining fireflies abstract themselves

over roads and concrete paths


prairie wants to stretch full out again and sigh‚Äî


purple prairie clover       prairie zinnia

prairie dropseed nodding into solidago

bee balm brushing rabbitbrush‚Äîprairie wants      prairie wants

prairie wants
Copyright ¬© 2023 by Camille T. Dungy. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on April 21, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS3678917903.mp3?updated=1681505709&mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID

‚ÄúThis poem appears in my new book, Soil: The Story of a Black Mother‚Äôs Garden. As I meditated on why my family and I want to return portions of our yard to a habitat that supports native plants, the words in this poem came to me.‚Äù
‚ÄîCamille T. Dungy
https://poets.org/poet/camille-t-dungy?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID

Camille T. Dungy (https://poets.org/poet/camille-t-dungy?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID) is the author of five collections of poetry, including Soil: The Story of a Black Mother‚Äôs Garden (Simon & Schuster, 2023). A 2021 Academy of American Poets Fellow, a Guggenheim Fellow, and an American Book Award winner, she lives in Fort Collins, Colorado, where she is a university distinguished professor at Colorado State University.

https://poets.org/poet/camille-t-dungy?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781982195304?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID

Soil: The Story of a Black Mother‚Äôs Garden (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781982195304?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID)
(Simon & Schuster, 2023)
https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781982195304?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID


‚ÄúBurn‚Äù by Janice N. Harrington
read more (http://poets.org/poem/burn-1?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID)
‚ÄúZinnias‚Äù by Tyler Mills
read more (http://poets.org/poem/zinnias?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID)
http://pcm23.eventbrite.com?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID
Thanks to U.S. poet laureate Ada Lim√≥n (https://poets.org/poet/ada-limon?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID) , author of The Hurting Kind (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781639550494?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID)  (Milkweed Editions, 2022), who curated Poem-a-Day for this month‚Äôs weekdays. As of this year, the U.S. poet laureate guest editorship during National Poetry Month (https://poets.org/library-congress-and-poem-day?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a collaboration between the Academy and the Library of Congress. Read or listen to a Q&A (https://poets.org/April-2023-poem-a-day-editor-ada-limon?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID)  about Lim√≥n‚Äôs curatorial approach and find out more about our guest editors for the year (https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=1bce495f63&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

994185644.subject: Adams Newsletter 04.26.23
994185644.text:
Gold Adams shield with red acorns and oak leaves


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** Adams House Newsletter
------------------------------------------------------------
April 26, 2023
Upcoming Events at a Glance
* Wednesday, April 26, 7pm @ Adams Library, Thesis Show Night 3
* Thursday, April 27, 5-7:30pm @ Dining Hall, House BBQ
* Friday, April 28, 12pm @ Conservatory, SCR Lunch with Dr. Anas Chala
* Friday, April 28, 10pm-2am @ Dining Hall, Spring Formal
* Saturday, April 29, 8:30pm @ Dining Hall, Mariachi Veritas de Harvard concert
* Sunday, April 30, 3-4:30pm @ Apthorp House, SolidariTEA
* Monday, May 1, 8pm @ Multi-Purpose Room, Boston Arab Music Ensemble concert

Important Reading Period Updates
As we head into reading period and exams, please be sure to take care of yourselves and to make use of the following resources if you need support.  If you would like to check in about your academic and personal wellbeing, please feel free to reach out to Chip (mailto:adamshousedean@fas.harvard.edu)  or Amber (mailto:adams_coordinator@fas.harvard.edu)  at any point.
Life in Adams House during reading period and exams
To give you a break from studying, there are a number of great Adams events coming up in the next few days: the Thesis Show tonight, House BBQ during dinner tomorrow, Spring Formal on Friday, a Mariachi concert on Saturday, and an Apthorp Tea on Sunday. Join us!
We will allow pre-formal parties on Friday between 8pm-10pm (see the party registration section below for details about registering your pre-formal party). After Friday night, no suite or common space parties are allowed in Adams during reading period or exams. Please also observe quiet hours from 11:00 pm to 7:00 am.
Here are a few useful resources for this time of the semester:
* The DSO's Getting Support (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3De60499def9-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=CT4aM0_UrSUt95V-wYNpFANWHkP1Hnwwou06qzARKvpgO4n4lR51Kb5jMHJL0teC&s=Jh8-xGURDR7jAjRAIyZQix75XVAybrNN8SiLfKubGXQ&e=) site
* The Honor Council's Top Five Tips (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3D95f8fc58ce-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=-FuVZjJw-ieb5xaBBFl-pHmlhm03kESFF4ULMgC8Xwm-CyFMTvFy97O6hCaW7Pdx&s=C4jUPcQ0X4tzwVT9gJrm5ptsV2qs6gz-fzwjlJgY5VQ&e=)
* Academic Resource Center (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3D54f3b14468-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=-FuVZjJw-ieb5xaBBFl-pHmlhm03kESFF4ULMgC8Xwm-CyFMTvFy97O6hCaW7Pdx&s=q-dJmoqhVOiKTvN0AHhrOXhCkusmAFtR1SPe-gJTY5Q&e=)  (workshops, peer tutoring, academic coaching, accountability hours, and more)
* Writing Center (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3D993380925c-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=-FuVZjJw-ieb5xaBBFl-pHmlhm03kESFF4ULMgC8Xwm-CyFMTvFy97O6hCaW7Pdx&s=NVAGVbYwHUrqOpfve9VClaRm1dWsrV-Dt7CEQeWUdX4&e=)  (conferences with writing tutors, drop-in hours, and workshops)
* Harvard University Health Services (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3Dd8f3a1dab7-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=-FuVZjJw-ieb5xaBBFl-pHmlhm03kESFF4ULMgC8Xwm-CyFMTvFy97O6hCaW7Pdx&s=mCyu3__Zv8KgWhWBsNU6S3tNBo4mygsQjtJcqgpCgOs&e=)
* Counseling and Mental Health Services (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3D25c05f88e0-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=-FuVZjJw-ieb5xaBBFl-pHmlhm03kESFF4ULMgC8Xwm-CyFMTvFy97O6hCaW7Pdx&s=mFTTMt2-yJDiqRd0ec8bqkiTLk7TTrdrtR0ZFHi8fx8&e=)
* Check your exam schedule (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3D7481cadbd3-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=-FuVZjJw-ieb5xaBBFl-pHmlhm03kESFF4ULMgC8Xwm-CyFMTvFy97O6hCaW7Pdx&s=Ntt6pkZxy1yZrwf5T5EU-wAsgUhLKWdCClTkhIU3Pl4&e=)  (make sure to note the time and location, and check that you don't have any conflicts with other exams!)

Extensions on final papers, take-home exams, or projects (not seated three-hour final exams)
* What if I need an extension on a final paper/take-home exam/project before the end of exam period?

Extensions on written work (not seated three-hour final exams) up to the end of the exam period may be granted by the instructor. Such extensions are at the discretion of the instructor; there is no need for Administrative Board action. Most instructors will request confirmation from your Resident Dean, so if you think you may need to request an extension, you should schedule a meeting with Chip (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3Db3dbc2c83d-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=-FuVZjJw-ieb5xaBBFl-pHmlhm03kESFF4ULMgC8Xwm-CyFMTvFy97O6hCaW7Pdx&s=KCdu7C3KXmRqGrpd6yDHuQfYQnck7cj1hch9vAD5i8g&e=)  to discuss your situation.
* What if I need an extension on a final paper/take-home exam/project until AFTER exam period ends?

No instructor can accept your work after the end of the exam period without the authorization of the Administrative Board. You must petition the Administrative Board for an official extension of time beyond the exam period; such extensions are not guaranteed and are given only in extenuating circumstances. Please note that the notation ‚ÄúIncomplete‚Äù (INC), often used in the grading of graduate students, cannot be given to undergraduates. You should be in touch with Chip (mailto:adamshousedean@fas.harvard.edu)  as soon as possible if you think you may need to petition for an extension of time beyond May 13.

For more details about extensions, please see the DSO's Getting Support site (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3Dbff13ffd5f-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=-FuVZjJw-ieb5xaBBFl-pHmlhm03kESFF4ULMgC8Xwm-CyFMTvFy97O6hCaW7Pdx&s=69BBxCW4myd62bjJZTKgGCdtVMEBHY3rV3nxZi0zB2A&e=) .
Check your Final Exam Schedule
Please take a moment to check your final exam schedule (https://registrar.fas.harvard.edu/take-exams) before making any end-of-term travel plans, and make sure you don't have any conflicts between your exams. See the Registrar's instructions on how to address exam conflicts (https://registrar.fas.harvard.edu/exam-conflicts) , and please contact Chip (mailto:adamshousedean@fas.harvard.edu) or Amber (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3D9361e00d11-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=LOgeH2k4LK4rJhqx54aQEx5xvsyyHYf_Jw3xkKoTiqtt4RnDbFIIegA7rJ2BqpBL&s=Qjev2h6wbq-eHsvh518CjTbqAcI31opf_mFP-mzMauU&e=) if you have any questions.
Party Registration Open for April 28
Party registration is open for pre-formal parties from 8-10pm on Friday night this weekend.  Please run your event by your entryway tutor and then complete the party registration form (https://adamshouse.harvard.edu/party-registration) before noon on Friday! After April 28, party registration will be closed during reading period and exams.
Party hosts are encouraged to apply for WISP grants (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3D15112a3ce7-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=taxSQiB8ZTSBIWEvOGnZW2YZkcZ1qfAGdF7B2aaigqIP-JErtQoDbal5LVAFJO-l&s=zjWAv5LdERZAK-9pK6CaTQA3aXLhsXOFjWO83kYaLkU&e=) which help fund food and non-alcoholic beverages for registered events and parties with or without alcohol during high risk hours. All current College students are eligible to apply (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3D2500994b8f-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=taxSQiB8ZTSBIWEvOGnZW2YZkcZ1qfAGdF7B2aaigqIP-JErtQoDbal5LVAFJO-l&s=vtwQYxa1BxKQ6cRg05myJ-g2D6PNrkird6KclMrqTAE&e=) .
Spring Term Move Out Information
Please see the DSO's Spring Move out page (https://dso.college.harvard.edu/move-out) for a complete move out checklist including information about storage and shipping. Sophomores and juniors must move out by noon on Sunday, May 14. Seniors participating in Commencement must move out by 5pm on Friday, May 26.
Adams Thesis Show tonight, 7pm in the Adams Library
Tonight is the third and final night of the annual Adams Thesis Show at 7pm in the Library. All are invited to come hear from our graduates about their research!
SCR Lunch with Dr. Anas Chalah
Friday 4/21, 12pm @ Conservatory
This Friday we will have our last SCR lunch of the semester. We will be hearing from Dr. Anas Chalah, Assistant Dean for Teaching and Learning, in a presentation titled ‚ÄúFrom Damascus to Cambridge: One way road!‚Äù Grab your tray from the Dining Hall and join us all in the Conservatory this Friday at noon! Due to Dr. Chalah's schedule, we will be starting the speaking portion of the lunch at 12:15.
Adams Spring Formal
Friday 4/28, 10pm-2am @ Adams DHall
There is a gnarled tree with green and blue colored leaves in the center of a green background. There are similarly gnarled trees, these without leaves, on either side. Text reads "Happily Ever Adams. Adams House 4/28, 10pm - 2am. Live Music ft. Indigo, Adams' Own DJ Brenda Ceja. Come for Food, Drinks, Dancing.
tickets are on sale now! purchase here (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__docs.google.com_forms_d_e_1FAIpQLSdU9wUBajblt3leBiH6VtZas31kaHJgpP6qmB1qCwV-2DEpvEzA_viewform-3Fusp-3Dsf-5Flink&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=YZPW5pmQyW38itZwUh-5TfR9BFs3qYwcd_kjJEp5cuQNWtJeiA5mtEL-E1NjLBa-&s=VWiW8IZ2A3MOfM2WNanTHtNzLm3oTPKFCRA6vB6EEd8&e=)
regular prices from 4/19 until capacity is reached: $20 for 1 & $35 for 2

All current Adamsians are encouraged to bring a +1, but if doing so must purchase two tickets. Non-HUID +1s are also more than welcome but must be able to show proof of vaccination at the door.

Formal tickets are SEF-eligible. If you have used up your allotted SEF tickets, please email adams@fas.harvard.edu (mailto:adams@fas.harvard.edu) for assistance.

Celebrating International Workers' Day: SolidariTEA
Sunday, April 30, 3-4:30 pm @ Apthorp House

The Adams Faculty Deans cordially invite you to Celebrating International Workers' Day: SolidariTEA on Sunday, April 30th, 2023, from 3:00pm-4:30pm. Come enjoy delicious sweets and savories at the Faculty Deans‚Äô Residence: Apthorp House inside Randolph Courtyard. You can enter Apthorp House from the Plympton Street gate across from Hampden Hall.

Boston Arab Music Ensemble
Monday 5/1, 8pm @ Claverly Multi-Purpose Room

The Adams Race Relations Team invites you to join us for our final event celebrating Arab American Heritage Month, an exciting performance by the Boston Arabic Music Ensemble (BAME) on Monday, May 1 at 8pm in the Claverly Multipurpose Room.  Reception with light refreshments to follow at 9:30 p.m.
RSVP HERE: https://forms.gle/NmpCGNM128qvody5A
Invite Faculty to meals in the Adams DHall!
Students are encouraged to invite their professors and lecturers to join them for meals in the Adams Dining Hall. Faculty members may enjoy up to 10 meals (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us2.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3D62ffd980490ab72203ab03a9a-26id-3D3dd4e872ee-26e-3D921394253b&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=i4KiN2_An3SlxToPziKbx-XYN4qn68LlioB_w5S2UcCxZL8naaj_AJTAfeeJQVAU&m=LOgeH2k4LK4rJhqx54aQEx5xvsyyHYf_Jw3xkKoTiqtt4RnDbFIIegA7rJ2BqpBL&s=_tKSTTy7tzeR4QOc42zypP8mQ6-uI3YGETFeDXXjU7M&e=) in Annenberg or the House dining halls each semester (any meal, any day). Please take advantage of this opportunity to connect with faculty over a meal and share the Adams Dining Hall experience with them.
College Workshops and Resources
* CAMHS Workshops and Groups (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us12.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3Deb85d7a5a3fb4e531ad907e64-26id-3D0efafbdb7a-26e-3D931b88e153&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=RFwuaw2G-qzQuy-k9ex7WGxWqvHgrpuF9hWPl7JK7Qg&m=-CL6ThkvVRzmjM6jxTcOoNotRwO3dxw9zT-IltWLCRJo0sQsOSpDmb9oR9vXDBHu&s=3J07Qpg1Tk-Z5v49bURD4_zRN1WWXyeBC-iDKZlXZRU&e=) . Counseling and Mental Health Services (CAMHS) offers a variety of virtual and in-person workshops and support groups. Visit the CAMHS events calendar (https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/search/events?search=counseling+and+mental+health)  for the Spring semester listings!
* The Academic Resource Center (https://academicresourcecenter.harvard.edu/) offers peer tutoring, academic coaching, accountability groups, workshops, and weekly accountability hours. Check out their upcoming workshops (https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/group/academic_resource_center_at_harvard_university/calendar) on topics including Recognizing and Responding to Burnout and Google Calendar for College Life.
* Remember that the Office of Career Services (https://careerservices.fas.harvard.edu/channels/student/)  has workshops and resources to help you plan for summer internships and research as well as post-graduation employment.
* The Office of Undergraduate Research and Fellowships (URAF) (https://uraf.harvard.edu/) holds Zoom advising hours Monday through Thursday afternoons and is a great resource for learning about funding and myriad opportunities for research, study, travel, and public service (https://uraf.harvard.edu/find-opportunities/browse-uraf-opps) .

997310241.subject: [ADAMS] Mini Tabling+Boba and Board Games at PBHA TODAY!
997310241.text:
The event of the year is finally here!!!!

Visitas 2023 at PBHA is TODAY!!

Our annual Visitas event is around the corner and we hope you can make it!
We'd like to welcome any incoming first years, their families, and other
Harvard students who are interested in public service. This is a great
opportunity to meet our wonderful directors, volunteers, and leaders while
getting to learn about PBHA‚Äôs wide range of programs.

Join us in front of PBHA for a mini tabling info session from
4:30-5:30 pm! PBHA
runs over 60 programs throughout the year that you can get involved with so
spend this hour mingling with other students, walking around program
tables, and asking any questions you have about PBHA! Then head inside our
historic building for a delicious and fun Boba and Board Games event from
5-7pm! We will have various boba flavors, games to play, raffle prizes, and
even more people to meet!



-- 
*Elizabeth Ogolo*
She/Her/Hers
Harvard College | Class of 2024
A.B. Candidate in Neurobiology
