1029098961.subject: The Slowdown for April 21, 2023
1029098961.text:
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=5513d3f757238cf52b59957a8a09db9bc5bba7aaccf4d29432f9b9463310ac1ea9006bcb42abd5c12227d8e2e8e7ff9ecc6642400d9122d8 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=5513d3f757238cf53c0ace9e0ebcad59f2d3aa222e405c7e968a508b41643dac0df42657ac46e02fdac3bcac9299d8abc64170dbb2589ec9 
Give Now 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=5513d3f757238cf5160f7c70f6fed37ef7b011e73a622dcc851dab23bc8e64d0bd20df00bd74d29563e10c6168b40e8784d11191b029ed06 
“I read the daily poems from The Slowdown with my morning coffee. These poems are a gift.” - Richarda E. 





 Today‚Äôs poem, drawn from the language of biology, contains a strong and simple message about diversity in society.       

   
— Major

Apologia
 by Cherene Sherrard



Today in the mail I received a handwritten

note from a person whose illegible signature 

required that I google the address to discover 

its provenance. Let me restate: its provenance 

was benevolent privilege. So accustomed am I 

to the casual pokes and missteps of daily 

interaction that I failed to be offended by,

or maybe misremembered, the incident 

obligingly related inside the card, imprinted 

with an abstract collage of what I think was

an Asian carp, an invasive species my son

likes to fish for in the lake and let suffocate on 

shore. He lures them with sweet corn. A kindness, 

he says, because these carp have no restraint. 

They obliterate biodiversity and we do not 

want a lake that only holds one type of fish.

“Apologia” from

1042751424.subject: [Adams-molotov] PROTEST NOW
1042751424.text:
HAPPENING NOW! Come to Harvard Art Museums and join us in calling for
Harvard to dename the TWO university buildings named after the Sacklers,
the family who created and profited off of the opioid crisis, killing
countless Americans and . Stand in solidarity as we ask Harvard to do what
several other institutions have already done and cut ties with the Sackler
name as well as all other buildings that honor perpetrators of violence and
oppression.--
Jennifer Luong

Class of 2023

1046340290.subject: "Anthropocenic" by Jake Skeets
1046340290.text:
:  when the nearest light is miles away yet

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 17, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** Anthropocenic (http://poets.org/poem/anthropocenic?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
Jake Skeets (https://poets.org/poet/jake-skeets?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID)

:  when the nearest light is miles away yet
and adorned on the night is a lightning bug
as in a jarred cactus plant
an open book without commas

:  when the only thing you can touch is a plastic raft
and drenched between the hours is a cutting board
as in a place for garlic
and onions the face of early sky

:  when water undresses into tar sands
and to one long tune acacia trees dance some
as in alder reach
anything is worth the rain

:  when above more and more narrow miracles
and answers set to stone by a single hand
as in a chorus of them
any shadow still means light
Copyright ¬© 2023 by Jake Skeets. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on April 17, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS4509433502.mp3?updated=1681322248&mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID

‚ÄúI was cutting garlic and onions for dinner and noticed how white the sky seemed through the small window in my kitchen during yet another wildfire. That image (https://poets.org/glossary/imagery?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID) became the poem‚Äôs first layer, and from there I explored different ideas and terms about climate change, each with its own definition. I found them all trying to translate the same experience: existing in a dying world. So the poem‚Äôs use of the colon is informed by those attempts at defining and translating the looking that we do through small windows and the way we encounter our vulnerability over and over again.‚Äù
‚ÄîJake Skeets
https://poets.org/poet/jake-skeets?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID

Jake Skeets (https://poets.org/poet/jake-skeets?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a Din√© poet and the author of Eyes Bottle Dark with a Mouthful of Flowers (Milkweed Editions, 2018), winner of the National Poetry Series. The recipient of a 92Y Discovery Prize, an American Book Award, and a Whiting Award, he lives in Norman, Oklahoma, the traditional home of the Hasinai Caddo Nation and Kirikir îi:s Wichita and Affiliated Tribes.

https://poets.org/poet/jake-skeets?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781571315205?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID

Eyes Bottle Dark with a Mouthful of Flowers (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781571315205?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID)
(Milkweed Editions, 2018)

https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781571315205?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID


‚ÄúThis One Goes Out to the Future‚Äù by Beau Sia
read more (http://poets.org/poem/one-goes-out-future?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID)
‚ÄúNetherland‚Äù by Julia B. Levine
read more (http://poets.org/poem/netherland?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID)
http://pcm23.eventbrite.com?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID
Thanks to U.S. poet laureate Ada Lim√≥n (https://poets.org/poet/ada-limon?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID) , author of The Hurting Kind (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781639550494?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID)  (Milkweed Editions, 2022), who curated Poem-a-Day for this month‚Äôs weekdays. As of this year, the U.S. poet laureate guest editorship during National Poetry Month (https://poets.org/library-congress-and-poem-day?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a collaboration between the Academy and the Library of Congress. Read or listen to a Q&A (https://poets.org/April-2023-poem-a-day-editor-ada-limon?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID)  about Lim√≥n's curatorial approach and find out more about our guest editors for the year (https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID) .


http://poets.org/donate/pad?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID
‚ÄúPoem-a-Day is brilliant because it makes space in the everyday racket for something as meaningful as a poem.‚Äù ‚ÄîTracy K. Smith

If this series is meaningful to you, join the community of Poem-a-Day supporters by making a gift today (https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=1a0759482b&mc_eid=UNIQID)  in honor of National Poetry Month. Now serving more than 320,000 daily subscribers, this publication is only possible thanks to the contributions of readers like you.

1065274438.subject: [hcs-d] [HCS AI x HAIST] The Future of AI and the Question of AI Safety
1065274438.text:
[image: Harvard AI Safety Team]

HCS AI Group is excited to announce our next (collaborative!) event, this
Friday, 3:30 PM in Emerson 101, on where AI is headed and how dangerous AI
will be in the near future. The pace of AI development is accelerating at
an unprecedented pace, and as models become more sophisticated, worries
will only increase.

Our upcoming event will delve into this topic in depth and provide insights
into the future of AI and its potential dangers. Max Nadeau, Deputy
Director of Harvard‚Äôs AI Safety Team and a friend of ours, will be joining
us with his talk, ‚ÄúProblems in AI Safety and Solutions that Scale,‚Äù and we
will have a Q&A + discussion following an introduction to this topic.

This event will answer questions such as: how will AI interact with humans
in the future? How likely will dangerous AI arise? All members are invited,
regardless of background. Concentrators from different backgrounds,
including math, philosophy, economics, CS, and beyond will find this
interesting.

Sincerely,

HCS AI Group

_______________________________________________
hcs-discuss mailing list
hcs-discuss@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/hcs-discuss

1091868059.subject: Soaking in the Sun with HFAI!
1091868059.text:
HFAI news, upcoming events, study break options and money-saving tips from the Office of Admissions & Financial Aid. 

Hello Eelaaf,

As the sun comes out and the biting wind blows away, 



We hope you are enjoying the warm weather! 



With the end of the semester coming up... 



We wish you the best of luck on finals,



And plenty of rest and sunshine! 



Yours truly, 
Your HFAI Student Coordinators
hfai@fas.harvard.edu



 
INTERNSHIP/JOB/LEADERSHIP OPPORTUNITIES

Ivy+ Just-In-Time Virtual Job & Internship Fair <https://app.joinhandshake.com/career_fairs/37964/employer_preview?token=12tFo-piW9BosnAfwJ3emkzMu9lJTY2CFcihfKh-QtcYQ8e89_iY4Q&utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Tuesday, April 18, at 1:00-4:00pm. Virtual. The Ivy+ Consortium is a conference that helps students connect with representatives that are hiring outstanding, motivated applicants. The fair invites both graduate and undergraduate students to connect with recruiters from a range of disciplines such as consulting firms, nonprofit organizations, public agencies, and more. Job opportunities include full-time positions, internships, and other fellowships. 

Introduction to the Fulbright Scholarship <https://uraf.harvard.edu/event/introduction-fullbright-scholarship?delta=0&utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Tuesday, April 18, at 7:30-8:30pm. Virtual. An in-depth introduction to the Fulbright grants for research and English teaching assistantships abroad. Hosted by the Office of Undergraduate Research and Fellowships (URAF). (This session is intended for juniors.) Registration required <https://harvard.zoom.us/meeting/register/tJwpduqhrjIrHdbBGfT2Q85YxoP5FTybeJjG?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>. 

Harvard Foundation Undergraduate Internship <https://harvardfoundation.fas.harvard.edu/?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021&utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter>

Applications due Wednesday, April 19, at 11:59pm. The Harvard Foundation for Intercultural and Race Relations is seeking dedicated Harvard College first-year and second-year undergraduate students to work as interns during the 2023-2024 academic year. The Foundation invites students who are passionate about building culturally affirming programming and engaging in equity, diversity, and belonging efforts at the college. They would also love to have interns lead initiatives and programming efforts for first-generation, low-income students at the college. Apply now at tinyurl.com/hfinternapp23 and email marvinbaclig@fas.harvard.edu for any questions. 

Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health Infomation Session <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfZNUdPqO6y7kG0Hve_jyf-jAYO7VMC7WGSbKosaQZJunHg_w/viewform?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Friday, April 21, at 10:00am-3:00pm. Are you considering a field in public health in the future or curious to know what a career in public health entails? The Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health (HSPH) is inviting you to tour their campus, learn more about future opportunities, and have the chance to speak with the admissions department and current HSPH students about their experiences! 

Introduction to the Rhodes, Marshall, and Mitchell Scholarships <https://uraf.harvard.edu/event/introduction-rhodes-marshall-and-mitchell-scholarships?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Wednesday, April 26, at 5:00-6:00pm. Virtual. An in-depth introduction to the Rhodes, Marshall, and Mitchell Scholarships for study in the UK and Ireland by the Office of Undergraduate Research and Fellowships (URAF). (This session is intended for juniors). Registration required <https://harvard.zoom.us/meeting/register/tJUkcuGhqDkiE9C4CXCoh2l88C52XqzxoprB?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>. 

Harvard Summer School Academic Tutor <https://opportunities.summer.harvard.edu/atp-tutor?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Rolling deadline. Harvard Summer School (HSS) is currently seeking Academic Tutors to provide virtual tutoring for Harvard Summer School students. Academic Tutors work with HSS students across a wide range of subjects. They assist students in the learning process by reviewing subject matter, clarifying concepts, helping to prepare for exams, and sharing their expertise in their field of study. HSS seeks tutors with a strong academic record and the patience and desire to help others learn difficult material in a fast-paced environment. Please submit an application at this link <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSf_aHMbNEMo_QJ5leCfKJi_zs3_-Ojn1n1UMvXWmVP9iMdGjA/viewform?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021> and reach out to Emily Walsh (walsh@fas.harvard.edu) with any questions. 
 

CAMPUS RESOURCES

Community in Practice <https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/community_in_practice?utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021&utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email>

Thursday, May 4, at 12:00pm. The Harvard College Women's Center. Join the Harvard Women's Center for a series on developing communities of restorative practices. This is a 3-part series that will be bring together people who are using restorative practices in their roles and personal lives at Harvard. There is no experience necessary. If you are interested in learning more, please come. This is a space for learning about restorative practices, building community amongst colleagues, and practicing circles and restorative strategies. Fill out the interest form here <https://forms.office.com/pages/responsepage.aspx?id=9CL6b2hFBUGtQy461HJpV3EpAhRQz5ZLsT8nWBQs92lUNVlZRDdYNERWMUhQU0FUNEpDUEpERDYyTC4u&utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>.  

Finish The Semester Strong with the ARC! <https://academicresourcecenter.harvard.edu/?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Various dates and times. Academic Resource Center, 1414 Mass. Ave., Floor 3R and Virtual. The Academic Resource Center can help you make the most out of Reading Period! Sign up for one of the ARC's workshops, meet with an academic coach, or learn about peer tutoring by logging into arcscheduler.fas.harvard.edu. Upcoming workshops include Schedule Your Reading Period on April 18 at 4:00pm or April 26 at 12:00pm, and Creating a STEM Final Exam Schedule on April 21 at 12:00 pm or April 25 at 4:00pm. 

Mindfulness Self-Care for Students of Color <https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/student_of_color_support_group?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Every Tuesday at 5:00-6:30pm. Virtual. The group will focus on holding space to build and share meditative practices and self-care techniques that foster healing for students of color. Participants will practice cognitive mindfulness-based stress reduction skills to reduce anxiety, depression, fear, worry, and panic. The group meets every Tuesday 5-6:30pm ET. Undergraduate and Graduate students of color are welcome. Open to all registered Harvard students (undergraduates and graduates) who have paid the 2022-2023 Student Health Fee. If you are interested, please email the group leader directly and include your Student ID number, which allows CAMHS to securely message the workshop/group zoom link. Contact Carmen Cruz, LICSW (ccruz@huhs.harvard.edu) for questions and referrals. 

Zumba¬Æ with Phebe <https://membership.gocrimson.com/Program/GetProgramDetails?courseId=bfb11405-0774-4311-ab94-1830bd5af817&semesterId=9bb3d48b-675f-4839-9a2a-df42a5436a5d&utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Weekly Saturday sessions, at 10:00-10:55am. Malkin Athletic Center. Intestested in a free dancing session? Zumba combines high energy and music that motivates you to dance away your worries. This class is dedicated to promoting staying active and happy through the power of dancing through a training class. No equipment or prior training needed! Registration opens three days before each class. 

Wellness Initiative for Safer Partying (WISP) Grant <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe_sFD2tIk6akkNZpVo8FflLhkyYbkgdXHbcbvaZo2gETl2yg/viewform?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Applications due Sundays, at 4:00pm, before your party. Wellness Initiative for Safer Partying (WISP) Grants are provided by the Wellness Educators and Center for Wellness and Health Promotion to help cultivate a fun and safer social environment at Harvard College. Submit your proposal at this link <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe_sFD2tIk6akkNZpVo8FflLhkyYbkgdXHbcbvaZo2gETl2yg/viewform?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>! 



FREE AND FUN EVENTS

Black Anime Night <https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/faculty-student_dinner_3727?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Wednesday, April 19, at 7:30pm. Dunster Junior Common Room. Ready for positive depictions of Black people in anime? Do you love and appreciate anime and manga as medium? Join us for Black Anime Night- where we'll be watching iconic anime with our favorite Black characters! Also enjoy free food from Flames, a local Jamaican favorite. RSVP now to secure your plate (and your seat) at this link <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeom_yx0K1p-QfWbkWGlHwpdSrvlBdFH_Ue0QjwkIyLbAcQDg/viewform?utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021&utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email>. 

Harvard Girl Up Open Mic Night <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScybesPCZPDzfOIgr14FpkcXp8IZCrOSTgjHB2Lrgb0fw-Njw/viewform?utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021&utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email>

Friday, April 21, at 6:00pm. Arthur & Elizabeth Schlesinger Library, 3 James Street. Harvard can be tough; Open Mic Night is an event open to all femme-identifying members of the Harvard Community who would like to share any experiences, feelings, or emotions. Come for food, good vibes, good music, and a supportive safe space. Please fill out this form <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScybesPCZPDzfOIgr14FpkcXp8IZCrOSTgjHB2Lrgb0fw-Njw/viewform?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021> to RSVP so we can account for food/drink, allergies, and any needs of accommodation. Dinner will be provided! 

Cabot Caf√© Art Sale <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScsBGswhEtEBEUc-Z7JhM-gQqm8-ThDXO_B0Duvc4ixb7tsKw/viewform?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Sunday, April 23, at 8:00-11:00pm. Cabot Caf√©, Cabot House. Cabot Caf√© is hosting an art sale on Sunday April 23rd! Come on by the caf√© to browse and purchase your fellow Quadlings' art! Each artist will keep 100% of their profits, and control their pricing + method of payment. 

2023 Harvard Arts Medal Ceremony: Adrian Margaret Smith Piper AM '77, PhD '81 <https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/2023_harvard_arts_medal_ceremony_adrian_margaret_smith_piper_AM_77_PHD_81?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Wednesday, April 26, at 7:00pm. The Harvard Film Archive, 24 Quincy St., Cambridge MA. Celebrate the work of award-winning conceptual artist and philosopher Adrian Margaret Smith Piper AM '77, PhD '81, recipient of the 2023 Harvard Arts Medal. Piper will be honored in absentia by Harvard University in a public gathering and screening of her film Passing Beyond Passing (2004). The ceremony is presented by the Office for the Arts at Harvard, Harvard Film Archive and the Department of Art, Film, and Visual Studies. Free and open to the public. 

Marine Debris Fashion Show <https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/marine_debris_fashion_show?utm_campaign=widget&utm_medium=widget&utm_source=Harvard+College+Calendar&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021&utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter>

Thursday, April 27, at 8:00-10:00pm. Science Center. The LPCE and REEF Marine Debris Fashion Challenge is a fashion challenge that invited artistic students to promote ocean conservation and sustainability. Creatives from Harvard will host a fashion show with fashion made from marine debris at the ARTS FIRST Festival.  

ARTS FIRST Festival <https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/arts_first_festival_1483?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Thursday, April 27 through Sunday, April 30. Science Center Plaza. Enjoy an "artstravaganza" during ARTS FIRST, Harvard's annual festival of creativity! Produced by the Office for the Arts, the festival opens university spaces to everyone for an experience of community togetherness and exciting discovery featuring performances and artwork by students, staff, faculty, alums and affiliates. Many events are also livestreamed. Join on April 27-30 for exhibitions and dynamic live presentations of music, dance, theater, film, fashion, visual arts and more. 

Ceramics Program Spring Show and Sale <https://ofa.fas.harvard.edu/ceramics/show-and-sale?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021&utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter>

Thursday-Sunday, May 11-14, at 10:00am-7:00pm. Ceramics Studio, 224 Western Avenue, Allston, MA. Twice a year in May and December, the Ceramics Program, Office for the Arts at Harvard opens its doors for an exhibition and sale featuring thousands of pieces of original ceramic artwork by staff, instructors, and participants in Ceramics Program classes. From functional dinnerware to sculptural masterpieces, this popular exhibition has something for everyone! 

Harvard Public Art Tours: Allston <https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/harvard_public_art_tours_allston?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Various days. Western Avenue, Allston. On this self-guided walking tour, you can discover "can't-miss" public art installations along Western Avenue and learn the stories behind them and their artists. Follow along on the Visit Harvard application to explore hand-painted murals, sky-high sculptures, 25-cent art prints, and more! 



BEYOND HARVARD

Nature Walk Through Mt. Auburn Cemetery <https://www.thebostoncalendar.com/events/nature-walk-through-mt-auburn-cemetery?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Thursday, April 20, at 10:00am-2:00pm. Mt. Auburn Cemetery, 580 Mt Auburn Street, Cambridge MA. Join WomenExplore for its spring lecture series, "Celebrating 50 Years and Still Exploring." The seventh lecture in the series will feature a nature walk through Mt. Auburn Cemetery led by MaryMargaret Halsey, a longtime WomenExplore member and nature expert. Mount Auburn Cemetery is the first rural, or garden, cemetery in the United States, located on the line between Cambridge and Watertown in Middlesex County, Massachusetts, 4 miles west of Boston. It is the burial site of many prominent Boston Brahmins, as well as being a National Historic Landmark. Check the WomenExplore website for updates on the scheduling and plans for lunch. 

PoeTREE: An afternoon of tree-themed poetry readings <https://arboretum.harvard.edu/events/event-signup/?id=69222&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021&utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email>

Sunday, April 23, at 1:00-2:00pm. Weld Hill Research Building, 1300 Centre Street, Boston. The Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University invites poets Jennifer Barber, Deborah Leipziger, and Charles Coe for a themed poetry reading session all about trees! There will be interactive dialogue with the audience where they will have the opportunity to create their own tree themed poetry. 

Live Jazz at 3rd Space <https://www.thebostoncalendar.com/events/live-jazz-at-3rd-space--4?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Every Thursday, at 12:15-2:00pm. 3rd Space, 12 Summer Street, Boston MA. As part of the Lunch Club <https://www.downtownboston.org/about-downtown-boston-bid/latest-news/3rdspace/?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021> at 3rd Space, they are pleased to present a soothing jazz duo every Thursday! Come by with lunch to enjoy the soothing jazz from a rotating group of musicians. Public restrooms, complimentary water, dessert, and Wi-Fi are all available. 

Arnold Arboretum <https://arboretum.harvard.edu/?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>

Open everyday from sunrise to sunset. Arnold Arboretum, 125 Arborway, Boston, MA 02130. Grab a friend and take a stroll through the Arnold Arboretum any day at any time between sunrise and sunset and enjoy over 16,000 plant varieties. A 281-acre preserve in the heart of Boston, the Arnold Arboretum stewards one of the world's most comprehensive and best documented collections of temperate woody plants, with particular focus on the floras of eastern North America and eastern Asia. 



April Spotlight: Mrs. Lidia Berger - Supervisor of Access Services, Cabot Library at Harvard College

We are excited to spotlight the Supervisor of Access Services at Cabot Library, Mrs. Lidia Berger. Originally from Poland, Lidia has been a long-serving Supervisor in Cabot Library. She is outstanding and known by many of the student workers that she supervises as "Grandma". Her charm and her service have radiated the walls of Cabot Library, and she is well-loved by her colleagues and students alike. Her presence continues to grace the popular study spot for Harvard College students.  


How long have you worked at Cabot Library?
I have worked at Cabot Library for the last 40 years, and these have been the most fulfilling years of my life. 

With such a long service at Cabot Library, what are some of your fondest memories?
My fondest memories have been, and will always be, the students. Seeing students come here as first-years and seeing them grow up and become great people in society during and after their time at Harvard always makes me smile. My fondest memories are with my colleagues who are student-workers. I have worked with, and supervised, countless students, and joked with them, disagreed with them, agreed with them, and thanked them for the last four decades, and seeing them succeed is always my greatest satisfaction. Also, serving students at the circulation desk for such a long time has allowed me to interact with the best of people. 

You've talked extensively about student workers; What impact do you think their jobs have?
Thanks for asking this question. I have worked with countless students who are on financial aid, and I must say that the financial aid today to Harvard College students is phenomenal. Many of my supervisees have many a time confided to me how the pay that they get from jobs such as in Cabot Circulation services goes a long way to help them live more comfortably, and offset many unwritten expenses, while also gaining invaluable experience in student jobs, of which at least for Cabot, I categorize as public service. 

What do you think has contributed to your exemplary service for such a long time to Harvard?
I don't like talking about myself, but I think that just being a decent and normal human being with humanity has been instrumental in my service. I treat my supervisees as my equals, even if they fondly call me "grandma" out of respect, and I value every person that I interact with, including everyone that I serve on the circulation desk. I also see a bright future with every Harvard affiliate that I interact with, and being a part of their success makes me happy to serve them in any way and as long as I humanly can. 

What is your hope for the future of the libraries at Harvard?
I hope that students can see the value in the millions of books that we have at Harvard. While technology has made things easier over the 40 years that I have worked in this library, I believe in the value of taking a physical book from the library, even if not required for class, and reading it out there in the sun, or in your break, or in public transportation to just enrich your knowledge and appreciation for study. I hope students continue to realize the treasure that they have in Harvard's countless books, and I hope that Harvard libraries continue serving students and scholars in the exemplary way that they have been doing. 
 

HFAI Newsletter Submissions

Have something you want to see in the HFAI newsletter? The newsletter comes out around the 15th of each month during the academic year. If you know of or are planning an event that is of interest to HFAI students, submit information about your event here <https://forms.office.com/r/N79PfcuhC5?utm_source=HFAI_Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HFAI_Newsletter_Apr_2021>!

1094856746.subject: üì± The great chip glut
1094856746.text:
‚Ä¶and China‚Äôs digi-yuan rollout gains steam with digital paychecks
 

Too many chips, not enough dip (Jakub Porzycki/Getty Images)

Hey Snackers,

Miller High Life proudly calls itself ‚Äúthe Champagne of Beers‚Äù on its cans, but the French aren‚Äôt having it: 2.3K cans of the lager were dumped and crushed in Europe after the Champagne regulator requested ‚Äúthe destruction of these illicit goods.‚Äù Someone call Emily in Paris.

Stocks barely budged yesterday as investors awaited Big Tech earnings, starting with Google parent Alphabet and Microsoft today. Meanwhile, Coke beat sales growth expectations as consumers kept chugging its famous beverages despite several price hikes.

Chip-dip

Samsung could post its worst profit in decades as the great chip shortage turns into a glut

Overflowing chip bowl‚Ä¶ not talking Doritos. Stale chip demand could take a big bite out of Samsung's earnings this week. The South Korean tech titan is the world‚Äôs largest producer of memory chips, which are used in everything from smartphones to computers to servers. Memory-chip prices dropped 20% last quarter as companies like Samsung slashed prices to cope with an industry-wide glut. Now the flip-phone icon expects its worst quarterly profit since 2009.

  • Short circuit: Earlier this month, Samsung said it would begin a ‚Äúmeaningful‚Äù chip-production cut, following similar moves by rivals like Micron and Western Digital.

  • Unchipper: Semiconductor giants have been losing money on every chip they churn out. Samsung's chip unit is forecast to post a record $1.6B loss on Thursday.

Boom and bust‚Ä¶ Tech gadgets were hot commodities midpandemic as homebound consumers splurged on new PCs, TVs, and phones. But demand for $1K flat screens has cooled, hurting chipmakers (which boosted production to ease ‚Äúthe great chip shortage‚Äù). Now they‚Äôve got too many chips. The industry is notoriously cyclical, but the latest oversupply is historic.

  • Geek Squad problems: Last quarter, Best Buy's profit fell 42%, and it hinted at slower sales ahead. Microsoft expects a PC sales slump ‚Äúfor the foreseeable future,‚Äù and Apple's Mac deliveries plunged 40% last quarter (worse than its laptop rivals).
THE TAKEAWAY

Not all chips are created equal‚Ä¶ It depends on what‚Äôs in demand. While appetite for personal devices like PCs and phones has cooled, demand for AI-powering tech is heating up. Chipmakers like Intel and Nvidia are going all in on AI, and the AI hardware market could hit $90B by 2030 (up 8X from 2021). Nvidia shares have surged on hunger for its AI chips, which are selling for up to 20X more than its gaming processors.

Digi

China plans its biggest digital-currency rollout, accelerating the global race to turn cash into code

Clearin‚Äô the cache‚Ä¶ more like cash. China‚Äôs prepping its digital piggy bank to pay public workers in the city of Changshu (population 1.7M) fully in digital yuan (#digi-yuan) starting next month. The project will affect all public workers, from teachers to government officials ‚Äî and marks the country‚Äôs biggest push to circulate its digital currency.

  • Number yuan: Back in 2021, China became the first major economy to launch an e-currency. Over 100 countries, including the US, have been playing catch-up since.

  • Mixed reaction: Changshu‚Äôs digi-yuan project is trending on Chinese social media. While some say it could help curb government corruption, others worry that older people will struggle to take their finances online.

Sorry, anon‚Ä¶ All digi-yuan transactions are recorded on a digital ledger that‚Äôs monitored by the Chinese government, giving the surveillance state even tighter control (picture: digi-yuan expiration dates to boost spending). Chinese citizens lead the way in global mobile-payment adoption, but getting them to use digital yuan could depend on integration with payment superapps:

  • Tap to pay: Alipay and WeChat Pay each have 1B+ users and process hundreds of billions of dollars‚Äô worth of annual transactions. China has struggled to get its citizens to use its digi-yuan app, because most of them use superapps for payments and social interactions.

  • Competing with corporate: The digi-yuan was tested as an express payment option on Alipay last year, and China could exert greater pressure on tech companies to fully integrate it.

THE TAKEAWAY

The e-conomic race is on‚Ä¶ China, India, Nigeria, and a handful of other countries have launched digital currencies. Now China is positioning the digi-yuan for international use, which could offer an attractive alternative to the US dollar for sanctioned countries like Russia. Meanwhile, the US Treasury is reportedly close to finishing its development of a digital dollar, which could give millions of unbanked Americans access to digital payments.

What else we're Snackin'

  • Beyend: Bed Bath & Beyond has thrown in the towel, filing for bankruptcy and announcing plans to liquidate its inventory and close up shop (unless it can find a buyer). FYI: tomorrow‚Äôs the last day to use its iconic coupons.

  • Out: Fox News said its top anchor, Tucker Carlson, will leave the network after it reached a $787.5M settlement in its defamation suit with Dominion Voting Systems. In 2020, Carlson had the highest-rated program in cable-news history.

  • Mo√´t: LVMH is popping the bubbly after becoming the first European company to cross $500B in market cap. The luxe glomerate crushed quarterly sales expectations as big spenders snatched up Louis bags and Bulgari bling.

  • Funged: The first NFT-related insider-trading case is going to trial after a former OpenSea employee was accused of using confidential token-listing info for personal gain. Scrutiny of digital tokens has been intensifying.

  • Kale: Sweetgreen hopes to fuel salad-bowl demand with a $10/month loyalty program for delivery and discount perks. Shares of the lettuce legend are down 75% over the past year as WFH hits office lunch breaks.

üç™ Thanks for Snacking with us! Want to share the Snacks? Invite your friends to sign up here.

1116229879.subject: [ADAMS] FREE BSO CONCERT THIS SATURDAY
1116229879.text:
The Harvard Undergraduate Symphony Society is back again for the *final
free **concert* opportunity this semester!


On Saturday, April 22nd, we will be hearing violinist Anne Sophie Mutter
perform Mozart Violin Concerto No. 1 as well as the premiere of Thomas
Ad√®s' *Air*. The concert will also feature Sibelius' Symphony No. 5 and
South African soprano Golda Schultz performing Jean Sibelius‚Äô Luonnotar. To
sign up, click here <https://sibeliusisintheair.splashthat.com/> and then
click the RSVP button. If you have questions, please send an email
<officers@symphonysociety.org> and we will do our best to assist as quickly
as possible.

As always, there will be a pre-concert reception with food and drinks
followed by a conversation with a member of the BSO. We ask that you arrive
at the Office for the Arts (74 Mt. Auburn Street
<https://www.google.com/maps/search/74+Mt.+Auburn+Street?entry=gmail&source=g>)
by 6:00pm on Saturday so that we can depart by 6:15pm sharp.

--
Ariana Chiu
Harvard College Class of 2023
AB Candidate in Economics
arianachiu@college.harvard.edu
412.983.0560

_______________________________________________
Check the Adams FAQ for answers to many common questions: http://adamshouse.harvard.edu/frequently-asked-questions
***List emails may not be reproduced, retransmitted, or otherwise republished without the express written consent of the author.

adams-schmooze mailing list
adams-schmooze@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/adams-schmooze

1118674669.subject: Vercel April Product Update
1118674669.text:
Vercel¬†April Product Update
Next.js 13.3 | Web Analytics | Edge Config | Linear integration
Vercel Ship
Join us online on May 1-5 for Vercel Ship: a special launch event‚Äîincluding the keynote with Vercel CEO Guillermo Rauch on May 4 at 9am PT.

 Register now ‚Üí <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxCTkTMff4GZzDFK8GMFowe0db8O4q2pZHarv3piryl21s6Uhzq2bnOMRRHgEGLhxEKQ=>
Next.js 13.3
In preparation for App Router stability, we‚Äôve added some of the community‚Äôs top requested features in 13.3: File-Based Metadata API, Dynamic Open Graph Images, Static Export for App Router, and Parallel Routes and Interception.

 Read the full announcement ‚Üí <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxGv0aUP27SSyM84Cv6zbTTQh9Zr0HKKRjU7KlQO42RtV7LIoVYQICSOvdIO4HTdk5w0=>
Web Analytics
Vercel Web Analytics is now available to all users for insights on your top pages, top referrers, user demographics, and more. As a part of this release, Pro and Enterprise teams can also set up custom event tracking <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxCTVIv8tY2qSLQ8tRohWcDXteKH85jHub0lPejGYn5uLXmyX7umCh02JopRwTvjbQQk=> to dive deeper into user interactions, such as button clicks or newsletter signups.

 Check out the documentation ‚Üí <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxIiTxTj8_kZ2IBCuf722-ilUgFM_A23OIGq5erU0wgwxNsgfHMVLci24p3eRoSXvjpI=>
Edge Config
Now generally available, Vercel Edge Config is an ultra-low latency data store for near-instant reads of configuration data‚Äîmaking it perfect for managing experimentation and configuration data in modern web applications. Push changes without redeploying, iterate faster, and ensure great site performance for users in all regions. 

 See the blog here ‚Üí <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxBYk3W7n92E9gg31Idda_ptxjVigclFSbpx8sFEVXDHzDoc82buvcMZiihey7P1Wx9w=>
Preview Comments Linear integration
Comments on Vercel Preview Deployments can now be directly converted to Linear issues. Further streamline your team‚Äôs workflow by taking immediate action on feedback‚Äîavailable to Pro, Enterprise, and Hobby users with public repos. 

 Check out the documentation <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxCcQJPfpYgf5-HzpHDns-Ek0T9d69Tkqf9ATFZi14dYmfAMmyWbWZEchot3WBE9jfBw=>¬†or watch the demo ‚Üí <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxC7RJzoYPxUZxam3q7hDCQNW1ViZ_rE1stEQe8svje57ZSudRCObT7fY1eHLYTSTGc4=>
More featured content
- The Vercel AI Playground: Compare and tune AI language models side-by-side <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxH7tpyQs6eDZK6gdv-76Uqjprn8zFPk1VC2hLM6Df8g2gwj0F6S0zwx5-UqE41RExbE=>
	- Build vs. Buy: what bootstrapping costs your business <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxO75pifNpszU9z_XKUNCg6WTh4DWN8ZxfIauiGFzJbyFVe06MraSN4_ZORCG694WZAg=>
	- Rich Harris shares Web insights at the recent Svelte Meetup <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxO9njuG3H5wN6euoJFtGOOZP7xAu3lVPIdTfM6lPgxFh37G2CYLJgf-fxYi92IRK7kM=>
	- Building towards operational excellence at CORE Construction <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxNIO8P9y0HLsmGUhu3Z10FhLtrhHnD3Tjf4cCxiLa0KOeeM1i-kweSg0hgJ9ahtaMsI=>
	- Vercel joins AWS Marketplace <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxAOIlIuPPd02TZ_ZX40z1s3EdefN33EJ1gp-4Wt-KI2UVMXjPUAo5ZDexodT-fKUOBs=>



See what else is new on the Vercel blog ‚Üí <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxAaHpwnl-uZiAiTNsRlbvfjHUHyIKXl9WrffPzeWBv7zfn0pbkAxcSWhwvCKbOJ0eO8=>
Community showcase
Search thousands of generative AI art pieces in Lexica's <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxFSFjPtIVJvZcCiZwa7v5n_MBZlgW-1tDN1diffrHTBymZcS8COu3ywQhlMM5jBBTk4=> gallery‚Äîand generate your own.
Jenni <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxPISsfnJbeX-kWZzIVIU6pvx8tcfNW9mc8qAVBjsHsqmdI4aOh_ojk-YtrroILJ_uJU=> puts the ‚ÄúI‚Äù in ‚ÄúAI‚Äù (even Harvard and MIT use it).
Build a custom chat app with Ora <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxB7pbUtUjr_5uSr7DUwL0Lto7XGUJuCipMWUaObuEHIjH5Q_v4YSNtwEJz8JPFzZUIg=> and go from prompt to prototype in seconds.
Vercel Changelog
- Improved infrastructure security with Vercel Secure Compute <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxIis-YflhXE5g7z1FtWW4-0Fu67X2zdFLyr68mBKSQAlrv1T_35fJqyOA7QJDAK7IV0=>
	- Usage notification settings are now generally available <https://info.vercel.com/MDAxLUxSRy0xOTQAAAGLXVCAxLrCcsXJp_316WVJVezC7NL1A3j-fLNYVLpQYfcjfZ2y9twQZ0D_yA4kgbXza0n6Tn4=>

1147485911.subject: SWE Boston April 2023 Digest
1147485911.text: SWE Boston Digest A compilation of SWE and non-SWE Boston events which may be interesting to our members, sent about once a month. Send any future digest requests to correspond@sweboston.org   ‚Ää Professional Development Save the date for our May PD event! Making the Most of a Mentor/Mentee Program with Medtronic Points covered: What a mentor is?  What a mentor is not Choosing a mentor who is right for you Preparing for the conversations Thinking outside of the box when connecting with your mentor Mentoring women in workplace Location: 35 Cherry Hill Dr, Danvers, MA 0192 Date: May 16, 2023 Time: 5:30/6 - 8 pm Be on the lookout for our registration link, which we will publish in our May newsletter! Membership Join us for a duo of events in May and June: first - get crafty with a hat making event, we'll provide all the supplies! Sport your finished product at our June Afternoon Tea at the Vintage Tea and Cake Company! Eventbrite links below - space is limited! Join us in May for a morning of crafting - we'll provide supplies, you decorate and make hat that you can sport at our June afternoon Tea.  Event is for SWE Boston Members Only!  ÔªøLocation is accessible by MBTA and street parking is available!  Eventbrite Link Join us for a fun afternoon tea at the Vintage Tea and Cake Company in Belmont MA. For those of you that attended our May Hat Making Event - sport your handiwork as we get together for tea, pastries and fun times!  Event is for SWE Boston Members Only!  Location is accessible by MBTA and street parking is available!  Eventbrite Link Local Events of Interest Harvard University Present's: The Sky‚Äôs Not the Limit: My Journey into Space Exploration and STEM Monday, April 24 - 4pm EDT Click here for details and to register: Register In person and Online Event MiMi Aung will share her personal journey as a space engineer‚Äîfrom her start as an electrical engineer in the NASA Deep Space Network to her role leading the team that built and deployed the Mars Helicopter, Ingenuity: the first-ever controlled flight on another planet. She will describe her constant pursuit of ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs next?‚Äù throughout her STEM career, including her current efforts in private industry to develop and launch a constellation of satellites in low Earth orbit to increase broadband access around the world, a mission in which she believes deeply.           SWE Boston | PO Box 244, Woburn, MA 01801 Unsubscribe eelaafzahid@college.harvard.edu Update Profile | Constant Contact DataNotice Sent by swebos@sweboston.org powered by Try email marketing for free today!

In a shift for Quantum Corp., the vendor is now competing in the file and object

mission-critical application [https://go.techtarget.com/r/265308133/45705094]

[https://go.techtarget.com/r/265308133/45705094]]

A mission-critical application is a software program or suite of related
programs that must function continuously for a business or business segment to
be successful.
content services platform [https://go.techtarget.com/r/265308134/45705094]
A content services platform is cloud-based SaaS software that enables users to
create, share, collaborate on and store text, audio and video content.
Cloud Security Alliance (CSA) [https://go.techtarget.com/r/265308135/45705094]
The Cloud Security Alliance (CSA) is a nonprofit organization that promotes
research into best practices for securing cloud computing and the use of cloud
technologies to secure other forms of computing.

1155895026.subject: [Fyre] WIN $50 FOR THIS QUICK SURVEY!!!
1155895026.text:
Hi everyone,

We are students in the class GOV 1318: The Great Food Transformation. We
are trying to collect information about internships and summer
opportunities for our lovely partner the Factory Farming Awareness
Coalition. Your answers to this survey
<https://forms.gle/W9gq4bDmxnRibWkt5> could
help this program reach more people and *make a real difference*!

*Plus, you will be entered into a raffle for a *$50 giftcard!

Here is the link again: https://forms.gle/W9gq4bDmxnRibWkt5

Thank you so much for your time!
Michelle, Elio, Neil, Simone, Althea

1161605929.subject: Final Submission Format for PA3 Part 2: COMPSCI 143: Computer Networks
1161605929.text:
Each team must submit a final slide deck by May 5th, 2023.

If you have modified the given code or have written new code (including graphing code), please upload the files.

The final slide deck is an improved version of the one shown on 4/24 or 4/26, addressing comments received during the presentation and covering additional results if applicable.

The slide deck must include two new slides:

- Hypothesis slide, containing a clear statement on your hypothesis and your analytical
reasons for it.

- Result summary slide, containing a few key plots of experiments with explanations
demonstrating that your hypothesis holds.

Overall, the submission should contain ten slides or fewer, including the following information:

- Title slide with a specific title related to your hypothesis,
team members' names, photos, and email addresses, and the date

- Problem statement slide. (A short description is sufficient if the project is option 1 of PA3 Part 2)

- Hypothesis slide

- Result summary slide

- Plots generated and analysis explaining the plots

- Group contribution statement

1171650070.subject: The Slowdown for April 26, 2023
1171650070.text:
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=cd0d227e56717d09680c2c31f37c78bfde6c308d7c9e01b1e3604659e5ef3f9903b925ccdfb17010c9e5fa51ae76b210fa8a17a6950fb624 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=cd0d227e56717d0927b282d8c33c0c4f34a38ba54b7570922d7f6618d84e3c696ca46f395fac81450c05d4fae4020ebd7c07a3543cfc38aa 
Give Now 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=cd0d227e56717d09cb21491f7dcb466f080d4354aabdb7ebd70dacb60c1d5dbffa0d09004089247f495a4eea93dd9b14091aac51d1dc6e5a 
“I read the daily poems from The Slowdown with my morning coffee. These poems are a gift.” - Richarda E. 





If you are a writer, old houses are more than quaint. They send the imagination down the corridors of time. What did the children dream of? Which songs were sung? What stories did the elders share? What sadness fell upon their souls and how did they tend to their wounds?       

   
— Major

To the Buyer of Our Old Home
 by Helen Pruitt Wallace



We can tell you, if you want, which doors creak,


      or windows that need to be re-glazed, which faucet


has a tendency to leak, and where a wine glass


      left a halo etched in the counter’s travertine.


And we could share which walls absorb sadness,


      till morning light leans in comforting the contours


of the bed, but chances are you’ll learn this


      on your own. There’s the cough of the AC kicking on,


and the hiss of the heater turning off, and a crack


      in the plaster by the stairs. You’ll study it at times


as metaphor, disaster creeping like the bifurcated lines


      of your palm. But then again, maybe you won’t....


Let’s go outside.

 


The doorbell never works when it rains. And the riot


      of white gardenias blooming now is always late.


A black snake burrows through ferns, and a cardinal


      spends days hurling himself against our bare window.


We say our, but it’s your house now. Our beloved dog


      was buried over there—along with his chew toys


and bones. And at night our kids’ laughter carries


      through the courtyard of the home (though they


moved out some years ago). And this large oak—


      what can we say? Old limbs keep falling even when no


wind stirs. The tree is gone. We sold because we couldn’t


      chop it down. Still, we hear the woodpecker crazed


as the leaves turn brown.

"To the Buyer of Our Old Home" by Helen Pruitt Wallace. Used by permission of the poet.

1178317901.subject: [hcs-d] HSRG: reading group on dataframe libraries
1178317901.text:
Hello from the Harvard Systems Reading Group <https://notes.ekzhang.com/events/hsrg>!

Ôøº

We're having weekly reading group at 1 PM in the Science Center (Room 109) on Saturday, April 15th. All are invited to join us, regardless of past background ‚Äî we believe that having diverse thoughts is important to learning together as a collective.

This week's topic is is dataframe libraries ‚Äî exploring how we talk to computers about data analysis & transformations, through languages and storage formats and performance optimization. Case studies on Polars and DuckDB.

To get updates please join our GroupMe at the website linked here: https://notes.ekzhang.com/events/hsrg :D

Best,
Eric

hcs-discuss@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/hcs-discuss

1181226137.subject: [hcs-d] [HUMIC] Talk to ML Researchers from Google Brain
1181226137.text:
Want to have a conversation on the latest Machine Learning research with
speakers from *Google Brain* and *Edge Computing Lab*?

Come to Lowell Screening Room (or join us via Zoom
<https://harvard.zoom.us/j/93253752985?pwd=NmhXUUhWK1l1cmhhM3NnT1pBc0NLQT09>)
on *April 24 at 11am!*

HUMIC (Harvard University Machine Intelligence Community) will be hosting a
speaker event with ML researchers Ike Uchendu and Colby Banbury. The event
is *open to ALL* current and incoming Harvard students. We will also be
revealing an *exciting new ML project* designed exclusively for use by
Harvard students üëÄ

Learn more at harvardai.org and join our mailing list here
<https://forms.gle/AGnhDTEuNgqfjXS17>!

1203847097.subject: The Slowdown for April 18, 2023
1203847097.text:
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=30d55bcfdfa685de526b3936180087eea2e2ef022217d330864c9ff8bb562839a91f04eebe95d453b170256a35cfe514771baeb055435014 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=30d55bcfdfa685de4fa210b556af8fab9a83f15f9a05ec7fce9f12e3a91a7640018228d912032a41c81e18933a2f799eca66d61ac2c9975f 
Give Now 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=30d55bcfdfa685de4b58e7c6089564c801f70f2dfaa348b9d8405214a6d5a4e0cbb2f5c58bfc9807a4f8523c6c88c61bc6b46cad4d350f77 
“I read the daily poems from The Slowdown with my morning coffee. These poems are a gift.” - Richarda E. 





Names carry family histories, maybe even indicate what region of the country we reside in, or from where our ancestors traveled. This is why it comes as an affront when someone fails to learn how to say our name or worse, makes up a name for us, like my fourth-grade teacher who, instead of learning to pronounce the “ethnic” names of her students, renamed all of us after French painters.        

  
— Major

from BOOK OF THE OTHER
 by Truong Tran



These things, they are just things. You are told all your life to

develop a thick skin, that you should not take these things so 

seriously. These things, these moments, they are just things in

the greater scheme of things, so what if you are consistently

called by your last name?—it is easier to pronounce—it is just

a small thing. These things, they accumulate, they stick, they

cling to your clothing, your skin, they alter your thinking, they

affect your seeing, your way of being. You wake up one day.

You look in the mirror. You have grown a thick skin, and the 

you in the mirror is no longer you. One day, in the third period 

on the first day of class, you decide to change your name to

Tom. You do not care for the name, not in the slightest. It is

easy to spell. It is easy to say. You will have plenty of time to 

regret your choices. It is just a thing, you tell yourself. You

carry these things. They are placed on you. They are thrown at

you. You walk through life. You are carrying these things. You

anticipate a time when someone is compelled to correct your

grammar; again it happens, and you collapse under the weight.

You are buried beneath a lifetime of these things.

“from BOOK OF THE OTHER” by Truong Tran

1231183086.text:
Kuumba's Spring concert this year is our 50th Anniversary! Help us make it
one for the books as we celebrate Freedom. Sign up to be a volunteer and
get free tickets.

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Taina Rico <tainarico@college.harvard.edu>
Date: Tue, Apr 18, 2023 at 10:59‚ÄØPM
Subject: [ABHW] Volunteer for a FREE ticket to Kuumba's Spring Concert
To: <abhw-list@hcs.harvard.edu>, <gaasa-list@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, <
leverett-bunnybanter-list@lists.fas.harvard.edu>, <
bmf-list@lists.fas.harvard.edu>, <soulfood-talk@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, <
eesa@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, <hsbse-list@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>


Hey y'all,

Kuumba's Half-Century Celebration is coming up May 5 - 7. As the oldest
Black organization on Harvard's campus, this celebration is a momentous
occasion, and we want to do it justice. We need help making sure everything
runs smoothly, so if you have the time, please consider volunteering
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1CIa78pe136SmK75TY6I13nzIgK6QEacovyilXGxw3Vc/viewform?edit_requested=true>.
You get a free ticket to our concert in Sanders on Saturday, May 6th!

Let me know if you have any questions.

Warmly,
Taina Rico

1245222789.subject: "Alchemy Horse" by Natalie Diaz
1245222789.text:
American they said + + but Horse I dreamed

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 24, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** Alchemy Horse (http://poets.org/poem/alchemy-horse?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
Natalie Diaz (https://poets.org/poet/natalie-diaz?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID)

American they said + + but Horse I dreamed
, and Horse became

++            ++            ++
+  ++       +++     ++     ++    +++       ++     ++
+            +++                           +++             +


+ + + I was cleaved + from human-earth + + +
Redsap lymph calcium + + + Atlas and femur
, A new Chaos‚Äî
+ come forth + through the world‚Äôs foaming + crust
+ + then licked + into my roan skin

+ + + A flesh being bearing + its first dreamSelf + + +


I came to life + + how stars appear‚Äî
, Of dust + +

collapsed + till struck
+        + +
+ ++              +     ++ to light + + +       +
+      ++   +        +            +   +     ++

Dream-erupted‚Äî
, Gila Monsters + lavablack + +

+++ Land +++ +++ +++
, All its thunders + + +


In this great magnetic field + +
I am a knowledge system + + +

My hair is a tangled Mojave Dictionary + + +
, And my tongue + is a danger + +
I speak a darkwhip + into the haboob‚Äôs goldthrob + + +

This valley‚Äôs bright-weather is my ceremony + + +
, Flashflood + is my medicine‚Äî
+ + how I clean myself of Self


+ + + America + + Hoard of Property + is a debris
+ of my cells‚Äî limestone + + wound-porous +
sea-floor + + basalt + trilobite + camel bones +
, glass and Blackmountain + + +
+
+ + + +
+ + + + + + +


+ + + We professional mourners + +
crying for our lives + and for hire + + +
From dark-colonies + in the caves behind our hearts
+ + we weep the sun to fall + and bats into the sky

+ + + We weep the saguaros to bloom + Eastward
+ and moonwhite + + soft-petaled wounds +
circling their night-wrists and crowns + + +
Grief is our lush and luxury‚Äî

, The strain + of anything + that grows
+ + + Sand rose + + iron wood + + smoke tree + + +
We tend dune-gardens + from Deadlands + +
till the halite beds + + reap selenite thorns +
from the horned toads‚Äô backs + + +


+ + + In the a.m. heatwarp + vultures
+ ripple the violet skydome + + +
A swarm of bloodgloved-archivists + + +
They sky-write                                  + +
+ + + + +                     + + +                   + +
+ + +      + + + directions‚Äî
+ + + +                        + + + +
+ +                                            + +
+ +                                                        + +
, To the museum , To the university
, To the hospital + + +


In this Epoch of Citizenship +
I must arrive everywhere twice‚Äî
, Occupied and Unceded + + +
One hand The Comet + +
the other hand + Who Makes the Comet Come
+ + + So call me Lodestone + or Alone + + +
Whisper me +
, Secret Magnet + + +


In pink twilight + + my love and I are effigies
+ + leaching salt +
through our terracotta hands + + +

My language clays + + and maps +
amaranth lather + along my thigh‚Äîa migration
+ of Exile‚Äî
, A self-determined Relocation of pleasure‚Äî
, wantneed + + +

We are the origin + + oxygen + and always becoming
+ + + Bloodworms
+ from which new land might grow + + +
, How we make soil + +
then mud where we laid + + +
Alchemy of our wet denim skinz + and gravity + + +

We pulse animal and sensual + + +
Thundercats of love + greening the desert‚Äî
, Pale grasses + fruit in my breath
+ + grey-green along the belly of the nightbranch + + +


We are + unacreable
+ + + We abrade + the transit + the survey
+ + hold tight and repeat ourselves +
in crystal lattice + + +


Come morning + + + Come Mercurylight + + +
We are blessed and scattered + + +
Shards + of a horsehead + water jar‚Äî
, Lonely for a body + + and aching +
for the cool taste + and shape the first water once took + + +


This Nation + is a white bright + magnesium
+ NDN burn + + +
I fume and illumine + in its quantum-arson‚Äî
, Indian Iron Alchemy Horse + + +


+ + + My brothers are the Cold Killers + +
shovelers + of silver anthracite + +
fuelgods + of the midnight train

+ boxcar + jumptrack + jolt-light
+ + + Vaporing + + nightsalt + to cloud‚Äî
, Mustanging + + +


Every desert highway is sacred +
and gas station pumps + break our hearts + + +
We have pedal bones + white doctors call coffin bones
+ + + That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm always dying‚Äî

+ + +That‚Äôs why‚Äî
, I‚Äôm always halfghost + + half-back + + half-dressed
+ as the war party who will return‚Äî
, With a full tank of gas + + +
, And a stick of scalps + + +


Tonight the city + + is a tectonic bone radio‚Äî
, Our ancestors are on every channel + + +

Scorpions whip and fluoresce + from the shadows of Settler houses
Green-eyed wolf spiders + emerge from their dens +
to join the dark hunt + + +

The midnight train + monsoons + around the bend
+ + recognizes me + as a relation + and cries +
Chuk+Shon     Chuk+Shon     Chuk+Shon

+ +     + +        + +     + +        + +     + +
+ +     + +        + +     + +        + +     + +
+ +     + +        + +     + +        + +     + +

+ + + We are each + the other‚Äôs + passenger + + +


+ + + On the horizon + my warriors volcano + + +
+ + + I shatter cinders + from my hair
+ + I‚Äôll watch them eat the day-aliens with flame
+ + + American + NDN + horse pyre + + +


The Hohokam canals + crack awake + +
gush their ghostwaters + through the settlement streets + + +
blister + and boneflower + + +

I war whoop out + into the empty + displaced hip +
of the Ghost-sea + + and the Ghost-sea +
war-weeps back +
spiraling + the etched shells of my ears + + +

+  + + A + M + E + R + I + C + A‚Äî
, Haunted hotel + shiprock + rockwreck + ship of fools + + +
, Little giant cemetery + of braids
+ +       + +       + +       + +
x           x            x           x
+++     +++      +++     +++
x           x            x           x
+ +       + +       + +       + +
+           +          +           +


+ + + Beloved Occupiers + + I am posting notice‚Äî
, There is no more vacancy + + +

When this world has ended + I will carry my people + Home
+ + +
Copyright ¬© 2023 by Natalie Diaz. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on April 24, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS3170710433.mp3?updated=1681845857&mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID

‚ÄúThis poem is a wonder alongside the work and language of Brad Kahlhamer, Sky Hopinka, Nicole Wallace, Christina Sharpe, Dele Adeyemo, Nadia Yala Kisukidi, Rinaldo Walcott, Paul Celan (https://poets.org/poet/paul-celan?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID) , and Black Sabbath‚Äôs ‚ÄòIron Man.‚Äô‚Äù
‚ÄîNatalie Diaz
https://poets.org/poet/natalie-diaz?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID

Natalie Diaz (https://poets.org/poet/natalie-diaz?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a Mojave poet and an enrolled member of Gila River Indian Community. The author of Postcolonial Love Poem (Graywolf Press, 2020), winner of the 2021 Pulitzer Prize for Poetry, her work has been supported by the Mellon Foundation and the MacArthur Foundation, among other organizations. Diaz is the director of the Center for Imagination in the Borderlands at Arizona State University.

https://poets.org/poet/natalie-diaz?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781644450147?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID

Postcolonial Love Poem (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781644450147?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID)
(Graywolf Press, 2020)
https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781644450147?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID


‚ÄúBlood/Soil‚Äù by Divya Victor
read more (https://poets.org/poem/bloodsoil?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID)
‚ÄúBeautiful Throat‚Äù by Bruce Smith
read more (https://poets.org/poem/beautiful-throat?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID)
http://pcm23.eventbrite.com?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID
Thanks to U.S. poet laureate Ada Lim√≥n (https://poets.org/poet/ada-limon?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID) , author of The Hurting Kind (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781639550494?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID)  (Milkweed Editions, 2022), who curated Poem-a-Day for this month‚Äôs weekdays. As of this year, the U.S. poet laureate guest editorship during National Poetry Month (https://poets.org/library-congress-and-poem-day?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a collaboration between the Academy and the Library of Congress. Read or listen to a Q&A (https://poets.org/April-2023-poem-a-day-editor-ada-limon?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID)  about Lim√≥n‚Äôs curatorial approach and find out more about our guest editors for the year (https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=caac44b8db&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

1250598253.subject: ‚öîÔ∏è Double-edged rate sword
1250598253.text:
‚Ä¶rising interest rates are a frenemy of consumers and banks
 

Good interest, bad debt (jayk7/Getty Images)

 
Yesterday‚Äôs Market Moves
 
Dow Jones
33,809 (-0.23%)		S&P 500
4,134 (-0.10%)		Nasdaq
12,072 (-0.42%)		Bitcoin
$27,281 (-10.57%)
Dow Jones
33,809 (-0.23%)		S&P 500
4,134 (-0.10%)
Nasdaq
12,072 (-0.42%)		Bitcoin
$27,281 (-10.57%)

Hey Snackers,

You may notice we got a little makeover, and that‚Äôs because we‚Äôve got some exciting news: Snacks is now part of Sherwood Media, Robinhood's recently launched independent news and info arm. We‚Äôll keep delivering the business stories you know and love, and will have even more to share in the coming months.

Stocks ticked down for the week despite stronger-than-feared bank earnings. The Fed said that inflation and hiring cooled over the past few weeks, boosting hopes of a rate-hike breather after May‚Äôs meeting. A slew of earnings are coming up this week, including from Big Tech.

CA$H

The double-edged sword of rising rates has consumers chasing interest and collecting IOUs

Not just platinum problems‚Ä¶ Last week American Express said it had set aside $1.1B ‚Äî way more than expected ‚Äî to cover potential loan losses. Amex isn‚Äôt the only lender worried about delinquencies. US consumer debt hit a record $4.82T in February, and Americans are starting to fall behind on credit-card and loan payments. Driving the IOU pileup: pandemic savings have dried up, wages are lagging behind inflation, and rising interest rates have become a national frenemy.

  • Enemy/friend: Folks hate high rates on their debt (picture: car payments at 15-year highs), but they dig higher returns on their savings.

  • APYes: Last month the average annual percentage yield (aka: return) for online savings accounts reached 3.75%, up from just 0.5% a year earlier.

  • Interest chasing: 30% of US customers moved $$ between banks last month, and a third of those said they were searching for a higher APY ‚Äî which also just hit a 15-year high.

Smilin' while they're cryin‚Äô... The double-edged sword of higher rates is jabbing banks too. Last quarter, the four largest US lenders wrote off $3.4B in loans (up 73% on the year) as consumers struggled to pay down debts. Citi, JPMorgan Chase, and Wells Fargo recently set aside a combined $2B to cover potential loan losses. But there‚Äôs a corporate plus side to climbing rates: this month, those same banks reported expectation-busting earnings as rising rates on customer loans (like mortgages) padded their coffers. They expect profits to increase if hikes continue.

THE TAKEAWAY

Cash is cool again‚Ä¶ Now that investors can earn higher interest on their cash, some are parking more $$ in interest-bearing accounts like money-market funds and savings. That can be bad news for stocks, since investors demand higher returns from equities to justify the changed opportunity costs. Meanwhile, banks are competing to offer higher APYs than rivals as the Fed continues raising rates. At least one more hike‚Äôs expected in May.

Events

Coming up this week

Big tech on deck‚Ä¶ Google, Microsoft, Amazon, and Meta are set to report, but slow growth (and high costs) could zap results. Last quarter, Microsoft missed sales expectations as PC and cloud demand cooled. Google disappointed as YouTube ads sagged. And despite Meta's cost slashing, analysts expect it to report its sixth straight quarter of declining profit. Tech stocks have jumped this year on hopes that the Fed would start cutting rates, but it may not be enough for a profit rebound.

Next stop‚Ä¶ cleanup. Norfolk Southern will report for the first time since one of its trains derailed in Ohio in February. The rail giant faces suits from the DOJ and Ohio, among others, after the disaster spilled toxic chemicals. Norfolk says it‚Äôs paid out $28M for cleanup so far, but the full price tag could be much higher. Since 2012, Norfolk‚Äôs workforce has shrunk 39% and its accident rate has spiked 80%. Experts think understaffing could be an industry-wide challenge. Last week, rival Union Pacific delivered muted #s.

Zoom out

Stories we‚Äôre watching

Fake Drake, real problems‚Ä¶ Last week, an AI-generated song featuring the voices of Drake and The Weeknd racked up millions of streams across TikTok, YouTube, Spotify, and other platforms. Universal Music Group, the world‚Äôs largest label, which reps the artists, had the song taken down on infringement grounds. Then another Drake fake was uploaded. Labels like UMG, Warner, and Sony Music have aggressively protected their music (think: YouTube vids removed), but AI tracks could be a game of Whac-a-Mole until rules are established.

Selling the forest for the trees‚Ä¶ just in time for Arbor Day. American logging titan Weyerhaeuser has found a profitable new venture in carbon offsets: credits that can be bought by companies to counteract their industrial emissions. A Wall Street Journal report found that the tree-chopping lumber producer is selling the CO2-sponging abilities of its 10.6M acres of forest to companies looking to cut emissions. But critics say the environmental-benefit math is fuzzy. The logger expects to generate $100M/year selling offsets by 2025.

ICYMI

Last week's highlights

  • Beef: Netflix added 1.7M subs last quarter, fewer than half what Wall Street was expecting. But the streamer hopes its password-mooching crackdown will fuel growth once the ‚Äúcancellation reaction‚Äù wears off.

  • Cut: The Writers Guild of America approved a strike if an agreement isn‚Äôt reached with studios by May. Streaming has led to a drop in writer payouts, but old rules may be catching up to disruptors.

  • Angst: Gen Z and millennials are racking up record debt as financial avoidance leads to retail therapy and the bar for ‚Äúdoing OK‚Äù rises. US workers are now demanding a minimum of $76K to start a new job.

What else we're Snackin'

  • Lift: The repo man‚Äôs back. Repossessors are prepping for a summer of tows as delinquencies hit a record. It‚Äôs a switch-up from the pandemic, when relief measures kept drivers from getting the boot.

  • Dry: Global water scarcity has led to a surge in theft from agua-rich areas like national parks, rivers, and even fire hydrants. Water scarcity could reduce some countries‚Äô GDP by up to 6% by 2050.

  • Likes: As social-media biggies like Instagram and TikTok get flooded with branded influencer content, users are turning to #ad-free networks. Picture: an app that lets you post only 100 times for life.

üç™ Thanks for Snacking with us! Want to share the Snacks? Invite your friends to sign up here.

Snack Fact Of the Day
In 1991, Mall of America gave Sears a 100-year lease on a three-story spot for $10/year
Read more

Monday

  • Monday: Earnings expected from Coke and Credit Suisse

  • Tuesday: Earnings expected from Microsoft, Google, Visa, UPS, Verizon, GM, McDonald‚Äôs, GE, Spotify, Pepsi, 3M, Raytheon, JetBlue, and Chubb

  • Wednesday: Earnings expected from Meta, Boeing, Hilton, Norfolk Southern, Roku, Wyndham, and Spirit Airlines

  • Thursday: Earnings expected from Amazon, Mastercard, American Airlines, Pinterest, Eli Lilly, Merck, Domino‚Äôs, Southwest Airlines, Hertz, Hasbro, Northrop-Grumman, AstraZeneca, Comcast, Keurig Dr Pepper, Capital One, Crocs, T-Mobile, Activision Blizzard, Caterpillar, and Snap

  • Friday: Earnings expected from Exxon, Chevron, Colgate-Palmolive, and Sony

1251730658.subject: [Fyre] CBE 2023 Sustainability Grant! (Apply by 5/5)
1251730658.text:
We're distributing *$15,000 *to fund your sustainability project!

Deadline: Friday, May 5th, 2023 at 11:59 PM EDT
[image: Screenshot 2023-04-22 at 7.46.12 AM.png]
Harvard CBE is excited to announce our annual sustainability grant program!
As a student-run sustainability-oriented consulting group, we initially
launched the sustainability grant program with the mission of supporting
our fellow students and community members in our collective mission
of sustainability.

Our funding pool this year is up to *$15,000 *and we want to support you in
your sustainability endeavors by distributing *grants to individuals and
non-profit organizations dedicated to sustainability impact. *We
particularly are looking to support underrepresented minorities and
projects with strong Diversity & Inclusion integration. CBE is funding up
to $2,000 per project.

If you'd like to submit a grant application, fill out the form below
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfR1Hic6zwAhMrC1naZShxblbuZtYW5pMqYVSVjD_Suk_Ub9Q/viewform?usp=sf_link>
by *Friday May 5th 2023 at 11:59pm EDT*.
Apply Here
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfR1Hic6zwAhMrC1naZShxblbuZtYW5pMqYVSVjD_Suk_Ub9Q/viewform?usp=sf_link>
*We can't wait to hear more about all of the cool projects you're working
on. Don't miss this chance to grow your sustainability project! If you have
any questions, please feel free to reach out to harvardcbe@gmail.com
<harvardcbe@gmail.com> or Haemaru Chung haemaruchung@harvardcbe.com
<haemaruchung@harvardcbe.com>**.*
Best,
-- 
*Daniel Kim (he/him)*
*First-Year at Harvard College*
*Concentration: History of Science*

1264059312.subject: A surprise from The Slowdown
1264059312.text:
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=2d6c93b03457e93ff92f4708c22cd547eab1b62f100a320eed6dfbdafc4e93ef7597d71cbb70c4f91628d77185af933b9e738d1256d63ded1819be78f5a62834 

Friend,

National Poetry Month is the perfect time to settle into your own writing practice. There’s no better time to lean in and create. 
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=2d6c93b03457e93ff92f4708c22cd547eab1b62f100a320eed6dfbdafc4e93ef7597d71cbb70c4f91628d77185af933b9e738d1256d63ded1819be78f5a62834 
When you make a donation to The Slowdown(R) today, in any amount, you can instantly download a digital, printable zine of writing prompts from me and some brilliant poets you’ll know from the show. 

https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=2d6c93b03457e93ff92f4708c22cd547eab1b62f100a320eed6dfbdafc4e93ef7597d71cbb70c4f91628d77185af933b9e738d1256d63ded1819be78f5a62834 

What’s more is that there’s another special reason to give right now. Not only do you get the zine, but fellow listeners of The Slowdown, Charles P. Pfleeger and Shari Lawrence Pfleeger, have generously provided another $5,000 match to help us end National Poetry Month strong. If you haven’t given yet, now is the time to chip in and have your gift doubled! 


When you give today, you can explore your own writing practice and support this public media podcast you love.

https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=2d6c93b03457e93ff92f4708c22cd547eab1b62f100a320eed6dfbdafc4e93ef7597d71cbb70c4f91628d77185af933b9e738d1256d63ded1819be78f5a62834 
Donate now  

Your gift uplifts our mission and ensures we can continue sharing poetry together for episodes to come. Donate today, grab your zine, and have your gift doubled.  


Warmest, 


Major Jackson 


P.S. 
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=2d6c93b03457e93ff92f4708c22cd547eab1b62f100a320eed6dfbdafc4e93ef7597d71cbb70c4f91628d77185af933b9e738d1256d63ded1819be78f5a62834 
Donate now – the zine download will disappear from our donation form at midnight on April 30! 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=2d6c93b03457e93f0b9efa735ff1ed8a9663cf2548e2f39d0a05963dca5657326e3b0a4cc81089ea99bb115a8bde02b6094e29d41d3d1865390c1bdefab8de9b

. If you are interested in both roles, keep in mind that a mentor account enables you to accept bookings from mentees, as well as schedule mentoring sessions with other mentors.

Adult advocates will learn about common STEM misconceptions and how to combat them effectively; topics include following non-traditional pathways to a STEM career, the importance of engineering job function vs. an engineering major, and the interconnectedness of STEM and the arts.
