http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/e-012606785-in-category/4w6vtr/457906051?h=4VQO6n8dbJ0x0LaWl-BAyLS7zX4T8-Pec5pxNrhabmc

	There are no hotels directly connected to the Los Angeles Convention Center.

	JW Marriott LA Live Hotel is the Headquarter hotel. 

	Most of the properties are walkable to the Convention Center.

	Hotels have a limited number of rooms. 

	If a property is sold out, please work with onPeak directly, as status changes often.  Contact OnPeak at SWE@onpeak.com

mailto:SWE@onpeak.com

. 

	Hotels may have a limited number of rooms. 

	You may secure small numbers of rooms through individual reservations (less than 10) or request a block of rooms (10 or more) through the link.

	You must provide a credit card, however it will not be charged until after names are finalized.

Please note that onPeak is the official housing partner of WE23. onPeak has been assigned by SWE, and onPeak representatives will be available pre-conference and onsite to assist attendees. SWE cannot guarantee room rates or availability by any company or representative other than onPeak. We ask that WE23 attendees not book outside our housing block, as it may result in penalties to SWE and our registrants. There are many housing scams aimed at companies and individuals, and these "firms" represent themselves as SWE. Remember that onPeak will never call/solicit you to book a room.

									 

															Deadline Approaching: Join Us for eXXec 2023

Transform your career in 3 days with SWE‚Äôs eXXec leadership development program

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/2023-04-24/4w6vtv/457906051?h=4VQO6n8dbJ0x0LaWl-BAyLS7zX4T8-Pec5pxNrhabmc

, where you‚Äôll discover techniques that champion your own career path, develop change management skills, and learn how to lead inclusive teams. Take part in rigorous personality and skill inventories, one-on-one coaching, and more. Plus, the program offers 1.7 CEUs/17 PDH. Use this employer support letter

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/Xec-Letter-Final-010621-2-docx/4w6vty/457906051?h=4VQO6n8dbJ0x0LaWl-BAyLS7zX4T8-Pec5pxNrhabmc

 template to ask your manager or HR team to support your participation in the program. Register by May 1 to save $200. 

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/finity-group-member-spotlight-/4w6vv2/457906051?h=4VQO6n8dbJ0x0LaWl-BAyLS7zX4T8-Pec5pxNrhabmc

Every month, we spotlight a different Affinity Group (AG) on SWE's All Together blog

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/2023-04-24/4w6vv5/457906051?h=4VQO6n8dbJ0x0LaWl-BAyLS7zX4T8-Pec5pxNrhabmc

. The Public Policy AG is one of this month's spotlights. Read the story

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/finity-group-member-spotlight-/4w6vv2/457906051?h=4VQO6n8dbJ0x0LaWl-BAyLS7zX4T8-Pec5pxNrhabmc

 of one of their most active members, Jan Williams, and how her advocacy helped introduce a bill in her state's house, on All Together.

									Leadership Coach Applications Open for FY24 LCC Cohort 1

We are looking for new coaches to join the Leadership Coaching Committee (LCC)! Consider completing an application by May 15, 2023 if you are interested in joining the LCC.

									The LCC provides proactive leadership coaching to SWE sections and affiliates. Trained SWE Leadership Coaches offer coaching and support essential to maintaining healthy, vital, and growing organizations. Coaches provide consulting to sections and affiliates and advise on various aspects of SWE. Leadership Coaches have prior leadership experience through SWE, their career, and/or broader community involvement, which is essential in having the perspective needed to tackle roadblocks and to advise on section and affiliate improvements. 

									Do you know a current/recent SWE leader who would make an excellent future Leadership Coach to SWE‚Äôs Collegiate/Professional Sections or Global Affiliates? Encourage them to apply and consider sending their info to our Recruitment Lead, Maryssa Weir, at LCC_Apply@swe.org

mailto:LCC_Apply@swe.org

.

									 

												Apply Today ¬ª

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/651-Society-Of-Women-Engineers/4w6vv8/457906051?h=4VQO6n8dbJ0x0LaWl-BAyLS7zX4T8-Pec5pxNrhabmc

									Our upcoming live web event is sponsored by Keysight Technologies. Registration for this live web event is free for all SWE members upon login

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/courses-51673-webinars-34997/4w6vvc/457906051?h=4VQO6n8dbJ0x0LaWl-BAyLS7zX4T8-Pec5pxNrhabmc

. 

‚Äã‚Äã

The purpose of this email is to publicize a program or activity sponsored by the Society of Women Engineers (SWE). You are receiving this email because you are either a SWE member or have an affiliation with SWE. All SWE members may login to the SWE portal to manage and update their email preferences

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/s-login--startURL-2Fs2F/4w6vsn/457906051?h=4VQO6n8dbJ0x0LaWl-BAyLS7zX4T8-Pec5pxNrhabmc

. Everyone, including non-members, may unsubscribe from all SWE email communications here

http://marketing.swe.org/unsubscribeConfirm/858553/730dc36aa2accab8712aaca4fdfc4230640d51abbf0384c92bcae7f3e7ff213c/457906051

. Due to their leadership responsibilities, all active SWE leaders will continue to receive SWE business emails even if they opt-out of marketing emails. Current SWE members may receive business critical emails and/or renewal emails even if they opt-out of marketing emails. To remove your email address from SWE's database entirely, email membership@swe.org

mailto:membership@swe.org?subject=SWE%20Database%20Removal%20Request&body=Hi%2C%0A%0APlease%20have%20my%20personal%20information%20completely%20removed%20from%20the%20SWE%20database.%0A%0AThank%20you.

. We respect your right to privacy. View our policy.

1280187925.subject: India-based Fellowships: Apply by May 25, 2023
1280187925.text: Call for Applications  CALL FOR APPLICATIONS India-based Fellowships: Apply for research funding INR 1,00,000 per month for the fellowship period (one year) Deadline: May 25, 2023 The Lakshmi Mittal and Family South Asia Institute India (LMSAI), an office of Harvard Global Research Support Centre India (HGI), is pleased to offer the Mittal Institute India Fellowship to host 1 - 2 postdoctoral scholars in India. As a fellow, scholars will have the opportunity to avail Harvard‚Äôs vast resources to contribute to self-driven, independent research. Applicants from any discipline are encouraged to apply, provided their studies advance, facilitate, and provide programs in and for the public benefit of India.  The Mittal Institute India Fellowship is meant for recent postdoctoral scholars who have completed their studies in the last five years. For this year‚Äôs application cycle, applicants must have obtained their Ph.D. between March 1st, 2018, and March 31st, 2023. Those who have not had opportunities in the past to access Harvard‚Äôs resources and who have primarily been educated at institutions in India will be given priority.  Fellows are expected to reside in New Delhi (India) and its vicinity for the fellowship duration of one year to actively participate in the events and intellectual life of LMSAI India. Participation may include, but is not limited to, grant review, hosting seminars, and engaging with Harvard faculty and affiliates in India. Fellows will be mentored by a Harvard faculty member in their area of research, and the research produced will be widely disseminated for public benefit in India.  Learn more by visiting the Mittal Institute Fellowship webpage and read the FAQs. Apply by May 25 ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå Harvard South Asia Institute | CGIS South Building, 4th Floor, 1730 Cambridge Street, Cambridge, MA 02138 Unsubscribe eelaafzahid@college.harvard.edu Update Profile | Constant Contact Data Notice Sent by sainit@fas.harvard.edu powered by Try email marketing for free today!

1284820511.subject: [ADAMS] Blockchain event at the Harvard Art Museums on Thursday
1284820511.text:
For anyone who's interested:

Mine, Yours, Theirs, Ours? Ownership and Stewardship in the Age of Blockchain<https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/mine-yours-theirs-ours-ownership-and-stewardship-in-the-age-of-blockchain>
Thursday, April 20, 2023
6:00 - 7:30 pm
Menschel Hall, Harvard Art Museums (480 Broadway Entrance)

Join artist and professor Kevin McCoy and writer, economist, and professor Amy Whitaker for a conversation about ownership and stewardship of cultural property in the 21st century. They will consider the current status of art ownership and if and how blockchain technology could be useful in crafting a new, more equitable model of ownership. Ruth Streeter, a 2021 Advanced Leadership Initiative Fellow at Harvard and former producer of 60 Minutes, will moderate this discussion.


Ana Barros (they/she)
Manager of Campus Partnerships
ana_m_barros@harvard.edu<mailto:ana_m_barros@harvard.edu>

Harvard Art Museums
32 Quincy Street, Cambridge, MA 02138
www.harvardartmuseums.org<http://www.harvardartmuseums.org/>

1289701692.subject: [ADAMS] FW: Media and medicine event on Friday
1289701692.text:
FYI for interested students

From: Silverstein, Jason Bryan <Jason_Silverstein@hms.harvard.edu>
Sent: Tuesday, April 18, 2023 7:54 AM
To: Keshavjee, Salmaan A. <Salmaan_Keshavjee@hms.harvard.edu>; Becerra, Mercedes Corina <Mercedes_Becerra@hms.harvard.edu>
Subject: Media and medicine event on Friday

Dear Salmaan and Meche,

Sharing our final installment of our spring lecture series, featuring Steven Thrasher, inaugural Daniel Renberg Chair, Northwestern's Medill School, the first journalism professor anywhere to focus on LGBTQ research. Steven's book, The Viral Underclass: The Human Toll When Inequality and Disease Collide receiving wide acclaim for its depiction of HIV/AIDS.

Steven will be speaking at 5pm on Friday in TMEC 209 and the event will also be livestreamed on zoom.

Would you share with the Adams House students? I think those interested in public health, racism, LGBTQ issues might like to attend.

Thank you!
Jason


Jason Silverstein, Ph.D.
Co-Director of the M.S. in Media, Medicine, and Health program

Associate, Department of Anthropology, Harvard University

1308250566.subject: "Someone Forgot to Whisper Your Death to the Bees" by Ansel Elkins
1308250566.text:
Someone forgot to whisper your death to the bees

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 25, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** Someone Forgot to Whisper Your Death to the Bees (http://poets.org/poem/someone-forgot-whisper-your-death-bees?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
Ansel Elkins (https://poets.org/poet/ansel-elkins?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID)

Someone forgot to whisper your death to the bees
And so all the bees have left
And the fruit trees have died.

In the house there are twelve ghosts
And all of them you‚Äî
Caught like birds in the stations of girlhood.

One ghost kneels before an empty fireplace;
She sings her sister‚Äôs name
Into the cool mouth of the chimney,

Listens as the voice shivers
Its return.

A barefoot ghost pitches stones
Down the red dirt road.

The melancholy sister at the kitchen window
Waits for a letter, watches for the postman.

Twelve ghosts. Each sister ties
A different color ribbon in her hair.

One sweeps all the rooms of the house.

Two stand before the mirror. But it‚Äôs bad luck
For two to look into a mirror at the same time;
The youngest will die.

And what of the one in the basement?

No, we don‚Äôt visit her.

Twelve white plates laid on the table for supper.

All twelve drink water from one well.

Each daughter moves in the mood of her own month.
They carry the tides, the seasons, the year of you.
Each daughter, each dancer,
Delivers the message of you.

One dreams she‚Äôs a racehorse rider‚Äî
She straddles the propane tank in the yard
And rides recklessly into the night.

One ghost plays a nocturne on the piano,

While another skips into the room,
Strikes the discordant keys, and vanishes.

The last ghost leans with her ear against a dead wasp nest.
She closes her eyes and listens

To you, still singing
Beyond the kingdom of the living

Copyright ¬© 2023 by Ansel Elkins. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on April 25, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS2700831293.mp3?updated=1681846531&mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID

‚ÄúI recall my Puerto Rican grandmother telling me when a bird was trapped in her house that it meant someone in the family was going to die. Belief in ghosts is something I grew up with. The Alabama of my girlhood was red dirt roads and abandoned houses where not much but the chimney was still left standing. That‚Äôs where the ghosts of my girlhood live. This poem originates from the folk belief that when one dies someone should go out and tell the beehive because bees are messengers that carry the news of your death to the gods.‚Äù
‚ÄîAnsel Elkins
https://poets.org/poet/ansel-elkins?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID

Ansel Elkins (https://poets.org/poet/ansel-elkins?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID) is the author of Blue Yodel (Yale University Press, 2015), winner of the Yale Younger Poets Prize. The recipient of fellowships from the National Endowment for the Arts, the North Carolina Arts Council, and the Bread Loaf Writers‚Äô Conference, she was awarded a 2011 Discovery/Boston Review Poetry Prize. Elkins was raised in Talladega County, Alabama.

https://www.biblio.com/search.php?stage=1&result_type=works&keyisbn=Blue+Yodel+by+Ansel+Elkins&mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID

Blue Yodel (https://www.biblio.com/search.php?stage=1&result_type=works&keyisbn=Blue+Yodel+by+Ansel+Elkins&mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID)
(Yale University Press, 2015)
https://www.biblio.com/search.php?stage=1&result_type=works&keyisbn=Blue+Yodel+by+Ansel+Elkins&mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID


‚ÄúI Have Never Been Anything Like Pink‚Äù by Kazuko Shiraishi
read more (https://poets.org/poem/i-have-never-been-anything-pink?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID)
‚ÄúVariations [Excerpt]‚Äù by Amelia Rosselli
read more (https://poets.org/poem/variations-excerpt?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID)
http://pcm23.eventbrite.com?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID
Thanks to U.S. poet laureate Ada Lim√≥n (https://poets.org/poet/ada-limon?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID) , author of The Hurting Kind (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781639550494?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID)  (Milkweed Editions, 2022), who curated Poem-a-Day for this month‚Äôs weekdays. As of this year, the U.S. poet laureate guest editorship during National Poetry Month (https://poets.org/library-congress-and-poem-day?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a collaboration between the Academy and the Library of Congress. Read or listen to a Q&A (https://poets.org/April-2023-poem-a-day-editor-ada-limon?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID)  about Lim√≥n‚Äôs curatorial approach and find out more about our guest editors for the year (https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID) .


http://poets.org/donate/pad?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID
‚ÄúPoem-a-Day is brilliant because it makes space in the everyday racket for something as meaningful as a poem.‚Äù ‚ÄîTracy K. Smith

If this series is meaningful to you, join the community of Poem-a-Day supporters by making a gift today (https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=f2d56e0e04&mc_eid=UNIQID)  in honor of National Poetry Month. Now serving more than 320,000 daily subscribers, this publication is only possible thanks to the contributions of readers like you.

1332557286.subject: [ADAMS] SEE MY ARTSFIRST INSTALLATION (and more art!)
1332557286.text:
*THURS 27 - SUN 30 SIT IN MY CHAIRS*
[image: CHAIRS FLYER.png]
[Alt text: "I DESIGNED AND BUILT CHAIRS FOR YOU TO SIT IN AND through cool
tech that cool people made YOUR BONES WILL BE RATTLED AND YOU WILL HEAR
MUSIC THROUGH YOUR BONES THROUGH THE CHAIRS" "For more details on the
exhibit or if you want me to show you the installation myself email me at
tamarsella@college.harvard.edu" "ARTSFIRST WEEKEND Thurs 27- Sun 30, 10 am
- 8 pm" "https://confluxcollective.org/Musical-Chairs"]
Over this past year I worked with Conflux Art Tech
<https://confluxcollective.org/Musical-Chairs> to create a crazy
interactive audio visual installation that will be on exhibit at ArtFirst
<https://ofa.fas.harvard.edu/arts/public-art-2023> *THIS THURS 27th - SUN
30th*!
Located in Tercentenary Theater next to Sever and Memorial Church, the
interactive audio parts of the installation will be running from 12 pm - 8
pm Thurs and 10 am - 8 pm Fri-Sun. I will be on site chair-watching for
certain hours so email or text me if you'd like me to show it to you irl!
Spoiler alert *YOU HEAR MUSIC THROUGH YOUR BONES THROUGH THE CHAIRS!!! *You
won't want to miss it!!!

And if you want to see more art of mine and all the other people in art
classes this semester and also the AFVS thesis show, come to *AFVS Open
Studios & Senior Thesis Exhibition* in the *Carpenter Center on Friday the
28th from 5-7 pm*!
[image: image (1).png][image: image.png]

Happy ArtsFirst!
Tamar Sella

_______________________________________________

1345344913.subject: SEAS Undergraduate Career Newsletter Monday, April 24, 2023
1345344913.text:
Last-minute note for those looking for internships/jobs - please see today's 4:30 USACE event

View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/seas/seas-undergraduate-career-newsletter-mon-apr-17-2023-3089690?e=65d2b2b7c0)
https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=be8b6be995&e=65d2b2b7c0


** Table of Contents
------------------------------------------------------------
1. Personalized Information (#Appointment Links)
2. Announcements (#Announcements)
3. Employer, Career, and Academic Events (#Events)
4. Selected Job Postings (#Jobs)
5. Harvard Center Links Useful for Careers (#Harvard Center Links)
6. Other Lists (#Lists)
7. Contact Information (#Contact Information)


** Personalized Information
------------------------------------------------------------

Calendly link to schedule a 25-minute appointment (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=cfcc8bec57&e=65d2b2b7c0)  with Keith Karasek (kkarasek@seas.harvard.edu ; SEC LL1.237) to discuss your career, internship, and job-search goals.

Email Ruth Sondermann (sonderm@g.harvard.edu) for advice regarding opportunities in European countries

SEAS Student Career Development (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=b5df0fa7ba&e=65d2b2b7c0)

Talk to students in concentration areas:
Applied Mathematics Peer Concentration Advisors (PCAs) (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=eb81c725f8&e=65d2b2b7c0)
Computer Science Peer Concentration Advisors (PCAs) (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=b71d2209ac&e=65d2b2b7c0)
Engineering Peer Concentration Advisors (PCAs) (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=95a616f46b&e=65d2b2b7c0)


** Announcements
------------------------------------------------------------



** Wednesday - Harvard FounderCrush
------------------------------------------------------------
Startup RAD (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=b51b41c0f9&e=65d2b2b7c0) has been a SEAS course-based effort for over 20 years, where student teams have developed their own startups,  Each spring they hold a demo day.  This year's event will be a celebration with the broader Harvard Startup community, which will gather for pitches, feedback, networking, live DJ, open bar & lots of food. Harvard FounderCrush (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=8b9aebae91&e=65d2b2b7c0) , will be this Wednesday, April 26, 2023, from 5-7pm in the SEC first floor.



** Late Notice - Event this Afternoon:
US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) Career Event
------------------------------------------------------------
This event came together late last week, so I'm getting the newsletter out early.  If you are still looking for a summer internship or a postgraduate job, this may be worth checking out.  From 4:30-5:30pm TODAY, US Army Corps of Engineers: Virtual Information Session (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=48db2075c5&e=65d2b2b7c0) . They have several positions available in many of the SEAS areas with locations across the US.  Although virtual, this event is exclusively presented to Harvard students. They will collect resumes at the session.



** Reminder: Concurrent Master (AB/SM) Event
------------------------------------------------------------
Thursday, April 27, 2023, 11am-noon, SEAS AB/SM (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=224d4639fc&e=65d2b2b7c0) Information Session, Register for Zoom Link (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=00decb4747&e=65d2b2b7c0)



** Harvard GRID Announcements
------------------------------------------------------------
* Venturing@Harvard (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=c4395f54af&e=65d2b2b7c0) merges this week with Wednesday's FounderCrush event.

Also check out these select I-Lab Events (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=2178816ae4&e=65d2b2b7c0) :
* Thursday, April 27, 2023, 5:30-6:30pm, Government Funding Sources for Educational Ventures (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=898341c00e&e=65d2b2b7c0)


** REEF Maker Space Events
------------------------------------------------------------
Tomorrow, Tuesday, April 25, 2023, from 1:30-3:30pm, there will be a Bike Maintenance Basics Workshop (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=e35f2fb5c8&e=65d2b2b7c0) in the SEC Maker Space.

In partnership with the LPCE (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=fde083729b&e=65d2b2b7c0) , the Marine Debris Fashion Challenge Fashion Show will be held on Thursday, April 27, 2023, in the Science Center Plaza tent.  Food trucks arrive at 7pm, the VJ starts at 7:30, and the fashion show begins at 8pm.

Reminder: May 15 is the deadline to apply to be a REEF (Maker Space) Maker Fellow (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=9a9b710220&e=65d2b2b7c0) .

1369612617.subject: [ADAMS] KEEP ADAMS THE BEST HOUSE! SAVE THE BOW AND ARROW PRESS!
1369612617.text:
*TL;DR: *SIGN <https://forms.gle/3yubynTVhzezJgz57> THIS
<https://forms.gle/3yubynTVhzezJgz57> PETITION
<https://forms.gle/3yubynTVhzezJgz57>

*Hi Adams! *

*It was recently announced that the Bow and Arrow Press is not being
allowed to return to its home in Westmorely after House Renewal. The Press
is ESSENTIAL to the awesome community we have in Adams, so please sign this
petition <https://forms.gle/3yubynTVhzezJgz57> to show the House Renewal
team how much the Bow and Arrow matters to our community!!*

*FIRST-YEARS: Even if you have never been to the press, please **sign
<https://forms.gle/3yubynTVhzezJgz57>**! You are the only class that will
still be here once renewal is complete, so your voices are SUPER
important. *

*Also, the more people that sign <https://forms.gle/3yubynTVhzezJgz57> now,
the less emails you have to receive from me about it! More awesome
community spaces and less emails is a win for everyone! *

*Link to sign: https://forms.gle/3yubynTVhzezJgz57
<https://forms.gle/3yubynTVhzezJgz57>*
*Link to read the petition: *
*https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TRQhJ12eSTwiJM4QEauEtz7uELJnq2pihi7sCwht-kY/edit?usp=sharing
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TRQhJ12eSTwiJM4QEauEtz7uELJnq2pihi7sCwht-kY/edit?usp=sharing>*

*Thank you, *

*Julia Pastreich *

1378583362.subject: [ADAMS] Fwd: Two Environmental Justice Events! Intersectional Earth Week DAY TWO
1378583362.text:
First, RSVP Here
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdXxePqji01XGqy6K67q3bGbBYz_mXuqNEA-mvs2HHvNR88wg/viewform>
!

Intersectional Earth Week Day Two!

We have reached day two of programming on Intersectional Earth Week! This
week is an initiative from the Harvard Climate Coalition to urge a broader
base of Harvard Students to Explore their identities within the Climate
Crisis. To do so, we are collaborating with *seventeen (yes,
seventeen!!) *different
organizations on-campus 11 thought-provoking events on environmental
themes. For more information, explore our event webpage
<https://harvardclimatecoalition.squarespace.com/intersectional-earth-week>!

Yesterday we had a phenomenal event run through the HKS program on Science,
Technology, and Society <https://sts.hks.harvard.edu/>. This event explored
a hypothetical scenario of a society with carbon currency. In the activity,
attendees devised economic models and considered the impact that carbon
could drive on our economies if held in such a way.

Also, go to the Science Center where you can see the *Power Connected Mural*!
Created by Grace Cen and Kayla Springer of the Harvard Undergraduate Urban
Sustainability Lab (HUUSL), the mural is meant to symbolize the embedded
hope and power of transmission lines in a sustainable society. Go check it
out!
_____________________________

*Programming for today:*


*Intersections with Gender and Indigeneity*
Harvard Foundation on Intercultural and Race Relations
Harvard College Women's Center
*6:00 PM | Harvard Hall 202*

- ~ -


*Pursuing Environmental Justice in Marginalized Communities in Boston*
Black Students Association
Fuerza Latina
Asian American Association
Latinas Unidas
*6:30 PM | Sever 113*

Join us to hear from Boston organizations advocating for environmental
justice for marginalized communities and learn how you can support their
work. Come hear from Neighborhood of Affordable Housing, La Colaborativa,
and more over food, a panel, and Q&A!
_____________________________

*Reminders:*

   1. "Writing for the Climate" submissions are due on Saturday, April 22
   (Earth Day)! Win up to $500 for fiction or nonfiction writing. More details
   here <https://writingfortheclima.wixsite.com/home>
   2. Five winners will have their art showcased at GEM23, an HKS
   conference in early May, and win $100 each! For submission details, check
   out our website under "events."
   3. Want to help organize future events or actions with the coalition?
   Feel free to send us an email here at harvardclimatecoalition@gmail.com


Harvard Climate Coalition
Join our newsletter <http://eepurl.com/inJzXI>!
Instagram
<https://instagram.com/harvard_climate_coalition?igshid=ZDdkNTZiNTM=>
Website <https://harvardclimatecoalition.squarespace.com/>
Together for a just and sustainable world

1390524622.subject: [wics-chatter] Fwd: [hcs-d] [HCS] Five Ways to F*ck Up Your Fundraise
1390524622.text:
Mark your calendar to hear from the CEO of Neo tomorrow at 6:30PM! RSVP
here: https://lu.ma/7pq3unw8

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Kaitlyn Zhou <kaitlynzhou@college.harvard.edu>
Date: Sun, Apr 23, 2023 at 9:43‚ÄØPM
Subject: [hcs-d] [HCS] Five Ways to F*ck Up Your Fundraise
To: <hcs-discuss@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>



[image: HCS Instagram Pub-9.png]


Cringe-inducing stories of failure from Neo CEO Ali Partovi. Join us
on *Thursday
at 6:30 - 7:30pm at Harvard Hall 104* as Ali Partovi shares his advice on
what to do (and what not to do) *when starting a company, as well as how to
prepare yourself for success when starting or joining an early stage
company.*

*About Ali and Neo:*

*Neo <http://neo.com/> is a diverse mentorship community, startup
accelerator, and VC. We help the top CS students become tomorrow's tech
leaders and help startups build legendary teams. Applications for our
premier undergrad Neo Scholar program
<https://www.notion.so/hr-neo-com-3964bd200285459d8ce282f5a42c2948> will
open in May, and applications for Neo Accelerator
<https://neo.com/accelerator> 2024 will open in Feb/March.*

*Ali Partovi <https://www.linkedin.com/in/apartovi/>**, CEO, Neo: **Ali
tries to make a career of investing in people smarter than himself. He has
backed Airbnb, Dropbox, Facebook, & Uber. He co-founded Code.org
<http://code.org/> (Hour of Code) to bring CS to classrooms. Ali grew up in
Tehran during the Iran-Iraq war, attended Harvard, and sold his first
startup, LinkExchange, in 1998. He's passionate about sustainable food and
loves climbing, snowboarding, guitar, puzzles, & family.*

1392585452.subject: HULS election candidacy declarations
1392585452.text:
[image: banner_good_ipa.png]

Hi everyone,

Now that the academic year is drawing to a close, it's time to elect next
year's Linguistics Society board! Here's how it will work:

*Now - April 28: Candidacy declarations*

   - If you want to run for a position, please fill out *this form*
   <https://forms.gle/cbUtEJwMF2B1xFQU7> and provide a brief statement on
   why you are running, which we will share with the club during the voting
   period. You may run for multiple positions; just provide a statement for
   each position.
   - To run, you must be planning to be an enrolled student for the
   entirety of the 2023-2024 academic year and you must have attended at least
   two meetings over the past two semesters.
   - The co-presidents reach out to guest speakers, communicate with the
   club, plan events, and generally oversee things. The treasurer gets funding
   from the HUA, buys stuff, and keeps a record of financial transactions. The
   secretary controls media and outreach activities.
   - You're encouraged to run for anything you're interested in!
   - Please feel free to contact anyone on the board if you have questions.
   - If you're free at our meeting tomorrow, feel free to do some light
   campaigning :)

*April 29 - May 1: Voting period*

   - Once the candidacy declaration period is over, we will email out the
   candidates' statements to the whole club.
   - All members will then be able to read the statements and vote on the
   new board. Each member may, of course, only vote once.

*May 2: Election results*

   - On May 2, we will make the results public and announce our board for
   next year.
   - If there is a tie, we will have a run-off election.

Best,
Joanna (the only graduating board member, and therefore your impartial
parliamentarian)

1410231561.subject: [ADAMS] Build an (AI) Bot Workshop Sunday, 4/30/23 now @ 11 am AND 3:30 pm!
1410231561.text:
*Hey Adams,*

*A pretty cool workshop that I'm helping with next Sunday!*

*Due to popular demand, we opened up a second session in the morning for
our AI Bot ü§ñ  Workshop at 11 AM on Sunday April 30!*

These are now the two sessions:
Morning, with lunch dumplings ü•ü: 11 AM to 3 PM. Sign up here
<https://www.eventbrite.com/e/build-an-ai-bot-workshop-morning-session-new-tickets-623028403727>
.
Afternoon, with dinner dumplings ü•ü: 3:30 PM to 7:30 PM. Sign up here
<https://www.eventbrite.com/e/build-an-ai-bot-workshop-afternoon-session-tickets-619793297437>
.
Location: Nieman Foundation's Lippman House @ Harvard 1 Francis Street
Cambridge, MA 02138

[image: image.png]

*Build an (AI) Bot Workshop *

AI is happening, and it‚Äôs easier than you think.

Join us for an (AI) Bot Building Workshop with Chinese food, instruction,
GPT4 and everything you need to walk away with an open-source bots your
friends can use and share.

If you‚Äôre looking to learn about AI or start a company from your dorm, this
workshop will leave you brimming with ideas and skills.

You‚Äôll modify your bot to add basic tools and learn how to develop your own.

So, Who Is It For?

   - This workshop works best in programmer-poet pairs (we can pair you).
      - One of you should know Python.
      - One of you should know Poe.
   - Other than that, we only need you to bring your laptops, empty
   stomachs, and ambitious brains.

*W*hat Will We Do?
    Part 1: No Code? No Problem

You‚Äôll use a web interface to create a GPT-4 based bot with a custom
personality, capable of answering questions about YouTube videos and PDF
files you care about.

    Part 2: Put it on your Phone

You‚Äôll add your bot to Telegram so you and your friends can chat with it.

    Part 3: Extending your Bot with ‚ÄúTools‚Äù

‚ÄúTools‚Äù are Python skills that an AI can use autonomously. A tool could be
generating a DALL-E image, remembering a grocery list, or looking up the
time of your next class.


*WÔªøhat Will We Eat?*We will feed you yummy Chinese ü•ü (and more) from Dumpling
House <https://www.dumplinghousema.com/>


*Who‚Äôs Hosting?*Hosted by Steamship <https://steamship.com/> (Team Python)
and Plympton <https://plympton.com/> (Team Poetry) ‚Äî two companies born
from opposite ends of Mass Ave who feel very much that they are coming home
with this event.


Ivan

_______________________________________________

1424403010.subject: [ADAMS] You Won, BIG: THE GREEN CUP! (& Gradams Market Updates)
1424403010.text:
Adams House,

I am THRILLED to announce that *we have won the Green Cup *for the House!!! You
all KILLED IT with your participation in sustainability education this
year!!!!!!

[image: confetti.gif]
*CONGRATS GRADAMS!*
*What does this mean?*
1. You all learned more about sustainability and conserving energy! From
recycling and composting to learning how to take care of your dorm room,
you put in the work to engage with materials that will make your footprint
that much greener!
2. The house gets a CASH PRIZE to do whatever it wants with it. Houses in
the past have used it for minor renovations like installing water bottle
fillers, to throw parties, to host a ~deluxe~ study break, or to fund HOCO
a little extra. If you have any ideas for what Adams should use it for, let
me know.
3. *Get. Your. Pie. On.* (more info on this below)

*Celebration + Gradams Market*
Gradams Market is an in-house FREE flea market/item swap event, April 22
from 1PM to 4PM in the Inn Atrium (which happens to be earth day ü•∞). The
purpose is to donate clothes, accessories, dorm decor, etc, that you won't
want for next year instead of throwing it away or into a giant donation bin
at the end of the year. The most sustainable option is to give items to be
directly reused in a new home since we know it's a guarantee it won't end
up in a landfill. Whatever doesn't get grabbed at the item swap will be
directly donated to local shelters. Bring one, take one policy encouraged.
For more details, check my previous emails!

Donate your stuff to it ahead of time at Carpe for raffle tickets, in the
box in the Lower Common Room, and the box in the Clav ground floor by the
biig staircase! If you can't drop off your stuff at those times, you can
drop by at 10AM in the Atrium or reach out to me! It's important to get
this stuff in ahead of time so the Gradams Market team and I can set up the
Atrium for you in time!

Come to divert stuff from landfills, get free stuff, have Felipe's and
fresh berries, get a chance to participate in the raffle, and enjoy the
community!

*Now... what's in this raffle I keep mentioning?*
*PIES*

That's right -- a bunch of the tutors agreed to get pied in the face early
last year if we won the Green Cup to encourage participation. The official
list of tutors who may have pies (kindly) thrown at them is...

Santi, Varnel, Shandra, Shannon, Michael, Ryan, Danielle, John (and feed
Oshie some whipped cream!), and Alex!

*Want to be the one pie-ing one of the tutors? Participate in Gradams
Market! Every donation will get you a raffle ticket! Winners will be drawn
during Gradams Market and notified to make sure they don't miss out! *Yes,
I am still using the pie-ing to motivate the house to engage with
sustainability one last time before I graduate (humor me here Gradams <3)
*This could be you:*
[image: face pie.gif]

If you want a raffle ticket but cannot make it to Carpe or the morning of
22nd, shoot me a message and I'll arrange a ticket for you! I live on the
ground floor of clav so it's really easy for me to step out for a minute if
you need a ticket!

*I can't wait to see you all there! *
If you have any questions or are interested in volunteering, let me know!



*[image: trophy.gif]*
*The green cup looks exactly like this ...*
*Except it's a giant pile of recycled e-waste in the shape of a trophy :)*
*Come visit it during Gradams Market and get your picture with it!*

Gradams Loveeeee,
Amelia






-- 
*Amelia Quezada* (she/her)

*A.B. Candidate in Government *
*Secondary in Sociology*

1478584671.subject: [ADAMS] Fwd: Please forward: Meet Mill Town
1478584671.text:
Hey Adams! Come to this cool event to hear from climate writer Kerri
Arsenault and other people mentioned in her book, *Mill Town*!!

*Meet Mill Town: A Roundtable*

AÔªøpril 28, 5:00-6:30pm

In-person (RSVP required): PÔªøarlor Room, Phillips Brooks House, Harvard
University

LÔªøivestream (RSVP not required): YouTube @mindichprogram



‚ÄúMeet Mill Town: A Roundtable‚Äù brings together host Kerri Arsenault, author
of *Mill Town: Reckoning With What Remains*, with guests from the eponymous
mill towns of Rumford and Mexico, Maine: Maddy Arsenault, Jim Aylward,
Marie Therese (Terry) Martin, and Lisa Russell.

For over 100 years, the Rumford and Mexico communities orbited around a
paper mill that sustained the livelihoods of nearly everyone in town,
including three generations of Arsenault‚Äôs family. But even as the mill
provided social, cultural, and economic cohesion for the tight-knit
community, it exacted a price‚Äîpaid for by environmental and family legacies.



Once a powerhouse manufacturing area that developed around industry on the
Androscoggin River, Rumford and Mexico, like manufacturing towns throughout
New England, experienced profound transformations because of economic
shifts. In this community conversation, students from the ‚ÄúStorytelling:
Hazards and Possibilities‚Äù study group will engage with guests in a
discussion exploring the lived experience of growing up in a New England
mill town, what it means to stay there, and what happens when you leave.
Together, the roundtable will explore questions of community, ecology, and
inequality in America.



*Kerri Arsenault* is the 2022-23 American Democracy Fellow, co-sponsored by
the Charles Warren Center and the Mindich Program in Engaged Scholarship.

*Maddy Arsenault* is Kerri‚Äôs mother and a longtime resident of Mexico;* Jim
Aylward* is the guidance counselor and former Head Coach of the high school
football team at Mountain Valley High; *Marie Therese *(*Terry) Martin* is
the author of *WHEN POISON FELL FROM THE SKY* and a nurse; and *Lisa
Russell* teaches high school math in Rumford.



The roundtable will be facilitated by undergraduate student discussants *Alex
White* (‚Äô23, Government and Public Policy), *Jana Amin* (‚Äô25), and *Katie
Catulle *(‚Äô24, English), *Aeden Marcus* ('25, Environmental Science,
Engineering), and *Eshan Vishwakarma *('26).

This event is sponsored by the *Mindich Program in Engaged Scholarship*.



*The Harvard University media relations policy outlines that the press is
not permitted to film or cover events on campus. If individuals attending
Harvard sponsored events meet someone or hear something as an attendee that
they would like to pursue as a journalist they should contact the Harvard
communications team (collegecomms@fas.harvard.edu
<collegecomms@fas.harvard.edu>) to discuss options.*









------------

Caitlin Schmid (she/hers)

Assistant Director of Engaged Scholarship, Mindich Program

Harvard University

1510378911.subject: [PSA-Harvard] Humanitarian Relief in Sudan
1510378911.text:
*TLDR: Support humanitarian relief efforts in Sudan by Venmo‚Äôing
@sasharvard.*


Dear Harvard College Pakistani Students Association,


We hope this email finds you well!


As you might be aware, a war broke out in Sudan between the national armed
forces and a paramilitary group on April 15th, 2023. The situation has now
become what the UN has termed a *humanitarian catastrophe*.


   - It is mainly civilians being targeted. Water and electricity have been
   cut off since the beginning of the conflict.
   - Over 70% of the capital Khartoum's hospitals are now out of
   commission, with only 19 remaining servicing a population of 6.3 million.
   - The majority of international relief organizations have stopped
   operations in the country and most nations have evacuated their personnel.


Given the dire nature of the situation, the Harvard Society of Arab
Students, the African Students Association, and the Islamic Society are
raising funds for medical relief in the nation. We humbly request that you
consider contributing a donation of any size to support the relief effort.
You can do so through *SAS's Venmo: @sasharvard*.

All collected funds will support the Sudanese American Physicians'
Association (SAPA), Fill-a-Heart (FaH), and the Sudan Doctors' Union - UK
(SDU-UK). We are grateful for any support you can provide and would love it
if you can forward this email to others.

Sincerely,

Iqra Noor

_______________________________________________
PakistanStudentAssociation mailing list
PakistanStudentAssociation@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/pakistanstudentassociation

1536194118.subject: [ADAMS] Jahnavi's Senior Recital this Sat, 4/29!
1536194118.text:
Please join me for my vocal senior recital on Saturday, April 29th at
6:30pm ET in Leverett Library Theater! I will be celebrating my time at
Harvard through singing pieces, both solo and with friends, from my
favorite operas, musicals, and artists. You can RSVP here
<https://partiful.com/e/h6mgyr6DcHni60vrOY9S>!

[image: Screen Shot 2023-04-25 at 3.22.53 PM.png]

Featuring Natalie Choo, James Rose, Isabella Meyer, Olympia Hatzilambrou,
Julia Paolillo, Ines Hynett, Andrew Lu, Hari Narayanan, and Judah Lampkin!
We will be accompanied on piano by the incomparable Lucas Amory.

Please bring additional guests! Please RSVP so my mom knows how many
~snacks~ to bring :)

Leverett Library Theater is located on 8 Mill Street, Cambridge, MA, 02138.
Please enter through the green door (there will be a sign for my recital on
the door) that is along the brick building. The door is beneath two green
flags and the words "McKinlock Hall." Once entering, the theater is through
the doors on your right. Can't wait!

1540266725.subject: [ADAMS] Clinical Research Coordinator Position for Graduating Seniors
1540266725.text:
*GENERAL SUMMARY/ OVERVIEW STATEMENT: * Dr. Anne-Marie Wills is looking to
hire a full time research coordinator to work on two-four clinical trials
for Parkinson‚Äôs disease.   The ideal candidate would be planning on a
future medical or allied health degree, and would be interested in working
in clinical research to gain experience and publications prior to going to
medical school.  A two-year commitment is required.  The coordinator must
be motivated, organized, and efficient, able to organize schedules,
evaluate participants, enter data electronically and respond quickly to
emails.  Prior clinical research experience is a plus but not required.



* PRINCIPAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:* ‚Ä¢       Coordinate and schedule
clinical trial visits both in-person and remotely
‚Ä¢       Create online advertising, webinars, and video instruction materials
‚Ä¢       Maintain documentation for the Institutional Review Board.
‚Ä¢       Perform primary data collection at study visits, including
questionnaires and limited physiological monitoring.
‚Ä¢       Enter all study data into the electronic data capture system.
‚Ä¢       Monitor and reports adverse events as required by
Institutional/federal regulations

* SKILLS & COMPETENCIES REQUIRED: *

Candidate must have strong organizational skills, a willingness and ability
to learn, and interest in working with human research participants.  Good
interpersonal skills, attention to detail, the ability to prioritize
multiple tasks and handle fluctuating priorities and deadlines, good
communication skills, and the ability to work independently as well as with
others are required.  Prior clinical research experience is a plus but not
required.





*EDUCATION: * Minimum Required:
Bachelor‚Äôs Degree

1543175720.subject: [HUES] [DUE APRIL 24TH] HUES Exec Board Applications
1543175720.text:
Hey Engineers!

With the end of the semester approaching, HUES will be
*running elections for board positions* for the coming school year
(2023-2024)! HUES always welcomes new board members no matter the
year/concentration as long as you're passionate about strengthening the
engineering community. You *do not need to have previous experience* being
on board for HUES in order to run for the positions, (*you technically
don't even need to be an engineer to run for the positions lol*), so we
hope to see you all run for the various openings!

HUES Board members direct and organize events for the engineering community
such as: SEAS Formal, Field Day, SEAS BBQ, Innovation Talks, Socials &
Happy Hours, Industry Tours, and much more!  If you've enjoyed any of these
events and want to take on a more active role in developing and organizing
these activities, please consider applying for a board position (*descriptions
attached*).

Feel free to reach out to me or Molly personally (
mwieczorek@college.harvard.edu or mollybosworth@college.harvard.edu) if you
have any questions or concerns. If you'd like to talk about your
application, the election process, or learn more about the organization the
current HUES co-presidents will be holding office hours throughout the
week.

Maycee:
- Wednesday 7-8pm (Wednesday Zoom <https://harvard.zoom.us/j/5437178419>)
- Thursday 10:15- 11:15am (Thursday Zoom
<https://harvard.zoom.us/j/5437178419>)

Molly:
- Thursday 3-4pm (Thursday Zoom <https://tinyurl.com/MollyZoomTh>)
- Friday 1-2pm  (Friday Zoom
<https://www.google.com/url?q=https://harvard.zoom.us/j/94489284561?pwd%3DTmc2cW5lSkNreXFrOG5XSFVPWGtCZz09&sa=D&source=calendar&ust=1682177024358877&usg=AOvVaw3ajlIfTExxqStzxyUTzi5t>
)

Details below:

*Applications for HUES Board 2023-2024 are due April 24th AT 11:59PM EDT
at THIS FORM
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeQp_yI-Ib5ahelBwt2cSMCnLwjjWQiF1wMCAdZr4mgInDtYQ/viewform?usp=sf_link>.*

*Running for a position:*


   - *All members of the hues-open list are eligible to run for a position*
   - Candidates are eligible to run for up to 3 positions (i.e. you can
   give speeches for two additional roles if you do not get your top choice)
   - *All candidates must send a candidacy statement (300 words max)
   to this form
   <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeQp_yI-Ib5ahelBwt2cSMCnLwjjWQiF1wMCAdZr4mgInDtYQ/viewform?usp=sf_link>*
    *for each position of interest by** April 24th at 11:59PM EDT*
   - Candidacy statements will be distributed before the elections

*Voting/Election:*


   - *The election is open to all members of the hues-open list who would
   like to come for deliberations and voting.*
   - Because the meeting is relatively long, voters can come and go, but *if
   you're running for a position please try to stay the whole time (please let
   us know if you can only stay part of the time.)*
   -  Please keep speeches to under 3 minutes.
   - You may not take part in the deliberations for any position you are
   running for; you will be in a different room while deliberations happen
   among voters.
   - For each position, the candidate with the most votes will be elected -
   for positions with 2 chairs, the candidates with the top 2 most votes will
   be elected.

*The election will take place on **Friday, April 28th *from 1:00 PM - 4:00
PM EDT*, but will likely not take the entire allocated time.* If you would
like to be considered for certain positions but are unable to submit a
candidacy statement and/or attend the election deliberations, please let me
or Molly know.


Best,

Maycee Wieczorek, Molly Bosworth

*HUES Co-Presidents*

--

1549606555.subject: English, Math (Short-term) - Tutoring Oppty
1549606555.text:
Hi all,

Please see below for an English and Math (Short-term) opportunity.

All tutoring opportunities are posted to this *Google Spreadsheet (Std
Tutoring Opps)*
<https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1T3iL7t433tOe7IBzQKyHTXjFzs4DejJk2a7W0VzwBBM/edit?usp=sharing>
 (and updated in real-time) -- please bookmark for future reference!

If you're interested in any tutoring opportunities (or have any questions),
then please respond to this email (tutormatching@princetontutoring.com).

Kind regards,
*Elizabeth*

*1 - English (Online)*
#DGRG

   - This 7th grader is on the spectrum, has an IEP & special curriculum
   for ELA, needs additional support to focus on reading comp. Parents are not
   native English speakers.
   - Interests/activities: puzzles, crosswords, art
   - Personality: between shy & outgoing, wants to communicate but
   struggles sometimes to do so, wants to make friends
   - Preferences for tutor: patient, has experiences working with students
   who have learning differences
   - *Logistics:* Online
   - *Frequency:* 1x/week
   - *Availability: *Saturdays 10 am-1pm (45 min sessions)
   - *Duration:* Ongoing
   - *Session length: *45 min
   - This opportunity pays your standard rate
   - *Tutor Tier: *Standard

*2 - Applications of Math (Short-term) (Online)*
 #KSKS

   - *FYI: this is a potential opportunity for an interested client. The
   client hasn't signed up yet. We are reaching out to gauge tutor interest.*
   - This college student is returning to school after 35 yrs, taking
   Applications of Math (not for math/science majors) at Atlantic Cape
   Community College. Topics of study: critical thinking skills, sets, logic,
   systems of numeration, geometry, mathematical systems, consumer
   mathematics, probability, statistics, graph theory, volume, surface area.
   Has high C/low B, goal is to maintain a B.
   - Personality: introvert
   - Preferences for tutor: patient as student's getting back into
   learning, breaks down the concepts
   - *Logistics:* Online
   - *Frequency:* 2x/week
   - *Availability: *Tues/Thurs afternoon/evenings, Mon after 4pm, Fri
   after 2pm, Wed after 2pm, Weekends are open
   - *Duration:* Until May 8th
   - *Session length: *1 hr min
   - This opportunity pays your standard rate plus $5/hour
   - *Tutor Tier: *Standard

---


*Elizabeth Smith *

Senior Operations Manager
Princeton Tutoring <http://princetontutoring.com/> / PrepMaven
<http://prepmaven.com/>

--

1578267692.subject: [ADAMS] Fwd: Join us! A Spring Restorative Foundation Friday
1578267692.text:
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: The Harvard Foundation <harvfoun@fas.harvard.edu>
Date: Thu, Apr 27, 2023 at 3:04 PM
Subject: Join us! A Spring Restorative Foundation Friday
To: <kylagolding@college.harvard.edu>


As the semester comes to a close, we invite the campus community to a Grays
Hall study break one more time.
Foundation Friday! April 28, 1-4PM
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=e47ba9960f&e=32558a02f6>

The Harvard Foundation for Intercultural and Race Relations presents
*A Spring Restorative Foundation Friday!*

Join us to talk one more time for 'Foundation Fridays'! We will have food,
painting, games, karaoke, volleyball, music, and more! Take a study break
with us at Grays Hall basement


*Friday 4/28, 1-4pm Grays Hall, Lower Level*
No RSVP needed!
Events and Opportunities
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=742125defd&e=32558a02f6>

ARTS FIRST Festival is a unique annual celebration of the Harvard
community's artistic creativity. It showcases the Harvard arts community
through performances, art exhibitions and art-making activities.  Join us
April 27-30 for live events, exhibitions and dynamic artist showcases
celebrating a wide variety of music, dance, theater, creative writing,
visual arts and our community.

*Full Lineup: Arts First 2023 Events*
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=e93896a4b2&e=32558a02f6>
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=24601aefe0&e=32558a02f6>

*Phillips Brooks House Association Public Service Celebration
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=745d13e9e5&e=32558a02f6>*
Quincy Dining Hall
Friday, April 28, 5:30-7PM

Dinner, speeches, awards, and more! Join us to celebrate an amazing year of
service. RSVP HERE
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=95ee7e0fe6&e=32558a02f6>
.
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=8afb4fbc1a&e=32558a02f6>

*Undergraduate Mariachi V√©ritas de Harvard* is proud to present its
free *Spring
2023 Concert: La Fiesta del Mariachi!*

The show will feature the spring 2023 setlist, which includes a variety of
Mexican music including: El Balaj√∫, Caminos de Michoacan, Besame Mucho, and
Cielito Lindo.

*Saturday, April 29 | Adams Dining Hall, 8:30PM*
More info here
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=7ca6e0aae9&e=32558a02f6>
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=72b73a41f1&e=32558a02f6>

*Service StorySlam*
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=88360f86f8&e=32558a02f6>
Sunday, April 30,2023
12:00pm - 1:00pm
Lowell Lecture Hall
RSVP here
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=904e5ce3a7&e=32558a02f6>

Come hear undergraduates share how different service experiences
challenged, changed, and shifted them!  This will be a live storytelling
event. Our goal is to bring the Harvard community together to listen and
learn from student service experiences that center the successes and
failures that inevitably occur in community engagement.

This conversation will feature:
Heba Mohamed, '23: The Power of Showing Up
Veronica Ruiz '26: Community, Community, Community
Tarina Ahuja, '24: Resiliency & Trolls
Jeremy Orenstein '24: Pitfalls of Planning a Revolution
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=11749b1ca1&e=32558a02f6>

The Harvard Foundation and Natives at Harvard College present
*Dialogue: Missing and Murdered Indigenous Persons*

Join us for a conversation in recognition of MMIP Remembrance Day on May
5th! The conversation will be led by Native American Students at Harvard!
Please wear red on May 5th to show solidarity. Dinner will be provided.

Location: Grays Hall Lower Level
Monday, May 5th, 5PM
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=1b49f2e368&e=32558a02f6>

*Harvard & the Legacy of Slavery: Our Path Forward*
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=1768e50c0a&e=32558a02f6>
An open discussion with Harvard students
Tuesday May 16, 2023, 11:30 a.m. ‚Äì 12:30 p.m.
Mount Auburn Room, 2nd Floor Smith Center

Join an engaging conversation with Roeshana Moore-Evans, Executive Director
of the Harvard & the Legacy of Slavery Initiative, and Sara Bleich, Vice
Provost for Special Projects. Light refreshments will be served.

Please register by Tuesday, May 9.
<https://harvard.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=dfa86cd678ffc37d0c0f26805&id=f12c8cd6a1&e=32558a02f6>
Share and Celebrate: Arab American Heritage Month!

Good morning. One month into the baseball season, new rules have already had an
impact on the game.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/03/27/multimedia/23-THE-MORNING-NL-LEDE/27kepner-new-rules-illo-web-gcvp-copy-jumbo.jpg]Michael
Waraksa


MORE EXCITEMENT

America‚Äôs oldest professional sport looks different this year.

For the first time in M.L.B.‚Äôs 148-year history, clocks in stadiums now count
down between every pitch, forcing pitchers and batters into action. It‚Äôs a
radical change
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/qddgFGvw5Q8jLPTfTjd_Pw~~/AAAAAQA~_B1Sp1IfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
for a sport defined by its leisurely pace ‚Äî but one that league executives
believed was necessary to grow baseball‚Äôs popularity.

The sport has gradually become less central to American culture over the last 50
years or so, as football‚Äôs popularity has skyrocketed
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/KUSk7WaRTZsncHEv11BJaw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJ53kP0TCaHR0cHM6Ly9uZXdzLmdhbGx1cC5jb20vcG9sbC80NzM1L3Nwb3J0cy5hc3B4P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjMmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTA4ODAmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTE1MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD7kGEVk_B1Sp1IfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
and other sources of entertainment ‚Äî like video games and on-demand television ‚Äî
have become more available. Even dedicated fans have grumbled in recent years
about games being longer and less exciting. To an extent, M.L.B. executives say
they agree, and they believe that this year‚Äôs rule changes will help.

So far, they are right. The changes ‚Äî including the pitch clock and others meant
to increase action ‚Äî have led to much faster games with more hits, more stolen
bases and less down time. Whether the changes will increase interest in baseball
is another question.

Today‚Äôs newsletter will explore how different this new version of baseball
really is, with some charts from my colleague Ashley Wu.


A QUICKER GAME

When it comes to game duration ‚Äî the amount of time between the first pitch and
the last ‚Äî M.L.B.‚Äôs new rules have been a smashing success.

For decades, outings at the ballpark had been getting longer and longer. When
Babe Ruth played in the 1920s, nine innings of play lasted less than two hours.
Over time, as it became more common for at-bats to last longer
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/oXAmmQiVXgvWufTI5gPD0w~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJ53kP0TQaHR0cHM6Ly9zYWJyLm9yZy9qb3VybmFsL2FydGljbGUvd2h5LWRvLWdhbWVzLXRha2Utc28tbG9uZy8_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyMyZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDg4MCZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMTUwJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPuQYRWT8HVKnUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
the average game time ticked up. It ultimately peaked at 3 hours 11 minutes in
2021.

That trend has sharply reversed this year.

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/20/briefing/23-the-morning-baseball-1/oakImage-1682014179916-jumbo.png]Sources:
Retrosheet; Baseball Reference | Data is through the first three weeks ofeach
season. | By The New York Times

During the first three weeks of this season, games lasted 2 hours 39 minutes on
average ‚Äî 29 fewer minutes than they did during the same time frame last year.
That means at a typical game beginning at 7:05 p.m., fans are heading home
around 9:45 p.m. instead of 10:15 p.m. It also means that all of the runs, hits,
strikeouts and errors occur during a shorter period of time, making the game
feel more action-packed.

The time reduction can be mostly credited to the implementation of the pitch
clock. Here‚Äôs how it works: After a pitcher receives the ball at the mound, a
15-second clock starts to count down (20 if a runner is on base). If the pitcher
waits too long, the umpire calls a ball as a penalty; if the batter delays, the
umpire calls a strike. The timer means that at-bats now move faster ‚Äî though
fans who are scrolling through social media or are in line for a hot dog are now
more likely to miss something.

‚ÄúI felt like I was at warp speed,‚Äù New York Mets pitcher David Robertson said
after his first appearance this year.


MORE ACTION

The second, and more important, goal that baseball is trying to achieve with its
new rules is to make the games more entertaining.

The M.L.B. commissioner, Rob Manfred, told my colleague Michael Schmidt
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/lKEalHzMzZD4wNDT7-p4hQ~~/AAAAAQA~_B1Sp1IfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
that baseball‚Äôs problems were at least partly a result of the sport‚Äôs recent
obsession with analytics. Teams over the past two decades have raced for a
statistical edge: They use more pitchers, and those pitchers throw faster, while
batters have tuned their swings to hit the long ball ‚Äî leading to more
strikeouts and more home runs, but fewer balls hit in play.

‚ÄúBaseball changed,‚Äù Manfred said. ‚ÄúFans wanted the game to look like the way it
used to look like.‚Äù

The sport‚Äôs new rules, including requirements about where certain defensive
players can stand, were designed to increase the game‚Äôs action ‚Äî and
entertainment value ‚Äî with more hits, more steals and more impressive defensive
plays. Through the first three weeks of the year, the M.L.B. has gotten the
result it hoped for: Runners are stealing more bases, runs are up and batting
average has risen modestly compared with the same period last season.

An increased leaguewide batting average, up to .247 from .231 last year, means
that at-bats more often end with a hit now. Statistically, it‚Äôs a significant
jump from last year‚Äôs historic low, though hits are still less common than they
were in the mid-2000s.

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/20/briefing/23-the-morning-baseball-2/oakImage-1682016475246-jumbo.png]Sources:
Retrosheet; Baseball Reference | Data is through the first three weeks ofeach
season. | By The New York Times

Though the changes have already had an impact, they still may not be enough to
solve baseball‚Äôs troubles. Hitting a professionally thrown baseball has always
been incredibly hard. In the modern era, when pitchers are stronger and more
informed by data, it is only getting harder.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the one thing that could really derail this,‚Äù my colleague Tyler Kepner,
who covers baseball, told me. ‚ÄúPitchers are only getting better, and I don‚Äôt
know how they‚Äôre really going to limit strikeouts.‚Äù

THE WEEK AHEAD

What to Watch For

 * House Republicans plan to vote this week on their debt ceiling bill, which
   would raise the cap but cut I.R.S. funding and impose strict food stamp
   requirements.
 * A civil trial is set to begin on Tuesday for a lawsuit from the writer E.
   Jean Carroll, who has accused Donald Trump of raping her in the 1990s.
 * President Biden is expected to announce his bid for re-election as soon as
   Tuesday.
 * The N.F.L. draft begins on Thursday. The Carolina Panthers have the first
   pick.
 * The annual White House Correspondents‚Äô Association dinner will be held on
   Saturday.

1631790020.subject: [ADAMS] Fwd: [NSA] [DUE TODAY] 2023-2024 Board Applications Open - Greener Scott Scholars
1631790020.text:
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Greener Scott Scholars <greenerscottscholars@gmail.com>
Date: Mon, Apr 17, 2023 at 6:54‚ÄØPM
Subject: [NSA] [DUE TODAY] 2023-2024 Board Applications Open - Greener
Scott Scholars
To: BSA <bsa-list@lists.fas.harvard.edu>, aabhw-list <
abhw-list@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, HSBSE <hsbse-list@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>,
<kuumba-talk@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, nsa-list <
nsa-list@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, <hbps@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, hasa list <
african-talk@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, <Hcclist@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, BMF
General List <bmf-list@lists.fas.harvard.edu>, <eesa@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>,
<gaasa-list@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, <bpla-list@hcs.harvard.edu>


Hello everyone!


Harvard's Greener Scott Scholars is excited to release Executive Board
Applications for the 2023 -2024 year! Founded in 2018 as Harvard's first
and only mentorship program that bridges Black Harvard undergraduate
students with Black Harvard Graduate students across all of Harvard's
graduate schools, we are excited to continue to expand and build our
Executive Board!


Applications to join Greener Scott Scholars' Executive Board are open to
everyone in Harvard's undergraduate community who identifies as Black even
if they were not a part of Greener Scott Scholars previously. All positions
must apply or be nominated. While you can only serve in one role on board,
we encourage you to apply to multiple positions! Due to the application
competition, Greener Scott Scholars would love to accommodate your second
choice whenever possible. Please look over this document
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ot0tEwvgY4-63YPuU6BNkvUL_CBTODGmTV2gRvKeHbk/edit?usp=sharing>to
learn more detail about the Executive Board positions. Please use this form
<https://forms.gle/TjGUH6ePoRyCi5aQ9> to apply for positions.


The deadline to apply for Greener Scott Scholar's Executive Board is Monday,
April 17th at 11:59pm ET.


We are currently seeking to fill the following positions:


Co-Presidents

Vice President

Secretary

Senior Treasurer + Deputy Treasurer

Director of Programming

Professional Development Chair

Community Development Chair

Outreach & Inclusivity Chair

Director of Public Relations

Sponsorship Chair(s)



 The board for the 2022-2023 year will be by appointment from the current
Staff and Executive Board.


The current 2021-2022 Executive Board members of Greener Scott Scholars are
President (jvgordon@college.harvard.edu), Vice-President (kudanagwatidzo
@college.harvard.edu), Secretary (rperpignan@college.harvard.edu), Treasurer
(curtiseverett@college.harvard.edu), Director of Public Relations (
malvarezharmon@college.harvard.edu), Co-Directors of Programming (jgillard
@college.harvard.edu)(emmamensah@college.harvard.edu), and First-Year
Outreach Chair (cristiangaines@college.harvard.edu). Please feel free to
reach out to any of them regarding their experiences on the Executive Board!



If you know a Black undergraduate student that you believe will be a great
fit for the GSS Executive Board use this link
<https://forms.gle/yz7fFiJPR6qQyMcp6> to nominate them!




Best,

GSS Leadership

[image: image.png]


-- 
Greener Scott Scholars
Cambridge, MA 02138
GreenerScottScholars@gmail.com  <GreenerScottScholars@gmail.com>

1651444422.subject: Supermode resonance, methane emissions and more
1651444422.text:
New research in bioengineering, environment and computer science


** APRIL 2023
------------------------------------------------------------

Spring is here! While you're enjoying the sunshine and flowers, check out new research from SEAS.


** RESEARCH HIGHLIGHTS
------------------------------------------------------------


**
BIOENGINEERING
------------------------------------------------------------
* Prof. Conor Walsh's group and a team of researchers from the Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) developed a soft robotic wearable (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=98e7ffdccd&e=65d2b2b7c0) capable of significantly assisting upper arm and shoulder movement in people with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
* In 2017, chimeric antigen receptor (CAR)-T cells were green-lit as the first modified therapeutic cells by the Federal Drug Administration (FDA) to treat leukemia. However, not all patients respond equally well to CAR-T cell therapies, and cancer immunologists have been trying to figure out what makes them work well or fail. Collaborators from SEAS and the Wyss Institute, led by Prof. David Mooney, as well as cancer immunologists from Dana-Faber Cancer Institute, have demonstrated that personalizing CAR-T cell stimulation during manufacturing can significantly enhance the consistency and potency of the resulting CAR-T cell products (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=cb9c409e1f&e=65d2b2b7c0) .
* A paper by Prof. Joost Vlassak revealed that previous estimates of the amount of energy expended by cell structures have been off by a factor of a billion. Working with Prof. Daniel Needleman, researchers deployed a unique pico-calorimetry method to analyze energy in microtubules and skeletal cell filaments, parts of cells that are crucial for determining cell shape, motions, and more.


** APPLIED PHYSICS
------------------------------------------------------------
* This cascaded-mode resonator, developed by Prof. Federico Capasso and his group, creates a supermode resonance (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=90a5e3068c&e=65d2b2b7c0) by reflecting the light back in a different mode at each reflection.
* Prof. Capasso's lab also unveiled a nanofabrication technique that uses holes to vacuum guide extreme ultraviolet light (EUV) (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=710952b46c&e=65d2b2b7c0) . Metalens derived from this fabrication will transform the semiconducting industry and allow for applications not even invented yet.


** ENVIRONMENT
------------------------------------------------------------
* Prof. Daniel Jacob is helping policymakers determine existing methane emissions (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=dd46b824b8&e=65d2b2b7c0) in order to support research and policy initiatives battling climate change.


** COMPUTER SCIENCE
------------------------------------------------------------
* Artificially intelligent neural networks typically rely on on visual facial and object libraries that are lacking diverse socioeconomic and demographic representation. Prof. Vijay Reddi, along with machine learning researchers and collaborators from MLCommons and Coactive AI, created a more diverse dataset using pictures of objects found in households around the world (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=f027e61852&e=65d2b2b7c0) and trained a neural network to sort objects based on that dataset.


** FEATURED VIDEO
------------------------------------------------------------

https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=cef143c948&e=65d2b2b7c0
Researchers from SEAS and the Wyss Institute have developed a rotational multimaterial 3D printing method for creating helical filaments (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=798ff3c0e8&e=65d2b2b7c0) . Using this new approach, the team, led by Prof. Jennifer Lewis, designed and fabricated artificial muscles and springy lattices for use in soft robotics and structural applications.


** BACKSTORY
------------------------------------------------------------

Prof. Steven Wofsy isn't ready to retire just yet. He, along with scientists from the Environmental Defense Fund and the Center for Astrophysics at Harvard & Smithsonian, are gearing up to launch MethaneSAT early next year. MethaneSAT is a methane-sensing satellite that will allow scientists to track emissions to their sources and provide key data for reduction efforts. (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=e67d23b9f6&e=65d2b2b7c0) Shifting the focus from carbon to methane may buy critical time in climate change mitigation. Since 2015, Wofsy and collaborators have been working on MethaneSAT with the hopes of reducing methane emissions and allowing renewable energy sources to grow.
Sign-up for cutting-edge science delivered monthly to your inbox (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=318af7d2ea)

1676073012.subject: Madhur Jaffrey; Annual Cambridge Symposium
1676073012.text: The Mittal Institute just wrapped up two inspiring weeks with our Inaugural Distinguished Artist Nilima Sheikh. We are looking forward to next week when we will host our signature spring events, the Harish C. Mahindra Lecture and Cambridge Symposium. ÔªøSee you on May 4 & 5! Harish C. Mahindra Lecture ‚Ää Thursday, May 4; 5:30pm | CGIS South, Tsai Auditorium S010 This year's Harish C. Mahindra Lecture welcomes Madhur Jaffrey. The legendary food expert, writer and actress is widely celebrated for having first introduced Indian cuisine to the West, with over 15 cookbooks, including classics such as Madhur Jaffrey‚Äôs Ultimate Curry Bible and Madhur Jaffrey‚Äôs World Vegetarian. Jaffrey is the 2023 Lifetime Achievement Award Winner She will be in conversation with Abhijit Banerjee, Ford Foundation International Professor of Economics at MIT, who is also a food author and Cooking to Save Your Life.  Followed by a public reception at the Faculty Club. Please RSVP. RSVP Annual Cambridge Symposium Friday, May 5; 9:00am - 5:00pm | Gutman Conference Center (6 Appian Way) Please join us for our Annual Cambridge Symposium, the Mittal Institute‚Äôs flagship event, which brings together scholars, practitioners and audiences to present work and discuss ideas central to South Asia. This year‚Äôs conference will focus on the theme of ‚Äúresiliency.‚Äù All are welcome to attend. The event will open with Harvard professor Maya Jasanoff in conversation with Reema Nanavaty of SEWA, discussing working on the ground with women in marginalized communities in the region. Prof. Vikram Patel of Harvard Medical School and the Lancet Citizens' Commission, will present research on ways to achieve universal health coverage in India with leading experts. In the afternoon, three Afghan artists will be in coversation with Harvard Prof. Homi Bhabha about artistic expression in Afghanistan. In addition, Mittal Institute scholars and students will talk about their work on topics ranging from the great Akbar period manuscript to Dastan e Amir Hamza to climate justice to health care to designing toward a green future. Full Schedule + RSVP  ‚Ää This Week @ Mittal: Inaugural Distinguished Artist Nilima Sheikh The Mittal Institute welcomed its inaugural Distinguished Artist Fellow, Nilima Sheikh, for two extraordinary weeks. Nilima visited the rich South Asian collections at the Harvard Art Museums and at the Museum of Fine Arts Boston; presented three lectures on her work, covering themes from color to feminism to loss to Kashmir and more; met with students in Prof. Vishal Khandelwal's class; and enjoyed discussions with Mittal Institute faculty, staff and fellows. We look forward to sharing her talks with you in the coming weeks! Announcements Call for Applications: Mittal Institute India Fellowship The Mittal Institute India Fellowship (MIIF) invites postdoctoral scholars in India to apply for this unique opportunity to be based at the Institute's New Delhi Office. India Fellows will have the opportunity to avail Harvard‚Äôs vast resources to contribute to self-driven, independent research under the mentorship of a Harvard faculty mentor while being based in India. Read about one of our MIIFs and apply by May 25. Pakistan's Political Parties: A Review by Mashail Malik Mashail Malik, LMSAI faculty grantee and Assistant Professor of Government at Harvard University, reviews Pakistan's Political Parties: Surviving between Dictatorship and Democracy from Mariam Mufti, Sahar Shafqat and Niloufer Siddiqui. Read the review.  Student Grants Faculty Grants Visiting Artist Fellowships Annual Report Job Openings If you enjoy what you're reading Forward to a Friend STAY CONNECTED ‚Ää       The Lakshmi Mittal and Family South Asia Institute, Harvard University | CGIS South Building, 4th Floor, 1730 Cambridge Street, Cambridge, MA 02138 Unsubscribe eelaafzahid@college.harvard.edu Update Profile | Constant Contact Data Notice Sent by sainit@fas.harvard.edu powered by Try email marketing for free today!

1690095571.subject: [Fyre] [Clinical Opportunity for Undergraduates]
1690095571.text:
Hi everyone!


Interested in gaining clinical experience? We are currently a volunteer
group partnered with the Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) Health
Decision Science Center <https://mghdecisionsciences.org/>. Our mission is
to help patients navigate our modern healthcare system, which can be
stressful and intimidating.


The Patient Support Corps utilizes student interns who can help patients
through the use of proven support strategies (below) and by providing
emotional support.

   1.

   Reviewing information and listing questions.
   1.

      The student intern will help the patient come up with a comprehensive
      question list based on the prompts and guide found here
      <https://psc.ucsf.edu/question-prompts>. Patients are encouraged to
      bring their question outline to their appointment and a copy may be given
      to the doctor during their appointment.
      2.

   Making decision aide calls.
   1.

      Student interns will support patients in accessing patient
      educational materials through their patient portal.
      2.

      Student interns will evaluate the effectiveness of decision aids
      patients receive to help them make choices about their healthcare or
      surgery prior to their appointments.
      3.

   In-person visits.
   1.

      Student interns will travel to MGH and help support the patient by
      taking notes.


Since this is the second year we are running the program, there are limited
volunteer positions available and we encourage you to attend office
hours Tuesday
April 25 2023 from 8-9pm ET at <https://tinyurl.com/officehrspasg>
https://harvard.zoom.us/j/94913427277?pwd=eDExd0d0VE1tQUgxa090TllZYTR0UT09
to answer any questions. We prioritize individuals who can commit to this
program for at least a year of service.

Visit https://tinyurl.com/HarvardMGHPSC to apply by April 28, 2023 at
11:59pm ET.



Please note there are also some board positions available to help with
logistics and social events and thus, if you are interested, you can fill
out the optional board application found on the form.



We hope you'll apply‚Äîand let us know harvardpasg@gmail.com if you have any
questions about the program.



Sincerely,

The Harvard Patient Support Corps Team

_______________________________________________
FYRE mailing list
FYRE@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/fyre
