1717926640.subject: Inside SEAS: Bike events, ARTS FIRST, and more
1717926640.text:
April 24, 2023


** April 24, 2023
------------------------------------------------------------


** IN THIS ISSUE
------------------------------------------------------------
* News & Announcements (#news)
* SEAS Community Events (#communityevents)
* Harvard Events (#harvardevents)


** News & Announcements
------------------------------------------------------------


** SEC Late Night Caf√© free food
------------------------------------------------------------
Once a week from 7-9:15 p.m., the SEC Caf√© offers a free item as part of their evening service. The free item for Wednesday, April 26 is:
* Brownie Sundae


** REEF Makerspace Innovation Fund for faculty and staff
------------------------------------------------------------
Thanks to generous support provided by SEAS Community Connections Fund, The REEF Makerspace in the SEC is excited to announce they are now accepting applications from SEAS staff and faculty to create and make personal projects to be worked on over the summer.

They are looking for innovative and creative proposals that showcase skills and passions. Once approved, the REEF staff will be able to meet with individuals accepted into the program to discuss project designs and provide feedback.

To help bring your project to life, the REEF is offering funding up to $300. In addition to financial support, accepted proposals will receive assistance from experienced staff in areas such as material purchasing, machinery, software training, and engineering support. They are committed to ensuring that your project is a success and will work closely with you throughout the process.
Don‚Äôt miss this opportunity to turn your ideas into reality with the support of the REEF. Submit your proposal (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeqkZHAACwBfjwdNGC9i9iBADX8r5P4Rk8_lGsuGUK4oSpivA/viewform?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=637a109119-InsideSEAS&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-637a109119-430354381) and take your first step towards bringing your vision to life. The deadline to apply is Friday, May 5. Community members will hear back by mid-May on accepted projects.


** Call for applications: New World Social Innovation Fellows
------------------------------------------------------------
The New World Social Innovation Fellows Program (https://sici.hks.harvard.edu/homepage/new-world-social-innovation-fellowship/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=637a109119-InsideSEAS&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-637a109119-430354381)  is a rigorous co-curricular program for change-makers committed to addressing critical social problems in new and creative ways. The Fellows Program supports selected students ‚Äì known as Cheng Fellows ‚Äì advancing progress on a social problem through an effort of their own design. Through weekly co-curricular programming, coaching, mentoring, and seed funding, the Fellowship provides a platform for students to explore, develop, and scale efforts while in school and post-graduation. Collectively, Fellows‚Äô work represents innovation across issues, around the world, and within sectors - encompassing civil society, business, government, and NGO organizations.

Applicants from SEAS master‚Äôs programs must graduate in Spring 2024. Doctoral students may apply as rising second-year students or rising third-year students (Spring 2026 or 2027 graduation). The application for this program opens Friday, May 5, and closes Monday, June 5.


** SEAS Community Events
------------------------------------------------------------


** April 25, May 17: Bike events
------------------------------------------------------------
Harvard CommuterChoice is hosting a couple bike-themed events (including one at the SEC) this semester.

Bike Maintenance Basics Workshop
* 10-minute tune-ups and bike safety checks
* Bring your bikes and bike parts to work 1:1 with a bike mechanic
* Register your bike or micromobility device

Date: Tuesday, April 25
Time: 1:30 - 3:30 p.m.
Location: SEC Makerspace, 150 Western Ave., Allston

Annual Bike Breakfast
* 10-minute tune-ups and bike safety checks
* Register your bike or micromobility device
* Enter to win bike prizes
* Breakfast catered by Oggi's

Date: Wednesday, May 17
Time: 8 - 10 a.m.
Location: Smith Campus Center patio, 75 Mt. Auburn Street, Cambridge


** May 22 - 25: Commencement Affinity Celebrations (https://edib.harvard.edu/affinity-graduations?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=637a109119-InsideSEAS&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-637a109119-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
Affinity celebrations are student-led, staff supported events that recognize and celebrate the accomplishments of graduates from marginalized and underrepresented communities. These University-wide celebrations provide an opportunity for graduates to honor those who have helped them achieve their milestone while centering their cultural traditions and values. Affinity celebrations are open to all Harvard graduates who pre-register to attend. The celebrations include keynote speakers, performances and cultural celebrations.

Registration for the 2023 Affinity Celebrations will close on Monday, April 24. If you have questions, please contact edib@harvard.edu (mailto:edib@harvard.edu) .


** [See all SEAS events] (https://events.seas.harvard.edu/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=637a109119-InsideSEAS&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-637a109119-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------


** Harvard Events
------------------------------------------------------------


** April 27: HMSC 10-Year Anniversary (https://hmsc.harvard.edu/calendar_event/anniversary-celebration/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=637a109119-InsideSEAS&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-637a109119-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
Celebrate the 10-Year Anniversary of the Harvard Museums of Science & Culture (HMSC) by visiting one or all four HMSC museums to collect museum swag, enjoy birthday cupcakes, participate in raffles, or explore galleries. HMSC is free for Harvard ID holders.



** April 27-30: ARTS FIRST (https://ofa.fas.harvard.edu/arts-first-2023-events?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=637a109119-InsideSEAS&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-637a109119-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
ARTS FIRST is Harvard's annual showcase of student, faculty, and Harvard affiliate creativity. Produced by the Office for the Arts, with support from the Board of Overseers of Harvard University, the festival is a public event with many free performances and activities for Harvard and community members of all ages.



** May 8: Creating the Climate Future: Harvard Climate Leadership Summit (https://www.harvardcls.com/index.php?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=637a109119-InsideSEAS&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-637a109119-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
All Harvard students are invited to attend the inaugural Harvard Climate Leadership Summit during Harvard Climate Action Week (May 8 - 12). The summit will provide a platform that convenes students and decision-makers across industry, government and civil society to cultivate a rising generation of climate leadership. There will be an opportunity to meet the Emerging Climate Leaders, a passionate and diverse group of students who are dedicated to tackling climate change. They are the next generation of leaders committed to building a more sustainable and equitable future.



** May 9: Harvard Climate Symposium (https://harvardclimatesymposium.cventevents.com/event/c2f2acd5-bd80-49de-b1d3-4206bc0c7c76/summary?rp=b485e4a4-efad-42bf-9efc-e57a893288f1&utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=637a109119-InsideSEAS&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-637a109119-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
The Salata Institute for Climate and Sustainability is hosting a Climate Symposium during Harvard Climate Action Week (May 8 - 12). This new Institute serves as a fulcrum for collaboration across Harvard‚Äôs many areas of expertise, pursuing practical, real-world solutions that address all aspects of the climate crisis.

The Symposium represents the first major event of the Salata Institute‚Äôs Climate Action Accelerator (https://salatainstitute.harvard.edu/the-accelerator/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=637a109119-InsideSEAS&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-637a109119-430354381) . The Accelerator will serve as a resource and partner to the full spectrum of stakeholders wrestling with the most difficult and divisive climate questions, building consensus for climate solutions grounded in Harvard‚Äôs research and expertise.


** SEAS suggestion box
------------------------------------------------------------
SEAS welcomes your ideas for ways to improve the school, build community, and make things work more efficiently. Submit feedback, suggestions, or ideas (https://harvard.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_ah3D4tyjx30av5z?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=637a109119-InsideSEAS&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-637a109119-430354381) . Include your name if you wish; otherwise all submissions are anonymous.


** Submit your news to Inside SEAS
------------------------------------------------------------
Inside SEAS is published weekly. If you would like to have news featured in future editions, please email Matt Goisman (mailto:mgoisman@g.harvard.edu?subject=Inside%20SEAS%20Submission) by 5 p.m. on Thursdays. Inside SEAS can help you share news and announcements with a wider audience.

While we make every effort to publish all items received, the editorial staff reserves the right to reject submissions and edit content for space and style.

1751483991.subject: Something waiting for absolutely everyone
1751483991.text:
‚ÄúPoetry matters because, in its clutches, there is something waiting for absolutely everyone‚Äù

https://poets.org/donate/p/27/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=c55f180c90&mc_eid=UNIQID
Dear Reader,

One of the gifts of Poem-a-Day, with readers in all fifty states and around the world, is the reminder that, ‚ÄúPoetry matters because, in its clutches, there is something waiting for absolutely everyone,‚Äù as Academy Chancellor Patricia Smith said.

Perhaps, like me, you save the daily poems that offer a new idea or that ring especially true and share them with others, expanding the circle of readers brought together by this one-of-a-kind-series.

And, of course, another gift is that Poem-a-Day is available to all readers for free, thanks to the contributions of a devoted few. Please help us meet our National Poetry Month fundraising goal with a special, one-time contribution (https://poets.org/donate/p/27/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=c55f180c90&mc_eid=UNIQID) .
https://poets.org/donate/p/27/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=c55f180c90&mc_eid=UNIQID
If each of our subscribers were to give just a dollar, we would double our goal for this National Poetry Month. Think about what an impact your support could have.

Readers like you, making gifts of all sizes, underwrite Poem-a-Day, enabling the Academy to send a new, never-before-published poem to more than 320,000 readers each morning and, importantly, to pay the Guest Editors and poets we feature.

Thank you for your support this April! (https://poets.org/donate/p/27/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=c55f180c90&mc_eid=UNIQID)

Gratefully,
https://poets.org/donate/p/20/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=c55f180c90&mc_eid=UNIQID
Tess O‚ÄôDwyer
Chair | Board of Directors
Academy of American Poets

P.S. We set aside a donor-exclusive blank notebook for you, featuring lines by U.S. Poet Laureate Ada Lim√≥n. Be sure to make your gift (https://poets.org/donate/p/27/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=c55f180c90&mc_eid=UNIQID) of $30 or more before this campaign ends in order to claim yours!

1780562413.subject: [hcs-d] Bridgewater Associated Investment Engineering Info Session
1780562413.text:
Bridgewater Associates will be on campus next Thursday, April 27th at
12:30pm in the Smith Collaboration Commons Isaacson Room, with two of our
Investment Engineers to host an information session to learn more about
what we do at Bridgewater as well as the role Investment Engineers hold in
the organization.



We are currently recruiting for our summer 2024 internship programs, and we
thought members of your club might be interested in stopping by to learn
more! If you think others in your club might be interested, please send
this flyer along!




*What is Investment Engineering?*As an Investment Engineer, your mission is
to understand how the world‚Äôs markets and economies work and codify this
understanding. You will spend your time designing and building the
algorithms which are used to generate Bridgewater's views on markets,
translate those views into portfolios, and trade those portfolios. Every
piece of investment logic is owned by an Engineer who:

   - Is an expert in their investment domain and can hold the whole model
   of the investment system in their head.
   - Designs systems that beautifully express and run our investment logic
   and evolves with our investment understanding.
   - Runs and develops a team of engineers to build and maintain the
   investment system.



We also shape how Bridgewater does investment research: we deeply
understand how exploration is done and evolve the methods and tools to more
rapidly develop breakthrough insights.



*Explore more information about Bridgewater‚Äôs culture on our website **here*
<https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/www.bridgewater.com/principles-and-culture__;!!IBzWLUs!Rn0EllmoiBk7uMQf1ViaFdv_Ewz7_cDdPEDOXrfmxR3J9aNITucOl1W9NmZ7oeTJ0ZI8aix9G2JPaiYbEYpGiPd-vw$>
*.What is the opportunity for summer intern hires?*

   - We are looking for undergraduate and graduate students who have a high
   affinity for building well-engineered solutions to complex problems
   pertaining to economics, markets, portfolio management and trading.
   - Summer interns will work on a challenging investment engineering
   project throughout the course of their internship with the potential to
   have real impact in our investment process and to shape how we do work.
   - Interns will also participate in a summer-long Investment Engineering
   class which will give each participant a well-rounded experience that
   covers the gamut of the problems we face, and the thinking required to
   solve them
   - Top summer interns will receive full time offers to join the team
   following the successful completion of their degree.



Spots are limited, and I wanted to reach out to you first with a link to
RSVP <https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/7NBZVZ9>. We hire from a diversity of
backgrounds ‚Äì and don‚Äôt require any prior finance, econ, or markets
knowledge to join our investment community. We‚Äôd love to have members of
your org at the chat. If you know someone who is a creative thinker with an
interest in exploring complex problems, please feel free to share this
invite to them as a version of a ‚Äúplus one‚Äù!



We are also hosting 1:1 coffee chats with current Investment Engineers! If
you would like to sign up for a chat, please use this link
<https://calendly.com/evajoycespivey/harvard-coffee-chats>.

1812692995.subject: [ADAMS] TONIGHT @6:30: Career paths of physician-scientists in the 21st century (Senior Common Room series)
1812692995.text:
Reminder to join us in the Conservatory tonight for another installment in our Physician-Scientist career path series! See below for more info. All are welcome, pre-med or not!

Guest: J. Ricardo McFaline-Figueroa, MD, PhD
Specialty: Neuro-Oncology

Date: Monday, April 17, 2023
Time: 6:30 ‚Äì 7:30 pm
Location: Adams House Dining Room (Conservatory)

Series Description:  ‚ÄúCareer paths of Physician-Scientists in the 21st Century‚Äù
The Senior Common Room of Adams House is pleased to offer a series entitled ‚ÄúCareer paths of physician-scientists in the 21st century‚Äù for interested students, tutors, and staff.  This series will bring to Adams House a range of physician-scientists to discuss their individual career path and their academic interests which range from laboratory medicine to clinical research to social science.  Over the course of the year, we hope to highlight the incredible diversity of physician-scientists, to demystify the path toward this career, and to inspire individuals who plan a career in academic medicine.

[X]
Short biography:
Dr. McFaline-Figueroa graduated with MD and PhD degrees from Columbia University in 2013. He completed training in internal medicine at the Massachusetts General Hospital in 2014 and in neurology at the Harvard BWH-MGH Neurology Residency Program in 2017. He completed his fellowship at the MGH-DFCI-BWH Neuro-Oncology Fellowship Program in 2018. His research focuses on glioblastoma and the use of combinatorial therapies to enhance response to immunotherapy in this disease.

1823576596.subject: Inside SEAS: Design Fair, Awards, and more
1823576596.text:
May 1, 2023


** April 24, 2023
------------------------------------------------------------


** IN THIS ISSUE
------------------------------------------------------------
* News & Announcements (#news)
* SEAS Community Events (#communityevents)
* Harvard Events (#harvardevents)


** News & Announcements
------------------------------------------------------------


** SEC Late Night Caf√© free food
------------------------------------------------------------
Once a week from 7-9:15 p.m., the SEC Caf√© offers a free item as part of their evening service. The free item for Wednesday, April 26 is:
* Brownie Sundae


** REEF Makerspace Innovation Fund for faculty and staff
------------------------------------------------------------
Thanks to generous support provided by SEAS Community Connections Fund, The REEF Makerspace in the SEC is excited to announce they are now accepting applications from SEAS staff and faculty to create and make personal projects to be worked on over the summer.

They are looking for innovative and creative proposals that showcase skills and passions. Once approved, the REEF staff will be able to meet with individuals accepted into the program to discuss project designs and provide feedback.

To help bring your project to life, the REEF is offering funding up to $300. In addition to financial support, accepted proposals will receive assistance from experienced staff in areas such as material purchasing, machinery, software training, and engineering support. They are committed to ensuring that your project is a success and will work closely with you throughout the process.
Don‚Äôt miss this opportunity to turn your ideas into reality with the support of the REEF. Submit your proposal (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeqkZHAACwBfjwdNGC9i9iBADX8r5P4Rk8_lGsuGUK4oSpivA/viewform?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381) and take your first step towards bringing your vision to life. The deadline to apply is Friday, May 5. Community members will hear back by mid-May on accepted projects.


** Call for applications: New World Social Innovation Fellows
------------------------------------------------------------
The New World Social Innovation Fellows Program (https://sici.hks.harvard.edu/homepage/new-world-social-innovation-fellowship/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)  is a rigorous co-curricular program for change-makers committed to addressing critical social problems in new and creative ways. The Fellows Program supports selected students ‚Äì known as Cheng Fellows ‚Äì advancing progress on a social problem through an effort of their own design. Through weekly co-curricular programming, coaching, mentoring, and seed funding, the Fellowship provides a platform for students to explore, develop, and scale efforts while in school and post-graduation. Collectively, Fellows‚Äô work represents innovation across issues, around the world, and within sectors - encompassing civil society, business, government, and NGO organizations.

Applicants from SEAS master‚Äôs programs must graduate in Spring 2024. Doctoral students may apply as rising second-year students or rising third-year students (Spring 2026 or 2027 graduation). The application for this program opens Friday, May 5, and closes Monday, June 5.


** SEAS Community Events
------------------------------------------------------------


** April 25, May 17: Bike events
------------------------------------------------------------
Harvard CommuterChoice is hosting a couple bike-themed events (including one at the SEC) this semester.

Bike Maintenance Basics Workshop
* 10-minute tune-ups and bike safety checks
* Bring your bikes and bike parts to work 1:1 with a bike mechanic
* Register your bike or micromobility device

Date: Tuesday, April 25
Time: 1:30 - 3:30 p.m.
Location: SEC Makerspace, 150 Western Ave., Allston

Annual Bike Breakfast
* 10-minute tune-ups and bike safety checks
* Register your bike or micromobility device
* Enter to win bike prizes
* Breakfast catered by Oggi's

Date: Wednesday, May 17
Time: 8 - 10 a.m.
Location: Smith Campus Center patio, 75 Mt. Auburn Street, Cambridge


** May 22 - 25: Commencement Affinity Celebrations (https://edib.harvard.edu/affinity-graduations?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
Affinity celebrations are student-led, staff supported events that recognize and celebrate the accomplishments of graduates from marginalized and underrepresented communities. These University-wide celebrations provide an opportunity for graduates to honor those who have helped them achieve their milestone while centering their cultural traditions and values. Affinity celebrations are open to all Harvard graduates who pre-register to attend. The celebrations include keynote speakers, performances and cultural celebrations.

Registration for the 2023 Affinity Celebrations will close on Monday, April 24. If you have questions, please contact edib@harvard.edu (mailto:edib@harvard.edu) .


** [See all SEAS events] (https://events.seas.harvard.edu/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------


** Harvard Events
------------------------------------------------------------


** April 27: HMSC 10-Year Anniversary (https://hmsc.harvard.edu/calendar_event/anniversary-celebration/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
Celebrate the 10-Year Anniversary of the Harvard Museums of Science & Culture (HMSC) by visiting one or all four HMSC museums to collect museum swag, enjoy birthday cupcakes, participate in raffles, or explore galleries. HMSC is free for Harvard ID holders.



** April 27-30: ARTS FIRST (https://ofa.fas.harvard.edu/arts-first-2023-events?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
ARTS FIRST is Harvard's annual showcase of student, faculty, and Harvard affiliate creativity. Produced by the Office for the Arts, with support from the Board of Overseers of Harvard University, the festival is a public event with many free performances and activities for Harvard and community members of all ages.



** May 8: Creating the Climate Future: Harvard Climate Leadership Summit (https://www.harvardcls.com/index.php?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
All Harvard students are invited to attend the inaugural Harvard Climate Leadership Summit during Harvard Climate Action Week (May 8 - 12). The summit will provide a platform that convenes students and decision-makers across industry, government and civil society to cultivate a rising generation of climate leadership. There will be an opportunity to meet the Emerging Climate Leaders, a passionate and diverse group of students who are dedicated to tackling climate change. They are the next generation of leaders committed to building a more sustainable and equitable future.



** May 9: Harvard Climate Symposium (https://harvardclimatesymposium.cventevents.com/event/c2f2acd5-bd80-49de-b1d3-4206bc0c7c76/summary?rp=b485e4a4-efad-42bf-9efc-e57a893288f1&utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
The Salata Institute for Climate and Sustainability is hosting a Climate Symposium during Harvard Climate Action Week (May 8 - 12). This new Institute serves as a fulcrum for collaboration across Harvard‚Äôs many areas of expertise, pursuing practical, real-world solutions that address all aspects of the climate crisis.

The Symposium represents the first major event of the Salata Institute‚Äôs Climate Action Accelerator (https://salatainstitute.harvard.edu/the-accelerator/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381) . The Accelerator will serve as a resource and partner to the full spectrum of stakeholders wrestling with the most difficult and divisive climate questions, building consensus for climate solutions grounded in Harvard‚Äôs research and expertise.


** SEAS suggestion box
------------------------------------------------------------
SEAS welcomes your ideas for ways to improve the school, build community, and make things work more efficiently. Submit feedback, suggestions, or ideas (https://harvard.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_ah3D4tyjx30av5z?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381) . Include your name if you wish; otherwise all submissions are anonymous.


** Submit your news to Inside SEAS
------------------------------------------------------------
Inside SEAS is published weekly. If you would like to have news featured in future editions, please email Matt Goisman (mailto:mgoisman@g.harvard.edu?subject=Inside%20SEAS%20Submission) by 5 p.m. on Thursdays. Inside SEAS can help you share news and announcements with a wider audience.

While we make every effort to publish all items received, the editorial staff reserves the right to reject submissions and edit content for space and style.

============================================================
** Website (https://www.seas.harvard.edu?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)

1832805689.subject: [wics-chatter] [HCS AI x HUMIC] Apply for the Harvard AI Vision Fellowship! (Summer 2023)
1832805689.text:
The Harvard AI Vision Fellowship will run this summer with the goal of
enabling Harvard students to explore and apply themselves to topics
relevant to AI, with greater resources and a strong support network.

Vision Fellows will have the opportunity to:

   -

   Work on independent projects of their interest, from technical
   applications to econ/policy research
   -

   Learn about various fields and interdisciplinary approaches in AI (e.g.,
   econ, law, engineering, ethics)
   -

   Discuss recent developments in AI with invited speakers and leaders in
   industry and academia
   -

   Connect with other students working at the cutting edge (weekly/biweekly
   remote fellows group)


The fellowship expects a commitment of 5-10 hours per week on
projects/development. Those more heavily involved in larger projects, such
as in research at Harvard or startups, may also apply, though no preference
is given to either type. AI experience is not needed to apply.

Applications for the Vision Fellowship are available now and will close May
10 at 11:59 ET.

Application link: bit.ly/visionfellows

More information: hcsaigroup.org/visionfellows

-- 
www.harvardwics.com
With questions/concerns/anything at all we can help with, reach out to Rachna or Karen! (rachnagupta / karen_li @ college.harvard.edu)

1839511687.subject: Re: Tue 8pm cookies: Hear from the linguist Chomksy personally recommended
1839511687.text:
Here's our poster! Feel free to pub it in your house/yard email lists!!
[image: chierchia-edited.png]

On Mon, Apr 17, 2023 at 11:09‚ÄØPM Joanna Boyland <
jboyland@college.harvard.edu> wrote:

> Xazha fellow linguaphiles,
>
> A couple years ago, we had Noam Chomsky as a speaker at HULS. When asked
> who he would recommend to us as a future speaker, he recommended Prof.
> Gennaro Chierchia. Now, two years later, we have invited him!
>
> Prof. Gennaro Chierchia is a semanticist who works on a wide variety of
> subfields within linguistics, including but not limited to semantics,
> pragmatics, philosophy of language, and language pathology. He is the
> author of several seminal works such as the first textbook on modern
> semantics.
>
> *Tomorrow (Tuesday April 18th)* at *8pm* in *Boylston 105*, Prof. *Gennaro
> Chierchia* is speaking on "The spontaneous logicality of language: How
> language creates meaning".
>
> Please join us for a delightful talk and just as delightful *cookies*!
>
> Xazhy,

1850687201.subject: [Fyre] Intersectional Earth Week: Workshop on Climate Migration this WEDNESDAY
1850687201.text:
HELLO EVERYONE! 

Harvard Act on a Dream and the Coalition for Global Affairs (IOP) invite you to a Workshop on Climate Migration this Wednesday, April 19, at 7PM at the Harvard Foundation (behind Grays Hall in the basement). 

This event is being presented as part of the Harvard Climate Coalition‚Äôs Intersectional Earth Week. At this event we will discuss how climate change has affected the migrant community. Latin America, South Asia, and sub-Saharan Africa are among the regions most vulnerable to the effects of climate change. They could see a large increase in both internal and cross-border migration as a result. Climate migrants have some basic rights under existing international human rights law. However, there‚Äôs a lack of protection afforded to other groups, such as refugees. 

If any of this sounds interesting to you then please come on Wednesday to hear more! There will be empanadas and refreshments and attendants will have the opportunity to create their own butterflies from recycled magazines and pipe cleaners! 


Please join us! All identities welcome ‚ù§Ô∏èüåé 

Ôøº


Warmly, 
Act on a Dream üíô



Eric J. Vasquez Reyes
Harvard University 2025
A.B. in Computer Science
Phone: (609) 672-4236 


_______________________________________________
FYRE mailing list
FYRE@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/fyre

1862264181.subject: [seasclubs] Fwd: US Army Corp of Engineers event announcement
1862264181.text:
Pls send along to your club membership if relevant

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Karasek, Keith R <kkarasek@seas.harvard.edu>
Date: Fri, Apr 21, 2023, 4:08 PM
Subject: US Army Corp of Engineers event announcement
To: DeLucas, Rachel <rachel@seas.harvard.edu>


Hi Rachel,



Could you forward the announcement below to the club presidents:



This is an event that just was scheduled for Monday afternoon, so I need to
get it to students before the next newsletter will go out.  For students
still looking for internships and jobs, this may offer some nice options.
The facilities are located across the US, and it probably applies to most
SEAS concentrations.



*Federal Government and U.S. Army Corps of Engineers‚Äô Virtual Career
Information Session*

Monday, 24 April, 2023

4:30pm - 5:30pm EDT

Link to join:
https://usace1.webex.com/usace1/j.php?MTID=m165b2afab00358cc7154c7c23fe8bead



The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is one of the world‚Äôs premier public
engineering, design, and construction management agencies. We serve the
American people, striving to provide the most effective engineering and
environmental science solutions to the nation‚Äôs complex problems affecting
national security, the economy, and the environment in which we live. In
support of our programs, we hire many environmental science professionals,
biologists, physical scientists, geologists, hydrologists, and many other
civilian positions. It‚Äôs an exciting time to work for USACE. We offer
challenging professional, technical and non-STEM assignments that include
paid summer positions, student internships, developmental and mid-career
opportunities, just to name a few.



Mission Critical Occupations:

   - General Natural Resources Management and Biological Sciences series
   (0401)
   - Engineering Technical series (0802)
   - Construction Control Technical series (0809)
   - Civil Engineering series (0810)
   - Mechanical Engineering series (0830)
   - Electrical Engineering series (0850)
   - Contract Specialist series (1102)
   - Realty series (1170)
   - Lock and Dam Operating series (5426)
   - IT Specialist (2210)



Join us to learn more about USACE and the exciting opportunities we have to
offer!











Keith R. Karasek, PhD (Applied Physics, 1980)
Director of Experiential and Career Development
Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering & Applied Sciences
Science and Engineering Complex LL1.237, 617-495-5073
kkarasek@seas.harvard.edu (primary)

kkarasek@g.harvard.edu (for sharing google docs)
SEAS Career Development <https://www.seas.harvard.edu/career-development>

Calendly Link <https://calendly.com/kkarasek/1-on-1-career-discussion> to
set up a 25-minute appointment

--

1916844926.subject: üíõüíô Sign-Up NOW! Be an ECHO Peer Counselor! üíôüíõ
1916844926.text:
Start your application HERE
<https://streaklinks.com/BeMDF3f2th8rR0LUyg8u-Lhw/https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSeWntw92peY0clFqAmS3SZMiufnpW5R6MYlrqRBabORQKd1OA%2Fviewform%3Fusp%3Dsf_link>
.


ECHO is interviewing for new Fall 2023 staffers!

Are you concerned about body, eating, and exercise issues on campus?

Would you like to support those around you?

Are you a good listener?


You can become an ECHO (Eating Concerns Hotline and Outreach)

 peer counselor ‚Äî no experience needed!

Start your application HERE
<https://streaklinks.com/BeMDF3b1NQeLkXumiw3kbDHM/https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSeWntw92peY0clFqAmS3SZMiufnpW5R6MYlrqRBabORQKd1OA%2Fviewform%3Fusp%3Dsf_link>
.

The application includes a short-answer Google form questionnaire and a
follow up Zoom interview. We would love to have you apply.

The Zoom link is below.

You will log on with the Zoom link here
<https://streaklinks.com/BeMDF3bVFWYv0Shn7g4ltbGo/https%3A%2F%2Fharvard.zoom.us%2Fj%2F96698486573>(and
below) at the time of your interview.

Complete the online form here
<https://streaklinks.com/BeMDF3rEBMxtUiCcgA0q7gJa/https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSeWntw92peY0clFqAmS3SZMiufnpW5R6MYlrqRBabORQKd1OA%2Fviewform%3Fusp%3Dsf_link>
.

Sign up for your interview slot here
<https://streaklinks.com/BeMDF3n6OvtLiRUgSg3N49mW/https%3A%2F%2Fcalendly.com%2Fharvardecho%2Fnew-staffer-interviews-s2023%3Fmonth%3D2023-04>
.

Once you sign-up for a slot, the Zoom link will be: bit.ly/echof23interviews
.

You can also find the link, the application, and any other relevant material on
our website
<https://streaklinks.com/BeMDF3rAgPc2vdZrqwgSbPKG/http%3A%2F%2Fharvardecho.crd.co>
.

*All applications are due at midnight on Sunday, April 23rd.*

ECHO is a peer counseling group that provides a confidential,
non-judgmental, non-directive space for undergraduate students to receive
support about any concern. ECHO specializes in addressing concerns about
exercising, body image, food, eating, and eating disorders.

****

ECHO is committed to training and maintaining a staff that reflects the
diversity of the people who struggle with eating concerns and/or body image
issues on campus. People of color have historically been underrepresented
in ECHO as an organization. In this and as in recent semesters, we are
reaching out to people of as many different backgrounds and experiences as
possible.

No concern is too big or too small.
·êß


--
*Cindy & Darlene*
*Co-Directors of ECHO*
*You deserve support.*
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
*Harvard Eating Concerns Hotline and Outreach*
*Resources at our Linktr.ee <https://linktr.ee/harvardecho>*
*Follow us on Instagram @harvardecho
<https://streaklinks.com/BeMDF3r2doIPnU4kCQmbnPyf/https%3A%2F%2Finstagram.com%2Fharvardecho%2F>*

-- 
*Cindy Wang*
A.B. Degree Candidate in Statistics
Secondary in Global Health and Health Policy
Harvard College '24
845-743-6807
·êß

--

1947984377.subject: [Fyre] Buddhist Concert 4/30
1947984377.text:
[image: image.png]
from Opening Heart Mindfulness
<https://www.openingheartmindfulness.org/events/the-way-out-is-in-music-meditation-spoken-word-events-with-plum-village-monastics-bethesda>

Hi friends / Ch√†o c√°c b·∫°n !!

This Sunday, April 30th, from 7-9PM, a monastic group from the French
monastery Plum Village will be traveling to Boston and performing a
concert, featuring (as advertised) "music, meditation, poetry, and short,
inspiring teachings." They mean to honor Th√≠ch Nh·∫•t H·∫°nh, a giant in the
Buddhist community who recently passed, and will be joined by a local
hip-hop artist.

If you are free and are at all interested, please sign up at the form here
<https://forms.gle/nCTqauEiCMaGDe7M7>. *You absolutely do not have to be
Buddhist to be able to enjoy the experience and share in the community!!* I'm
Buddhist (loosely) and honestly don't know anything about being
Buddhist!! The emotions, lessons, and energy are meant to be universal and
transcend whether or not you identify as Buddhist. It is truly a
once-in-a-lifetime kind of opportunity.

More information about the event can be found here
<https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-way-out-is-in-a-musical-meditation-boston-ma-tickets-546423516447>
 and here
<https://www.lionsroar.com/plum-village-announces-north-american-fundraising-concert-tour/>.
Much love and hope to see some familiar faces there <3

-- 
*Cindy Phan*

*B.A. Candidate in History and Science*
*Harvard '24* | she/her/hers

*M:* (801) 413-9481

1964376985.text:
Hi all,

Please see below for an AP Computer Science A opportunity.

All tutoring opportunities are posted to this *Google Spreadsheet (Std
Tutoring Opps)*
<https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1T3iL7t433tOe7IBzQKyHTXjFzs4DejJk2a7W0VzwBBM/edit?usp=sharing>
 (and updated in real-time) -- please bookmark for future reference!

If you're interested in any tutoring opportunities (or have any questions),
then please respond to this email (tutormatching@princetontutoring.com).

Kind regards,
*Elizabeth*

*AP Computer Science A (Short-term) (Online)*
 #RMJW

   - *FYI: this is a potential opportunity for an interested client. The
   client hasn't signed up yet. We are reaching out to gauge tutor interest.*
   - This 10th grader is self-studying for the AP CompSci A exam, wants
   guidance on how to approach the test.
   - Interests/activities: everything CompSci--coding, creating programs,
   inventing/creating tech, inventions
   - Personality: very outgoing
   - *Logistics:* Online
   - *Frequency: *Ideally 3xs (2hr sessions)
   - *Availability: *Weekday afternoon/evenings & Weekend afternoons
   - *Duration:* Until May 3 test
   - *Session length: *1-2 hrs (hoping for 2 hr sessions)
   - This opportunity pays your standard rate plus $5/hour
   - *Tutor Tier: *Standard

---

*Elizabeth Smith *

Senior Operations Manager
Princeton Tutoring <http://princetontutoring.com/> / PrepMaven
<http://prepmaven.com/>

1965456928.subject: [cs-undergrads] TSMC Seminar - "Science behind Chip Manufacturing" - May 8 at 2:00 pm, Pierce 209
1965456928.text:
Dear SEAS faculty, researchers, and students,

We warmly welcome you to attend a seminar by Jun He, Vice President of Quality and Reliability and Advanced Packaging Technology and Service at TSMC:

‚ÄúScience behind Chip Manufacturing‚Äù seminar by Jun He, TSMC Vice President
Monday, May 8 at 2:00 pm
Pierce Hall 209

TSMC (Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.) is the world‚Äôs largest semiconductor foundry. Semiconductors have become increasingly critical in many aspects of society, and Dr. He will discuss how science enables advanced semiconductor fabrication.

There will be refreshments served after the seminar. More details on the seminar are below and attached.

Best,
David

--
David Hwang, Ph.D.
Dean for Research
Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences

1980412249.subject: [Fyre] Hot Breakfast in the Yard!
1980412249.text:
*TLDR: SEND THIS EMAIL <https://tinyurl.com/hotbrekky> AND SWING BY THE
JOHN HARVARD STATUE ON THE MORNING OF 4/20*


Image Description: Colorful poster advertising Hot Breakfast in the Yard.
Text: "Send a quick email to admin for pancakes before class! Thurs, April
20th 8:30-10:30AM in front of university hall. SLAM and HUDS workers unite
for the return of hot breakfast in the houses‚Äî to improve working
conditions, hours, and student wellbeing."


Hello Hot Breakfast Hotties!

We know you‚Äôre still missing that early morning pancake ‚Äì or you will be
soon, first years (sad face).



The Hot Breakfast Campaign would like to invite you to come and get a free
pancake at our cook-in: Hot Breakfast in the Yard! Swing by the John
Harvard Statue on your way to class between 8:30 and 10 AM on April 20th
(4/20 munchies??) to grab a delicious pancake and send a quick email
<https://tinyurl.com/hotbrekky> to the administration demanding Hot
Breakfast in the Houses!

No student should have to travel long distances or go out of their way just
to get a fulfilling and nutritious meal in the morning, and most of us
don‚Äôt have the time. We shouldn‚Äôt have to skip breakfast or make do with
just pastries and yogurt.

On the other side of the issue, HUDS workers are overwhelmed in Quincy
House and Annenberg by the hundreds of students who swarm the halls for
food throughout the morning, and expanded breakfast in the Houses would
provide more hours for workers trying to support their families on jobs
that aren‚Äôt guaranteed to be 40 hours a week. Harvard has the money to
provide breakfast in more houses, and for the health and wellbeing of its
students and workers, it must.

It takes just 60 seconds to send the email template below, but it lets our
administrators know that students across Harvard really do care about
expanding hot breakfast across Houses, and it shows HUDS workers that
someone is listening. We and unionized HUDS workers really appreciate your
support.

PLEASE SEND THE AUTO-FILLED EMAIL <https://tinyurl.com/hotbrekky> (
https://tinyurl.com/hotbrekky) NOW!

We‚Äôll see you on 4/20 for pancakes in the Yard!

Xoxo,

The Hot Breakfast Campaign

_______________________________________________
FYRE mailing list
FYRE@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/fyre

1986133767.subject: ü§ñ Big Tech roundup
1986133767.text:
‚Ä¶and Boeing‚Äôs delivery setback could spoil the summer travel party
 

When copying TikTok pays off (Drew Angerer/Getty Images)

 
Yesterday‚Äôs Market Moves
 
Dow Jones
33,826 (+1.57%)		S&P 500
4,135 (+1.96%)		Nasdaq
12,142 (+2.43%)		Bitcoin
$29,650 (+4.41%)
Dow Jones
33,826 (+1.57%)		S&P 500
4,135 (+1.96%)
Nasdaq
12,142 (+2.43%)		Bitcoin
$29,650 (+4.41%)

Hey Snackers,

First Taylor Swift, now King Charles: Ticketmaster's caught up in a royal scandal after some fans were told they‚Äôd won free tickets for next week's coronation concert, only to find out the tickets were already gone when they tried to claim them.

Yesterday the S&P 500 had its biggest daily gain since January and the Nasdaq rallied 2.4% as investors digested better-than-feared tech earnings. We also got word the US economy grew slower than expected last quarter.

Recap

Big Techies surge after surprising investors, showing how low expectations have fallen

Scrollin‚Äô with the homies‚Ä¶ Investors sighed after Amazon, Alphabet, Microsoft, and Meta delivered better-than-feared quarterly earnings this week. Those four make up about 15% of the S&P 500, and their results lifted the broader market. ‚ÄúAI‚Äù was a favorite in earnings calls, with Microsoft mentioning it 50 times. Other highlights:

  • Amazon unboxed expectation-beating revenue growth, helped by solid gains in its #ad biz. The Prime padre said AI investments have helped it surface more relevant sponsored listings.

  • Meta spiked 15% after it surprised investors with its first quarterly sales growth in a year and gave upbeat guidance as it served up more ads. Time spent on Instagram surged 24% thanks to AI recs and TikTok-esque Reels.

  • Alphabet popped after the Google parent beat expectations, though ad revenue and profit fell from last year as YouTube advertising sagged.

  • Microsoft also topped estimates, though quarterly sales grew just 7% after previous years of double-digit gains. AI-powered Bing had 100M+ daily users.

From Insta Stories to industry stories‚Ä¶ Tech earnings paint a broader picture of consumer and corporate demand. Some trends:

  • Ad-pocalypse not now? Google said it‚Äôs still suffering from an ad pullback, but Meta pleasantly surprised. Social-media ad growth is expected to accelerate this year.

  • AI on the prize: Meta CEO Zuck said AI recs were boosting social engagement, while Microsoft said bots would drive revenue growth in its productivity tools.

  • Cloud growth is slowing for Google, Amazon, and Microsoft as companies cool their spend, but it held up better than forecast (Google finally turned a cloud profit).

THE TAKEAWAY

Low bars are easier to clear‚Ä¶ Earnings expectations were low, with S&P 500 companies forecast to report the worst profit decline since lockdown-era 2020. After years of double-digit revenue growth being the norm for Big Tech, now investors are cheering baby gains. Meta stock popped to a one-year high despite its profit plunging by nearly $2B.

Delay

Boeing halts some plane deliveries just as summer vacays get ready for takeoff

Plz fix‚Ä¶ A sharp-eyed Boeing employee deserves a bonus after detecting a ‚Äúgnarly‚Äù but hard-to-spot flaw in nearly three-quarters of stored 737 Max jets. Boeing said the defect isn‚Äôt safety-related, but it is putting deliveries of the popular model on hold just as travel heats up.

  • Jet not set: Boeing will deliver fewer planes than planned for the next several months as it addresses the problem.

  • Wing it: The company still expects to meet its annual targets by boosting 737 Max production later this year. Southwest was set to receive 90 Max jets this year, but now expects 70.

  • FYI: In its quarterly earnings this week, Boeing said sales were up 28%, while its loss narrowed as aircraft demand was hot.

Bad timing‚Ä¶ Everyone‚Äôs dreaming of a ‚ÄúWhite Lotus‚Äù summer (minus the drama). The TSA‚Äôs expecting a record-breaking year for flights, and some analysts say this could be the busiest spring ever. Meanwhile, airlines are seeing record summer bookings. Delta's summer flights were 75% reserved as of mid-April, and United Airlines added 24 global routes to meet eat-pray-lovers‚Äô demand. Hilton unpacked strong #s this week as hotel bookings quadrupled worldwide.

THE TAKEAWAY

A perfect storm could rain on travelers‚Ä¶ Booming demand + aircraft delays + staffing shortages + airport congestion = summertime blues. Southwest plans to cut hiring as a result of Boeing‚Äôs delivery delays, even as the industry faces a labor shortage that has NYC airports so short-staffed that airlines are cutting scores of flights. American Airlines‚Äô CEO said this about aircraft-delivery delays: ‚ÄúGuess what? We‚Äôre going out and having to cancel flights.‚Äù

NFTrial

The Crypto Catch-Up‚Ä¶.

üí∞ Costly‚Ä¶ Binance.US backed out of its $1B deal to buy the assets of bankrupt crypto lender Voyager (a fund infusion that would‚Äôve helped it make its customers whole), citing an "uncertain regulatory climate."

üå∂Ô∏è Spicy‚Ä¶ Coinbase said the SEC is making up rules ‚Äúon the fly‚Äù after suing the regulator to force it to issue clearer guidelines. The commission is brewing up its own suit against the US‚Äôs largest crypto exchange.

ü§î Sus‚Ä¶ The first NFT insider-trading case went to trial this week. The suit, which accuses an ex-OpenSea employee of using confidential token-listing info for personal gain, could set a precedent for the unique asset class.

What else we're Snackin'

  • Ban: US senators proposed a bipartisan bill that would ban social media for kids under 13 as mental-health concerns mount. It follows similar tween-focused bills that‚Äôve become law in states like Arkansas and Utah.

  • Jenga: Hasbro shares jumped 15% after the toy legend topped sales expectations, fueled by its card game ‚ÄúMagic: The Gathering.‚Äù Hasbro and rival Mattel also signed cobranded IP deals (like: Barbie Monopoly).

  • Rocked: Here comes the bride slide. Signet Jewelers said sales have slumped as fewer couples get engaged. It‚Äôs a theme: this month wedding icon David‚Äôs Bridal filed for bankruptcy after 70+ years in biz.

  • Skip: NBC's Peacock streamer logged a $700M+ quarterly loss (and expects a $3B annual hit). The plus side: Peacock‚Äôs sales and sign-ups soared, with paid US subs up 60% from last year.

  • Roof: The GOP-led House passed a bill to raise the US debt ceiling by $31.4T. While the Biden admin said it has ‚Äúno chance‚Äù of becoming law, it could spark talks as the default deadline looms.

üç™ Thanks for Snacking with us! Want to share the Snacks? Invite your friends to sign up here.

Snack Fact Of the Day
US job postings fell 15% in the first quarter, with tech roles leading declines
Read more

Friday
  • Earnings expected from Exxon, Chevron, Colgate-Palmolive, and Sony

1988697522.subject: [hcs-d] [RSVP] Tech, product, growth with JAE TAYLOR & PRODUCT LAB!
1988697522.text:
TL;DR tomorrow, April 18th 7pm on Zoom: Fireside chat w/ Jae Taylor (Founder, ex- Peloton, Twitter, Salesforce, Microsoft) on tech/product leadership (RSVP <https://lu.ma/51g12bod>)

Hey friends,

Join HCS Product Lab on a talk about how to break into the current hottest field within tech ~product~, and how to grow within this role in your company :)

Jae has worked as a senior engineering PM @ Microsoft, director of product management @ Salesforce, group PM @ Twitter, and senior director of product and insights @ Peloton among others, and he has so much ~wisdom~ to share.

Grab some dinner and tune in tomorrow, Tuesday, April 18th at 8pm via Zoom ‚Üí RSVP here!! <https://lu.ma/51g12bod>
Cheers,
Aika & folks at HPLüí°

1991541458.subject: [ADAMS] Steelpan Ensemble - INTEREST FORM
1991541458.text:
*TL;DR: Fill out this form
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeaJpidiCWEj613A12dMUwctN-sgXqnQ6X0Rk4Biz_ccVgAQ/viewform?usp=sf_link>
to
support us in forming the first-ever steelpan ensemble on campus!*


*Hey Everyone! *

Do you love music?

Do you think there should be a more diverse range of musical ensembles on
campus?

Do you want to learn to play the steelpan?

[image: Steel Pan.jpeg]

*Fill out the INTEREST FORM
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeaJpidiCWEj613A12dMUwctN-sgXqnQ6X0Rk4Biz_ccVgAQ/viewform?usp=sf_link>
for
the first-ever steelpan ensemble on campus!  *


We are Adam and Elizabeth, two music students here at Harvard. We have both
been playing in steelpan ensembles for many years, and now we want to bring
the joy of pan to campus!
We're still in the process of forming this ensemble, and we need your
help. *Fill
out this form
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeaJpidiCWEj613A12dMUwctN-sgXqnQ6X0Rk4Biz_ccVgAQ/viewform?usp=sf_link>*
to
help us make it happen!

Want to learn more?
*Check out this short video! <https://youtu.be/2OnoTFkb4Hw> *

*FORM LINKED HERE
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeaJpidiCWEj613A12dMUwctN-sgXqnQ6X0Rk4Biz_ccVgAQ/viewform?usp=sf_link>
*

Lots of love,

Adam Bartholomew and Elizabeth Bennett

1992318636.subject: Fwd: Ghungroo 2024 Director App Open Now!
1992318636.text:
DUE IN 3 DAYS!!!! Reach out if you have any questions!!

-grex

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Ghungroo Directors 2023 <ghungroodirectors2023@gmail.com>
Date: Sun, 16 Apr 2023 at 08:00
Subject: Ghungroo 2024 Director App Open Now!
To: Ghungroo Directors 2023 <ghungroodirectors2023@gmail.com>


*Apply to Direct GHUNGROO 2024*
Ghungroo 2024 Director Application: DUE 4/30 at 11:59 pm
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSd0XlMLB7pJF_mYAT7wU3g3ubWlJGnWmd5UA4H9akCHTX_axw/viewform?usp=sf_link>




*üíé Direct Ghungroo 2024 üíé Director Application Open Now!Apps due no later
than Sunday, April 30th @ 11:59pm ET*

Ghungroo is Harvard's largest student-run production, with almost 400 cast
members each year. It centers South Asian and South Asian diaspora culture
through music, dance, spoken word, skit, writing, and visual art. More than
that, Ghungroo is a family, bringing together people from all across
Harvard.

As a director, your responsibilities will be to create and implement a
vision for the show, from envisioning the artistic objectives of the
production to managing and coordinating dancers, choreographers, and other
cast members; select dance directors, music directors, and set designers,
and manage their progress; coordinate with the producers to handle the
logistics of the production. You will also help build the Ghungroo
community as a creative and performing arts space within Harvard's South
Asian community!

If you have any questions at all, or want to chat more about the role,
please do not hesitate to reach out to us!

G-rateful and g-leefully excited to read your applications,
Sarah, Harini, Shraddha
Ghungroo 2023 Directors
Application Link
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSd0XlMLB7pJF_mYAT7wU3g3ubWlJGnWmd5UA4H9akCHTX_axw/viewform?usp=sf_link>
Instagram Page <https://www.instagram.com/harvardghungroo/>

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Danielle Paulson <dpaulson@college.harvard.edu>
Date: Sat, Apr 22, 2023 at 1:56‚ÄØPM
Subject: Fwd: Inclusion and Belonging in Mathematics Panel
To: Krisha Patel <krishapatel@college.harvard.edu>

Dear all,

We'd like to invite you to a panel on Inclusion and Belonging in
Mathematics on Monday, with dinner offered after.  Everyone is welcome to
attend, including students, faculty, and staff.  Please RSVP at this link
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeuhC-Eyx1ggkhPJIaUcsjQwgqRZg8liS3u-8ma7gNxNaqOWQ/viewform?fbclid=IwAR3yLA2J4680pPKBMsaz0SSwvfKlTQcy_cW2nYDXIT75KqJdnBel-DKC03Q>
.

Date: Monday, April 24 from 4:15-5:30pm

Title: Inclusion and Belonging in Mathematics Panel

Location: Science Center Hall B

Description: The student group Harvard Gender Inclusivity in Mathematics
(GIIM) will be hosting a panel on inclusion in mathematics in our
department and beyond. The panelists will speak to the highlights and
challenges they've experienced in mathematics, especially as mathematicians
from underrepresented groups.  There will be some preset questions, but we
will also encourage the audience to ask questions throughout.

List of panelists:

- Robin Gottlieb (professor)

- Hakim Walker (preceptor)

- Theo McKenzie (postdoc)

- Isabel Longbottom (graduate student)

- Clair Xinle Dai (graduate student)

- Hana Lang (undergraduate student)

- S√≠lvia Casacuberta (undergraduate student)

- Moderators: Danielle Paulson and Dora Woodruff

All the best,


HUGIIM (Harvard Undergraduate Gender Inclusivity in Mathematics)

-- 
www.harvardwics.com
With questions/concerns/anything at all we can help with, reach out to Rachna or Karen! (rachnagupta / karen_li @ college.harvard.edu)

2027370100.subject: [ADAMS] SCR Book Talk! Tomorrow 8pm LCR!
2027370100.text:
Hi Schmooze

Tomorrow at 8pm in the LCR we will be hosting SCR member Justin Gest as he
talks about his new book, *Majority Minority*.

More info below and see you there!

Santi


*Majority Minority: How will America respond to demographic change?*

How do societies respond to great demographic change? This question lingers
over the contemporary politics of many countries where persistent
immigration has altered populations and may soon produce a majority
minority milestone, where the original ethnic or religious majority loses
its numerical advantage to one or more foreign-origin minority groups.
Until now, most of our knowledge about large-scale responses to demographic
change has been based on studies of individual people‚Äôs reactions, which
tend to be instinctively defensive and intolerant. We know little about why
and how these habits are sometimes tempered to promote more sustainable
coexistence. In *Majority Minority*, Justin Gest wields polling research,
historical analysis, and interview-based fieldwork inside six of the
world‚Äôs few societies that have already experienced a majority minority
transition to understand what factors produce different social outcomes.
Grounded in rich narratives and surprising survey findings, *Majority
Minority* reveals that this contentious milestone and its accompanying
identity politics are ultimately subject to unifying or divisive governance.

*Justin Gest <http://justingest.com/>* is an Associate Professor of Policy
and Government at George Mason University‚Äôs Schar School of Policy and
Government. He is the author of six books, primarily on the politics of
immigration and demographic change‚Äîall from Oxford University Press or
Cambridge University Press. He has also provided commentary, analysis, or
reporting to a number of broadcast networks, including ABC, BBC, CBC, CNN,
and NPR, and news publications including *The Boston Globe*, *The Guardian*
, *Los Angeles Times*, *The New York Times*, POLITICO, Reuters, *The Times*,
and *The Washington Post*. From 2010 to 2014, Professor Gest was a
postdoctoral fellow and lecturer in Harvard University‚Äôs Departments of
Government and Sociology. From 2007 to 2010, he co-founded and served as
the co-director of the Migration Studies Unit at the London School of
Economics and Political Science (LSE).

[image: MM - Cover.jpeg]

2030632640.subject: [hcs-d] [HCS AI x HUMIC] Apply for Harvard AI Vision Fellowship (Summer 2023)
2030632640.text:
The Harvard AI Vision Fellowship will run this summer with the goal of
enabling Harvard students to explore and apply themselves to topics
relevant to AI, with greater resources and a strong support network.

Vision Fellows will have the opportunity to:

   -

   Work on independent projects of their interest, from technical
   applications to econ/policy research
   -

   Learn about various fields and interdisciplinary approaches in AI (e.g.,
   econ, law, engineering, ethics)
   -

   Discuss recent developments in AI with invited speakers and leaders in
   industry and academia
   -

   Connect with other students working at the cutting edge (weekly/biweekly
   remote fellows group)


The fellowship expects a commitment of 5-10 hours per week on
projects/development. Those more heavily involved in larger projects, such
as in research at Harvard or startups, may also apply, though no preference
is given to either type. AI experience is not needed to apply.

Applications for the Vision Fellowship are available now and will close May
10 at 11:59 ET.

Application link: bit.ly/visionfellows
More information: hcsaigroup.org/visionfellows

2038220985.subject: üéµ Fake Drake, real problems
2038220985.text:
‚Ä¶and Ikea‚Äôs $2B American dream
 

Champagne Papi meets AI copies (Frazer Harrison/Getty Images)

 
Yesterday‚Äôs Market Moves
 
Dow Jones
33,787 (-0.33%)		S&P 500
4,130 (-0.60%)		Nasdaq
12,060 (-0.80%)		Bitcoin
$28,239 (-1.98%)
Dow Jones
33,787 (-0.33%)		S&P 500
4,130 (-0.60%)
Nasdaq
12,060 (-0.80%)		Bitcoin
$28,239 (-1.98%)

Hey Snackers,

Move over, Great Pacific Garbage Patch. There's a new ocean blob in town: 13M tons of floating sargassum (think: gassy seaweed) threatens to stink up Florida and Caribbean beach vacays this summer. Don't forget to pack the nose plugs.

The Nasdaq slipped yesterday, weighed down by a 10% drop in Tesla after disappointing earnings. Meanwhile, underwhelming midsize-bank earnings tugged down the banking sector.

Drizzy

An AI-generated ‚ÄúDrake‚Äù song raises alarm bells for labels like Universal Music

Nice for bot‚Ä¶ ICYMI: an AI-generated song featuring the voices of Drake and The Weeknd went viral this week. ‚ÄúHeart on My Sleeve,‚Äù posted on TikTok by a bed-sheet-clad user called Ghostwriter977, racked up millions of streams across YouTube, Spotify, Apple Music, and other platforms. The ghostwriter said they wrote and produced the verses for the AI-generated vocals. Then came the takedowns:

  • Universal Music Group, the world‚Äôs largest label, which reps Drake and The Weeknd, had the song removed from platforms.

  • Legal verse: Universal said ‚Äúthe training of generative AI using our artists‚Äô music‚Äù violates copyright law and that ‚Äúwe will not hesitate to take steps to protect our rights and those of our artists.‚Äù

Fake Drake(s) aren‚Äôt the only problem‚Ä¶ Universal was quick to act, but now another Drake fake (‚ÄúWinter‚Äôs Cold‚Äù) has hit the internet. Labels like UMG, Warner Music Group, and Sony Music have been effective in aggressively protecting their music (think: YouTube videos and Insta stories being taken down or demonetized). Platforms like YouTube scan videos to see whether they contain copyrighted content, so identification is nearly instant. But AI tracks could be harder to spot. For consumers, it‚Äôs also tough to know if a track is authentic because Auto-Tune (used to synthetically improve tracks) is so prevalent.

THE TAKEAWAY

It may be endless Whac-A-Mole‚Ä¶ until hard rules are established for AI-generated content. Copyright issues will likely keep popping up, and not just for the music industry: media publishers are said to be gearing up for a showdown with Microsoft, Google, and OpenAI, demanding compensation for use of their articles. Meanwhile, AI-art lawsuits could set precedents for bots trained on copyrighted artwork.

Balling

As the home-furnishing boom fades, Ikea‚Äôs splurging $2B to take over American living rooms

Meatballs and measuring tape‚Ä¶ Yesterday Ikea said it would invest $2.2B to build up its US biz ‚Äî its biggest investment ever in a single country. Over the next three years, it plans to roll out 17 new stores, creating 2K+ US jobs. The Swedish sofa king also plans to bulk up its fulfillment centers. It notched record sales last year and has slowly grown its market share in the US (its second-largest market by sales after Germany). Now Ikea‚Äôs hoping its trendy ‚Äúlow cost, high quality‚Äù furniture will turn the US into its top market.

  • DIY: Ikea‚Äôs planning to open nine "plan and order points," studios where shoppers can meet with specialists to design their dream home (but have the furniture delivered).

The great home retreat‚Ä¶ (not the relaxing kind). Home-furnishing spend has plunged since the pandemic as people ditch home-office builds for Cabo trips. Furniture-store sales generally dipped 2.4% in March from a year ago. The slowdown is starting to nail some of Ikea‚Äôs rivals: last quarter, Home Depot missed its sales expectations for the first time since 2019. TJX's HomeGoods saw a 4% sales dip, and Bed Bath & Beyond is reportedly days from filing for bankruptcy. Online furniture retailer Wayfair lost 5M customers last year and posted a $1.3B loss.

THE TAKEAWAY

One brand‚Äôs loss is another brand‚Äôs opportunity‚Ä¶ Ikea‚Äôs US biz alone racked up nearly $6B in sales last year, attracting some 70M shoppers in stores and about 500M visits online as it kept prices stable compared to rivals. Now, as competitors like Wayfair cut jobs and scale back, Ikea‚Äôs doubling down to grow its market share.

VACAY

The Crypto Catch-Up‚Ä¶

üìú Policy‚Ä¶ European lawmakers approved sweeping crypto regs (meet: MiCA) that are expected to take effect this summer. The rules will allow registered companies to operate across the EU, and have been hailed by crypto cos. About that‚Ä¶

üå∂Ô∏è Spicy‚Ä¶ Coinbase's CEO said the biz might exit the US in search of greener regulatory pastures, and that a move to the UK is "on the table." The exod-US isn't all bluster: Coinbase reportedly plans to launch an offshore exchange.

üß≥ Movin'‚Ä¶ Kraken's been hit with the travel bug too. The exchange, which earlier this year agreed to a $30M SEC settlement and killed its staking program, scored a license to operate in Ireland.

What else we're Snackin'

  • Setback: SpaceX's uncrewed Starship rocket (the most powerful ever built) exploded minutes after liftoff, failing to reach orbit. Employees still cheered that it cleared the launchpad.

  • Charged: Footage appearing to show an electric Ford F-150 on fire has reignited worries about the hotter, longer blazes that EV batteries can cause. Extinguishing the flames can take hours and may require new methods.

  • AI-xpense: ChatGPT may cost OpenAI up to $700K/day to run thanks to the colossal computing power and pricey servers needed to keep it writing essays. To cut costs, Microsoft is developing an in-house AI chip.

  • Scraping: SL Green, NYC‚Äôs largest office-property owner, has struggled with hybrid-work norms and reported 10% less cash flow than expected. To keep spaces full, it‚Äôs offered new tenants almost five months rent-free.

  • Pivot: BuzzFeed said it would lay off 15% of staff and shut down BuzzFeed News, while Insider announced a 10% cut. A shrinking ad market has rocked the media industry.

By German Lopez
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/saAPzCAXqBiGgHXJ-IS3uw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJOxnP0S8aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZ2VybWFuLWxvcGV6P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjEmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTA3MTkmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMDk5MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD5nZ0Jk664a_lIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]

Good morning. A.I. does not have to be perfect or have human-level intelligence
to be useful.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/21/multimedia/21themorning-lede-tpkb/21themorning-lede-tpkb-jumbo.jpg]OpenAI
offices in San Francisco.Jim Wilson/The New York Times


SAVING TIME

For most people, ChatGPT is more of a toy than a tool. You can ask it silly
questions, but it‚Äôs not robust enough to write high-quality work memos or school
essays. Yet the people behind artificial intelligence programs believe these
systems will someday become a regular part of our lives, helping us in
day-to-day routines.

How? Some type of A.I. will usher in that reality not because it will be perfect
or display human-level intelligence. It will simply perform a task better than
people can now. We don‚Äôt yet know what that task or the piece of A.I. will be.
Perhaps it will be a task that seems small but nonetheless takes up time, like
writing an email response or organizing a schedule. Or it could be bigger, such
as driving a car. Either way, the shift will be enough to get the public to
widely adopt it.

Phone cameras are a useful analogy. They typically take lower quality
photographs than stand-alone cameras. But most people have embraced them because
they are so convenient, packaged in devices most of us carry everywhere. That
sort of usefulness is a much lower bar for A.I. to meet than creating the kind
of all-knowing, all-doing A.I. depicted in science fiction.

Then, widespread adoption could help A.I. rapidly improve further. The
technology is built on data. And the more people use A.I., the more data
developers can collect to adapt their programs. Today‚Äôs newsletter will look at
how that future could start.


BETTER, NOT PERFECT

There is a pithy way to describe how technology progresses: It has to be better,
not perfect.

One example is A.I. that can code. People who don‚Äôt know how to code already use
bots to produce full-fledged games, as my colleagues Francesca Paris and Larry
Buchanan explained
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/3nLKUmob7A8IVWDwbkOZ1A~~/AAAAAQA~_lIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~].
And some professional programmers use A.I. to supplement their work.

The current technology is imperfect. It can make mistakes, and it struggles with
more complicated tasks or programs. But the same is true for human coders.
‚ÄúHumans are not perfect at many of the tasks they perform,‚Äù said Helen Toner, a
director at Georgetown University‚Äôs Center for Security and Emerging Technology.

By this standard, coding bots do not have to be flawless to replace existing
work. They merely have to save time. A human coder could then use that extra
time to improve on the A.I.‚Äôs work, brainstorm other ideas for programs or do
something else entirely.


UNINTENDED CONSEQUENCES

A.I. outcomes won‚Äôt always be good. With phone cameras, people sacrifice photo
quality for convenience. The trade-offs could be more consequential with
artificial intelligence.

Consider an A.I. that can write well. At first, the quality might fall short of
writing you can do yourself. Still, like a coding A.I., it could give you time
that you could use to sharpen the draft, focus on research or complete a
different task.

But this bot also might not care about some qualities that humans value. Perhaps
it will spin out falsehoods that some writers won‚Äôt catch before publishing
online. Or bad actors could use A.I. to create and distribute well-written
disinformation more efficiently.

In other words, what an A.I. does can fail to align with its creators‚Äô or users‚Äô
goals. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very general technology that‚Äôs going to be used for so many
things,‚Äù Katja Grace, an A.I. safety researcher, said. ‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs much harder to
anticipate all the ways that you might be training it to do something that could
be harmful.‚Äù

Here‚Äôs a real-world example: Ted Rall, a political cartoonist, recently asked
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/NZDI0aygXkLY_BikfXpdkg~~/AAAAAQA~-Z2dCZOuuGv5SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
ChatGPT to describe his relationship with Scott Stantis, another cartoonist. It
falsely suggested Stantis had accused Rall of plagiarism in 2002 and that both
of them had a public feud. None of this happened.

But current A.I. technologies frequently produce these kinds of tall tales ‚Äî
what experts call hallucinations ‚Äî when asked about real people or events.
Experts aren‚Äôt sure why. One potential explanation is that these systems are
primarily programmed to put out convincing, conversational writing, not to
distinguish fact from fiction. As similar A.I. replaces human tasks or current
technologies (such as search engines), the falsehoods could mislead many more
people.


EXPONENTIAL GROWTH

A.I. is developing incredibly quickly. The computing power behind the technology
has grown exponentially for decades, and experts expect it to continue doing so.
As impressive as GPT-4 is
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/D-DRHNH8H9dxmAE0PUCeNA~~/AAAAAQA~-Z2dCZOuuGv5SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~],
we could plausibly get A.I. programs that are many times as powerful in the span
of years.

This technology is developing so quickly that lawmakers and other regulators
have been unable to keep up. More than 1,000 tech leaders and researchers
recently called for a pause on A.I. development to establish safety standards.
So far, there is no sign those calls have been heeded. Tech companies like
Google and Microsoft have instead resisted internal dissent
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/wW2Sio-gBTxuxGzm2nHIcA~~/AAAAAQA~-Z2dCZOuuGv5SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
against releasing their A.I. programs and have pushed them out to the public as
quickly as possible.


FOR MORE

 * Here are 35 ways people are using A.I. right now
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/3nLKUmob7A8IVWDwbkOZ1A~~/AAAAAQA~_lIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~],
   including planning workouts and writing a wedding speech.
 * A.I.‚Äôs potential impact is too sweeping for governments to take a hands-off
   approach, Ezra Klein argues in Times Opinion
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/o5tlCDXm6IuESgm4hfgUsw~~/AAAAAQA~-Z2dCZOuuGv5SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].

POP IN THE DESERT

Today is the start of the second weekend of Coachella, the California festival
that has grown into one of the biggest annual events for pop music and celebrity
sightings. Some highlights from the first weekend:

 * Blackpink became the first K-pop act to headline the festival, delivering a
   90-minute set that The Guardian
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/4TtwJPOtMX2dSU5bZPQKgw~~/AAAAAQA~_lIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
   described as a ‚Äúhigh-octane stream of pop bangers.‚Äù
 * The pop-punk band Blink-182 surprised fans with a reunion show, playing
   together for the first time in almost a decade.
 * The most divisive performance came from Frank Ocean, who reimagined his songs
   in new styles. Variety
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/gw-ijThFwuRMpIPwdgK1Fw~~/AAAAAQA~_lIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]

2053453808.subject: "Gift" by¬†Hilda Conkling
2053453808.text:
This is mint and here are three pinks

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 23, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** Gift (http://poets.org/poem/gift-6?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
Hilda Conkling (https://poets.org/poet/hilda-conkling?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID)

This is mint and here are three pinks
I have brought you, Mother.
They are wet with rain
And shining with it.
The pinks smell like more of them
In a blue vase:
The mint smells like summer
In many gardens.

This poem is in the public domain. Published in Poem-a-Day on April 23, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS1337186115.mp3?updated=1681318810&mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID

‚ÄúGift‚Äù appears in Hilda Conkling (https://poets.org/poet/hilda-conkling?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID) ‚Äôs first collection, Poems by a Little Girl (Frederick A. Stokes Company, 1920). According to the table of contents, ‚ÄúGift‚Äù was composed by Conkling when she was between the ages of seven and nine years old. In her preface to the collection, Amy Lowell (https://poets.org/poet/amy-lowell?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID) writes, after listing ‚ÄúGift‚Äù among the book‚Äôs most successful poems, that ‚Äú[s]he probably hardly thought at all, so natural was it, to say that three pinks ‚Äòsmell like more of them in a blue vase,‚Äô but the expression fills the air with so strong a scent that no superlative could increase it. ‚ÄòGift‚Äô is a lovely poem, it has feeling, expression, originality, cadence. If a child can write such a poem at eight years old, what does it mean? That depends, I think, on how long the instructors of youth can be persuaded to keep ‚Äòhands off.‚Äô A period of imitation is, I fear, inevitable, but if consciousness is not induced by direct c
riticism, if instruction in the art of writing is abjured, the imitative period will probably be got [sic] through without undue loss. I think there is too much native sense of beauty and proportion here to be entirely killed even by the drying and freezing process which goes by the name of education.‚Äù
https://poets.org/poet/hilda-conkling?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID

Hilda Conkling (https://poets.org/poet/hilda-conkling?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID) was born in New York State in 1910. Her poetry, which she composed between the ages of four and fourteen, is collected in Poems by a Little Girl (Frederick A. Stokes Company, 1920), Shoes of the Wind (Frederick A. Stokes Company, 1922), and Silverhorn, the Hilda Conkling Book for Other Children (Frederick A. Stokes Company, 1924). Hilda‚Äôs mother, poet Grace Hazard Conkling (https://poets.org/poet/grace-hazard-conkling?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID) , transcribed all of Hilda‚Äôs poems, which Hilda ceased composing altogether in her adulthood. She died on June 26, 1986.

https://poets.org/poet/hilda-conkling?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://archive.org/details/poemsbylittlegir0000hild/page/n9/mode/2up?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID

Poems by a Little Girl (https://archive.org/details/poemsbylittlegir0000hild/page/n9/mode/2up?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID)
(Frederick A. Stokes Company, 1920)

https://archive.org/details/poemsbylittlegir0000hild/page/n9/mode/2up?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID

‚ÄúThe Little Dandelion‚Äù by Lula Lowe Weeden
read more (https://poets.org/poem/little-dandelion?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID)
‚Äú[A cloud of flowers!]‚Äù by Matsuo Basho
read more (https://poets.org/poem/cloud-flowers?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID)
http://pcm23.eventbrite.com?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID
Thanks to U.S. poet laureate Ada Lim√≥n (https://poets.org/poet/ada-limon?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID) , author of The Hurting Kind (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781639550494?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID)  (Milkweed Editions, 2022), who curated Poem-a-Day for this month‚Äôs weekdays. As of this year, the U.S. poet laureate guest editorship during National Poetry Month (https://poets.org/library-congress-and-poem-day?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a collaboration between the Academy and the Library of Congress. Read or listen to a Q&A (https://poets.org/April-2023-poem-a-day-editor-ada-limon?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID)  about Lim√≥n‚Äôs curatorial approach and find out more about our guest editors for the year (https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=4cbb5e9a7b&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

‚ÄúPoem-a-Day is brilliant because it makes space in the everyday racket for something as meaningful as a poem.‚Äù ‚ÄîTracy K. Smith

https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=743a47cfd6961a9c21072f778b4f746e1d9a0f3b9e9df14e9d79ac941e145479a3d8d4b379dd606665bca40140432ab3e13da21a2e64bc47
