 After living through all manner of personal and communal tribulations, I‚Äôve come to believe things will work themselves out. Yet, it‚Äôs not that the worries have gone away. Just like in my early days, I‚Äôve learned to find ways to ease the burdens and uneasiness of living. Of course, I‚Äôm not trying to find a fully anxiety-free existence; it‚Äôs good to have a barking dog occasionally at one‚Äôs heels. I just try to walk past it when I need to.       

   
— Major

Worry (the Dybbuk)
 by Anthony Immergluck



I have a worry mother and

I have a worry father and

once they shared a worry and

my own worry a sprout in

this worry dirt, bullied by 

the worry weeds, spoiled by

the worry sun and rain and

I the runt among a litter of

suckling worries and the 

worry is the current and 

we are its conductors and

the worry is the currency we

interchange on holidays and 

the worry is the ribbon of

rot running deep in the

center of a chestnut and

my worry and another

worry said Ido to worry and

we warm our tea with

worry and we wonder if 

there ever was and ever

could be a home with

no worry chewing through

the attic and we wonder how

a shoulder might shoulder un-

burdened by this dybbuk and

I worry that were we to

land on an island without

worry our worries would

starve or worse, survive

on each other’s meat and

I worry that the worry is

the best of us after all

I only ever held a worry

hand and I only ever ate

a worry pastry and I don’t 

know why I told a worry

child not to worry when

surely the trick is to give

the worry a name and then

to call it again and again.

"Worry (The Dybbuk)" by Anthony Immergluck. Used by permission of the poet.

2091350778.text:
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=33493560c021dea1d26b2abc479e4581ac2c8c464ca926bde9a526692413b2743c82ccb65dc8414a3abe676f0f1b9d1f78cb35bcd109ffa3

Give Now 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=33493560c021dea1e468f23a5967cc95ef561ba1db46a70fbd93d7e9d402615c96b9a8cf49cc39b78e5992575439576791120f86625e5362 
“I read the daily poems from The Slowdown with my morning coffee. These poems are a gift.” - Richarda E. 





 In the spirit of Walt Whitman who heard the chorus of voices that made America and its geography, today‚Äôs poem continues the rich tradition of celebrating a poetry of place, utterly unique and rich for its ability to cultivate its poets to sing our land into our literary record.       

   
— Major

Diving at Blue Hole
 by Ally H. Young


In Wimberley, Texas, there is a hole in the sandstone someone has called definitely deep blue. Bluebon-

 nets grow on the road up to it and lost mountain bluebirds fly around and in it in concentric circles.

 Tourists drop things in the freshwater and leave with new things that are harder to name like how do

 you name your own blue? As a child I tried not to lie. I had little to say about the screaming cow-bird

 and I didn’t care about what it might like to eat. Mice, I might have guessed. Snakes. Or small-

 er birds, like blue jays. But it seemed often just as true that ravens might subsist solely on the wind from

 plumper birds, on their even more indigo hearts, that they might devour nightly the full blue apexes of

 constellations, tear Saturn apart at her ripe cerulean center. I dreamed of it. My name, Little Blue

 Heron. Little and blue like whatever is sky is blue, like whatever is not is a Greater Blue Heron, landing,

 just for a moment, on the creaking rink of a half frozen lake.

"Diving at Blue Hole" by Allyson Young. Used by permission of the poet.

We are thrilled to announce that the Office of Career Services has been renamed the Mignone Center for Career Success, in honor of the generous support of the Mignone family. Author Headshot
[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/01/13/reader-center/author-german-lopez/author-german-lopez-blogSmallThumb-v2.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/CNZCufl75C6E7rba5_xyQA~~/AAAAAQA~~~

By German Lopez
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/CNZCufl75C6E7rba5_xyQA~~/AAAAAQA~~~]

Good morning. A lawsuit against Fox News could help decide the boundaries of
press freedom.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/12/multimedia/17themorning-lede/17themorning-lede-jumbo.jpg]Times
Square.John Taggart for The New York Times


A FIRST AMENDMENT CASE

Starting tomorrow, Fox News is scheduled to be on trial
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/d52Yx8bosOe_n4RXjJjOyg~~/AAAAAQA~~~].
Dominion Voting Systems, which makes voting machines, is suing the cable news
network for $1.6 billion. Dominion claims that Fox spread a false conspiracy
theory that its machines were rigged against Donald Trump in the 2020 election.

The trial had been set to start today, but the judge overseeing the case
announced a one-day delay last night. Fox may be seeking to settle the case
before a trial can begin, The Wall Street Journal reported
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/ixqyw7NRComeTLQ7lyQgog~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmH6hzP0T_~].

We have already seen some of the evidence for Dominion‚Äôs side. Texts and emails
uncovered through the lawsuit show that several of Fox‚Äôs executives, hosts and
producers privately doubted the claims against Dominion, which were promoted by
Trump, but amplified them on the air anyway.

Even with this evidence, Dominion may not have an easy time winning the case
because of legal protections for media companies. Those protections were
established by a 1964 Supreme Court ruling, New York Times v. Sullivan, based on
the First Amendment‚Äôs safeguards for freedom of speech and the press. The ruling
requires that defamation lawsuits by public figures against media companies
prove ‚Äúactual malice,‚Äù meaning that journalists must have known an allegation
was false but broadcast it anyway or have acted so recklessly that they
overlooked the facts.

‚ÄúIt is an incredibly high bar to prove,‚Äù said my colleague Katie Robertson, who
is covering the lawsuit.

The case will test whether Fox‚Äôs brand of journalism ‚Äî which includes a long
record of spreading falsehoods
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/PTexZmPPFw82mbr9teN2Hw~~/AAAAAQA~~]
(such as about where Barack Obama was born) ‚Äî is legally vulnerable. Today‚Äôs
newsletter will look at both sides of the case and its broader implications.


WHAT IS DOMINION‚ÄôS ARGUMENT?

There is no doubt that Trump‚Äôs allegations against Dominion were false. The
judge overseeing the case
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/OHydHx1Fv_d0PgpogbKg7w~~/AAAAAQA~~~],
Eric Davis of the Delaware Superior Court, has already ruled that Dominion won‚Äôt
have to prove that the claims were wrong during the trial. Its task will be
proving actual malice, as well as proving financial damage because of the
coverage.

To do that, Dominion will point to a trove of texts, emails and other documents
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/3TBa8bKHr2l65n4tIXmOWQ~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
showing that Fox News‚Äôs leaders and hosts doubted the claims against Dominion
but aired them anyway.

Referring to claims that Dominion‚Äôs software rigged the election, Tucker Carlson
texted his producer, Alex Pfeiffer, that the idea was ‚Äúabsurd.‚Äù He also texted
that Sidney Powell, one of Trump‚Äôs lawyers, was ‚Äúlying.‚Äù Yet Carlson later
argued on his show, ‚ÄúThis is a real issue no matter who raises it or who tries
to dismiss it out of hand as a conspiracy theory.‚Äù

Why did Carlson do this? It seems the answer has to do with his audience.
Carlson initially cast doubt on Powell‚Äôs claims on air, saying, ‚ÄúShe never
demonstrated that a single actual vote was moved illegitimately by software from
one candidate to another. Not one.‚Äù His audience revolted
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/Xt9X-RldbYPtJ2B4Y6NYAA~~/AAAAAQA~~~],
criticizing him for questioning a Trump ally. Carlson then walked back his
public skepticism on air.

It‚Äôs a recurring theme in the texts and emails. Fox‚Äôs leaders and hosts
expressed doubt about the conspiracy theory in private, but they also raised
concerns about ‚Äúrespecting our audience.‚Äù To avoid losing viewers to competitors
like Newsmax, Fox hosts and producers seemingly chose to broadcast and support
the claims by Trump and his allies.


WHAT IS FOX NEWS‚ÄôS ARGUMENT?

Fox News previously¬†argued that even though it knew the claims against Dominion
were false, it had to cover them anyway because they were newsworthy. But Judge
Davis has ruled that Fox won‚Äôt be able to make that argument in the trial. ‚ÄúJust
because someone is newsworthy,‚Äù he said, referring to Trump and his lawyers,
‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt mean you can defame someone.‚Äù

Without that argument, Fox has focused on others. The network argues that
Dominion still needs to prove that Fox‚Äôs hosts ‚Äî who ultimately decide what to
air ‚Äî knew the claims were false and broadcast them anyway. And Fox claims that
at least some of the hosts genuinely believed the allegations and therefore were
not intentionally defaming anyone.

Mostly, though, Fox is relying on Dominion failing to clear the high legal
standard established by New York Times v. Sullivan. Dominion, not Fox, has the
burden of proof.

Legal experts have said that Dominion‚Äôs case is stronger than most defamation
lawsuits but that the company still may not win. ‚ÄúProving this in a legal sense
is more complicated than proving it in the court of public opinion,‚Äù said my
colleague Jim Rutenberg, who wrote a Times Magazine article about the case
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/PTexZmPPFw82mbr9teN2Hw~~/AAAAAQA~~].


WHAT ARE THE IMPLICATIONS?

Fox News argues that if it loses, the case will do irreparable damage to press
freedoms, opening all news outlets to lawsuits. ‚ÄúA free-flowing, robust American
discourse depends on First Amendment protections for the press‚Äô news gathering
and reporting,‚Äù a network spokesperson said in a statement.

Some legal experts argue the opposite, saying that a loss for Fox could bolster
protections for the press. Fox‚Äôs actions in covering the 2020 election were so
egregious, the argument goes, that any legal standard that protected them would
be no standard at all: For First Amendment protections to endure, news
organizations need to be held accountable for knowingly spreading false and
damaging information.

Lofi Girl
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/-V45l1GSJiZhV6SmzfyYAQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmH6hzP0TUaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cueW91dHViZS5jb20vd2F0Y2g_~~]
is a YouTube channel with more than 12 million subscribers that airs constant
streams of lo-fi hip-hop music: ambient, usually lyricless tunes with relaxed
beats. The style grew popular on YouTube in the 2010s, and listeners often play
lo-fi music to relax or boost focus.

As part of a campaign to promote the channel‚Äôs newest livestream, Lofi Girl
herself ‚Äî a Studio Ghibli-style animated character, writing at her desk ‚Äî now
has a friend: Lofi Boy. He lives across the street from her and plays computer
games with a dog by his side. For more, read how lo-fi streams became a popular
alternative

-138872291.text:
https://view.hu.harvard.edu/?qs=85be12f3c216ee8e343bbc28a618e9f79a2257e3b18caa5abf9b0ded4b0047dc5f89b37b7769879167b78c26ac6f638accc0467df89483bdfb5d73fe3024ea8ebc275dd2f88c82d9fa51386aa1814c39 
View this email in your browser .

Harvard College Class of 2023


Dear Class of 2023,


Do you want to learn how to stay connected to your classmates and Harvard as alumni? Wondering what the difference is between a Club and a Shared Interest Group? Looking for a mentor who has been in your shoes?

https://click.hu.harvard.edu/?qs=ece201510ad8585ea8041409163c7a2bab87f0126bd3a7789692bcab42d1a8d055f4dc610be9628ab5e4096c3cba5e596ef80fc26aba5666 
Come learn  about the many communities, resources, and volunteer opportunities available to you as alumni at the Harvard Alumni Association Alumni Life Orientation session on Tuesday, April 25, from 4:00 to 4:45 p.m.

https://click.hu.harvard.edu/?qs=ece201510ad8585ea8041409163c7a2bab87f0126bd3a7789692bcab42d1a8d055f4dc610be9628ab5e4096c3cba5e596ef80fc26aba5666 
Register Now 

We’ll also give an overview of Senior Week and Commencement Week (and Senior Desk) and review frequently asked questions.
Zoom links and calendar holds will be sent to registrants before the sessions.



Sincerely,

Your 2023 Class Committee


 
 

 
 

 Your HAA ID number is: 0005007233

-1292322604.subject: [cs-undergrads] Reminder: CA application for select SEAS courses-apply by 4/19 for full consideration
-1292322604.text:
Hello: A reminder to complete the application by Wednesday for full consideration. The application will remain open after that date but instructors have access after Wednesday.
Sarah

From: Colgan, Sarah <scolgan@seas.harvard.edu>
Sent: Wednesday, April 5, 2023 1:00 PM
To: seas-undergrads@seas.harvard.edu
Subject: [cs-undergrads] CA application for select SEAS courses-apply by 4/19 for full consideration

Dear SEAS undergraduate students,

Are you interested in working on the teaching staff for a SEAS course this fall?

SEAS is hiring Course Assistants (CAs, often referred to in SEAS as TFs) for Fall 2023. Typical responsibilities for this position include, but are not limited to, leading discussion or laboratory sections, holding office hours, answering student questions on course content, grading assignments, maintaining the course website, and attending course meetings. Applicants who have a strong interest in or understanding of the course material (for example, who took the course and received an A- or an A) are encouraged to apply.

To apply to select SEAS courses in AM, AP, Eng Sci and ESE, please complete this form: https://forms.gle/HVspeZKpPcn1KU3aA<https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__forms.gle_HVspeZKpPcn1KU3aA&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=oUO5mwpQ-aFXjiroqfBYXBwsDriw25PVAWN3XaQ0GU4&m=BnLxU4GsdN8C5mb7ajN0fHsiGc66BRCyxZV0kp5leNWxcHdNDWDmZqhcQVGar6p7&s=W9odL6NxVzXtbBUeStMYY0DAFpPYOksfGiblTG_K9Zg&e=>
Please note that not all courses that have open positions are included in the application, and CS courses have a separate application process (see email from Adam Hesterberg).

The application form requires a reference name, a CV, an unofficial transcript, and any previous CA evaluations. Applications will be reviewed on a rolling basis, with full consideration guaranteed for applications submitted by April 19. Some courses may guarantee full consideration for applications submitted later.
There are various teaching fellow roles available, depending on the course. Start and end dates are to be determined, but these are fall term appointments. These positions are supervised by the instructor of record and all positions are in-person in Fall 2023 in Cambridge or Allston. The pay rate is $23/hour and pay is distributed weekly. A standard CA position is for 10 hours/week averaged over the appointment period.

Harvard students who fill these roles would be eligible for membership in the Harvard Graduate Student Union (HGSU-UAW). SEAS is dedicated to building a diverse community of individuals who are committed to contributing to an inclusive environment. Some of our core values include respect for all, serving the greater good, and welcoming individuals from diverse backgrounds, experiences, and perspectives. We are an equal opportunity employer, and all qualified applicants will receive consideration for employment without regard to race, color, religion, sex, national origin, disability status, protected veteran status, gender identity, sexual orientation, pregnancy and pregnancy-related conditions, or any other characteristic protected by law.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Sarah
---
Sarah Colgan
Academic Programs Administrator | she/her/hers
Office of Academic Programs | P: 617-496-1524
Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences
On campus: M, Tu, Th; remote: W, F

Be sure to take advantage of one of the following options by our deadline of May 1st!

 PARTNER WITH SWE

									SWE & Partner Societies Joint Membership: Networking Meet Up!

Join SWE‚Äôs Member Engagement Committee for a SWE & Partner Societies Joint Membership Virtual Networking Meet Up on April 18th from 6-7pm CT!

									SWE Member Engagement Committee & Partner Society representatives will share about their organizations' missions, discuss the benefits of joint membership, and attendees will have opportunities to network and ask questions with the various representatives and volunteers. This event is intended for both SWE and Partner Society members, anyone interested in joint membership, and those looking for ways to collaborate between AISES, NSBE, oSTEM, Out to Innovate, SASE, SHPE, and SWE. Contact Emily Walvoord

mailto:emily.a.walvoord@gmail.com

 with questions.

												Sign Up on Facebook ¬ª

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/1759699095520--mibextid-RQdjqZ/4w5z8k/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

 

									SWE & Partner Societies Joint Membership Event Zoom Link:

Join Zoom Meeting: http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/j-83149206148/4w5z8n/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/j-83149206148/4w5z8n/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

									Meeting ID: 831 4920 6148

									Find your local number: http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/u-kb9LV6qX0x/4w5z8r/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/u-kb9LV6qX0x/4w5z8r/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

									This Week on the SWE Mentor Network: Community College & Beyond!

Typically a members-only benefit, for the April 17 - 28, 2023 cohort we‚Äôre opening up the SWE Mentor Network

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/2023-04-17/4w5z8v/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

 to community college students, regardless of member status! Please spread the word about this opportunity to any students or faculty in your life. Learn about how community colleges are integral to the diversity of the engineering workforce in this All Together post: Community Colleges Affinity Group Spotlight: the Community College Dream

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/t-the-community-college-dream-/4w5z8y/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

.

									Please note that you are not required to be a community college student to participate in this cohort. If you haven‚Äôt yet created an account for the SWE Mentor Network, check out the FAQ page

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/faqs/4w5z92/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

 and follow one of the links below:

										Interested in being a mentor to other SWE members? Sign up today

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/join-mentor-sign-up-cc23/4w5z95/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

! 

											Please note that a mentor account enables you to accept bookings from mentees, as well as schedule mentoring sessions with other mentors. Mentors need mentoring too!

											If you have experience with community college, be sure to select this as one of your areas of expertise when you create your profile.

										Looking for guidance in your engineering studies or career choices? Sign up

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/join-mentee-sign-up-cc23/4w5z98/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

 as a mentee! 

									New SWE Program to Support Community College Affiliates

Women who attend community colleges are significantly underrepresented, especially in the engineering and technology field. Community colleges provide a pathway to higher education, allowing those with socioeconomic barriers to pursuing a degree in engineering or technology. To better support women in community college engineering programs, SWE is launching the Community College Affiliates Support and Expansion (CCASE) program

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/research-2023-ccase-program-/4w5z9c/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

. CCASE is a pilot program to support existing community college affiliates and establish new ones across the United States. Read more on SWE's All Together blog

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/-community-college-affiliates-/4w5z9g/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

.

									Thank you to our email sponsor, US Space Force!

Interested in a career related to space? The U.S. Space Force

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/2023-04-17/4w5z9k/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

 is setting the pace and we‚Äôre looking for the brightest minds in aerospace and engineering to help us expand our reach.

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/2023-04-17/4w5z9k/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

We offer countless ways to take your career and education to new levels, whether you‚Äôre enlisted, an officer or a civilian. Each career includes continuous opportunities for growth and an amazing benefits package including a generous retirement plan, life insurance and health insurance. So, while you serve your country, we make sure you and your family are taken care of. 

									From protecting our satellites to coordinating communication and detecting threats across all military branches, our mission knows no bounds. And neither should you. To learn more, visit spaceforce.com

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/2023-04-17/4w5z9k/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

.

									Upcoming Virtual Career Fair

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/a-SWE-e-lx3LY/4w5z9n/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

Register now for the SWE Virtual Career Fair for Professionals

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/a-SWE-e-lx3LY/4w5z9n/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

 on Wednesday, May 3 from 1:00p - 4:00p EDT! Don‚Äôt miss your opportunity to discover new career opportunities from leading employers and interact live and one-on-one with recruiters through text and video chat. The hiring employers are looking to tap into SWE‚Äôs diverse community of experienced engineers to fill their positions! 

									Who Should Attend the Event?

										Professionals with at least 3 years of professional experience post-undergraduate degree in engineering and technology fields seeking new career opportunities. 

										Experienced engineering and technology professionals that want to learn more about opportunities for advancement.

												Check out who is hiring and more details! ¬ª

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/a-SWE-e-lx3LY/4w5z9n/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

									Step into Spring with new sweSwag! 

Check out the latest additions to our sweSwag store

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/sweswag/4w5z9r/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

! Collegiate sections can enter for a chance to win SWE honor cords for your section by purchasing the new SWE Souvenir Tassels

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/dp-B0BT25V9B3-ref-myi-title-dp/4w5z9v/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

 and emailing sweswag@swe.org

mailto:sweswag@swe.org

 proof of purchase. This contest ends May 1 and winners will be announced May 3.

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/sweswag/4w5z9r/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

The new SWE Stainless Steel Coasters

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/dp-B0BZQMTWLC-ref-myi-title-dp/4w5z9y/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

 feature a minimalist design that's both elegant and functional, making them the perfect addition to any coffee table or home bar. Each coaster is made from high-quality stainless steel, ensuring that your drinks stay in place and your furniture stays protected.

									Our SWE swag button pack

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/dp-B0BL5D8XPW-ref-myi-title-dp/4w5zb2/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

 includes a variety of colorful and quirky buttons that are perfect for showing off your personality. Pin them to your backpack, jacket, or hat to add a little flair to your outfit. 

									Be sure to head to swe.org/sweswag

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/sweswag/4w5z9r/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

 to see all of these items and more! 

									Affinity Group Spotlights

															Community Colleges AG

Did you know that, in 2023, community college students are 59% female and 55% from diverse ethnic backgrounds? Read more about how Community Colleges are the "bedrock of the 'American Dream'" on SWE's All Together blog

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/t-the-community-college-dream-/4w5z8y/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

!

															Public Policy AG

The Public Policy AG's mission is to inspire members to get involved in public policy, support and create a community, and have safe discussions around advocacy at the local, state, and federal levels to advance policy interests that align with SWE‚Äôs goals. Read more on SWE's All Together blog

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/olicy-affinity-group-overview-/4w5zb5/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

!

The purpose of this email is to publicize a program or activity sponsored by the Society of Women Engineers (SWE). You are receiving this email because you are either a SWE member or have an affiliation with SWE. All SWE members may login to the SWE portal to manage and update their email preferences

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/s-login--startURL-2Fs2F/4w5zb8/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

. Everyone, including non-members, may unsubscribe from all SWE email communications here

http://marketing.swe.org/unsubscribeConfirm/858553/730dc36aa2accab8712aaca4fdfc4230640d51abbf0384c92bcae7f3e7ff213c/453617800

. Due to their leadership responsibilities, all active SWE leaders will continue to receive SWE business emails even if they opt-out of marketing emails. Current SWE members may receive business critical emails and/or renewal emails even if they opt-out of marketing emails. To remove your email address from SWE's database entirely, email membership@swe.org

mailto:membership@swe.org?subject=SWE%20Database%20Removal%20Request&body=Hi%2C%0A%0APlease%20have%20my%20personal%20information%20completely%20removed%20from%20the%20SWE%20database.%0A%0AThank%20you.

. We respect your right to privacy. View our policy.

http://marketing.swe.org/e/858553/about-swe-privacy-policy-/4w5zbc/453617800?h=yZ5Lxl5aPz3uc2RhEHg2HYeu33-xOXNK5tk-d7MGfEc

Society of Women Engineers

									130 East Randolph Street, Suite 3500

									Chicago, IL 60601

-1212342818.subject: [HAM Student News]
-1212342818.text:
** April
------------------------------------------------------------

http://www.twitter.com/

http://www.instagram.com

http://www.facebook.com

#
https://hvrd.art/o/360018
This Barbie is... Barbie. Sorry, we couldn't resist sharing our own version of the pop culture icon and soon-to-be movie star, photographed here by David Levinthal (https://davidlevinthal.com/biography/) .

Come check out more artistic icons in our galleries, or engage with artists, researchers, and fellow students through one of our programs. There's always more to explore at the Harvard Art Museums!
https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/mine-yours-theirs-ours-ownership-and-stewardship-in-the-age-of-blockchain


** lecture
------------------------------------------------------------


** Mine, Yours, Theirs, Ours? Ownership and Stewardship in the Age of Blockchain
------------------------------------------------------------

Thursday, April 20
6-7:30PM

Discuss (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/mine-yours-theirs-ours-ownership-and-stewardship-in-the-age-of-blockchain)  some of the most pressing cultural issues today with an artist, a blockchain researcher, and an award-winning television producer.

https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/lyrical-colors-flowing-stories-conversations-on-paintings-with-artist-nilima-sheikh


** lecture
------------------------------------------------------------


** Lyrical Colors, Flowing Stories: Conversations on Paintings with Artist Nilima Sheikh
------------------------------------------------------------

Saturday, April 22
2-3:30PM

Hear (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/lyrical-colors-flowing-stories-conversations-on-paintings-with-artist-nilima-sheikh) from Baroda-based artist Nilima Sheikh, who will talk about her artistic practice and traditional painting forms of South Asia.

https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/student-guide-tour-crusades-in-material-culture-continuing-a-legacy


** student guide tour
------------------------------------------------------------


** Crusades in Material Culture‚ÄîContinuing a Legacy
------------------------------------------------------------

Sunday, April 23
12-12:50PM

Explore (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/student-guide-tour-crusades-in-material-culture-continuing-a-legacy) the legacy of the Crusades in the art and architecture of Venice, with Hannah Gadway ‚Äô25.

https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/tell-me-oh-muse-an-afternoon-of-poetry-2


** tour
------------------------------------------------------------


** Tell Me, Oh Muse: An Afternoon of Poetry
------------------------------------------------------------

Friday, April 28
2-3PM

Don't miss (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/tell-me-oh-muse-an-afternoon-of-poetry-2) the final installment of our National Poetry Month celebration with Harvard undergraduates!

_______________________________________________
From Our Friends...

Explore the landscape of slavery at Harvard (https://edib.harvard.edu/landscape-slavery-harvard-tours) on a free tour led by Harvard chaplains. Dates and registration can be found here (https://harvard.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_5bBlJRKyrvet3OS) .

On Thursday, April 20, join the Harvard & Legacy of Slavery Memorialization Committee for a panel conversation, ‚ÄúSetting the Table: Descendant Communities, Institutions, and Engagement Toward Possible Futures.‚Äù (https://www.harvard.edu/vice-provost-for-special-projects/1160-2/)

Densho (https://densho.org/) , a nonprofit organization documenting the testimonies of Japanese Americans who were incarcerated during World War II, is seeking applicants for a Remote Archives Internship (https://densho.org/get-involved/volunteer-jobs/archives-internships-remote/) .

-1264531901.subject: üîÆ Earnings-season forecast
-1264531901.text:
‚Ä¶expectations are low for America‚Äôs biggest companies
Disclosures
 

Busy week on Wall Street (Mario Tama/Getty Images)

 
Last Week‚Äôs Market Moves
 
Dow Jones
33,886 (+1.20%)		S&P 500
4,138 (+0.79%)		Nasdaq
12,123 (+0.29%)		Bitcoin
$30,474 (+8.67%)
Dow Jones
33,886 (+1.20%)		S&P 500
4,138 (+0.79%)
Nasdaq
12,123 (+0.29%)		Bitcoin
$30,474 (+8.67%)

Hey Snackers,

AI is coming for your future ‚Äî literally. The fortune-cookie industry is debating whether to use ChatGPT, instead of humans, to draft those little snippets. One AI-generated bit of wisdom said: ‚ÄúYour fate is written in the stars and encrypted in the clouds.‚Äù That‚Äôs deep‚Ä¶ learning.

Stocks ticked up for the week, led by the Dow, after some big banks kicked off earnings season with stronger-than-expected #s. But major indexes dipped on Friday as Fed rate-hike expectations jumped. Traders are no longer betting on a breather in May.

Btw... Do you want to start getting Snacks daily? Or prefer to unsubscribe? Manage your subscription preferences here.

SZN

Earnings-season forecasts are dim for America‚Äôs biggest companies as profits get pressured

‚ÄôTis the season‚Ä¶ but it may not be so jolly. Earnings season is upon us, and expectations aren‚Äôt high for the first-quarter stocking. Quarterly profits from S&P 500 companies are expected to have dropped 6.8% from last year ‚Äî that would be the sharpest earnings decline since lockdown-era 2020 and the second straight quarter of falling profit. Meanwhile, analysts expect that sales inched up a measly 1.8%. But the kickoff to earnings season pleasantly surprised:

  • Bank buster: On Friday JPMorgan Chase and Citi reported stronger-than-expected #s, with JPM posting record revenue and a 50% profit surge on higher interest rates.
  • Stocking stuffer: Despite less-than-stellar earnings expectations, the S&P 500 is up 8% for the year, while the techy Nasdaq has gained 17%.

Growth at all costs < profit at less cost‚Ä¶ Soaring interest rates and sticky inflation have eaten into profits and cooled demand. Cue: companies are shifting away from growth-driven investments to focus on cost-cutting profit boosters. It‚Äôs ‚Äúthe year of efficiency,‚Äù Meta CEO Zuck says. Corporate titans are tightening their belts to prep for a downturn. Last week the Fed said it expected that the banking-crisis fallout would tip the US into a recession this year.

  • Cold-brew cuts: In addition to sweeping layoffs, companies like Meta, Goldman Sachs, and Salesforce have cut cushy employee perks like barista-brewed coffee. Google is swapping pricey MacBooks for Chromebooks.
  • Robo-savings: Companies like Disney and Microsoft are backtracking on big bets like the metaverse. Instead, corporations are investing in things that could reduce costs long term (think: Walmart and Amazon leaning into warehouse automation).
THE TAKEAWAY

‚ÄúHow low will you go‚Äù is the question‚Ä¶ on investors‚Äô lips. They‚Äôll be listening for guidance about how much lower corporate profits could fall. If companies signal further declines ahead, this year‚Äôs rally could reverse. But if cost-cutting measures start to show up on earnings reports as improving profits, markets could be pleasantly surprised.

Events

Coming up this week

Biscoff cookies en route to Cabo‚Ä¶ United Airlines and Alaska Air may have reason to join the spring-break party when they report this week. While US airline fares are up 17% on the year, travel demand is still taking off. The TSA's expecting a record-breaking year for flights, and analysts think this may be airlines' busiest spring ever. Last week Delta unloaded a quarterly loss, but projected strong growth and profit ahead. It expects record advance summer bookings as consumers prioritize delayed YOLO experiences.

It‚Äôs finally here‚Ä¶ Tuesday is the deadline to file tax returns for most Americans (many residents of CA, GA, and AL have until October). And it may be the last go-around for what you could call ‚ÄúIRS 1.0.‚Äù Over the next two years, the IRS will use billions in federal funding to upgrade its ‚Äô60s-era tech and hire 20K new employees. For you: faster returns and shorter phone wait times. Next tax year, the IRS will require anyone earning $600+ on payment apps (for goods and services ‚Äî not from splitting checks) like Venmo to report it.

Zoom out

Stories we‚Äôre watching

An apple a day‚Ä¶ keeps the bills away. More Americans could see a boost in their credit scores after credit agencies scrapped 70% of all medical debt in collections. Last year, Experian, TransUnion, and Equifax removed already paid medical debt from millions of credit reports. Last week they took it a step further by removing all unpaid debt up to $500. Nearly a tenth of US adults owe at least $250 in medical debt, but many don‚Äôt notice until it dings their credit score. The move could provide relief at a time when US households carry record debt.

Still watching‚Ä¶ Votes will be counted today to see if the Writers Guild of America will strike in the event that a new contract agreement isn‚Äôt reached with studios by May 1. If the WGA strikes, we could see a repeat of the last screenwriting stoppage in 2007, which lasted 100 days. On the table: shortened TV seasons, cancellations, and a bump in unscripted content (imagine: more ‚ÄúLove Is Blind‚Äù). A strike would be a headache for streamers who are hungry for the next ‚ÄúSuccession.‚Äù They‚Äôre expected to splurge $23.4B on scripted titles this year.

ICYMI

Last week's highlights

  • Stuck: Amazon's $1.7B deal to buy Roomba maker iRobot is gathering dust as the FTC gets tougher on mergers. As antitrust gets anti-er, companies might think twice before snagging startups.
  • Oops: Samsung workers reportedly leaked secret company info while asking ChatGPT for help. Nearly half of companies (and the Biden admin) are exploring guidelines for AI-chatbot usage.
  • Volt: Tesla's building a Shanghai ‚ÄúMegapack‚Äù plant to build more energy-storage solutions for businesses and homes. Rising energy demand could fuel Elon‚Äôs biz as EV growth slows.

What else we're Snackin'
  • RTO: Niche consultants attempting to get WFH‚Äôers back to the office without a morale plunge are imploring execs to ditch return-to-office mandates in favor of communal perks like yoga and lunch.
  • Emote: Lots of young Chinese men have grown emotionally attached to AI companions like Microsoft's spinoff Xiaoice, which had 650M users in 2018. Robo-romances could give China a leg up in the AI race.
  • Exhausted: The EPA‚Äôs new pollution-standards proposal that seeks to limit tailpipe emissions could speed up the EV transition. It would require up to 67% of all new cars sold in the US to be electric by 2032.

-2051123892.subject: [ADAMS] SCR Book Talk! Majority Minority
-2051123892.text:
Hi Schmooze,

This Thursday at 8pm in the LCR we will be hosting SCR member Justin Gest
as he talks about his new book, *Majority Minority*.

More info below and see you there!

Santi


*Majority Minority: How will America respond to demographic change?*

How do societies respond to great demographic change? This question lingers
over the contemporary politics of many countries where persistent
immigration has altered populations and may soon produce a majority
minority milestone, where the original ethnic or religious majority loses
its numerical advantage to one or more foreign-origin minority groups.
Until now, most of our knowledge about large-scale responses to demographic
change has been based on studies of individual people‚Äôs reactions, which
tend to be instinctively defensive and intolerant. We know little about why
and how these habits are sometimes tempered to promote more sustainable
coexistence. In *Majority Minority*, Justin Gest wields polling research,
historical analysis, and interview-based fieldwork inside six of the
world‚Äôs few societies that have already experienced a majority minority
transition to understand what factors produce different social outcomes.
Grounded in rich narratives and surprising survey findings, *Majority
Minority* reveals that this contentious milestone and its accompanying
identity politics are ultimately subject to unifying or divisive governance.

*Justin Gest <http://justingest.com/>* is an Associate Professor of Policy
and Government at George Mason University‚Äôs Schar School of Policy and
Government. He is the author of six books, primarily on the politics of
immigration and demographic change‚Äîall from Oxford University Press or
Cambridge University Press. He has also provided commentary, analysis, or
reporting to a number of broadcast networks, including ABC, BBC, CBC, CNN,
and NPR, and news publications including *The Boston Globe*, *The Guardian*
, *Los Angeles Times*, *The New York Times*, POLITICO, Reuters, *The Times*,
and *The Washington Post*. From 2010 to 2014, Professor Gest was a
postdoctoral fellow and lecturer in Harvard University‚Äôs Departments of
Government and Sociology. From 2007 to 2010, he co-founded and served as
the co-director of the Migration Studies Unit at the London School of
Economics and Political Science (LSE).

[image: MM - Cover.jpeg]

-24891660.text:
April 17, 2023


** April 17, 2023
------------------------------------------------------------


** IN THIS ISSUE
------------------------------------------------------------
* News & Announcements (#news)
* SEAS Community Events (#communityevents)
* Harvard Events (#harvardevents)


** News & Announcements
------------------------------------------------------------


** SEC Late Night Caf√© free food
------------------------------------------------------------
Once a week from 7-9:15 p.m., the SEC Caf√© offers a free item as part of their evening service. The free item for Tuesday, April 18 is:
* Flatbread Pizza


** Planned Oracle shutdown
------------------------------------------------------------
There is a planned shutdown of Oracle starting at 5 p.m. today (Tuesday, April 18) through 8 a.m. on Monday, April 24. This downtime is necessary to facilitate a required system update. This affects all the systems that are supported by Oracle, including Buy-to-Pay (B2P), HART and others. B2P will be unavailable for the duration of the outage. Check out details about the outage and the impacts to each system (https://oracle.fss.finance.harvard.edu/releases?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=78e270389e-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-78e270389e-430354381) . Please reach out to procurementhelp@seas.harvard.edu (mailto:procurementhelp@seas.harvard.edu)  with any questions or concerns.


** REEF Makerspace Innovation Fund for faculty and staff
------------------------------------------------------------
Thanks to generous support provided by SEAS Community Connections Fund, The REEF Makerspace in the SEC is excited to announce they are now accepting applications from SEAS staff and faculty to create and make personal projects to be worked on over the summer.

They are looking for innovative and creative proposals that showcase skills and passions. Once approved, the REEF staff will be able to meet with individuals accepted into the program to discuss project designs and provide feedback.

To help bring your project to life, the REEF is offering funding up to $300. In addition to financial support, accepted proposals will receive assistance from experienced staff in areas such as material purchasing, machinery, software training, and engineering support. They are committed to ensuring that your project is a success and will work closely with you throughout the process.
Don‚Äôt miss this opportunity to turn your ideas into reality with the support of the REEF. Submit your proposal (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeqkZHAACwBfjwdNGC9i9iBADX8r5P4Rk8_lGsuGUK4oSpivA/viewform?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=78e270389e-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-78e270389e-430354381) and take your first step towards bringing your vision to life. The deadline to apply is Friday, May 5. Community members will hear back by mid-May on accepted projects.


** SEAS Community Events
------------------------------------------------------------


** April 20: Research Convergence Topics: Data-Driving Discovery (https://seasresearchconvergence.splashthat.com/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=78e270389e-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-78e270389e-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
Want to learn about exciting research projects happening at SEAS? All are welcome to attend the SEAS Research Convergence Topics event this Thursday. The SEAS Research Convergence Topics (RCT) is a faculty-led initiative that supports collaborative research projects that are tackling complex, cross-disciplinary challenges. The initiative brings together the community for idea sharing, research awareness, and the generation of new projects. The current Research Convergence Topic is Data-Driven Discovery.

The event will include faculty-led project presentations and a community happy hour. There will also be a live-stream and popcorn in the SEC Main Atrium.


** April 21: Ph.D. Focus Group - Campus Climate Survey (https://harvard.zoom.us/meeting/register/tJYtcO2urz4rE9BLDowcOMBcLYD6aQbc1yHT?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=78e270389e-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-78e270389e-430354381#/registration)
------------------------------------------------------------
The Office of Diversity, Inclusion, and Belonging (ODIB) is hosting a virtual focus group for Ph.D. students to give honest and constructive feedback on the SEAS experience as a graduate student. The focus group will be moderated by two of the DIB Fellows who are also currently enrolled as Ph.D. students.


** May 22 - 25: Commencement Affinity Celebrations (https://edib.harvard.edu/affinity-graduations?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=78e270389e-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-78e270389e-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
Affinity celebrations are student-led, staff supported events that recognize and celebrate the accomplishments of graduates from marginalized and underrepresented communities. These University-wide celebrations provide an opportunity for graduates to honor those who have helped them achieve their milestone while centering their cultural traditions and values. Affinity celebrations are open to all Harvard graduates who pre-register to attend. The celebrations include keynote speakers, performances and cultural celebrations.

Registration for the 2023 Affinity Celebrations will close on Monday, April 24. If you have questions, please contact edib@harvard.edu (mailto:edib@harvard.edu) .


** [See all SEAS events] (https://events.seas.harvard.edu/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=78e270389e-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-78e270389e-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------


** Harvard Events
------------------------------------------------------------


** April 19: Harvard Science Book Talk: Philip Plait, in conversation with Jessie Christiansen, "Under Alien Skies: A Sightseer's Guide to the Universe" (https://science.fas.harvard.edu/event/harvard-science-book-talk-philip-plait?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=78e270389e-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-78e270389e-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
Astronomer Philip Plait will discuss his book, "Under Alien Skies: A Sightseer's Guide to the Universe," in which he draws on both the latest scientific research and imagination to transport readers to ten of the most spectacular sights outer space has to offer.



** May 8: Creating the Climate Future: Harvard Climate Leadership Summit (https://www.harvardcls.com/index.php?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=78e270389e-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-78e270389e-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
All Harvard students are invited to attend the inaugural Harvard Climate Leadership Summit during Harvard Climate Action Week (May 8 - 12). The summit will provide a platform that convenes students and decision-makers across industry, government and civil society to cultivate a rising generation of climate leadership. There will be an opportunity to meet the Emerging Climate Leaders, a passionate and diverse group of students who are dedicated to tackling climate change. They are the next generation of leaders committed to building a more sustainable and equitable future.



** May 9: Harvard Climate Symposium (https://harvardclimatesymposium.cventevents.com/event/c2f2acd5-bd80-49de-b1d3-4206bc0c7c76/summary?rp=b485e4a4-efad-42bf-9efc-e57a893288f1&utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=78e270389e-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-78e270389e-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
The Salata Institute for Climate and Sustainability is hosting a Climate Symposium during Harvard Climate Action Week (May 8 - 12). This new Institute serves as a fulcrum for collaboration across Harvard‚Äôs many areas of expertise, pursuing practical, real-world solutions that address all aspects of the climate crisis.

The Symposium represents the first major event of the Salata Institute‚Äôs Climate Action Accelerator (https://salatainstitute.harvard.edu/the-accelerator/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=78e270389e-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-78e270389e-430354381) . The Accelerator will serve as a resource and partner to the full spectrum of stakeholders wrestling with the most difficult and divisive climate questions, building consensus for climate solutions grounded in Harvard‚Äôs research and expertise.


** SEAS suggestion box
------------------------------------------------------------
SEAS welcomes your ideas for ways to improve the school, build community, and make things work more efficiently. Submit feedback, suggestions, or ideas (https://harvard.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_ah3D4tyjx30av5z?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=78e270389e-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-78e270389e-430354381) . Include your name if you wish; otherwise all submissions are anonymous.


** Submit your news to Inside SEAS
------------------------------------------------------------
Inside SEAS is published weekly. If you would like to have news featured in future editions, please email Sabrina Doshi (mailto:sdoshi@seas.harvard.edu) by 5 p.m. on Thursdays. Inside SEAS can help you share news and announcements with a wider audience.

While we make every effort to publish all items received, the editorial staff reserves the right to reject submissions and edit content for space and style.

============================================================

-489068220.subject: [ADAMS] Fwd: The Christian Story, Relationships, and Harvard
-489068220.text:
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Rohan Rajeev <rohanrajeev@college.harvard.edu>
Subject: The Christian Story, Relationships, and Harvard
To: <daniel_wang@college.harvard.edu>


Started at Harvard in 1992, Veritas Forums <https://www.veritas.org/> ask
life‚Äôs biggest questions and put the Christian faith in dialogue with other
worldviews. To wrap up this semester, the Harvard Undergraduate Veritas
Forum team presents: "The Christian Story, Relationships, and Harvard: A
Conversation with Mark Shepard.‚Äù


Mark is a former Harvard undergrad who began college as an atheist. He is
now a Professor at HKS, and a Christian. Come hear him share about his
faith journey, and what he‚Äôs learned about relationships in a high-pressure
environment like Harvard. There will be lots of time for Q&A ‚Äì Prof.
Shepard is eager to hear your questions.


April 24th, 7:30 pm. Admission is free. Please RSVP here
<https://forms.gle/nBnYB31DF1oXqXjY9>. We look forward to seeing you!



- the Harvard Undergraduate Veritas Forum Team

_______________________________________________
Check the Adams FAQ for answers to many common questions: http://adamshouse.harvard.edu/frequently-asked-questions

-2029921675.subject: SEAS Undergraduate Career Newsletter Monday, April 17, 2023
-2029921675.text:
View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/seas/seas-undergraduate-career-newsletter-mon-apr-17-2023-31?e=65d2b2b7c0)
https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=63070ebcb7&e=65d2b2b7c0


** Table of Contents
------------------------------------------------------------
1. Personalized Information (#Appointment Links)
2. Announcements (#Announcements)
3. Employer, Career, and Academic Events (#Events)
4. Selected Job Postings (#Jobs)
5. Harvard Center Links Useful for Careers (#Harvard Center Links)
6. Other Lists (#Lists)
7. Contact Information (#Contact Information)


** Personalized Information
------------------------------------------------------------

Calendly link to schedule a 25-minute appointment (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=73ded0543b&e=65d2b2b7c0)  with Keith Karasek (kkarasek@seas.harvard.edu ; SEC LL1.237) to discuss your career, internship, and job-search goals.

Email Ruth Sondermann (sonderm@g.harvard.edu) for advice regarding opportunities in European countries

SEAS Student Career Development (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=e21d5cb47c&e=65d2b2b7c0)

Talk to students in concentration areas:
Applied Mathematics Peer Concentration Advisors (PCAs) (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=90f4a1845c&e=65d2b2b7c0)
Computer Science Peer Concentration Advisors (PCAs) (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=5334569b11&e=65d2b2b7c0)
Engineering Peer Concentration Advisors (PCAs) (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=eff7c3de3e&e=65d2b2b7c0)


** Announcements
------------------------------------------------------------



** SEAS Research Convergence
------------------------------------------------------------
Want to learn about exciting research projects happening at SEAS? Join us and enjoy flavored popcorn and drinks in the SEC Main Atrium while watching a livestream of the SEAS Research Convergence Topics presentations on Thursday, April 20 from 4-5pm. The SEAS Research Convergence Topics (RCT) is a faculty-led initiative that supports collaborative research projects that are tackling complex, cross-disciplinary challenges. The initiative brings together the community for idea sharing, research awareness, and the generation of new projects. The current Research Convergence Topic is Data-Driven Discovery.

The event will include faculty-led project presentations and discussion about their project developments livestreamed on the SEC Atrium screen.

4-5pm | SEAS RCT: Data-Driven Discovery Presentations
‚Ä¢    Advancing quantitative forecasts of risk from rapid changes in the climate structure project led by Professors Jim Anderson and Frank Keutsch
‚Ä¢    From activity to health: Assessment and intervention via rich physical activity monitoring and wearable technology project led by Professor Conor Walsh
‚Ä¢    Data-driven causal models for prediction and control of complex systems project led by Professors Petros Koumoutsakos and Na (Lina) Li



** Breaking into Tech (Part 2)
------------------------------------------------------------
Interested in applying your CS skills in a tech organization? Please register (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=b4dbebaf56&e=65d2b2b7c0) and attend this workshop (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=a17c4e0e21&e=65d2b2b7c0) on Tuesday, April 18, 2023, 4-5pm, in SEC 2.122 & 2.123 where we hear from upperclassmen as they discuss how they broke into tech and offer insights on how you can too! In this collaboration with OCS, we will discuss topics like working at startups, technical interview prep and different types of roles like ML engineering vs. SWE, data science and AI, and more!



** Reminders: Field of Study and Concurrent Master (AB/SM) Events
------------------------------------------------------------
* Tuesday, April 18, 2023, 2-3:45pm, Field of Study Event for Computer Science (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=9a33754de5&e=65d2b2b7c0) ,  SEC LL2.229.
* Wednesday, April 19, 2023, 3-4pm, Applied Mathematics Field of Study Event (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=0093916497&e=65d2b2b7c0) , Pierce G11 (AM Lounge).
* Tuesday, April 18, 2023, 4:30-5:30pm, Mark Glickman of the Statistics Department hosts Statistics concurrent masters (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=bf165a3549&e=65d2b2b7c0) information session in Science Center 705. RSVP (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=f1726e0b85&e=65d2b2b7c0) is appreciated.
* Thursday, April 27, 2023, 11am-noon, SEAS AB/SM (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=9340caa325&e=65d2b2b7c0) Information Session, Register for Zoom Link (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=45146a25f0&e=65d2b2b7c0)


** This is Space Week
------------------------------------------------------------
The annual Space Week in Boston is being held this week.  Events will be held at several schools - check out the schedule (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=ed9dfe89ea&e=65d2b2b7c0) , andregister for events (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=a7869fb587&e=65d2b2b7c0) . Note the career fair from 3-5pm Friday in the Science Center.



** Harvard GRID Announcements
------------------------------------------------------------
* This Thursday, April 20, 2023, 4-6pm, LLL Series: i2O Therapeutics, Cellino Biotech, Day Zero Diagnostics (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=aa86b21b84&e=65d2b2b7c0) , SEC 2.203

Also check out these select I-Lab Events (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=0f2adf0e13&e=65d2b2b7c0) :
* Tuesday, April 18, 2023, 5:30-8:30pm, Cross-Community Biotech Pitch-to-Peers Night (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=0fbf1e8a5e&e=65d2b2b7c0)
* Wednesday, April 19, 2023, 5:30-6:30pm, The Dos and Don‚Äôts of Web3, Blockchain, & Crypto (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=4acd313386&e=65d2b2b7c0)
* Thursday, April 20, 2023, 5:30-7pm, Founders/Joiners Pitch Open Mic (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=4846456e22&e=65d2b2b7c0)
* Monday, April 24, 2023, 12-2pm, I-Lab Tour (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=00732e018b&e=65d2b2b7c0)

And this LPCE (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=e148c2c3cd&e=65d2b2b7c0) Event
* Wednesday, April 19, 2023, 2-5:30pm, Harvard HealthLab (H2L) Pitch Competition (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=51268f86bc&e=65d2b2b7c0) . 2-5:30pm, Harvard HealthLab (H2L) Pitch Competition, 77 Avenue Louis Pasteur, Boston


** Applications for Fall Positions
------------------------------------------------------------
The REEF (Maker Space) is seeking applications for Maker Fellow (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=519a208f9d&e=65d2b2b7c0) .  Deadline is May 15.

SEAS is hiring Course Assistants (CAs, often referred to in SEAS as TFs) for Fall 2023. The initial deadline (i.e., for some courses) is Wednesday, April 19, 2023.
* To apply to select SEAS courses in AM, AP, Eng Sci and ESE, please complete this form (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=54e75d4cb7&e=65d2b2b7c0)
* To apply to courses taught by a CS faculty (including AM22a), please complete this form (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=df9086139b&e=65d2b2b7c0) .

The Academic Resource Center is hiring tutors for the fall semester - see the ARC Student Employment webpage. (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=1eab4803c6&e=65d2b2b7c0) Applications are due by April 21.



** Career Fairs
------------------------------------------------------------
There are several career fairs on the calendar.  In addition to the in-person ASML Career (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=f06b460275&e=65d2b2b7c0) event on Thursday (which is really a single company event), note the Ivy+ Just in Time Virtual Career Fair (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=da577a269d&e=65d2b2b7c0) on Tuesday.  Students with CAD experience may want to check out the DCAMM Virtual Internship Fair (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=f3cf73f9d2&e=65d2b2b7c0) on Wednesday. The Space Career Fair (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=b6ccecc797&e=65d2b2b7c0) is Friday in the Science Center.


** Monday, April 17, 2023
------------------------------------------------------------
5:30-7:30pm, Harvard Coffee & Chat about Teach For America (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=0ba96889ac&e=65d2b2b7c0) , Smith Center
6-7pm, [HCQCA (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=cfe57e958e&e=65d2b2b7c0) ] Peter Chapman, President & CEO, IonQ, (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=cffcbebc6a&e=65d2b2b7c0) Boylston 105
7:30-8:30pm, [HSAC (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=f5b660270d&e=65d2b2b7c0) ] weekly meeting, CGIS South Belfer Case Study Room

 June 2, 2023

Harvard Yard




You’re Invited to Harvard Alumni Day

https://click.hu.harvard.edu/?qs=2c2d6133545dc709cf1153830e257e4009b5b8bab9fe4ed4f5fc004386faaecc0e2f39032154598ae3db9454a394114bf2b419ea714b64c7 
Register Now 

Dear Eelaaf,


Here at the Harvard Alumni Association (HAA), we’re thrilled to invite you to join your global alumni community at Harvard Alumni Day on Friday, June 2! 

https://click.hu.harvard.edu/?qs=2c2d6133545dc709cf1153830e257e4009b5b8bab9fe4ed4f5fc004386faaecc0e2f39032154598ae3db9454a394114bf2b419ea714b64c7 
Register Now 

This special annual tradition is an opportunity to come together on campus and celebrate our outstanding alumni with all the pomp and circumstance we know and love.


The festivities begin with the time-honored alumni parade led by the eldest alumni through the Old Yard. Following the parade into Tercentenary Theatre, there will be a special program that includes featured speaker 
https://click.hu.harvard.edu/?qs=2c2d6133545dc70930695f9601a92b57b5d4016fe35ef20e73112f1e12055d831b504d9976923cca6c97c45f823f7dfd6e69563f5feaf293 
Mary Louise Kelly AB‚ÄØ’93 —co-host of NPR’s award-winning All Things Considered—remarks from President Larry Bacow JD‚ÄØ’76, MPP‚ÄØ’76, PhD‚ÄØ’78, and a celebration of the Harvard Medalists.


The fun continues with live music and a Yard party with food and beverage trucks from local favorites such as Pinocchio’s Pizza, Bon Me, El Jefe’s, and more.


We hope you and your family will join us to experience the excitement, warmth, and joy of this extraordinary day!


Cheers,


Your friends at the Harvard Alumni Association
If you aren’t able to return to Cambridge this year, we hope you will join the livestream or connect with your local alumni community for possible events happening in your area in celebration of Alumni Day. Learn more at 
https://click.hu.harvard.edu/?qs=2c2d6133545dc709ef902396887d300893c0445497cd6a38cbe49496bbbe746020e392312bfcd1910fc42ed50392d869816246f99e7fa2ed 
alumni.harvard.edu/alumni-day .

-1508513772.subject: [ADAMS] Ice Cream + Snacks! Come see a projection on Friday, 4/21!
-1508513772.text:
WANT FREE üç¶ <https://emojipedia.org/soft-ice-cream/> VEGAN ICE-CREAM üç¶
<https://emojipedia.org/soft-ice-cream/> AND SNACKS?

Join us on Friday, April 21 from 7-9pm at Lehman Hall to view our
projections on how our food systems impact climate change and how
individual dietary choices can alleviate the climate crisis alongside
ice-cream, snacks, and games!

[image: image.png]

Check out the rest of the programming
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdXxePqji01XGqy6K67q3bGbBYz_mXuqNEA-mvs2HHvNR88wg/viewform>
for the Harvard Climate Coalition‚Äôs Intersectional Earth Week here
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdXxePqji01XGqy6K67q3bGbBYz_mXuqNEA-mvs2HHvNR88wg/viewform>
.

From the Harvard Climate Clock Group.

Hans Bach-Nguyen, Jos√© Quiroz-Yanez, Mariana Haro, Lulu August, Hanna Chang

Who are we? A student-led project group from Mindich course Gov 1318 aiming
to spread awareness about the meat industry and its effects on climate
change and the planet. This project consists of projections about climate
change statistics that we hope incite conversation and insightful learning
experiences for people of all backgrounds.

-374521441.subject: [ADAMS] HU Mind, Brain, & Behavior Spring Symposium 4/21!
-374521441.text:
*Harvard Undergraduate Mind, Brain, and Behavior* is excited to announce
our
*Spring Symposium 2023: Language and Communication!*

Join us in *William James Hall B1* *on Friday, April 21 from 5-8pm *for a
panel discussion and research talks, featuring *Dr. Catherine Snow *(Graduate
School of Education), *Dr. Gina Kuperberg *(Massachusetts General
Hospital), *Dr. Jesse Snedeker* (Psychology), *Dr. Asifa Majid* (Radcliffe
Fellow in Social Sciences), and *Dr. Gennaro Chierchia* (Linguistics and
Philosophy)! Full schedule coming soon.

All Harvard affiliates are welcome to attend, and undergraduates -
especially thesis writers - are invited to *share research at our poster
session*! Please *RSVP* <https://forms.gle/Ph8bMovaaNv8rQeU6> here if you
would like to attend or share work. Dinner will be provided.

[image: HSMBB Symposium 2023.png]


Speaker Bios:

*Dr. Catherine Snow: *"Catherine Snow is an expert on language and literacy
development in children, focusing on how oral language skills are acquired
and how they relate to literacy outcomes. Her current research activities
include a study of how Boston Public School early childhood classrooms are
supporting children's development, and participation in a long-standing
research-practice partnership (the Strategic Education Research
Partnership, SERP) that is developing curricular tools to support teachers
in introducing innovative classroom practices. Word Generation, a
discussion-based academic language and literacy program developed by SERP,
has been shown to improve middle-school literacy outcomes, in particular
for students from language-minority homes."

*Dr. Gina Kuperberg:* "Gina R Kuperberg, MD PhD, is the Dennett Stibel
Professor of Cognitive Science at Tufts University. She is also a Board
Certified Psychiatrist and Principal Investigator in the Psychiatry
Neuroscience Program at Massachusetts General Hospital. Her research
program uses multimodal neuroimaging techniques (fMRI, MEG and EEG evoked
responses, oscillatory activity, and Representational Similarity Analysis),
neuropsychological testing and computational modeling to understand when,
where and how the human brain builds meaning from language, and how these
mechanisms break down in neuropsychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia."

*Dr. Jesse Snedeker: *"Research in my lab explores how children learn
language, how language encodes meaning (semantics), how people understand
speech as they are hearing it, and how these processes are affected by
developmental disorders (e.g., autism) or differences in the context in
which a language is acquired (e.g., international adoption)."

*Dr. Asifa Majid:* "Asifa Majid is a professor of cognitive science at the
University of Oxford. Majid studies the relationship among language,
culture, and mind. Humans are one species, and yet we speak 7,000
different, mutually unintelligible languages, each hosted in distinct
cultural niches around the globe. How does this diversity of language,
culture, and experience affect how people think and behave? During her
fellowship year, Majid is writing a book to synthesize her wide-ranging
empirical work to elucidate which aspects of cognition are fundamentally
shared and which are language- or culture-specific."

*Dr. Gennaro Chierchia:* "I have been spending my intellectual life
studying how meaning takes shape in human language. A common thread in my
work is the idea/claim/speculation that a logic (a way of drawing
inferences) spontaneously grows and latches on to the syntactic structures
produced by our capacity for recursive computation. This ‚Äònatural logic‚Äô
gives a special power to our ability to use language to communicate and
refer, a power not found in other species. Some more specific recurring
themes/obsessions are properties and predication (control/raising/*de
se* attributions),
Noun Phrase structure (quantified vs. ‚Äòbare‚Äô nominals, mass vs. count),
anaphora and presuppositions, implicatures and polarity phenomena. I am
also very interested in pursuing these topics by experimental means."


-- 
*Carly Tiras*
A.B. Candidate in Cognitive Neuroscience and Evolutionary Psychology
Harvard University | Class of 2023
+1 832-499-6282 | ctiras@college.harvard.edu

-15299961.subject: WEDNESDAY! RSVP: Vertex Executive VP and Chief Regulatory Officer!
-15299961.text:
How does biotech's *executive leadership* achieve excellence in *regulatory
strategy and quality*? How are these considerations decided in *breakthrough
drug launches?*

Join the Harvard Biotech Club in welcoming Dr. Nia Tatsis, *Vertex's Executive
Vice President and Chief Regulatory and Quality Officer*.

* tinyurl.com/biotechregulatory <http://tinyurl.com/biotechregulatory> *

Dr. Nia Tatsis provides *global regulatory leadership to Vertex* and
manages all regulatory interactions and *quality assurance involving the
research and development, manufacturing and commercialization* of our
medicines. In addition to creating and executing the company‚Äôs global
regulatory strategy, Nia also manages a worldwide team of regulatory
professionals. Before joining Vertex, she held positions of increasing
responsibility at pharmaceutical companies such as *Sanofi, Stemnion,
Pfizer and Wyeth*.  In 2021, she was named to *Fierce Pharma‚Äôs list of the
Fiercest Women in the Life Sciences*.

This event will take place on *Wednesday, April 19th, from 6-7 pm in Sever
102. *Snacks will be served!

*RSVP NOW at tinyurl.com/biotechregulatory
<http://tinyurl.com/biotechregulatory> !!*

[image: Nia Tatsis (1).png]

-- 
Litsa Kapsalis
*A.B. & S.M. Candidate in Bioengineering*
*Harvard College | Class of 2024*
*(847) 770 - 3630*

--

-2090899826.subject: Tue 8pm cookies: Hear from the linguist Chomksy personally recommended
-2090899826.text:
Xazha fellow linguaphiles,

A couple years ago, we had Noam Chomsky as a speaker at HULS. When asked
who he would recommend to us as a future speaker, he recommended Prof.
Gennaro Chierchia. Now, two years later, we have invited him!

Prof. Gennaro Chierchia is a semanticist who works on a wide variety of
subfields within linguistics, including but not limited to semantics,
pragmatics, philosophy of language, and language pathology. He is the
author of several seminal works such as the first textbook on modern
semantics.

*Tomorrow (Tuesday April 18th)* at *8pm* in *Boylston 105*, Prof. *Gennaro
Chierchia* is speaking on "The spontaneous logicality of language: How
language creates meaning".

Please join us for a delightful talk and just as delightful *cookies*!

Xazhy,
Your HULS co-presidents Blake and Joanna

-1755653895.subject: Re: [ADAMS] Looking for a fourth suitemate to join a quad!
-1755653895.text:
Hi Amanda, Helen, and Ann! I wanted to reach out because I am a female-identifying super senior entering the lottery with junior status this year and I would def be interested in potentially rooming together :) To give you a little bit of background about me: I too love wine & cheese nights and berryline! My sleep schedule varies, but I tend to go to sleep at around 1am and wake up at 8:30‚Äì9. I try to keep my space tidy, and am very happy to split up chores/help out however I can. Outside of school (I am a hist of sci concentrator with a secondary in GHHP), I love cooking, lifting weights, and making Spotify playlists with friends! My insta is @may.moorefield, and my number is 832-248-4674 if you want to reach me more quickly. Would y‚Äôall like to meet sometime tomorrow to get to know each other/discuss rooming? Thank you so much for offering to include someone in your room!!

Best regards,

May Moorefield

I like to keep my living space clean, and I go to bed around 11:00 and wake up around 6:30 for morning practice. I love music, being outdoors, and creative writing :) Insta:¬†@a_sudzy
>

I always keep my living space organized and clean, so messiness won‚Äôt be an issue. I love to dance, play the piano, and make yt videos! Insta:¬†@helenpiltner
>
> Ann: My name is Ann and I am an (undeclared) Econ concentrator planning a sociology secondary! I tend to go to bed around 1-2 am and wake up around 10 am and am typically a neat person. I love country music and have a slight obsession with Gilmore Girls. Insta:¬†@annncatt
>
> If you're interested, please respond to this email, reach out on insta or text¬†9125413367 :)
>
> Thanks,
>
> Ann, Helen and Amanda
>
> <Screen Shot 2023-04-17 at 10.47.30 PM.png>

-790862007.subject: "Poem for a Suicide" by Matthew Zapruder
-790862007.text:
The yellow flowers on the grave / make an arch, they lie

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 18, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** Poem for a Suicide (http://poets.org/poem-suicide?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
Matthew Zapruder (https://poets.org/poet/matthew-zapruder?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID)

The yellow flowers on the grave
make an arch, they lie

on a black stone that lies on the ground
like a black door that will always

remain closed down into the earth,
into it is etched the name

of a great poet who believed
he had nothing more to say,

he threw himself into literal water
and everyone has done their mourning

and been mourned over, and we all
went on with our shopping,

I stare at this photograph of that grave
and think you died like him,

like all the others,
and the yellow flowers

seem angry, they seem to want to refuse
to be placed anywhere but in a vase

next to the living, someday
all of us will have our names

etched where we cannot read them,
she who sealed her envelopes

full of poems about doubt with flowers
called it her ‚Äúgranite lip,‚Äù I want mine

to say Lucky Life, and what would
a perfect elegy do? place the flowers

back in the ground? take me
where I can watch him sit eternally

dreaming over his typewriter?
then, at last, will I finally unlearn

everything? and I admit that yes,
while I could never leave

everyone, here at last
I understand these yellow flowers,

the names, the black door
he held open

and you walked through.
Copyright ¬© 2023 by Matthew Zapruder. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on April 18, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS4785510225.mp3?updated=1681322934&mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID

‚ÄúThe ‚Äògreat poet‚Äô whose grave is mentioned in this poem isPaul Celan (https://poets.org/poet/paul-celan?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID) . He took his own life in Paris in 1970. Emily Dickinson (https://poets.org/poet/emily-dickinson?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID) , who referred to her own gravestone as her ‚Äògranite lip,‚Äô and Gerald Stern (https://poets.org/poet/gerald-stern?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID) , whose ‚ÄòLucky Life‚Äô I would like read at my funeral, also appear. The ‚Äòyou‚Äô addressed is not one person, but several people. I want to understand them, and want to hold onto them, but have no choice but to let them go.‚Äù
‚ÄîMatthew Zapruder
https://poets.org/poet/matthew-zapruder?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID

Matthew Zapruder (https://poets.org/poet/matthew-zapruder?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID) is the author of five collections of poetry, most recently Father‚Äôs Day (Copper Canyon Press, 2019), and two collections of prose, including Story of a Poem (Unnamed Press, 2023). The recipient of a William Carlos Williams Award from the Poetry Society of America, a Lannan Literary Fellowship, and a Guggenheim Fellowship, he is editor-at-large at Wave Books.

https://poets.org/poet/matthew-zapruder?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781556595783?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID

Father‚Äôs Day (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781556595783?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID)
(Copper Canyon Press, 2019)

https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781556595783?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID


‚ÄúInheritance Cistern Sweet Dominion‚Äù by Gabrielle Calvocoressi
read more (http://poets.org/poem/inheritance-cistern-sweet-dominion?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID)
‚Äúfrom Please Bury Me in This‚Äù by Allison Benis White
read more (http://poets.org/poem/please-bury-me?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID)
http://pcm23.eventbrite.com?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID
Thanks to U.S. poet laureate Ada Lim√≥n (https://poets.org/poet/ada-limon?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID) , author of The Hurting Kind (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781639550494?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID)  (Milkweed Editions, 2022), who curated Poem-a-Day for this month‚Äôs weekdays. As of this year, the U.S. poet laureate guest editorship during National Poetry Month (https://poets.org/library-congress-and-poem-day?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a collaboration between the Academy and the Library of Congress. Read or listen to a Q&A (https://poets.org/April-2023-poem-a-day-editor-ada-limon?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID)  about Lim√≥n's curatorial approach and find out more about our guest editors for the year (https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID) .


http://poets.org/donate/pad?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID
‚ÄúPoem-a-Day is brilliant because it makes space in the everyday racket for something as meaningful as a poem.‚Äù ‚ÄîTracy K. Smith

If this series is meaningful to you, join the community of Poem-a-Day supporters by making a gift today (https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=46e0f966ba&mc_eid=UNIQID)  in honor of National Poetry Month. Now serving more than 320,000 daily subscribers, this publication is only possible thanks to the contributions of readers like you.
