-348269344.subject: [ADAMS] HOT BREAKFAST IN THE YARD
-348269344.text:
Image Description: Colorful poster advertising Hot Breakfast in the Yard.
Text: "Send a quick email to admin for pancakes before class! Thurs, April
20th 8:30-10:30AM in front of university hall. SLAM and HUDS workers unite
for the return of hot breakfast in the houses‚Äî to improve working
conditions, hours, and student wellbeing."


Hello Hot Breakfast Hotties!

We know you‚Äôre still missing that early morning pancake ‚Äì or you will be
soon, first years (sad face).



The Hot Breakfast Campaign would like to invite you to come and get a free
pancake at our cook-in: Hot Breakfast in the Yard! Swing by the John
Harvard Statue on your way to class between 8:30 and 10 AM on April 20th
(4/20 munchies??) to grab a delicious pancake and send a quick email
<https://tinyurl.com/hotbrekky> to the administration demanding Hot
Breakfast in the Houses!

No student should have to travel long distances or go out of their way just
to get a fulfilling and nutritious meal in the morning, and most of us
don‚Äôt have the time. We shouldn‚Äôt have to skip breakfast or make do with
just pastries and yogurt.

On the other side of the issue, HUDS workers are overwhelmed in Quincy
House and Annenberg by the hundreds of students who swarm the halls for
food throughout the morning, and expanded breakfast in the Houses would
provide more hours for workers trying to support their families on jobs
that aren‚Äôt guaranteed to be 40 hours a week. Harvard has the money to
provide breakfast in more houses, and for the health and wellbeing of its
students and workers, it must.

It takes just 60 seconds to send the email template below, but it lets our
administrators know that students across Harvard really do care about
expanding hot breakfast across Houses, and it shows HUDS workers that
someone is listening. We and unionized HUDS workers really appreciate your
support.

-346115924.subject: [ADAMS] Seeking Two Roommates for Housing Lottery
-346115924.text:
Hi Schmooze!

My roommate and I are looking for two people to join us in regrouping for a
quad in the Round 3 Lottery tomorrow. We are open to living with anyone so
long as they are comfortable living with two guys.

For anyone interested, here is a little bit about us:

Acer (Me): I am a rising senior studying CS. I usually go to bed around 11
and get up around 8. Both Ben and I run distance for the Track team. I'm
big into making coffee with my Aeropress in the morning and grabbing a
slice from Pinocchios at night.

Ben: Hi! My name is Ben and I am a rising senior studying Applied Math with
a secondary in Energy & Environment. I usually go to bed around midnight
and wake up around 10. Like Acer, I also run distance for the track/cross
country team and I love going to concerts.

We are relatively quiet for most of the year but are happy to meet your
friends if you want to have people over.

If you are interested (either as an individual or a pair), feel free to
reply to this email or text me at (651) 600-4139. We can organize getting
lunch or dinner or just meeting up to chat.

We look forward to meeting you!

Thanks,
Acer and Ben

-888037910.subject: [Fyre] Join Us for Visitas: Info Sessions, Boba, Board Games, Raffle Prizes, and more!
-888037910.text:
Join us for Visitas 2023 at PBHA this Sunday!!

Our annual Visitas event is around the corner and we hope you can make it,
please RSVP here <https://forms.gle/tndYHhZn46vw441HA>! We'd like to
welcome incoming first years, their families, volunteers, directors, and
any other Harvard students who are interested in public service. This is a
great opportunity to meet our wonderful directors, volunteers, and leaders
while getting to learn about PBHA‚Äôs wide range of programs.

Join us in front of PBHA for a mini tabling info session from
4:30-5:30 pm! PBHA
runs over 60 programs throughout the year that you can get involved with so
spend this hour mingling with other students, walking around program
tables, and asking any questions you have about PBHA! Then head inside our
historic building for a delicious and fun Boba and Board Games event from
5-7pm! We will have various boba flavors, games to play, raffle prizes, and
even more people to meet!




-- 
Diana Gandara (she/her/hers)
A.B. Candidate in Sociology
Secondary in Educational Studies
Harvard College | Class of 2024

FYRE mailing list
FYRE@lists.hcs.harvard.edu

-286746452.subject: The Q is now open
-286746452.text:
Dear Harvard students:

Course evaluations for the 2023 spring term are now open.

Evaluations will be open now through Monday, May 15. Beginning May 15th,
students who have completed all of their evaluations will be able to view any of
their grades that have been submitted.

To complete your evaluation, use the following link:

https://harvard.bluera.com/harvard

or

Choose this link to evaluate [https://harvard.bluera.com/harvard]
[https://harvard.bluera.com/harvard/a.aspx?s=380_2_1HV4JfQnc5z]

As the term comes to an end, we wish you all the best on your final papers and
exams.

Sincerely,

FAS Course Evaluation Staff

For more information about the Q, visit http://q.fas.harvard.edu/.
Questions or concerns about evaluations? Email evals@fas.harvard.edu.

-1386218166.subject: [wics-chatter] Fwd: $100,000 Xperiment Stake
-1386218166.text:
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Jadyn Bryden <jadyn@xfund.com>
Date: Tue, Apr 18, 2023 at 8:00‚ÄØAM
Subject: $100,000 Xperiment Stake
To:


Happy Tuesday!

We are super excited to launch the Xperiment Stake: Xfund.com/xperiment. It
is a pleasure to collaborate with each of you and your student
organizations. We would love for each of you to help us judge this
Xperiment and help us determine a winner along with Professor Mike Smith
<https://scholar.harvard.edu/mikesmith/home>. The applications are now open
and they will close on April 30th. We‚Äôll plan to do asynchronous voting of
the top contenders in the first week of May with a synchronous deliberation
for those who can make it (details to come).

Now is the time to share this opportunity with your student organizations,
encourage your friends to apply, and get people excited about starting
their companies! Feel free to share the link to the website:
Xfund.com/xperiement and add a blurb of why your peers should apply! No
team is too early and all verticals are fair game for this Xperiment. Let
me know if you have any questions.

We can‚Äôt wait to create a real opportunity for a team to make their startup
a reality post-graduation. :)

Best,
Jadyn

--
Jadyn Bryden | Xfund
313.613.4704

-1887433740.subject: [wics-chatter] TODAY at 4pm: Breaking into Tech Career Exploration Event @SEC
-1887433740.text:
Happening today at 4pm at the SEC, 2.122/2.123 conference room (2nd floor)!  Come get a breakdown of the tech recruiting process and hear from upperclassmen about their experiences in AI research, SWE internships, startup endeavors and more so you can chart your own path into career opportunities in tech!  Sugar and caffeine pick-me-up included!


[cid:image002.jpg@01D971E8.5FA2B3B0]

Meaghan Shea
Assistant Director, Technology, Data Analytics, Life & Physical Sciences, Entrepreneurship
617-495-4501 / meaghanshea@fas.harvard.edu<mailto:meaghanshea@fas.harvard.edu>  / LinkedIn<https://www.linkedin.com/in/meaghanshea16/>
Pronouns: She/her/hers

Office of Career Services<https://careerservices.fas.harvard.edu/>, Harvard University, Faculty of Arts and Sciences
54 Dunster Street, Cambridge, MA 02138

-- 
www.harvardwics.com
With questions/concerns/anything at all we can help with, reach out to Rachna or Karen! (rachnagupta / karen_li @ college.harvard.edu)
---

-1861352655.text:
[image: Logo]

Citi Group Coffee Chat

This Wednesday (April 19th), SWS associates will have the exclusive
opportunity to participate in a group coffee chat with representatives at
Citi. This is a great opportunity to hear from established professionals in
the banking industry and expand your network. Please RSVP by Wednesday at
noon.

-1210906336.subject: [hcs-d] [RSVP] HAPPENING TODAY 7pm - product in Big Tech!!
-1210906336.text:
TL;DR today, April 18th 7pm on Zoom: Fireside chat w/ Jae Taylor (Founder, ex- Peloton, Twitter, Salesforce, Microsoft) on tech/product leadership (RSVP <https://lu.ma/51g12bod>)

Hey friends,

Join HCS Product Lab on a talk about how to break into the current hottest field within tech ~product~, and how to grow within this role in your company :)

Jae has worked as a senior engineering PM @ Microsoft, director of product management @ Salesforce, group PM @ Twitter, and senior director of product and insights @ Peloton among others, and he has so much ~wisdom~ to share.

Grab some dinner and tune in today, Tuesday, April 18th at 8pm via Zoom ‚Üí RSVP here!! <https://lu.ma/51g12bod>
Cheers,
Aika & folks at HPLüí°

Friday, April 28, 2:00 - 4:00pm ET
Harvard Law School

Harvard Law School (HLS) is excited to welcome Harvard College students who are thinking about applying to law school for a special session. The afternoon will include an outdoor walking tour, a panel with current HLS students, and connecting with the J.D. Admissions team.

-1417278741.subject: Reminder: April 20 Talk, "Individual Contributor to Software VP" with Author and Speaker Steve McConnell
-1417278741.text:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Reminder: April 20  Talk, "Individual Contributor to Software VP" with Author and Speaker Steve McConnell
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you haven't done so yet, register now for the next free ACM TechTalk, "Individual Contributor to Software VP: Four Career Transitions, Many Challenges" (https://acm-org.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_afC2PrxkSS2i3sx13D5Q-g), presented on Thursday, April 20 at 12:00 PM ET/16:00 UTC by Steve McConnell, CEO and Chief Software Engineer at Construx Software. Will Tracz, former Chair of ACM SIGSOFT and Member of the ACM Professional Development Committee, will moderate the questions and answers session following the talk. 

Leave your comments and questions with our speaker now and any time before the live event on ACM's Discourse Page (https://on.acm.org/t/individual-contributor-to-software-vp-four-career-transitions-many-challenges/2725). And check out the page after the webcast for extended discussion with your peers in the computing community, as well as further resources on Software Engineering leadership and more.

(If you'd like to attend but can't make it to the virtual event, you still need to register to receive a recording of the TechTalk when it becomes available.)

Note: You can stream this and all ACM TechTalks on your mobile device, including smartphones and tablets.


Software leadership is hard! This talk covers the top challenges that emerging software leaders face as they pass through four distinct career transitions: I.C. to technical lead, then to manager, then to director, and ultimately to VP. Understand the issues that unnecessarily cause some potentially good leaders to drop off the path. Steve McConnell, the award-winning author of Code Complete, describes the detailed challenges involved in each transition and the key factors needed to navigate each transition successfully. He presents a holistic model for understanding how roles, responsibilities, and skills must evolve as a software professional's career progresses. 

Duration: 60 minutes (including audience Q&A)

Presenter:
Steve McConnell, CEO and Chief Software Engineer, Construx Software

Steve McConnell is CEO and Chief Software Engineer at Construx Software, where he consults to a broad range of industries and oversees Construx's consulting and training offerings. Steve is the best-selling author of the industry classic "Code Complete," as well as" Software Estimation: Demystifying the Black Art, Rapid Development," and other titles. Steve has served as Editor in Chief of IEEE Software magazine and Chair of the IEEE Computer Society's Professional Activities Board. Readers of Software Development magazine voted Steve one of the three most influential people in the software industry, along with Bill Gates and Linus Torvalds. Steve can be reached at stevemcc@construx.com.

Moderator:

Will Tracz, Former Chair of ACM SIGSOFT; Member, ACM Professional Development Committee

When he retired, Dr. Tracz was a principal software engineer/application architect for the Global Combat Support System - Air Force (GCSS-AF) program. He is currently the Special Projects Coordinator of the ACM Special Interest Group on Software Engineering (SIGSOFT), a member of the ACM Professional Development Committee, and US, ACM representative of the International Federation for Information Processing (IFIP) Technical Committee (TC) 2 - Software Theory and Practice. He has served as the editor of the ACM SIGSOFT Software Engineering Notes, general chair of the International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE), and the ACM Foundations of Software Engineering (FSE).

Visit learning.acm.org/techtalks-archive for our full archive of past TechTalks.
You are subscribed with: eelaafzahid@college.harvard.edu

Unsubscribe:  https://optout.acm.org/unsubscribe.cfm?rm=RLHFHwF954D9FCFC14CE43E0544370EE4913B4C436A63765569554C534F577468506D67&ln=ACM-WEBINAR

-1569417733.subject: [Adams-molotov] Help Save the Press!!
-1569417733.text:
[image: image.png]
party in the igloo Friday night... but only if you save the press :/

Hey Molotov!

Help Save the Bow and Arrow Press!

It is one of the only open presses for student use here at Harvard and is a
cool part of Adams House. Unfortunately, a decision has been made that the
press is likely to be removed during renovations this fall.
*If you will miss the Bow and Arrow Press and want to save the Press please
fill out this short anonymous form
<https://forms.gle/2j7eUnnwqdM6KDED6> ASAP *
Thanks, Adams :)

Selorm

-1700559251.text:
Please fill out our *SURVEY <https://forms.gle/6WMB5tH6qXzkYj2k7>**!*
Hey everyone! We are doing a research project for our class, Race in a
Polarized America, and we need YOU to fill out our survey! It will only
take 5 minutes and your responses will be kept completely confidential.
Please fill out the survey here <https://forms.gle/6WMB5tH6qXzkYj2k7>. We
greatly appreciate it!

-1574199694.subject: [hcs-d] HCS x Jane Street OCaml Bee [DATE CHANGE]
-1574199694.text:
Wanna flex your OCaml skills? Unsure what to do after taking CS51?

Come to the annual HCS x Jane Street OCaml Bee on *April 28, 12-2pm,
Harvard Hall 104!*
Players will compete in pairs for prizes, taking turns solving OCaml
problems with a twist!
You can either sign up to *watch or play*, and everyone gets free merch and
food! You can read the full rules here
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1yp8Onorcc57XehEwG3Ln7lLuozbrA_SOK35ADJXYQww/edit?usp=sharing>
!

>>> RSVP for Jane Street Merch & Catering
<https://forms.gle/p2fHySSwQX2yC3F56> <<<
*note the date & time change*
[image: OCaml Bee.png]

-1677001788.subject: [ADAMS] Fwd: [PSA-Harvard] [RSVP REQUIRED] HCPSA presents Chaand Raat!!
-1677001788.text:
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Harvard College Pakistani Students Association <hcpsa00@gmail.com>
Date: Thu, Apr 13, 2023 at 12:28‚ÄØPM
Subject: [PSA-Harvard] [RSVP REQUIRED] HCPSA presents Chaand Raat!!
To: <pakistanstudentassociation@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>


Hello beautiful people!


[image: 20f3642b-3614-48ab-a5f6-859511c3950f.jpg]

HCPSA is so incredibly excited to host you all for the cultural event of
the semester, Chand Raat, on April 20th! Our Chand Raat will start at 8:00
PM and will be in the Harvard SOCH Penthouse (take the elevator up). Chand
Raat, translating to Night of the Moon, is a South Asian tradition that
takes place on the eve of the Islamic holiday Eid ul-Fitr. This night is
filled with festivities, traditional food, mehndi, and much more! We are
excited to recreate this experience for you all! Even if you don‚Äôt
typically observe this holiday, we encourage everyone to come. Please RSVP
here <https://forms.gle/A35kxiMvVAfC7z9r8> or with the link in the QR code
(RSVP is required)! Looking forward to seeing you all! Please feel free to
reach out with any questions or concerns.

Lots of love,
HCPSA
_______________________________________________
PakistanStudentAssociation mailing list
PakistanStudentAssociation@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/pakistanstudentassociation


-- 
Malaika Syeda Zaidi
Harvard College | Class of 2024
A.B. Candidate in the History of Science
Secondary in Global Health and Health Policy

-695937603.subject: Re: [HoCo-announce] Adams House Spring Formal 2023
-695937603.text:
*LAST DAY FOR EARLY BIRD TICKETS*
tickets are on sale *now! *purchase *here*
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdU9wUBajblt3leBiH6VtZas31kaHJgpP6qmB1qCwV-EpvEzA/viewform?usp=sf_link>
*early bird sales* from now *until* *4/19:* $15 for 1 & $30 for 2
*regular* *prices* from 4/19 until capacity is reached: $20 for 1 & $35 for
2
formal tickets are SEF-able -  if your SEF funds have run out,
please email *adams@fas.harvard.edu <adams@fas.harvard.edu>*

On Fri, Apr 14, 2023 at 11:30‚ÄØAM Adams HoCo Publicity <
adamshocoannounce@gmail.com> wrote:

> With love from the 92nd HoCo

-1999813673.subject: [Fyre] Write to a Friend: Supporting those protecting the Weelaunee Forest
-1999813673.text:
*Write to a Friend: Supporting those protecting the Weelaunee Forest*

Come to a postcard-making event for Intersectional Earth Week with the
Climate Coalition tomorrow, *Wednesday 19th from 5-6pm* in the *Women's
Center Lounge!*

*11 forest defenders are in jail for alleged domestic terrorism from
protesting ‚ÄòCop City‚Äô in Atlanta, Georgia. Join us to learn about the
DefendTheAtlantaForest movement and be part of a conversation on how
communities have been affected. Finally, write postcards to our friends
protecting the Weelaunee Forest!*

[image: Write to a Friend Supporting those protecting the Weelaunee
Forest.png]

_______________________________________________
FYRE mailing list
FYRE@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/fyre

-517307581.subject: [Fyre] HUBC ELECTIONS THIS SUNDAY!
-517307581.text:
Hey y'all!

HUBC elections will take place this *Sunday, April 23rd, from 7-9 PM in
Sever Hall 207 *(there will be food!).

As a reminder, to run for a position on the HUBC board and vote in
elections, you must have been involved in HUBC in some capacity this year,
either as a board member, a case team leader, or an analyst. *If you're
interested in running for board, please fill out this form
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSf0xJfkM8_aB1kjuoVjVkpzHcUvc4qZoNF4RqcAlIcag7Sz9Q/viewform?usp=sf_link>
and upload your position paper by Friday Morning. *The form also contains a
description of the positions.

Feel free to reach out if you have any questions.

All the best,

HUBC principles



--

_______________________________________________
FYRE mailing list
FYRE@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/fyre

-258088390.subject: [Fyre] Fwd: Act in the Harvard Playwright Festival: This Saturday!
-258088390.text:
Hi,

Seeking undergraduate actors (or students who do not identify as actors but
are willing to commit to a reading of *That Time When Aliens Incinerated
the ATM*, written by Mireya S√°nchez-Maes.) The script is an absurdist
comedy that follows a family as they watch an alien attack unfold on the
television. Rehearsal runs *this Saturday (Apr. 22) from 11:00am to 2:00
pm, and the reading is that same day from 8:00 to 9:00 pm in Farkas 203*.
You would work under the directorship of* Carla Mirabel Rodr√≠guez*, who
works as a director at Boston's Huntington Theatre. If you are interested
or happen to know friends who might be, please reach out to me at
msanchezmaes@college.harvard.edu <echo@college.harvard.edu> or (575)
649-1736. I would be indebted to you, and am happy to buy you cookies!

Warmly,
Mireya S√°nchez-Maes
--

-1659764400.text:
Calling all Harvard undergraduates!

If you are interested in Latin America, promoting democracy, and an
impactful trip during next spring break, you should apply to staff the XXIX
Summit of the Americas during spring break 2024!

Harvard Association Cultivating Inter-American Democracy has officially
opened its applications for staff! It is the world‚Äôs largest simulation of
the Organization of American States (OAS) for high school students in Latin
America. The topics in committees range from politics to economics, health,
Indigenous and immigration rights, etc.!

The conference will be in a yet-to-be disclosed Latin American country
during spring break, and following the conference, there is a
post-conference trip during spring break, as well. Last year, there were
400+ students from 8 countries who participated in the conference.

You can speak either English, Spanish, or Portuguese. No MUN experience
required
* and all identities welcome to apply!*
Application link is here: *tinyurl.com/haciaxxixapply
<http://tinyurl.com/haciaxxixapply>*

Join our info session on Monday, April 24th for more information!

-1435233174.subject: [Fyre] Earth Week ‚Äî 4/17 ethics and politics of climate change workshop
-1435233174.text:
As a part of Intersectional Earth Week
<https://harvardclimatecoalition.squarespace.com/intersectional-earth-week>
hosted by the Harvard Climate Coalition, the Program on Science, Technology
and Society at HKS is hosting a workshop discussion about the ethics and
politics of addressing climate change. Join us* (on Monday, April 17th from
4-5pm at HLS in Hauser 105* ‚Äî where there will be snacks!) to discuss and
reflect on not just what we should do about climate change, but how we know
what the ‚Äúright thing‚Äù to do might be in the first place and what is at
stake in the kinds of futures we collectively envision.

This deliberative exercise will focus on a hypothetical proposal to make
carbon a global currency as a means of adapting to climate change. From the
perspectives of individuals, experts, and societies, participants will
discuss how the problem of climate change gets framed and distributed, who
is responsible for ‚Äúsolving‚Äù it, and how our sense of who we are and who we
want to be gets wrapped up in these efforts.

RSVP
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdXxePqji01XGqy6K67q3bGbBYz_mXuqNEA-mvs2HHvNR88wg/viewform>
and learn more here!

[image: IMG_0184.jpg]

Thanks,
Aishani

Looking for a Mother's Helper!

Hi everyone :) The family I work for is looking for extra help this summer
since I will not be around in Boston. Below is some information about
them!!

We are two Harvard grads who met at Currier House and now live one block
from the Quad. We have three children (4.5yrs, 3yrs, and 18 months) and are
looking for a capable, fun college student to help out during the summer.
Schedule would be flexible -- some babysitting, a few hours on a weekday
afternoon or weekend morning etc, with the option to continue working
during the school year starting in the fall.

the fun and pitch-in -- playing, activities, helping out around the house.
The kids love to play in the garden, read, do legos, color, etc!

Please reach out to Becky at rsmwyman@gmail.com if interested.

I am a rising junior studying Social Studies. I like reading, art,

up around 9 am on most days. I really value quiet and cleanliness. :)

Adreanna

-183198229.subject: A graduation gift for you
-183198229.text:
https://view.hu.harvard.edu/?qs=660668bea206f32715673f25fdae286084a449b16d0dca6d3a101faa8652f34925b533fe79c936c15d12021b62fc166faabb6eebdb10d6c291803caf26f02fa4faa116f8df0e1184afaa1e5323eaee63 
View in your browser .



 
 


 
Congratulations, Class of 2023! With graduation quickly approaching, all of us at the Harvard Clubs of New York City and Boston want to share a gift with you—a special membership opportunity for each Club.


Becoming a member is a great way to stay connected to Harvard and build your network as our Clubs have extensive reach into the alumni community. Through membership, you’ll have the opportunity to connect with thousands of alumni living in NYC and Boston who are ready to support you in this next phase of your life.


Don’t worry if you won’t be living in NYC or Boston. You can still take advantage of these membership offers no matter where you call home. 


A special membership offer

Harvard Club of New York City
As a member of the HCNY community, you will have access to Clubhouse dining, including the Rooftop restaurant and terrace, lounge and coworking spaces, guest rooms, and athletics. Plus, enjoy a full calendar of events including networking socials, talks, concerts, holiday celebrations, and fitness classes.

https://click.hu.harvard.edu/?qs=5a5748ca6ce1e8ff2de9c87706e3005d2b0148a4f8204f1c7ca2fc1c7f88ac73390f4e2f3e9666ed9d7b236b459be5f10b22b54ff5957935 
Learn More and Apply 



May
25

Complimentary Membership

Commencement Dinner—Seating Times at 5:00 p.m., 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. (ET) 

Harvard Club of Boston
Members enjoy more than 250 club activities and events per year and facilities, including dining, coworking spaces, overnight rooms, and athletics. If you apply and join in advance, you will have the opportunity to register for the annual Commencement dinner at the clubhouse with family and friends. Limited reservations available.

https://click.hu.harvard.edu/?qs=5a5748ca6ce1e8ffac43c6de65261637bb95ed1f4b91b6e126ea51db984a6122e36651045faf7c9558ef27d6ecacb54719c825044b05ffdd 
Learn More 


https://click.hu.harvard.edu/?qs=5a5748ca6ce1e8ff316e2b1d60a55b78a33a520f797086feae0e24f5f0f07d47f2f750d24fab85590c1de76124efa1542769e8da622191cb 
Apply Now 



Again, congratulations, and we hope to see you soon.

 
 
Warmly, 
 


The Harvard Clubs of New York City and Boston 




 
 


 Harvard Alumni Association  |  124 Mount Auburn Street, 6th Floor  |  Cambridge, MA 02138.
Your HAA ID number is: 0005007233

By David Leonhardt
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/D-cOEetx-r4tfxunBaT9XA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIkxcP0S_~~]

Good morning. We look at India‚Äôs looming status as the world‚Äôs most populous
country and also give you the latest on the Fox News settlement.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/19/multimedia/19themorning-lede/19themorning-lede-jumbo.jpg]A
train station in Mumbai, India.Atul Loke for The New York Times


RISING AND FALLING

The United Nations released data this morning confirming that India will soon
surpass China as the most populous country. When that happens, it will be the
first time in centuries that China does not have the world‚Äôs largest population.

The milestone is focusing attention on both India‚Äôs potential to become a global
power and the significant challenges that it faces. My Times colleagues who are
based in India will be writing about the subject frequently this year, and I
want to use today‚Äôs newsletter to frame these issues.

China‚Äôs economic and geopolitical rise over the past few decades has changed the
world
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/73rnh3NGSI4sAnflyEDncw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIkxcP0TfaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vaW50ZXJhY3RpdmUvMjAxOC8xMS8xOC93b3JsZC9hc2lhL2NoaW5hLXJ1bGVzLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQxOSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDU0NyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMwODAyJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkP1zHP2QEBRSRUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
If India can use its size ‚Äî and China‚Äôs declining population ‚Äî to catch up, the
world would change again.


THE FIRST APPLE STORE

China today is vastly richer than India, but that is a relatively recent
phenomenon.

In the late 1970s, India was more affluent (based on the most telling measure,
economic output per person). Since then, the two countries have followed very
different paths:

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/18/briefing/oakImage-1681845821564/oakImage-1681845821564-jumbo.png]Source:
World Bank | Data is in current U.S. dollars. | By The New York Times

What happened after the late 1970s? Under Deng Xiaoping, its ruler at the time,
China began to open its economy to market forces and foreign investment. It
moved away from the inefficiencies of state-run communism.

But the government did so in a measured way, rather than fully embracing
laissez-faire capitalism. China maintained trade protections that helped its
companies grow: In exchange for allowing foreign companies to build factories,
China restricted those companies‚Äô ability to sell goods in China and required
them to share technology with local companies. This mix of market capitalism and
government regulation was the same one that other countries ‚Äî including the
United States, long ago ‚Äî have used to industrialize.

The strategy worked phenomenally well. Hundreds of millions of Chinese citizens
moved from poor, rural areas to take factory jobs in cities. The resulting
decline in poverty may be the largest in human history.

India was never a communist country, but it did have a weak socialist-style
economy in the 1970s suffering the aftereffects of British colonialism. And
India was slower to modernize than China, as my colleagues Mujib Mashal and Alex
Travelli ‚Äî both based in Delhi ‚Äî point out in a new story about the population
milestone
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/xhiVwg0afJrJlVJpWw_9Qw~~/AAAAAQA~_XMc_ZAQFFJFSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].

‚ÄúIndia started opening its quasi-socialist economy nearly a decade later,‚Äù Mujib
and Alex write. ‚ÄúIts approach remained piecemeal, constrained by tricky
coalition politics and the competing interests of industrialists, unions,
farmers and factions across its social spectrum.‚Äù

India‚Äôs lag allowed China to grab a first-mover advantage. By the 1990s, China‚Äôs
manufacturing sector was developed enough to be much more efficient than
India‚Äôs. Even though wages were somewhat lower in India, many foreign companies
chose to locate in China.

One factor was the Chinese government‚Äôs aggressive investments in roads,
airports, rail networks and other infrastructure. Today, transit in China is
often more advanced than in the United States
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/kVx93rE1HUioD74YXc2M6g~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIkxcP0TfaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8xNC9vcGluaW9uL2NoaW5hLWFtZXJpY2EtcmVsYXRpb25zaGlwLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQxOSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDU0NyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMwODAyJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkP1zHP2QEBRSRUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
Transportation in India tends to be less convenient.

India‚Äôs recent leaders, including Narendra Modi, the current prime minister,
have absorbed this lesson and tried to catch up, spending large sums on
infrastructure. They have made significant progress even though China remains
far ahead, Mujib and Alex explain. ‚ÄúIndia‚Äôs time has arrived,‚Äù Modi recently
said.

(Related: Apple opened its first retail store in India
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/IGzMQn1Azzcql4dMyS84sg~~/AAAAAQA~_XMc_ZAQFFJFSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
yesterday.)


INDIA‚ÄôS GENDER GAP

A second factor is education. China‚Äôs population has long been more educated
than India‚Äôs, with higher literacy rates and larger shares of people completing
grade school, high school and college. Education was one of the few economic
successes of the brutal Mao Zedong era, from the late 1940s through mid-1970s.
And educated people make for more productive workers
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/PT7tCtFaOBOaPr7qYGKZ6A~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmIkxcP0TWaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAxMS8wNi8yNi9zdW5kYXktcmV2aWV3LzI2bGVvbmhhcmR0Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQxOSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDU0NyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMwODAyJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkP1zHP2QEBRSRUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
in both white-collar and blue-collar jobs, research has shown.

Importantly, the Communist Party‚Äôs focus on learning included both girls and
boys. India, by contrast, has large gender gaps in literacy and educational
attainment.

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/18/briefing/oakImage-1681849325746/oakImage-1681849325746-jumbo.png]Source:
World Bank | Data for India is through 2018. | By The New York Times

These gaps contribute to employment gaps between men and women. Only about
one-fifth of Indian women work in a formal job. ‚ÄúIn terms of education,
employment, digital access and various other parameters, girls and women do not
have equal access to life-empowering tools and means as the boys and men have,‚Äù
Poonam Muttreja, the executive director of the Population Foundation of India, a
research group, told The Times. ‚ÄúThis needs to change for India to truly reap
the demographic dividend.‚Äù

The ‚Äúdemographic dividend‚Äù is a reference to recent population trends in India:
The country‚Äôs largest age group is people in the prime of their working lives.
China‚Äôs population is aging rapidly, because of its longtime one-child policy,
and declined last year for the first time since the 1960s (when Mao‚Äôs policies
caused a famine). The World Bank projects China‚Äôs working-age population to fall
to 600 million by 2050 and India‚Äôs to rise to 800 million.

The demographic dividend gives India a chance to expand both its economy and its
global influence. One big question is whether it can do so (as these charts show
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/rQeox6rtaJ9SREAg8xDWAA~~/AAAAAQA~_XMc_ZAQFFJFSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]).
A second question is what kind of country it will be.

Indian leaders are proud of their country‚Äôs status as the world‚Äôs largest
democracy, and India‚Äôs relations with the United States are better than with
China. In the continuing global competition between democracies and autocracies,
India could be a key player.

But it‚Äôs still not clear exactly which side it will be on. I recommend reading
the story by Mujib and Alex
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/xhiVwg0afJrJlVJpWw_9Qw~~/AAAAAQA~_XMc_ZAQFFJFSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~],
which points out Modi‚Äôs continuing crackdown on dissent and embrace of strongman
tactics.

In data transmission, Manchester encoding is a form of digital encoding in which
a data bit's state -- 0 or 1 -- is represented by the transition from one
voltage level to another.

the corresponding IP address or domain name system (DNS) record.

-1146809348.text:
Interested in hearing from an Indigenous leader in healthcare? Join the
Harvard Quechua Initiative on Global Indigeneity on *Friday, April 21th at
3:00 pm in the SCC Mt. Auburn Room *to hear from Rachel Wilbur MPH, PhD.
Dr. Wilbur will be talking to us about her work addressing the impact
social determinants have on Native Americans and Alaska Native Healthcare
with a Q&A session afterwards.

-563707213.subject: "The Head of the Cottonmouth" by Roger Reeves
-563707213.text:
Why would I abandon the hunger-suffering

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 19, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** The Head of the Cottonmouth (http://poets.org/poem/head-cottonmouth?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
Roger Reeves (https://poets.org/poet/roger-reeves?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID)

Why would I abandon the hunger-suffering

Vulture, spread-winged in the middle of the road

Eating a rabbit while it snows? Wouldn‚Äôt you

Want to touch, watch his comrades close down the sky

And, in a black circle, eat red on the white Earth?

And when the hiss of something slithers in‚Äî

Panic un-paused‚Äîwouldn‚Äôt you watch the circle

Break into black leaves pulled from the earth and flung

Into the falling sky? Wouldn‚Äôt you want to be

A servant of this paradise, not a God

In front of a screen, naked, lonely, asking‚Äî

No more a God than the crown of vultures

Frightened by a hiss that was a tire deflating?

Why would you trade Paradise for an argument

About Paradise?
Copyright ¬© 2023 by Roger Reeves. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on April 19, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS5295065867.mp3?updated=1681504590&mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID

‚ÄúThis poem is part of a longer series of poems called ‚ÄòThe Head of the Cottonmouth‚Äô and ‚ÄòThe Cottonmouth‚Äôs Head.‚Äô The series started with an incident with a cottonmouth in Arkansas and the ritual of cutting off its head and burying it far away from the body. I began to think of this sort of ritual in relationship to other rituals around fear, cleanliness, disease, and the pandemic. The pandemic caused many of us to retreat behind our screens and seek validation there, distancing us from others as well as ourselves. This poem asks us to come back to ourselves, to our finitude, to our hungers.‚Äù
‚ÄîRoger Reeves
http://poets.org/poet/roger-reeves?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID

Roger Reeves (http://poets.org/poet/roger-reeves?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID) is the author of Dark Days: Fugitive Essays (Graywolf Press, 2023), Best Barbarian (W. W. Norton, 2022), and King Me (Copper Canyon Press, 2013). The recipient of the 2023 Kingsley Tuft Award, a 2015 Whiting Award, and a National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship, he is an associate professor of poetry at the University of Texas at Austin.

http://poets.org/poet/roger-reeves?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://bookshop.org/a/262/9780393609332?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID

Best Barbarian (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9780393609332?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID)
(W. W. Norton & Company, 2022)

https://bookshop.org/a/262/9780393609332?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID


‚ÄúOne Fire, Quenched with Another‚Äù by Jeremy Michael Clark
read more (http://poets.org/poem/one-fire-quenched-another?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID)
‚ÄúWhat the Silence Said‚Äù by Marie Howe
read more (http://poets.org/poem/what-silence-said?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID)
https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/677665/eb-and-flow-by-kelly-j-baptist/?ref=PRHDB4955DB7759&aid=48144&linkid=PRHDB4955DB7759&mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID
Thanks to U.S. poet laureate Ada Lim√≥n (https://poets.org/poet/ada-limon?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID) , author of The Hurting Kind (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781639550494?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID)  (Milkweed Editions, 2022), who curated Poem-a-Day for this month‚Äôs weekdays. As of this year, the U.S. poet laureate guest editorship during National Poetry Month (https://poets.org/library-congress-and-poem-day?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a collaboration between the Academy and the Library of Congress. Read or listen to a Q&A (https://poets.org/April-2023-poem-a-day-editor-ada-limon?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID)  about Lim√≥n‚Äôs curatorial approach and find out more about our guest editors for the year (https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID) .


http://poets.org/donate/pad?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID
‚ÄúPoem-a-Day is brilliant because it makes space in the everyday racket for something as meaningful as a poem.‚Äù ‚ÄîTracy K. Smith

If this series is meaningful to you, join the community of Poem-a-Day supporters by making a gift today (https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=90edc931c8&mc_eid=UNIQID)  in honor of National Poetry Month. Now serving more than 320,000 daily subscribers, this publication is only possible thanks to the contributions of readers like you.

-1768500979.subject: üçø Streaming strike
-1768500979.text:
‚Ä¶and Gen Z rides retail therapy to record debt levels
Disclosures
 

Show business, meet show labor (David McNew/Getty Images)

 
Yesterday‚Äôs Market Moves
 
Dow Jones
33,977 (-0.03%)		S&P 500
4,155 (+0.09%)		Nasdaq
12,153 (-0.04%)		Bitcoin
$30,373 (+3.19%)
Dow Jones
33,977 (-0.03%)		S&P 500
4,155 (+0.09%)
Nasdaq
12,153 (-0.04%)		Bitcoin
$30,373 (+3.19%)

Hey Snackers,

Started from the bottom, now we're‚Ä¶ a deepfake? An AI-generated song featuring the voices of Drake and The Weeknd went viral on TikTok and Spotify. Then Universal Music had it pulled on infringement grounds. Last week Drizzy warned bots: "this is the final straw."

Stocks were mostly flat yesterday as investors chewed on more big-bank earnings and comments from two Fed officials, who both supported at least one more rate hike in May.

Scene

The WGA approves a Hollywood writers strike, signaling a potential shift for streaming

EXT. HOLLYWOOD ‚Äî DAY‚Ä¶ In a nearly unanimous vote this week, 9K members of the Writers Guild of America approved a TV and movie writers strike if a new contract agreement isn‚Äôt reached by May 1 with studios (aka: their employers). A record 80% of WGA members turned out to vote, signaling clear dissatisfaction among the teams creating your fave shows.

  • Buffering: Streamers like Netflix and Disney+ are playing a major role in the negotiations. Streaming has led to shorter TV seasons and exclusive rights, causing a steep drop in residual payouts to writers (watching ‚ÄúSuccession‚Äù five times doesn‚Äôt count as a rerun). The WGA wants a new formula to account for the shift.

  • WG-AI: The union also wants studios to regulate the use of AI ‚Äî and to bar studios from lowering pay or reducing rights and credits for content that leverages the tech.

  • Not guaranteed: The WGA authorized a strike in 2017 but ultimately reached a last-minute deal to avoid one. The last WGA work stoppage, in 2007, lasted three months and cost California over $2B.

Lights, camera, no action‚Ä¶ While a strike isn‚Äôt certain, Hollywood is making moves to prepare. Streaming platforms have several shows wrapped and ready to roll out in the event of a stoppage, and renewals to shows like ‚ÄúAbbott Elementary‚Äù were given out earlier than usual. Networks are also bulking up on animated shows (which are written far in advance) and unscripted TV (maybe Netflix can figure out live reunions by May).

THE TAKEAWAY

Old rules can catch up to disruptors‚Ä¶ Now that streaming has transitioned from industry disruptor to industry standard, evading old issues that networks and studios know well (like labor disputes) can only last so long. Similar battles are underway in other tech-disrupted industries like ecomm and ride-hail (think: Uber's gig work and taxi union issues).

Charge

Gen Z and millennials rack up record debt as ‚Äúfinancial avoidance‚Äù leads to retail therapy

Self-soothing with an Amazon order‚Ä¶ But seven pairs of Crocs won‚Äôt help the real problem (neither will that popular fluffy headband). US consumer debt hit a record high of $4.8 trillion in February as inflation-strapped Americans took out high-interest loans and maxed out credit cards. The IOU blues are especially bad for younger generations:

  • Pricey cold-brew habit: Millennials‚Äô average credit-card debt rose nearly 30% in March from a year earlier, hitting a whopping $5.8K, Credit Karma reported.

  • Thrifting or splurging? Gen Z‚Äôs average credit-card debt soared 40% to $2.8K as Shein hauls and Celsius habits weighed down balances.

Need those fuzzy slides‚Ä¶ to ease the sliding state of finances. April is financial literacy month, but many appear to be choosing ‚Äúfinancial avoidance‚Äù instead. Sticky inflation, high interest rates, and dwindling savings have fueled anxiety. Psychologists say that ignoring your finances and overspending to cope with stress is typical among younger generations. The pandemic just made it more common.

  • Saw it on TikTok: Social media has exacerbated zillennials‚Äô splurge cycle. Lots of younger users make purchases based on influencer recs, a recent Pew survey suggested. And over 60% of users said they regretted a social-inspired impulse purchase, Bankrate found.
THE TAKEAWAY

The bar for ‚Äúdoing OK‚Äù is a lot higher‚Ä¶ In December, over half of Americans earning more than $100K/year said they lived check to check. As prices rise faster than wages, US workers are demanding a minimum of $76K to start a new job ‚Äî up $2K+ from November. Meanwhile, the overconsumption cycle has also raised the bar for getting by.

What else we're Snackin'

  • Pill: Johnson & Johnson posted expectation-beating sales growth thanks to strong results across divisions (think: pharma products, shampoo). The Tylenol and Band-Aid maker raised annual guidance by $1B.

  • APY: As interest rates go up, deposits at banks like Charles Schwab, State Street, and M&T Bank shrank last quarter as customers moved cash out of checking accounts in search of higher returns.

  • Kicks: Nike said it'll sell digital shoeboxes next month, each containing an NFT styled after the brand's sneakers (blockchain of choice: polygon). As of last year, Nike's NFT sales had totaled more than $184M.

  • Bans: Montana‚Äôs newly passed House bill to ban TikTok downloads could be signed into law soon, but it's unclear how the legislation would be enforced. The bill's author said the app "endangers" Montanans.

  • Marcus: Goldman Sachs' first-quarter profit fell 18% from last year as losses piled up in its consumer-lending biz. Still, consumer-heavy rivals like Citi, Chase, and BoA notched higher profits.

üç™ Thanks for Snacking with us! Want to share the Snacks? Invite your friends to sign up here.

Snack Fact Of the Day
20% of Americans who've used buy now, pay later apps have used them to pay for groceries
Read more

Wednesday
  • Earnings expected from Morgan Stanley, Ally Financial, Citizens Bank, and Abbott

-1842790481.subject: [Fyre] DESCENDANT 4/19 Screening & Panel @ Harvard College
-1842790481.text:
*RSVP HERE* <https://forms.gle/LBeCPjYRkJSpMxrf9>
[image: Descendent Film & Panel Poster (1).png]

*Descendant* is a powerful documentary that shares the story of the
descendants of the survivors of the Clotilda, believed to be the last ship
that carried enslaved Africans to the United States." *- President Barack
Obama*

In Africatown‚Äìthe community founded by the Clotilda survivors and
maintained by their descendants near Mobile, Alabama‚Äìthe tragedies of
systemic racism live alongside an embodied, enduring celebration of Black
resilience. *Descendant* invites us to consider what preservation,
solidarity, and justice look like in the context of long‚Äìand presently
unfolding‚Äìhistories of gentrification, environmental racism, and contested
narratives.

Join us from* 6-9PM on Wednesday, April 19th at Leverett Library Theater* for
a screening of the award-winning film Descendant, followed by a panel
conversation with Veda Robbins, Dr. Kern Jackson, and Ramsey Sprauge
moderated by Aaryan Morrison '22.5. Food will be served.
This event is a student-led initiative, with support from the
Harvard College Race Relations Tutors and The Harvard Foundation for
Intercultural and Race Relations. RSVP here
<https://forms.gle/fbutobuzNtmWTQXi6>.
-- 
Aaryan Morrison
*2023 Harvard College Alex G. Booth '30 Fellow*
*Independent Researcher and Project Manager *
*B.A. in Social Studies, Harvard College 2022*
*amorrison1@college.harvard.edu <amorrison1@college.harvard.edu>*

-2058625140.subject: Princeton Tutoring Session Recap (Record 27530)
-2058625140.text:
This recap was sent from Princeton Tutoring's mail servers. If you would like to respond to the tutor, please REPLY ALL to this email. Thanks.

  Student: Olivia Dessalines
  Tutor: Eelaaf Zahid
  Subject(s): General Math - Middle School (excluding Algebra)
  Date: 04/08/2023
  Location: Online
  Time Tutored: 10:00 - 11:00
  Next Scheduled Session: Sat, 04/29  9:00 AM (https://harvard.zoom.us/j/93719566999?pwd=c2h2WC9VWGc3V1JPc1RuYXlPTTRxUT09)

  Material Covered:
  We first reviewed the word problems homework. Olivia had only 1 correct out of 6. We then worked on practicing with word problems. I first walked Olivia through one problem and showed her what to underline and how to set up the problem. Afterwards, Olivia guided me through 9 problems correctly. We emphasized underlining the important information in the problem and then thinking about what the problem was asking. 

  Additional Comments:
  Dear Amber,

I had a great session with Olivia last week. She was able to walk me through word problems and how to approach them. I highly encourage Olivia using underlining as a technique to figure out all complicated problems. She should also re-read the question many times to make sure she understands what is being asked. 

I apologize for the delay in recap. Finals and final project this past week and Ramadan wrapping up soon has made me quite busy and forgetful of pending tasks. 

If you have any questions or concerns, please let me know. 

Best,

Eelaaf 

  Assignments for Next Week:
  Please find the homework in the google drive. 

https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1q32pY23c4-aQg6q7_DCy9lokPIXoRS9n?usp=sharing

If you have any questions or concerns, please let me know. 

Regards,

Eelaaf 

  Assignments for Next Week:
  Correct homework from last time.

-1110834740.subject: [Fyre] PBHA Housing Awareness Month! Speaker Panel (this Friday!) + Community Organizing Training
-1110834740.text:
[image: üì¢] It‚Äôs Housing Awareness Month! [image: üì¢]

HAM's Goals:

- raise awareness about housing justice on campus

- highlight the work of local housing organizations and the voices of
people impacted by homelessness and housing insecurity

- promote critical housing policy at the local, state, and federal level

This Friday, April 21st, we will be having a speaker panel
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScsJl897MuXEkn8nWTN1F-1-skylxpj1Rl9zNHwjGqGdKEPgg/viewform>
with
three incredible speakers from organizations working towards housing
justice (such as the Massachusetts Housing and Shelter Alliance and
CityLife Vida Urbana, an organization working against housing
discrimination). Sign up for the panel HERE
<https://forms.gle/7rkLY8DqFUnvnz6U6>.

Join us for a community organizing training from 5:30-7 pm on Thursday,
April 27th! We will discuss community organizing practices and principles
in the context of housing justice and will also go over current housing
justice movements in Massachusetts. The interest form is linked HERE
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfNucNxGkfUTSpN3l1zVF37Q6PcTOt65ynDDsaNaTY3-Wop1Q/viewform>
.

Here is our LinkTree <https://linktr.ee/housingawarenessmonth> with other
community events related to housing justice and quick action items you can
take to help push housing policy forward.

To learn more about housing in the US, Harvard's Joint Center for Housing
State of the Nation's Housing Report
<https://www.jchs.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/reports/files/Harvard_JCHS_State_Nations_Housing_2022.pdf>
and Citizens' Housing and Planning Association Report
<https://www.chapa.org/sites/default/files/2023-02/annual-report-2022-final_0.pdf>
are
great resources to check out!

If you have any questions or suggestions, feel free to reach out to Sophie
at advocacyhousing@pbha.org and Sophia at advocacy@y2yharvardsquare.org!



[image: üíó] The Housing Awareness Month Committee [image: üíó]

_______________________________________________
FYRE mailing list
FYRE@lists.hcs.harvard.edu
https://lists.hcs.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/fyre

-953899743.subject: You're Invited! üì©
-953899743.text:
View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/2df2ff1ae8a4/tvyvzjfc9l-3178013?e=80df76ea2d)
https://dso.college.harvard.edu
You're Invited!
The last edition of You're Invited for the semester will go out Wednesday, April 26.
Want your event featured in You're Invited? Submit events with our newsletter event submission form (https://form.jotform.com/92485668784175) ! The deadline for submissions is Tuesdays at 5pm EST. You MUST submit a flyer with your submission form. This newsletter goes out every Wednesday.

Descendents: Documentary Screening and Talk (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeF_dslZczp5Xl-rquQP6kTcNMvG4fzNaVJIXkP1Szzdc9dlA/viewform)
April 19th
6:00PM EST
Join us at Leverett Library Theater for a screening of the award-winning film Descendant, followed by a panel conversation with Veda Robbins, Dr. Kern Jackson, and Ramsey Sprague moderated by Aaryan Morrison '22. Descendant is a powerful documentary that shares the story of the descendants of the survivors of the Clotilda, believed to be the last ship that carried enslaved Africans to the United States.

Gallery Talk: De los Andes al Caribe: El arte americano desde el imperio espa√±ol/From the Andes to the Caribbean: American art from the Spanish Empire (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/gallery-talk-de-los-andes-al-caribe-el-arte-americano-desde-el-imperio-espanol-from-the-andes-to-the-caribbean-american-art-from-the-spanish-empire-4?utm_source=museummarketing&utm_medium=listing&utm_campaign=Ap)
April 20th
12:30PM EST
Join us for a guided look at works of art in the special exhibition from the Andes to the Caribbean, with associate curator Horace D. Ballard.

Traditional Ecological Knowledge Panel: An Indigenous Perspective to Environmental Sciences (https://www.instagram.com/p/Cq_FrKhO076/?img_index=1)
April 20th
5:00PM EST
For Intersectionality Earth Week, Harvard Foundation is hosting a panel featuringIndigenous scientists and activists who are working to uplift indigenous knowledge systems and praxis in their respective fields. Join us for a free dinner in Ticknor Lounge to learn how Indigenous people are reclaiming science and providing alternatives for effective environmental sustainability.

Mine, Yours, Theirs, Ours? Ownership and Stewardship in the Age of Blockchain (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/mine-yours-theirs-ours-ownership-and-stewardship-in-the-age-of-blockchain?utm_source=museummarketing&utm_medium=listing&utm_campaign=Blockchain&utm_id=Mine%2C+Yours%2C+Theirs%2C+Ours%3F+Ownership+and+Stewardship)
April 20th
6:00PM EST
Join an artist, a blockchain researcher, and an award-winning television producer to discuss some of the most pressing cultural issues today. Free admission, but seating is limited.
The Bach Society Orchestra Presents: Season Finale (https://cglink.me/2rf/r376637)
April 21st
8:00PM EST
Join BachSoc in celebrating the end of the semester with their season finale! The concert will feature selections by Faure, Respighi, Handel, and Mendelssohn!
Free and open to the public.
Gender Focus Group (https://www.instagram.com/p/CrJqSk-p-Ji/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link)
What would it look like to build healthy relationships that set a stronger foundation to address patterns of gender and power-based violence? The Harvard College Women's Center and SHARE (Sexual Harassment/Assault Resources and Education) are hoping to host a series of gender-based affinity spaces for the university community in 2023. Come join us and help shape the conversations by attending these focus groups or reaching out via email to hcwc@fas.harvard.edu (mailto:hcwc@fas.harvard.edu) or oge_share@harvard.edu (mailto:oge_share@harvard.edu) .
Our Narratives (https://hksexeced.tfaforms.net/f/event-registration?c=7014V000002Mw2PQAS)
April 21st
4:00PM EST
The Institute of Politics is full of students with rich and complex stories that define their passion for public service. This Friday, join us in the John F. Kennedy Jr. Forum as ten Harvard undergraduates take the stage to deliver TEDx-style talks about their personal journeys into public service and stories of identity.
HUSL Ping-Pong Tournament (https://www.harvardsportslab.com/events/ping-pong-tournament-school-wide)
HUSL is excited to announce their annual ping-pong fundraising tournament. All skill levels are welcomed to play. There will be free food, prizes, raffles, and special guests!All benefits will go to a youth charity in the Cambridge or Boston area.

Women's Lacrosse Senior Day (https://gocrimson.com/splash.aspx?id=splash_10&path=wlax)
April 22nd
2:00PM EST
Come cheer on the Harvard Women‚Äôs Lacrosse team as they take on Columbia in their final regular season game at home this Saturday at Jordan Field. Plus, join us as we celebrate and recognize our nine seniors.

Lyrical Colors, Flowing Stories: Conversations on Paintings with Artist Nilima Sheikh (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/lyrical-colors-flowing-stories-conversations-on-paintings-with-artist-nilima-sheikh?utm_source=museummarketing&utm_medium=listing&utm_campaign=Calderwood&utm_id=Lyrical+Colors%2C+Flowing+Stories%3A+Conversations)
April 22nd
2:00PM EST
In this conversation between Baroda-based artist Nilima Sheikh, scholar Jinah Kim, and curator Ay≈üin Yoltar-Yƒ±ldƒ±rƒ±m, we will explore the themes of color and water in traditional painting of South Asia and how these are reflected in Sheikh‚Äôs work.

Eleganza MMXXIII: Rebirth (https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/eleganza)
April 22nd
7:30PM EST
Buy your tickets for Eleganza 2023: Rebirth!
Eleganza is Harvard's premier fashion and dance showcase. The largest student-run event and only charity fashion show on campus, this highly anticipated night is an opportunity for students of all identities to celebrate fashion, dance, music! Tickets available at bit.ly/Ganza2023 (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdETXLD_tXyQLzX4Yjjobnq37bzv2k5FZfi1ODrAuIYNlwKsQ/viewform) and at the Harvard Box Office.

Gender Focus Group (https://www.instagram.com/p/CrJqSk-p-Ji/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link)
What would it look like to build healthy relationships that set a stronger foundation to address patterns of gender and power-based violence? The Harvard College Women's Center and SHARE (Sexual Harassment/Assault Resources and Education) are hoping to host a series of gender-based affinity spaces for the university community in 2023. Come join us and help shape the conversations by attending these focus groups or reaching out via email to hcwc@fas.harvard.edu (mailto:hcwc@fas.harvard.edu) or oge_share@harvard.edu (mailto:oge_share@harvard.edu) .

Wired Hope: Mental Health and Entrepreneurship with Dr. Calisha Brooks (https://www.lpce.college.harvard.edu/events-1)
Join the Lemann Program on Creativity and Entrepreneurship for a discussion of mental health and entrepreneurship with Dr. Calisha Brooks. During this talk, we will have a candid conversation about the wiring of an entrepreneur, three things impacting their mental and emotional well-being, and three proven practices that provide hope for successful outcomes.

The Sky‚Äôs Not the Limit: My Journey into Space Exploration and STEM (https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/event/2023-mimi-aung-lecture)
April 24th
4:00PM EST
Mimi Aung will share her personal journey as a space engineer - from her start as an electrical engineer in the NASA Deep Space Network to her role leading the team that built and deployed the Mars Helicopter, Ingenuity: the first-ever controlled flight on another planet.

In My Life: Lessons Learned and Futures Imagined in the Preservation of Photographs (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/in-my-life-lessons-learned-and-futures-imagined-in-the-preservation-of-photographs?utm_source=museummarketing&utm_medium=listing&utm_campaign=Photo+preservation&utm_id=In+My+Life%3A+Lessons+Learned+and+Futures+I)
April 25th
5:30PM EST
During this presentation, professor Debra Hess Norris, from the Winterthur/University of Delaware Program in Art Conservation, will share information on the characterization and preservation of photographic materials. She‚Äôll offer lessons she learned as a conservator, educator, fundraiser, and advocate, from Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C., to the TEDx public stage.

The Healing Power of Music (https://careerservices.fas.harvard.edu/events/2023/04/25/healing-power-of-music/)
Join us in a casual evening roundtable music discussion featuring insights from physicians, musicians, researchers, and leaders in the arts and humanities. Event will feature brief presentations from speakers regarding careers in music and medicine as well as the ability of music to provide healing for patients and the community at large. Dinner will be served and the opening and closing of the program will include performances from music groups including Harvard MIHNUET and Virtual Bedside Concerts (VBC).

Eat, Poop, Die: How Animals Make Our World (https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/event/2023-joe-roman-fellow-presentation-virtual)
April 26th
12:00PM EST
Joe Roman is a conservation biologist and researcher. In this lecture, he will examine how recent studies of animal ecology have changed our views of the role of marine vertebrates in ocean ecosystems through the lens of ‚Äúpostindustrial ecology‚Äù‚Äîa term he has coined for the transition from extractive industries to cultural and supporting services, such as ecotourism and recreational fishing.

Dine & Discuss with U.S. Diplomat Chelsea Wilson (https://soco.college.harvard.edu/events)
Join HUWiFP for a "Dine and Discuss" conversation with Chelsea Wilson, a U.S. diplomat, former Rangel Fellow, and founder of the blog Hey Ms. Traveler. She will be sharing about her extensive experience in foreign policy and various government departments as well as what it is like to work abroad as a woman. Dinner will be served!
RSVP here: https://forms.gle/v8zqxmPQAkgEHifr7 (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeq_8_JGn210IXt1Mpt0Woqr7v1TQWeWJJJczubfcPFr7_kjA/viewform)

FounderCrush (https://www.lpce.college.harvard.edu/events-1)
Calling all founders, explorers, and creative entrepreneurs! Join the Lemann Program on Creativity and Entrepreneurship for our second annual Harvard-wide FounderCrush, an event designed to share, showcase, and synergize all our commercial and social ventures. Join us in the Science and Engineering Complex lobby, 150 Western Avenue, Harvard, Allston, MA.
Gender Focus Group (https://www.instagram.com/p/CrJqSk-p-Ji/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link)
What would it look like to build healthy relationships that set a stronger foundation to address patterns of gender and power-based violence? The Harvard College Women's Center and SHARE (Sexual Harassment/Assault Resources and Education) are hoping to host a series of gender-based affinity spaces for the university community in 2023. Come join us and help shape the conversations by attending these focus groups or reaching out via email to hcwc@fas.harvard.edu (mailto:hcwc@fas.harvard.edu) or oge_share@harvard.edu (mailto:oge_share@harvard.edu) .

Tireless Sacred Work: Performance and Conversation with Ezra Furman (https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/event/2023-tireless-sacred-work-performance)
April 27th
7:00PM EST
Singer, songwriter, musician, and critic Ezra Furman will perform and open Harvard Radcliffe Institute's ‚ÄúMinding the Gap: Gender and the Mental Health Crisis‚Äù conference. Through music and conversation, she will explore themes of identity and anxiety, angst and fearlessness.

HUECU Book Drive (https://www.abedforeverychild.org/ccua)
Help young bookworms thrive. The Massachusetts Credit Unions are hosting a ‚ÄúChildren‚Äôs Book Drive" in April. Donate new or gently used books by April 28th at one of HUECU's branches: Harvard Square (HSQ), Mass General (MGH), or Longwood Medical Area (LMA).

Minding the Gap: Gender and the Mental Health Crisis (https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/event/2023-minding-the-gap-conference)
April 28th
9:00AM EST
Harvard Radcliffe Institute‚Äôs 2023 gender conference will explore the relationship between gender and mental health, with a focus on youth, underserved communities, and the impact of social justice issues.

ARTS FIRST Festival (https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/artsfirstfestival)
April 27th-30th
Join us for public art, museum exhibitions and dynamic presentations of music, dance, theater, film, visual arts and many other innovative arts. Bring your friends, family, and colleagues to an artstravaganza of free performances, exhibitions and art-making activities. Drop in for a little; stay for a lot.
Welcome to the arts at Harvard!

-1791993710.subject: [cs-undergrads] Computational Challenges in Environmental Epidemiology: Embedding Spatial Data Science, Mobile Health Technology, and Deep Learning into Prospective Cohort Studies - CRCS Social Impact Seminar Series - Monday, April 24 at 11:15 AM, SEC LL2.224
-1791993710.text:
Computational Challenges in Environmental Epidemiology: Embedding Spatial Data Science, Mobile Health Technology, and Deep Learning into Prospective Cohort Studies

[Graphical user interface, text, email, website  Description automatically generated]

Peter James, ScD
Monday, April 24, 2023
11:15 AM Eastern

Seminar is in person - in SEC LL2.224
Lunch vouchers for the SEC cafeteria will be provided following the seminar


Title: Computational Challenges in Environmental Epidemiology: Embedding Spatial Data Science, Mobile Health Technology, and Deep Learning into Prospective Cohort Studies

Abstract: The places in which we live, work, play, and age influence our health behaviors, our mental health, our cognitive function, and our chronic disease risk. However, the majority of research on spatial factors and health has relied on residential addresses to assign exposure, questionnaire data to measure health behaviors and health outcomes, and coarse and nonspecific indices to estimate exposure to spatial factors. Recent technological advances have provided opportunities to overcome these limitations. Mobile health technologies‚Äîincluding GPS-enabled smartphones and consumer wearables like Fitbits‚Äîhave opened new doorways to track personalized exposure and granular data on mental health, cognitive function, and health behaviors from minute to minute. Deep learning algorithms applied to Google Street View images empower us to estimate exposure to specific features of the built and natural environment from an on the ground perspective to quantify their impact on health. In this talk, I will speak about my experience integrating mobile health technologies, consumer wearables, and Google Street View imagery into several prospective cohorts, including the Nurses' Health Studies and Project Viva.

Bio:  Peter James is an Associate Professor in the Department of Population Medicine at Harvard Medical School and the Harvard Pilgrim Health Care (HPHC) Institute, and an Associate Professor in the Department of Environmental Health at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. His research focuses on estimating the influence of spatial factors, including exposure to nature, the built environment, the food environment, air pollution, light pollution, noise, and socioeconomic status, on health behaviors and chronic disease. More recently, he is developing methodologies to assess real-time, high spatio-temporal resolution objective measures of location and behavior by linking smartphone-based global positioning systems (GPS) and consumer wearable device accelerometry data to understand how spatial factors influence health behaviors. Dr. James earned his ScD from the Department of Environmental Health and the Department of Epidemiology at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. He holds a MHS in Environmental Health Sciences from the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.

--

-1919914890.subject: We‚Äôre updating our privacy policy
-1919914890.text:
We‚Äôre updating our privacy policy
Hi Eelaaf,

Starting May 17, you and other customers may be eligible to use Pay & Request. This feature will let you and your friends send each other money on Robinhood.¬†

As part of this launch, we‚Äôre revisiting our Privacy Policy and making some changes that impact your privacy settings. Your profile visibility settings will be updated so people with a spending account can search for you on Robinhood. See the full details of our updated Privacy Policy which will take effect on May 17.

How exactly are my privacy settings changing?
On May 17, people with a Robinhood spending account who can use Pay & Request can search for your profile. This will be the default setting unless you opt out beforehand. No one outside of the Robinhood app will be able to see your profile information.

How can I change my profile visibility settings?
You can manage how people can find your profile in your profile visibility settings. Your election won‚Äôt take effect until May 17 but you can adjust your settings at any time before then. You can choose between two options:
  • Anyone on Robinhood - Anyone with a spending account can find you. You can adjust if they can search by your name and username, phone number, or email. This option will automatically take effect. If you‚Äôd rather stay hidden, you can change your settings before May 17 or any time after.
  • No one - No one will be able to find your profile.
What information will display on my profile?
Your profile shows your profile picture, username, full name, the year you joined, and the transaction history between you and the person viewing it. Don‚Äôt worry‚Äîyour profile doesn't contain any sensitive personal or financial information.¬†

Contact support if you have questions.
- The Robinhood Team

-2058622133.subject: Princeton Tutoring Session Recap (Record 27564)
-2058622133.text:
This recap was sent from Princeton Tutoring's mail servers. If you would like to respond to the tutor, please REPLY ALL to this email. Thanks.

  Student: Ishika Bhagavathula
  Tutor: Eelaaf Zahid
  Subject(s): Algebra
  Date: 04/19/2023
  Location: Online
  Time Tutored: 17:00 - 18:00
  Next Scheduled Session: Tue, 04/25  5:00 PM (https://harvard.zoom.us/j/95887604540?pwd=TUlKQjQ0empvNzFRK01rT053Q1hxQT09)

  Material Covered:
  We first reviewed the homework. Ishika had been asked to correct the two problems she had wrong last time. She did so correctly and was able to inform me that she just made some incorrect math calculations, which led to the errors. We then worked on solving systems of linear equations with substitution. Ishika really struggled with setting up the equations for word problems. We discussed defining the variables, then defining as many equations as variables, and finally solving with substitution. Ishika did better with the third problem, but I do encourage her to practice by working through the homework problems. 

  Additional Comments:
  Dear Mrs. Sangeeta,

I had a wonderful session with Ishika yesterday. We practiced setting up systems of equations for word problems. With practice, Ishika will find the process a lot easier, as she starts seeing the patterns in the problems. 

If you have any questions or concerns, please let me know. 

Best,

Eelaaf 

  Assignments for Next Week:
  Please find the homework in the google drive. 
https://drive.google.com/drive/u/1/folders/1foOTmnWMFTDld3co9wMsAOmV3bdtDyG_
