[https://static.nytimes.com/email-images/N-TheMorning%402x.png]

April 20, 2023

Author Headshot
[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/05/01/multimedia/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning/David-Leonhardt-Headshot-The-Morning-blogSmallThumb-v3.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/SVEF4UjaLwF3P6VZwcrT_Q~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m-P0S_aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZGF2aWQtbGVvbmhhcmR0P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjAmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTA2MjUmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMDg4MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD6-FEFkpAUSvlIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~

By David Leonhardt
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/SVEF4UjaLwF3P6VZwcrT_Q~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m-P0S_aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZGF2aWQtbGVvbmhhcmR0P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjAmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTA2MjUmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMDg4MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD6-FEFkpAUSvlIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]

Good morning. We look at the costs of Dianne Feinstein‚Äôs absence to the
Democratic Party‚Äôs agenda.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/20/multimedia/20themorning-lede-tpwg/20themorning-lede-tpwg-jumbo-v2.jpg]Dianne
Feinstein last year.Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times


A STALLED AGENDA

President Biden and Senate Democrats have a numbers problem.

With Republicans controlling the House ‚Äî and showing little interest in
bipartisan legislation there ‚Äî the appointment of judges is one of the few ways
that Biden can get something done on Capitol Hill: The Senate confirms federal
judges, and the Democrats narrowly control the Senate.

But Senator Dianne Feinstein‚Äôs failing health
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/56kBvFpORO10t-hBBNWLpg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m--vhRBZKQFEr5SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
has frozen the Senate Judiciary Committee, the group that must consider any
judicial nominees before the full Senate votes on them. Feinstein, who‚Äôs 89 and
has represented California since 1992, has been ill with shingles since
February. She has also been suffering from a deterioration in her short-term
memory and her ability to hold conversations for more than a year
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/rZ-K_vvtC8zYOZvrJg9HcA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m--FEFkpAUSvlIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~].
It is unclear when she will return to the Senate.

Biden and other Democrats had hoped for the appointment of judges ‚Äî both to
federal trial courts (known as District Courts) and to appeals courts (known as
Circuit Courts) ‚Äî to be a major accomplishment this year. That plan is now in
doubt because Democrats do not have the votes to confirm judges without
Feinstein.

Instead, about 20 Biden nominees are in limbo, and 9 percent of District Court
and Circuit Court judgeships remain vacant. Among Biden‚Äôs unconfirmed nominees:
M√≥nica Ram√≠rez Almadani, a civil rights lawyer; Robert Kirsch, a former
prosecutor who focused on white collar crime; and Kato Crews, an expert in labor
law.


TRUMP‚ÄôS RECORD

Until recently, Republicans often put more emphasis on appointing judges than
Democrats did. That focus has contributed to conservative policy victories, with
federal courts stymying liberal policies on climate change, immigration and
workers‚Äô rights.

The past few weeks have brought another such issue ‚Äî abortion.
Republican-appointed judges have issued rulings that would restrict the
distribution of pills used to end pregnancies, an increasingly important part of
abortion practice. The Supreme Court has paused the effect of those rulings
through Friday while it considers the case
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ntppyZeIh-KqjxITVU3mZw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m--vhRBZKQFEr5SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].

Donald Trump, with help from Mitch McConnell and other Senate Republicans, was
especially aggressive
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/pOChJ-MjhQse-WNX7jfhIw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m--FEFkpAUSvlIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
about appointing judges. Trump appointed more federal judges in his four-year
term than any other recent president did in his first term:

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/19/briefing/oakImage-1681937015447/oakImage-1681937015447-jumbo.png]Source:
The Brookings Institution | Data includes trial and appeals courts, not the
Supreme Court. | By The New York Times

As a result, Republican appointees held most judgeships on both trial courts and
appeals courts when Biden took office. Biden‚Äôs fast start to judicial
appointments during his first two years narrowed the gap, though. Today, 51
percent of appeals courts judges were appointed by Republicans, 43 percent by
Democrats and 6 percent of seats are vacant
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/3HfEObzo_zqyzZoYSnjGOg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m--FEFkpAUSvlIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~],
according to Russell Wheeler of the Brookings Institution.

To continue their progress, Democrats have tried to replace Feinstein on the
Judiciary Committee, but Republicans blocked the switch¬†this week.

Without Feinstein, Democrats have lost their one-vote margin on the committee,
causing it to deadlock on nominees rather than advancing them to the Senate
floor. Some progressive activists argue that Democratic leaders should try to
change Senate rules so that the filibuster could not block a change to the
Judiciary Committee membership, but Democrats may not have the votes to pass
that change, my colleague Annie Karni, who covers Congress, says.

‚ÄúDemocrats are stuck,‚Äù Annie told me, ‚Äúand they just hope she comes back soon.‚Äù

The other solution for Democrats would be Feinstein‚Äôs resignation. In that case,
Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, a Democrat, would replace her, and he has
pledged to name a Black woman to fill the seat. Either way, Feinstein has said
she will not run for re-election next year, and three high-profile California
politicians have announced their candidacies: Representatives Barbara Lee, Katie
Porter and Adam Schiff.


‚ÄòABOUT THE NATION‚Äô

Some Democrats have become increasingly bold about calling for Feinstein‚Äôs
resignation or at least raising the subject:

 * ‚ÄúIf this goes on month after month after month, then she‚Äôs going to have to
   make a decision with her family and her friends about what her future holds,‚Äù
   Senator Amy Klobuchar, a Minnesota Democrat, said this week. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt just
   about California; it‚Äôs also about the nation.‚Äù
 * ‚ÄúShe has been an icon on issues of gun violence and women‚Äôs rights, but it
   has become painfully obvious to many of us in California that she is no
   longer able to fulfill her duties as she doesn‚Äôt have a clear return date,‚Äù
   Representative Ro Khanna, who represents Northern California, said last week
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/RAgJjntI--W5rRJUhLeWNA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m-P0TfaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY25uLmNvbS8yMDIzLzA0LzEyL3BvbGl0aWNzL2toYW5uYS1mZWluc3RlaW4tcmVzaWduL2luZGV4Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyMCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDYyNSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMwODgwJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPr4UQWSkBRK-Uh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].
 * ‚ÄúSenator Feinstein is a remarkable American whose contributions to our
   country are immeasurable,‚Äù Representative Dean Phillips of Minnesota tweeted
   last week. ‚ÄúBut I believe it‚Äôs now a dereliction of duty to remain in the
   Senate and a dereliction of duty for those who agree to remain quiet.‚Äù

Other Democrats, including Nancy Pelosi, the former House speaker, say that
Feinstein has earned the right to remain and have suggested that the criticism
of her is sexist. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never seen them go after a man who was sick in the
Senate in that way,‚Äù Pelosi said.

Feinstein‚Äôs defenders are certainly correct that sexism plays a big role in
American politics. But the biggest distinguishing feature of the current
situation isn‚Äôt Feinstein‚Äôs sex. She is not the first female member of Congress
to serve while old or ill. What makes this case different are the consequences.

No other aging member of Congress in decades, if not longer, has blocked one of
his or her political party‚Äôs biggest priorities.

But Democrats do not seem to have a solution to their problem.

Related: Some Democrats have also called for an end to the ‚Äúblue slip‚Äù process,
which has given Republicans a veto over any Biden nominee to a trial-court
judgeship in their home state. Read more here.
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/2ECRvUPH_JsPog7VxXfstQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m--vhRBZKQFEr5SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]

Continue reading the main story


ADVERTISEMENT

Ad
[https://liveintent.newyorktimesinfo.com/imp?s=859187&li=NN&m=ba2ff69ed6e9fec6f31f322ce534bd15&p=NN_20230420]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/VUZcDbjXNlG0ruk7pVdRfA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m-P0SWaHR0cHM6Ly9saXZlaW50ZW50Lm5ld3lvcmt0aW1lc2luZm8uY29tL2NsaWNrP3M9ODU5MTg3JmxpPU5OJm09YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTUmcD1OTl8yMDIzMDQyMCZ0ZT0xJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDIwVwNueXRCCmQ-vhRBZKQFEr5SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~


THE LATEST NEWS

Politics

 * The Supreme Court delayed a ruling
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ntppyZeIh-KqjxITVU3mZw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m--vhRBZKQFEr5SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   on an abortion pill, keeping it available through Friday.
 * Donald Trump and other Republicans are criticizing Ron DeSantis‚Äôs feud with
   Disney
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/_RtP_A0bgG2ooNAn18U33g~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmI5m-P0TcaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8xOS91cy9wb2xpdGljcy9kZXNhbnRpcy1kaXNuZXktZ29wLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyMCZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDYyNSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMwODgwJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPr4UQWSkBRK-Uh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],

-1277298160.text:
Mignone Center for Career Success;¬†ARTS FIRST Festival;¬†Enrolled Student Survey


** Weekly Update
------------------------------------------------------------
Thursday, April 20, 2023


** Announcements
------------------------------------------------------------

The Office of Career Services has been renamed the Mignone Center for Career Success, in honor of the generous support of the Mignone family. If you haven‚Äôt yet seen their renovated space, please visit them at 54 Dunster St.

ARTS FIRST Festival is seeking volunteers (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfAGVeby2Fz2CaddP5HQ2JaBhOzDJpqnR6Wx5NUM2woatfZ9w/viewform)  for Saturday, April 29 to help set up, clean up, greet audience members, hand out ARTS FIRST programs, and keep performance venues running smoothly. All volunteers will get a free ARTS FIRST t-shirt!

Don't forget to fill out the Enrolled Student Survey (https://harvard.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_8GgXw9ALHQcEZ0i)  that you received earlier this week. Your feedback will be shared anonymously and is used as an important tool in decision-making. The survey is available until May 1 and should only take 5 ‚Äì 10 minutes to complete.

Join the Harvard College Honor Council for a ChatGPT Forum for the Community (https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/chatgpt_forum_for_the_community_hosted_by_the_honor_council) tonight, April 20, from 4:00-5:30 PM in Science Center Hall D. Attendants can enter a raffle to win Harvard swag items!


** Connect
------------------------------------------------------------
Join Bach Society Orchestra in celebrating the end of the semester with their Season Finale (https://www.eventbrite.com/e/bach-society-orchestra-presents-season-finale-tickets-613400195497)  on Friday, April 21, at 8:00 PM. The concert will feature selections by Faure, Respighi, Handel, and Mendelssohn. Tickets are free, but limited.

The Harvard African Students Association is hosting Africa Night (https://www.boxoffice.harvard.edu/Online/default.asp?BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::permalink=hasa&BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::context_id=) on Friday, April 21, at 6:00 PM. Their theme this year is "AMANDLA", Zulu for "power", inspired by their mission to shed light on Africans breaking barriers.

Join the Harvard Premedical Society Book Club for a discussion about ‚ÄúThe Trauma of Deportation (https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/04/03/the-trauma-of-facing-deportation) ‚Äù by Rachel Aviv over Insomnia Cookies at Boylston Hall Room 105 this Friday, April 21, at 4:00 PM.

The Mihnuet is hosting the Healing Power of Music (https://careerservices.fas.harvard.edu/events/2023/04/25/healing-power-of-music/)  featuring a panel of physicians, researchers, and musicians who will explore the relationship between music and medicine on Thursday, April 25, at 6:00 PM.

The Harvard Undergraduate Sports Lab is excited to bring its ping-pong fundraising tournament (https://www.harvardsportslab.com/events/ping-pong-tournament-school-wide) to life on Saturday, April 22 at 12:00 PM. They welcome all skill levels to join for a good time. There will be free food, prizes, raffles, music, and more.

Come cheer on Harvard Women‚Äôs Lacrosse as they take on Columbia in their final regular season game at home on Saturday, April 22 at 2:00 PM and celebrate and recognize their nine seniors (https://gocrimson.com/sports/womens-lacrosse) .


** Resources and Opportunities
------------------------------------------------------------
Join the Institute of Politics on Friday, April 21, at 4:00 PM for "Our Narratives (https://hksexeced.tfaforms.net/f/event-registration?c=7014V000002Mw2PQAS) ." Ten Harvard undergraduates take the stage to deliver TEDx-style talks about their personal journeys into public service and stories of identity.

Join the Harvard Office for Sustainability and Harvard Common Spaces for an Earth Day Event (https://green.harvard.edu/campaign/april-earth-day-events) on Friday, April 21, at 12:00 PM in the Science Center Plaza. There will be a Freecycle, bike repair checks, and spaces to learn from and connect with Harvard groups.

British poet and children‚Äôs/YA novelist, Patience Agbabi (https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/patience_agbabi_in_conversation_with_prof_anna_wilson) , is coming to Harvard to read from her collection Telling Tales and have a conversation with Professor Anna Wilson and interested students. Monday, April 24, 5:00-6:30 PM in the Thompson Room, Barker Center

The ARTS FIRST Festival welcomes conceptual artist Adrian Piper (https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/2023_harvard_arts_medal_ceremony_adrian_margaret_smith_piper_AM_77_PHD_81) AM ‚Äô77, PhD ‚Äô81 to be honored in absentia as the 2023 Harvard Arts Medalist in a ceremony and screening on Wednesday, April 26, at 7:00 PM.

Join the Center for Wellness and Health Promotion and the Harvard College DSO for Finals Fest (https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/finals_fest_5468)  on Thursday, April 27, from 12:00 -3:00 PM in the MAC Quad. Food trucks, ice cream, donuts, chair massage, tie-dyeing, yard games, and more!

The Harvard College Women's Center and SHARE (Sexual Harassment/Assault Resources and Education) are hoping to host a series of gender-based affinity spaces (https://www.instagram.com/p/CrJqSk-p-Ji/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link) for the university community in 2023. Help shape the conversations by attending focus groups or reaching out to hcwc@fas.harvard.edu (mailto:hcwc@fas.harvard.edu) or oge_share@harvard.edu (mailto:oge_share@harvard.edu) .

Harvard Hillel is proud to partner with the Foundation to Combat Antisemitism (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__www.standuptojewishhate.org_&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=EgkfwX7URUjrxz4zg9mX8t7GudJf8IQxRx1q-X93sfo&m=LgYfPna2Q1EmDSuLh_cEreuYhJPVTqOQuNgfkr-z4X14nYfZXIyEYVwOV7Cth2wp&s=n8B9fSSM2OjcrVCjHQ1YmR76JN6nSRUcK9kSSY8RC30&e=)  on their #StandUpToJewishHate campaign. Stop antisemitism now and join the conversation by using #üü¶, the Blue Square emoji, to show support for the Jewish community.

Mignone Center for Career Success events (https://careerservices.fas.harvard.edu/events/?ctag%5B%5D=workshops&ctag%5B%5D=career-fairs&stag%5B%5D=student) for the week include a workshop on Completing the AMCAS Application, a session on Paying for Law School, a roundtable discussion on careers in Music dubbed Healing Power of Music, and more.

Lemann Program on Creativity and Entrepreneurship events:
* Come to a discussion of mental health and entrepreneurship (https://www.lpce.college.harvard.edu/events-1) with Dr. Calisha Brooks on Monday, April 24, at 4:00 PM in Science Center D.
* FounderCrush (https://www.lpce.college.harvard.edu/events-1) , an event designed to share, showcase, and synergize commercial and social ventures on Wednesday, April 26, at 5:00 PM.
* The Marine Debris Fashion Challenge (https://www.lpce.college.harvard.edu/events-1)  celebrates artistic student teams and promotes ocean conservation and sustainability. Thursday, April 27, at sunset in the Science Center Plaza.

Harvard Art Museums events:
* Mine, Yours, Theirs, Ours (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/mine-yours-theirs-ours-ownership-and-stewardship-in-the-age-of-blockchain?utm_source=museummarketing&utm_medium=listing&utm_campaign=Blockchain&utm_id=Mine%2C+Yours%2C+Theirs%2C+Ours%3F+Ownership+and+Stewardship+in+the+Age+of+Blockchain) ? Ownership and Stewardship in the Age of Blockchain today at 6:00 PM.
* Lyrical Colors, Flowing Stories (https://harvardartmuseums.org/calendar/lyrical-colors-flowing-stories-conversations-on-paintings-with-artist-nilima-sheikh?utm_source=museummarketing&utm_medium=listing&utm_campaign=Calderwood&utm_id=Lyrical+Colors%2C+Flowing+Stories%3A+Conversations+on+Paintings+with+Artist+Nilima+Sheikh) : Conversations on Paintings on Saturday, April 22, at 2:00 PM.

Harvard Museums of Science and Culture events:
* Join the Harvard Museum of Natural History in celebrating Earth Day and the bicentenary of Alfred Russel Wallace‚Äôs birth at Alfred Russel Wallace is 200 (https://hmsc.harvard.edu/calendar_event/alfred-russel-wallace-200/) ! on Saturday, April 22, at 1:00 PM and A Night of Lightning Talks and Birthday Cocktails (https://hmsc.harvard.edu/calendar_event/alfred-russel-wallace-party/)  at 5:30 PM.
* ArtsThursdays (https://hmsc.harvard.edu/calendar_event/artsthursdays-at-hmsc-april/) invites students to a special after-hours event at their museums on Thursday, April 27, at 5:00 PM.

Graduate School of Education events:
* The Real World of College (https://web.cvent.com/event/0d1ef7db-c304-4974-b760-8a89c11076e2/regProcessStep1?RefId=HC%20Update)  on Monday, May 1, at 6:00 PM.
* Education, Truth and the Future of Democracy (https://web.cvent.com/event/c2b5dc8d-9e90-4269-a85d-083f108191d0/regProcessStep1?RefId=HC%20Update)  on Thursday, May 4, from 4:30-6:30 PM.
* Building Our Resilient Future: Education Driving Hope, Innovation, and Action (https://web.cvent.com/event/9e179842-7444-4028-aca8-3bd581802d5f/regProcessStep1?RefId=HC%20Update) , Wednesday, May 10, from 10:00 AM - 2:00 PM.

------------------------------------------------------------
April 24: Deadline for first-years to report an advising conversation
April 26: Last day of Spring Full Term classes
May 4-13: Final Examination Period

-2062387978.text:
‚Ä¶and Lulu's Mirror cracks
 

The beef is with the password crackdown (Michael Buckner/Getty Images)

 
Yesterday‚Äôs Market Moves
 
Dow Jones

$29,185 (-3.93%)

Hey Snackers,

Not a fan of your coworker‚Äôs virtual deep-sea background (even though it‚Äôs very cool)? Google Meets now lets you turn off their video feed, without letting them know you blocked their face.

Stocks barely budged yesterday as earnings rolled in from more US banks, plus big names like Tesla and Netflix. The Fed said that inflation and hiring cooled over the past few weeks, boosting hopes of a rate-hike pause after May‚Äôs meeting.

Share

Netflix posts anticlimactic results, but hopes its mooching crackdown will fuel growth

RIP red-envelope DVDs‚Ä¶ this one‚Äôs for you. Netflix shares dipped yesterday, and not because the streamer announced it‚Äôs ending DVD rentals (was still a thing). It added only 1.7M new subscribers last quarter ‚Äî fewer than half what Wall Street was expecting. Netflix said subscriber growth would be similar this quarter, but hopes for brighter days ahead.

  • Play next‚Ä¶ ad. After rolling out in November, Netflix's $7/month US ad-tier now earns more revenue per subscriber than its standard plan, which costs twice as much.

  • Three months left‚Ä¶ to use your ex‚Äôs password. Netflix delayed its global ‚Äúpaid sharing‚Äù plan (ahem, password-mooching crackdown) in the US and other major markets until June. It doesn‚Äôt expect the extra $$ to kick in till the third quarter.

Are you still watching‚Ä¶ on Mom‚Äôs account? 100M people use someone else's Netflix without paying. In February, the streaming icon launched its paid-sharing plan in countries including Canada, Spain, and New Zealand. Cue: searches for ‚Äúcancel Netflix account‚Äù soared 8X. FYI: nearly two-thirds of zillennials have canceled a streaming sub in the past six months.

  • But Netflix said the initial ‚Äúcancel reaction‚Äù was followed by a boost in subscriptions and revenue. Canadian subs have grown since the crackdown, despite it costing $8/month to add new users to accounts ‚Äî and revenue there is growing faster than in the US.
THE TAKEAWAY

Good content captures eyeballs‚Ä¶ but must-see content captures wallets. No one wants to pay yet another monthly subscription fee. But Netflix hopes that its multibillion-dollar content budget (and loyal watchers of series like ‚ÄúYou‚Äù and ‚ÄúOuter Banks‚Äù) will shell out to stay. While the ‚Äúcancel reaction‚Äù could lose casual watchers, it may add lifelong subscribers.

BADLUCK

Lululemon moves to shed Mirror as a pandemic-era home-fitness bet shows cracks

‚ÄúCause it's like you're my mirror‚Äù‚Ä¶ but maybe not for long. Lululemon reportedly wants to offload its in-home-fitness biz, Mirror, to its competitor Hydrow. The soft-pants producer bought the exercise startup for $500M in 2020 as living-room sweat sessions drove sales (goodbye suits and gym memberships, hello leggings and Pelotons). Now the 70-pound wall-mounted ‚Äúmirror,‚Äù which displays fitness classes, is weighing down profits.

  • Self-reflection: In its last reported quarter, Lululemon said it took a nearly $443M impairment charge related to Mirror.

  • Losing more than a few pound$... Lululemon discounted the Mirror device to $1K (down from $1.5K) as sales came in below expectations.

Buffing out the profit problem‚Ä¶ Mirror's drag on earnings has threatened to sour Lulu's otherwise sweet business. Last month the company's stock stretched up after it beat expectations (picture: a 30% sales jump) and shared rosier-than-expected guidance. Other comfy-first brands that saw a pandemic bump (like Crocs) have likewise seen customers hesitant to shift back to ‚Äúhard clothes.‚Äù But Lulu's rush into hardware hasn't aged as well as its leggings

THE TAKEAWAY

Striking while the iron's hot can get you burned‚Ä¶ when the fad cools. At the height of the pandemic, home-exercise tech was a must-have. Peloton went into overdrive trying to keep up with demand for its stationary bikes, and Lulu scrambled to get in on the action with Mirror. But Peloton ended up with a mountain of unsold bikes, and Lulu with Mirrors gathering dust. From indoor bikes to the metaverse to AI, brands that go big on the hot new thing risk mistaking flash-in-the-pan fads for long-term trends.

What else we're Snackin'

  • Teslash: Tesla slashed US prices for the sixth time this year as competition stiffens and EV tax-credit standards get tougher. Yesterday the carmaker reported that its Q1 profit fell 24% as the cuts dented margins.

  • Nevermine: Intel axed its first bitcoin-mining chip less than a year after its debut at the onset of ‚Äúcrypto winter.‚Äù The move follows a reheated debate over the environmental toll of bitcoin mining.

  • Board: United Airlines unloaded a quarterly loss after business travel dipped following Silicon Valley Bank‚Äôs collapse. Like Delta, United sees a profit on the Q2 horizon as summer travel demand booms.

  • Cleanup: Population loss in rural areas is leading small grocery stores to close their doors. USDA data shows that 76 US counties are without a single grocer, limiting the areas‚Äô access to healthy food.

  • Settled: In an 11th-hour deal, Fox News agreed to pay $788M to Dominion Voting Systems ahead of their trial, in one of the largest defamation settlements ever. Fox said ‚Äúcertain claims‚Äù it made about Dominion were false.

üç™ Thanks for Snacking with us! Want to share the Snacks? Invite your friends to sign up here.

-1273780288.subject: Poetry now is as necessary as ever.
-1273780288.text:
Will you join me in showing what Poem-a-Day means to you by stepping up to support the series with a gift? This National Poetry Month, we need to¬†

https://poets.org/donate/p/20/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=78798b2bd1&mc_eid=UNIQID
Dear Reader,

As a devoted reader of Poem-a-Day, you know, as Academy Chancellor Ilya Kaminsky wrote recently, ‚ÄúPoetry now is as necessary as ever.‚Äù This ‚Äúverbal music,‚Äù as he calls it, ‚Äúhelps us to articulate the most impossible moments.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a comfort to know that so many thousands of us are a part of the Poem-a-Day community sharing in the daily practice of reading new works by poets from across the U.S. and beyond.

But Poem-a-Day only exists because devoted readers like us make it possible. Please, if you can, take a moment and help support Poem-a-Day (https://poets.org/donate/p/20/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=78798b2bd1&mc_eid=UNIQID) .
https://poets.org/donate/p/20/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=78798b2bd1&mc_eid=UNIQID
This National Poetry Month, the Academy is actively raising much-needed funds to underwrite this one-of-a-kind, free series that is a balm for so many of us.

Thank you for your support (https://poets.org/donate/p/20/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=78798b2bd1&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

Gratefully,
https://poets.org/donate/p/20/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=78798b2bd1&mc_eid=UNIQID
Tess O‚ÄôDwyer
Chair | Board of Directors
Academy of American Poets

P.S. We need to raise $125,000 this month to continue to meet the costs of offering Poem-a-Day as a free daily series. If just one out of every hundred people reading this right now were to make a gift, we would meet our goal. Can you be our one-in-a-hundred today (https://poets.org/donate/p/20/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=78798b2bd1&mc_eid=UNIQID) ?

============================================================

-870040285.subject: [cs-undergrads] Plug in | Your Weekly Guide to Harvard Grid Events and Happenings
-870040285.text:
[cid:image001.png@01D9736D.84682EB0]



Venturing@Harvard Teams Up with FounderCrush @SEC W.Atrium - April 26, 5-7pm

This month, Venturing@Harvard happens coincident with the Lemann Program's FounderCrush! event. Too good. Join us for a monthly meet-up and idea-exchange for all things Venturing@Harvard: Hear from founders, demo products, enjoy music, refreshments, and networking with the startup and venture community!

RSVP required (capacity is limited, last year's event sold out)

Presented by: LPCE<https://www.lpce.college.harvard.edu/>, TECH<http://tech.seas.harvard.edu/>, & HV<https://www.harvardventures.org/>

Register at https://venturingharvard3.splashthat.com<https://venturingharvard3.splashthat.com/>

________________________________



Limited Passes for HBS Alumni event @ SEC: Future of Sensors, Implants and Wearables in Healthcare - May 11, 6:30p, The Node (2.203)

Harvard Business School Association of Boston and the Harvard Grid host a fireside with MIT Professor Dr. Michael Cima<https://ki.mit.edu/people/faculty/michael-cima>, moderated by Chief Innovation Officer of Carequest, Mariya Filipova<https://www.carequest.org/who-we-are/leadership-team/mariya-filipova>.

*Capacity is limited, Harvard Grid is offering 5 free tickets to this paid event.

Apply for a free ticket and learn more: https://thefutureofsensorsimplantsandw.splashthat.com<https://thefutureofsensorsimplantsandw.splashthat.com/>



________________________________

Summer programming is well underway, stay plugged in @ grid@harvard.edu<mailto:grid@harvard.edu>

---

Harvard Grid

Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences

Harvard Office of Technology Development

--

-1314491076.subject: [ADAMS] Fwd: [hasa-talk] Seeking interview participants
-1314491076.text:
Forwarding for a friend! Sign up pls because research is cool!

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Ananda Birungi <abirungi@college.harvard.edu>
Date: Wed, Apr 19, 2023 at 3:49‚ÄØPM
Subject: [hasa-talk] Seeking interview participants
To: <african-talk@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, <bsa-list@lists.fas.harvard.edu>,
<fyre@lists.hcs.harvard.edu>, <pfoho-open@lists.fas.harvard.edu>


Hello,

My name is Ananda, and I am a junior in Social Studies.

For my junior paper, I am interested in learning more about political
engagement and belonging among African students at Harvard College that
have moved to the U.S. for college.
If you are interested, please reply to this email so that I know to
schedule an interview. Interviews will last approximately 45 minutes to an
hour, and your identity and responses to my questions will be kept
confidential. I am happy to meet with you at a convenient location in
person or over Zoom.

You can also schedule an interview at this link <https://zcal.co/i/lHP-jhzS>
.

Please see attached document for more information on this project.

Thank you very much.

Best,
Ananda

 98MI Research Information Sheet.docx
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1bd0FeV23v-0TH2VvxJXIFhknaSu0IxP1guKpRyo6yc4/edit?usp=drive_web>

-1672146387.subject: Re: [ADAMS] SCR Book Talk! Tomorrow 8pm LCR!
-1672146387.text:
Tonight! 8pm! LCR!

On Wed, Apr 19, 2023 at 11:17 AM Santiago Pardo S√°nchez <
santiagopardo@g.harvard.edu> wrote:

> Hi Schmooze
>
> Tomorrow at 8pm in the LCR we will be hosting SCR member Justin Gest as
> he talks about his new book, *Majority Minority*.
>
> More info below and see you there!
>
> Santi
>
>
> *Majority Minority: How will America respond to demographic change?*
>
> How do societies respond to great demographic change? This question
> lingers over the contemporary politics of many countries where persistent
> immigration has altered populations and may soon produce a majority
> minority milestone, where the original ethnic or religious majority loses
> its numerical advantage to one or more foreign-origin minority groups.
> Until now, most of our knowledge about large-scale responses to demographic
> change has been based on studies of individual people‚Äôs reactions, which
> tend to be instinctively defensive and intolerant. We know little about why
> and how these habits are sometimes tempered to promote more sustainable
> coexistence. In *Majority Minority*, Justin Gest wields polling research,
> historical analysis, and interview-based fieldwork inside six of the
> world‚Äôs few societies that have already experienced a majority minority
> transition to understand what factors produce different social outcomes.
> Grounded in rich narratives and surprising survey findings, *Majority
> Minority* reveals that this contentious milestone and its accompanying
> identity politics are ultimately subject to unifying or divisive governance.
>
> *Justin Gest <http://justingest.com/>* is an Associate Professor of
> Policy and Government at George Mason University‚Äôs Schar School of Policy
> and Government. He is the author of six books, primarily on the politics of
> immigration and demographic change‚Äîall from Oxford University Press or
> Cambridge University Press. He has also provided commentary, analysis, or
> reporting to a number of broadcast networks, including ABC, BBC, CBC, CNN,
> and NPR, and news publications including *The Boston Globe*, *The
> Guardian*, *Los Angeles Times*, *The New York Times*, POLITICO, Reuters, *The
> Times*, and *The Washington Post*. From 2010 to 2014, Professor Gest was
> a postdoctoral fellow and lecturer in Harvard University‚Äôs Departments of
> Government and Sociology. From 2007 to 2010, he co-founded and served as
> the co-director of the Migration Studies Unit at the London School of
> Economics and Political Science (LSE).
>
> [image: MM - Cover.jpeg]
>

-679522977.subject: [hcs-d] [APPLY NOW] Summer Incubator for AR/VR, wearable tech, AI/ML
-679522977.text:
Hi all,

Applications
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScojmBRC4yJMQ1qge5FjZOg7azUhFX8dJhnt_lA3_yHiMxRVw/viewform>
are
open for the 2023 Augmentation Incubator
<http://augmentationlab.org/incubator>! Open to *all* who are interested in
AR/VR, wearable tech, AI/ML, or other human augmentation technologies.
Applications will be processed on a rolling basis until all 10 cohort
positions are filled. Final round applicants will receive invites to a
personal call by 5/1.

The Augmentation Incubator <http://augmentationlab.org/incubator> is a 2.5
month long (June - August) program where 10 creative technologists live and
work together to build the next impactful technologies in the fields of
wearable computing, AR/VR, and AI/ML. With mentorship from renowned
experts, the incubator will integrate product development, scientific
methods, software-hardware engineering, and creative storytelling to
produce innovations backed by rigorous research, as well as a documentary
capturing the experience to expand our impact and inspire the public.

The Augmentation Lab <http://augmentationlab.org/> at Harvard has a history
of developing innovative technologies- from natural language driven XR game
engines
<https://www.augmentationlab.org/post/atomxr-the-first-natural-language-driven-in-hmd-game-engine>
 to eye gaze controlled supernumerary limbs
<https://www.augmentationlab.org/post/limbx-an-eye-gaze-controlled-supernumerary-limb>
 to haptic gloves that reinvent IoT interactions
<https://www.notion.so/49d450528e7a4c5794b0f4ddffe27058>, our work spans
cognitive and physical augmentation, seeking to understand & improve the
human condition. Collectively, our team has founded & led HAR/VRD
<http://harvrd.org/> (XR developers group) and Conflux
<http://confluxcollective.org/> (art tech collective) at Harvard, as well
as worked in research and development across AR/VR, haptics, BCI, data
science, generative AI, HCI, nanotechnology, optics, and quantum physics,
at MIT Media Lab, Harvard SEAS, Harvard Berkman Klein Center, CERN, Center
for Quantum Networks, and more.

Best,
Alice
--
*Alice Cai*
*Storyteller & Engineer*
*Human Augmentation | Harvard College*

HAPPENING NOW! Come to Harvard Art Museums and join us in calling for
Harvard to dename the TWO university buildings named after the Sacklers,
the family who created and profited off of the overdose crisis, killing
countless Americans. Stand in solidarity as we ask Harvard to do what
several other institutions have already done and cut ties with the Sackler
name as well as all other buildings that honor perpetrators of violence and
oppression.

-187379120.subject: Same-Sex Marriage; Climate Change; Maternal Health
-187379120.text: Plus: Our Distinguished Artist Fellow Talks ‚Ää Top Stories from the Mittal Institute April 21, 2023 Harvard Alumnus Fights for the Fate of Same-Sex Marriage in India This week, as India's Supreme Court began hearing arguments for a historic same-sex marriage case, Utkarsh Saxena, HLS '14 and HKS '20, talks about what prompted him to file the petition with the country's highest judicial body. Read this Alumni Spotlight. Climate Challenges of Working Poor Women in South Asia "The climate crisis, if not addressed with the participation of [the] poor, and especially poor women and workers, will take the form of violence that exacerbates poverty," says LMSAI Climate Workshop keynote speaker, Reema Nanavaty, Self Employed Women‚Äôs Association. ÔªøÔªøÔªøRead this Climate Feature. Transforming Maternal Care in India Janhavi Nilekani, Ph.D '18, founder of the Bangalore-based Aastrika Foundation, works to create ‚Äúa future in which every woman is treated with respect and dignity during childbirth, and the right treatment is provided at the right time.‚Äù Read this Health Feature. Featured Event Nilima Sheikh, Distinguished Artist Fellow Series Lyrical Colors, Flowing Stories: Conversations on Paintings April 22, 2023; 2:00 pm ET | Menschel Hall, Harvard Art Museums, 32 Quincy St The Pain of Others: In quest of a lexicon April 25, 2023; 5:30 pm ET | Sackler Building Lecture Hall (Room 004) Of Home, Neighborhood, Love and Labor April 27, 2023; 12:30 pm ET | Sackler Building Room 521 Register Here Upcoming Mittal Institute Events Private insurers as purchasing intermediaries in publicly financed health insurance: Lessons from India‚Äôs Ayushman Bharat ‚Äì Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana Monday, April 24; 5:30pm ET | Register Tellings, Translations, and the Uncanny: Thinking about Dastan-e Amir Hamza Wednesday, April 26; 12:00pm ET | Register Asia and the War in Ukraine Thursday, April 27; 12:00pm ET | CGIS South, Tsai Auditorium S010 Madhur Jaffrey in Conversation with Prof. Abjihit Banerjee: Annual Mahindra Lecture at the Mittal Institute Thursday, May 4; 5:30pm ET | CGIS South, Tsai Auditorium S010 Followed by a public reception at the Faculty Club. Please RSVP. Culture, Climate, and Health - A More Resilient South Asia: The Mittal Institute's Annual Cambridge Symposium Friday, May 5; 9:00am ET | Gutman Conference Center (6 Appian Way) Spring 2023 Mittal Institute Graduate Student Associates Showcase Tuesday, May 9; 10:00am ET | CGIS South S235 Upcoming South Asia-focused Events at Harvard Beyond the National Frame: Scenes from the Indo-Pak Border Thursday, April 27; 3:00pm ET | Tozzer 203 Tell Me Everything: Homeira Qaderi Wednesday, May 17; 12:00pm ET | Register via Zoom ‚Ää In Case You Missed It: Sri Lankan President Ranil Wickresmesinghe LMSAI and the Center for International Development hosted President Ranil Wickremesinghe live from Sri Lanka in a moderated discussion with professors Tarun Khanna, Harvard Business School, and Asim Khwaja, Harvard Kennedy School. The one-hour discussion covered a wide range of topics, from the recently announced IMF deal to social, economic, and political reforms to human rights issues and the way forward for the country. Read our coverage of the talk and watch the video. All past LMSAI event videos can also be found on our YouTube channel. Announcements OpEd: Caste and Climate Change This Indian Express OpEd by Ajmal Khan A.T., LMSAI Raghunathan Fellow, explores how Dalit and Adivasi communities have fewer adaptation resources to combat climate change since they continue to be deprived of socio-economic and political rights and face systemic discrimination. Read the article.  Call for Applications: Mittal Institute India Fellowship The Mittal Institute India Fellowship (MIIF) invites postdoctoral scholars in India to apply for this unique opportunity to be based at the Institute's New Delhi Office. India Fellows will have the opportunity to avail Harvard‚Äôs vast resources to contribute to self-driven, independent research under the mentorship of a Harvard faculty mentor while being based in India. Read about one of our MIIFs and apply by May 25. We're Hiring: Communications and Outreach Coordinator (New Delhi) This less-than-halftime position will be responsible for assisting in the communication efforts related to LMSAI programs operating out of India and South Asia. Full job description and application. -297022614.subject: [ADAMS] Democracy Day Advocacy Demonstration
-297022614.text:
Hey Adams,


Do you think voting is too hard as a college student? Do you wish you had
more opportunities to be civically engaged? Do you want a day off of school
on Election Day?

If you‚Äôve ever thought any of these things, you should attend the Democracy
Day Advocacy Day Demonstration on Sunday, 4/23 at 2:00 in front of the John
Harvard Statue! This demonstration is in support of the Harvard Democracy
Day initiative, which aims to gain a university-wide holiday and day of
civic action on federal election days. This initiative has been endorsed by
over 400 Harvard students and 15+ campus organizations.

We want to prove to administration that the Harvard community broadly
supports our mission, and to do that, we‚Äôre going to need a big crowd.
Please attend and bring your friends! Posters will be provided!

Additionally, if you have not already signed our petition, please take a
minute to sign at the link here <http://tinyurl.com/harvarddemocracyday>.

Thank you so much for your support!


[image: Democracy Day Advocacy Day Flyer (3).jpg]

still in use. Legacy systems include computer hardware, software applications,
file formats and programming languages.

desktop computers, laptops, smartphones and tablets in a connected, cohesive
manner from a single console.

-200991421.subject: [ADAMS] Support Sudan (+ Eid Mubarak)
-200991421.text:
Hi Adams,

As many of you have heard in the news,

Sudan is currently facing an extreme political and humanitarian crisis.
Fighting broke out between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the
paramilitary group (RSF) on April 15th. The crisis continues to worsen and
numbers of those killed, wounded, and displaced are rising. The WHO reports
that over 300 people have been killed and over 3,000 have been wounded, and
the people of Sudan need your help. Please donate, share, and advocate. *Venmo
@sasharvard* to donate. Please caption your donation ‚Äú*SD Crisis*.‚Äù All
proceeds will go directly to aiding impacted communities in Sudan through
the Sudanese American Physicians‚Äô Association (SAPA), Fill-A-Heart (FaH),
and the Sudan Doctors‚Äô Union - UK (SDU-UK).

[image: WhatsApp Image 2023-04-20 at 8.40.11 PM.jpeg]
https://www.instagram.com/p/CrQmCtauAht/?utm

Keeping everyone in the Sudanese community and their families in our
prayers
Please let us know if the tutor teams can support you in any way

Eid Mubarak to all those celebrating!
I hope it is a blessed one for you surrounded by friends and family <3

-1520694022.subject: [ADAMS] This could be your big break
-1520694022.text:
Hi everyone!
Calling all actors, aspiring actors, or anyone that can read that isn't
going to Eleganza or AADT this Saturday: I am in search of actors to
participate in my play reading this coming Saturday at the *Harvard
Playwrights Festival!*
"Bananas" is the play! It's pretty short, it's about gay hookups and grindr
and friendship. You could play the main role or you could be a headless
torso on Grindr. It's up to you. I'm open to any gender as long as you're
open to playing a male role. There will be a single rehearsal tomorrow
on *Saturday,
April 22nd from 11:00 AM to 2:00 PM*, followed by the reading from *7:00 PM
to 8:00 PM* on the same day.

Participation in both the rehearsal and the reading will be fun, chill
acting opportunities that will not require any memorization, as all the
necessary materials will be printed for you. If you have any questions, I
am happy to provide you with a draft script or answer any questions you may
have!

Thank you, Benji Pearson

-1895980331.subject: [Fyre] Visitas 2023 at PBHA is just THREE DAYS AWAY!!
-1895980331.text:
The moment you‚Äôve all been waiting for is just around the corner‚Ä¶..

Visitas 2023 at PBHA is officially THREE DAYS AWAY!!


Our annual Visitas event is around the corner and we hope you can make it,
please RSVP here <https://forms.gle/tndYHhZn46vw441HA>! We'd like to
welcome any incoming first years, their families, and other Harvard
students who are interested in public service. This is a great opportunity
to meet our wonderful directors, volunteers, and leaders while getting to
learn about PBHA's wide range of programs.

Join us in front of PBHA for a mini tabling info session from 4:30-5:30 pm!
PBHA runs over 60 programs throughout the year that you can get involved
with so spend this hour mingling with other students, walking around
program tables, and asking any questions you have about PBHA! Then head
inside our historic building for a delicious and fun Boba and Board Games
event from 5-7pm! We will have various boba flavors, games to play, raffle
prizes, and even more people to meet!





-- 
*Elizabeth Ogolo*
She/Her/Hers
Harvard College | Class of 2024
A.B. Candidate in Neurobiology

-996695781.subject: Three Cheers for Changemakers¬† üéâ
-996695781.text:
Meet the PIC Finalists; Celebrating Climate Ventures; Join our Alumni Accelerator; Introducing the 2023 Life Lab Cohort

https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=3116950621&e=440616fa6a


** Three Cheers for Changemakers
------------------------------------------------------------

A note from the Harvard Innovation Labs Executive Director.
Since launching in 1970, Earth Day has been a force for change in the modern environmental movement. It's helped elevate climate consciousness and launch a new wave of climate action and activism.

While recent estimates suggest this day of service now mobilizes a billion people annually, the current climate crisis demands our attention with increasing urgency, each and every day. At the i-lab, we‚Äôve made it a distinct part of our mission to support ventures building a more sustainable future (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=d1d7bf819a&e=440616fa6a) . We‚Äôre proud to recognize the 67 ventures we‚Äôve incubated over the past three years through the Harvard Climate Entrepreneurs Circle (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=885af5083c&e=440616fa6a) ‚Äî a collaboration with Harvard Business School‚Äôs Business and Environment Initiative and Harvard Alumni for Climate and the Environment.

You can meet the 2023 Climate Circle cohort here, (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=1a8a23bb2b&e=440616fa6a) along with this year‚Äôs 25 President‚Äôs Innovation Challenge finalist teams (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=bece8f9b53&e=440616fa6a) . We‚Äôre blown away by their collective ambitions and potential for impact. Their imaginations can unlock some of society‚Äôs toughest challenges. We‚Äôre humbled and honored to support them on their journeys.

All my best,

Matt Segneri
Bruce and Bridgitt Evans Executive Director
https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=91f71e7474&e=440616fa6a


** Join us at the 12th Annual President‚Äôs Innovation Challenge
------------------------------------------------------------

Find out what happens when imaginations are put to the test. When zero ideas are wasted, and impossible is just the beginning of the journey.
You‚Äôre invited to our biggest annual celebration of innovation and entrepreneurship ‚Äî to hear from our 25 finalist teams (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=6d19fec203&e=440616fa6a) , whose ideas are reimagining the future of healthcare, exploring the business applications of AI, decarbonizing the planet, and so much more. By the end of the night, winning ventures will receive a share of $515,000 in prize funding to propel their ventures even further. Join us for an immersive audio-visual experience on campus, or register to watch virtually. RSVPing right now is the only way to save your future self from FOMO.

RSVP Now (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=933868aa35&e=440616fa6a)
https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=54cb660dfe&e=440616fa6a


** Celebrating Climate Ventures
------------------------------------------------------------
Conversations with earth-conscious entrepreneurs.
When temperatures soar into the mid-80s in April across New England, some may relish the early sense of summer, but entrepreneurs working to address climate change to learn how they got involved in sustainability and what advice they have for fellow founders interested in climate solutions.

Meet the Climate Founders (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=91754f4467&e=440616fa6a)


** Join Harvard‚Äôs Community of Alumni Entrepreneurs
------------------------------------------------------------
Connecting innovators across the globe.
https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=a34b257fdd&e=440616fa6a
Calling all Harvard alumni founders: The time is now to find your global community of fellow dreamers and innovators. Applications for Launch Lab X GEO (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=56c43e66a3&e=440616fa6a) , Harvard‚Äôs accelerator for early-stage alumni entrepreneurs and venture teams, are due Wednesday, May 31. The i-lab is hosting two LLX GEO info sessions for Harvard alumni who are building pre-seed to seed-stage ventures on Tuesday, May 9 (9‚Äì10am ET) and Tuesday, May 16 (1‚Äì2pm ET). Join us to learn how we can support you and connect you with alumni around the world.

REGISTER HERE (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=c86722a189&e=440616fa6a)


** Introducing the 2023 Pagliuca Harvard Life Lab Ventures
------------------------------------------------------------
Since opening in 2016, more than 50 ventures have made their mark at the Life Lab. This Spring, we welcome 11 more.
https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=62800a84a5&e=440616fa6a
As part of the Harvard Innovation Labs ecosystem, the Pagliuca Harvard Life Lab‚Äôs 15,000-square foot facility features a fully-equipped and permitted wet laboratory and collaborative co-working space. Ventures have access to robust programming and resources ‚Äî from business-building and industry-specific programming to expert advisors and mentors. Collectively, Life Lab ventures have raised more than $850 million in funding and created hundreds of jobs. Current Life Lab founders represent four different Harvard schools, and 45% of the ventures have a woman founder or co-founder.

MEET THE LIFE LAB VENTURES (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=9850b5381d&e=440616fa6a)


** HBS Alumni Angels of NY Startup Showcase with Harvard Innovation Labs
------------------------------------------------------------
Learn how to build a compelling pitch.
Tune in online as alumni ventures pitch and receive feedback from top-tier investors on April 27 from 6‚Äì7:30pm ET. You'll see first-hand what investors expect from pitch decks in regards to value proposition, financials, and go-to-market strategy.

Six teams were selected to pitch based on the strength of their product, business model, and viability. Come hear them convince investors to invest.

RSVP Now (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=55f73e6944&e=440616fa6a)


** Teams in the News
------------------------------------------------------------
Check out ventures generating press and rising through the startup scene.
* Bright Feeds (HBS) ‚Äî Startup Aims to Prevent Food Waste, Make Animal Feed (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=f826836ef6&e=440616fa6a) , Record Journal
* Mark43 (Harvard College) ‚Äî How One Technology Company Is Helping To Make Communities Safer Around The U.S. (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=eac1df8ebd&e=440616fa6a) , Forbes
* Overjet (Harvard School of Dental Medicine) ‚Äî 35 AI Startups to Watch (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=f07f38eee8&e=440616fa6a) , DC Inno
* Skew the Script (SEAS) ‚Äî Getting Students Interested in Math (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=aef91ae8d0&e=440616fa6a) , CBS San Antonio
* Vaxess (HBS) ‚Äî Vaccine Patch Maker Vaxess Names Former Sanofi Exec Chief Strategy Officer (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=d4e7e98a7b&e=440616fa6a) , Drug Delivery Business News


** What Inspires Us
------------------------------------------------------------

What made our team smile, frown, or think.
Over the past few years, we‚Äôve interviewed a diverse group of more than 30 women founders (students and alumni) from across all 13 Harvard schools who are creating products and services that are expanding what it means to be an entrepreneur ‚Äî whether that‚Äôs transforming industries, or creating products and services that intentionally benefit women, or making life on this planet a little better for all. In celebration of women's contributions to business all year long (not only Women‚Äôs History Month (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=d07d26f6c0&e=440616fa6a)) !) and the contributions of our diverse group of women founders, we‚Äôre revisiting our conversations with eight women-led teams to share these key takeaways and lessons learned (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=0287acb32f&e=440616fa6a) .

‚ÄîLex Schroeder, Senior Writer
This collection of wisdom (https://harvard.us2.list-manage.com/track/click?u=fa4d71772068da0016522f5b4&id=b63f3650a4&e=440616fa6a)  from i-lab advisor Apeksha Kothari, former COO of Rare Carat, has us grinning with gratitude for all of our amazing expert volunteers. Apeksha says she compiled this list of advice based on student questions and feedback. Working with our founders inspired her to "think through what I would have done differently," she says, and share "what I wish I had figured out sooner at Rare Carat."

‚ÄîLindsay Tucker, Senior Writer

============================================================
PRESS THIRTEEN IS THE HARVARD INNOVATION LABS NEWSLETTER


We celebrate innovators from all 13 Harvard schools who aren‚Äôt afraid to exit on the 13th floor.

-1646020243.subject: Re: [hcs-d] [HCS AI x HAIST] The Future of AI and the Question of AI Safety
-1646020243.text:
Happening today, 3:30pm at Emerson 101! :)

On Wed, Apr 19, 2023 at 6:14‚ÄØPM HCS AI Group <hcsaigroup@gmail.com> wrote:

> [image: Harvard AI Safety Team]
>
> HCS AI Group is excited to announce our next (collaborative!) event, this
> Friday, 3:30 PM in Emerson 101, on where AI is headed and how dangerous
> AI will be in the near future. The pace of AI development is accelerating
> at an unprecedented pace, and as models become more sophisticated, worries
> will only increase.
>
> Our upcoming event will delve into this topic in depth and provide
> insights into the future of AI and its potential dangers. Max Nadeau,
> Deputy Director of Harvard‚Äôs AI Safety Team and a friend of ours, will be
> joining us with his talk, ‚ÄúProblems in AI Safety and Solutions that Scale,‚Äù
> and we will have a Q&A + discussion following an introduction to this topic.
>
> This event will answer questions such as: how will AI interact with humans
> in the future? How likely will dangerous AI arise? All members are invited,
> regardless of background. Concentrators from different backgrounds,
> including math, philosophy, economics, CS, and beyond will find this
> interesting.
>
> Sincerely,
>
> HCS AI Group
>
>

-480144831.subject: [ADAMS] Boston Arabic Music Ensemble Concert in Claverly Multipurpose Room, 5/1 at 8-9:30pm!
-480144831.text:
Hi Adams !

The Adams Race Relations Team invites you to join us for our final event
celebrating Arab American Heritage Month, an exciting performance by the
Boston Arabic Music Ensemble, titled "A musical journey from Mesopotamia to
Andalusia" on *Monday, May 1st at 8-9:30pm* in the Claverly Multipurpose
Room (63 Mt Auburn St).

Please plan to arrive by 7:50pm. Your seat will be held until 8pm, after
that unclaimed seats will be given for waitlisted persons on a first come
first serve basis.
A reception with light refreshments will follow concert end at 9:30pm.

RSVP HERE: https://forms.gle/NmpCGNM128qvody5A

[image: BAME Flyer (Updated) 1.png]

[image: BAME Flyer (Updated) 2.png]


*Description: Flyer with a black background and musical notes in gold, as
well as the BAME logo. Reads:  Adams Race Relations presents Boston Arabic
Music Ensemble "A musical journey from Mesopotamia to Andalusia" Claverly
Hall Multipurpose Room Adams House, May 1 2023 8:00PM. RSVP at link below.
Performance by: Sharon Arslanian: Nay, percussion; Alejandro Castellano:
Oud, guitar; Ghaleb Daouk: Nay, flute; Rania El-Fekih : Voice; Lisa Ann
Esperson : Percussion; Bengisu G√∂k√ße: Violin; Samia Mora: Oud; Anne Phipps:
Percussion; Jamal Sinno: Qanoun; Jamila Talhi : Voice*

RSVP HERE: https://forms.gle/NmpCGNM128qvody5A


*The Boston Arabic Music Ensemble (BAME)*[image: BAME Group photo_March 3
2023.jpeg]
*Learn More about BAME:*
https://cacboston.org/cac-arabic-chamber-music-ensemble/
https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100091372615855

In the early 1980s, a few amateur musicians and friends from the Boston
community gathered to play some popular folkloric and other classical songs
from the Arabic musical heritage. The
group gathered in several venues from private homes to local universities
such as MIT and Harvard, and lately at the Center for Arabic Culture to
celebrate that rich musical heritage. Many of the group members have
participated in and learned the musical format through the Arabic Music
Retreat that is held yearly at Mount Holyoke College under the direction of
Simon Shaheen and AJ Racy, as well as students and faculty from the Berklee
School of Music in Boston.

More recently, the group has evolved into its current members from the
Boston community and performs classical and folkloric Arabic musical
repertoire. The Boston Arabic Music Ensemble was under the artistic
direction of the late maestro Bassam Saba (from 2010 to 2018). Since 2018,
it has been led by the award-winning violinists, composers, and educators
Layth Sidiq and Bengisu G√∂k√ße.

The Boston Arabic Music Ensemble (BAME) welcomes committed intermediate and
advanced level musicians. For all queries, please contact
BostonArabicMusicEnsemble@gmail.com

-1217694928.subject: [ADAMS] 3 DAYS LEFT TO APPLY!! üíõüíô Sign-Up NOW! Be an ECHO Peer Counselor! üíôüíõ
-1217694928.text:
Start your application HERE
<https://streaklinks.com/Begqrc8m5rKs8wumkwOQFNy6/https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSeWntw92peY0clFqAmS3SZMiufnpW5R6MYlrqRBabORQKd1OA%2Fviewform%3Fusp%3Dsf_link>
.


ECHO is interviewing for new Fall 2023 staffers!

Are you concerned about body, eating, and exercise issues on campus?

Would you like to support those around you?

Are you a good listener?


You can become an ECHO (Eating Concerns Hotline and Outreach)

 peer counselor ‚Äî no experience needed!

Start your application HERE
<https://streaklinks.com/BegqrdRjo44DI7EhkgZAiBl7/https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSeWntw92peY0clFqAmS3SZMiufnpW5R6MYlrqRBabORQKd1OA%2Fviewform%3Fusp%3Dsf_link>
.

The application includes a short-answer Google form questionnaire and a
follow up Zoom interview. We would love to have you apply.

The Zoom link is below.

You will log on with the Zoom link here
<https://streaklinks.com/BegqrdZUFN2yEhSnoAYAzTFs/https%3A%2F%2Fharvard.zoom.us%2Fj%2F96698486573>(and
below) at the time of your interview.

Complete the online form here
<https://streaklinks.com/BegqrdZEBC-3ceLnrAPEq2UY/https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSeWntw92peY0clFqAmS3SZMiufnpW5R6MYlrqRBabORQKd1OA%2Fviewform%3Fusp%3Dsf_link>
.

Sign up for your interview slot here
<https://streaklinks.com/BegqrdJxMdxYHnlu0Auiu4b2/https%3A%2F%2Fcalendly.com%2Fharvardecho%2Fnew-staffer-interviews-s2023%3Fmonth%3D2023-04>
.

Once you sign-up for a slot, the Zoom link will be: bit.ly/echof23interviews
.

You can also find the link, the application, and any other relevant material on
our website
<https://streaklinks.com/BegqrdZXFwIrhG6_dghGYoJK/http%3A%2F%2Fharvardecho.crd.co>
.

*All applications are due at midnight on Sunday, April 23rd.*

ECHO is a peer counseling group that provides a confidential,
non-judgmental, non-directive space for undergraduate students to receive
support about any concern. ECHO specializes in addressing concerns about
exercising, body image, food, eating, and eating disorders.

****

ECHO is committed to training and maintaining a staff that reflects the
diversity of the people who struggle with eating concerns and/or body image
issues on campus. People of color have historically been underrepresented
in ECHO as an organization. In this and as in recent semesters, we are
reaching out to people of as many different backgrounds and experiences as
possible.

No concern is too big or too small.

-33516199.subject: [ADAMS] Join T4SG and Greentown Labs for Green Justice on 4/27!
-33516199.text:
TL;DR: RSVP <https://forms.gle/JdiTWGEPadBTvm6P7> for Green Justice: A
Climate Crisis Conversation on 4/27!


Join HCS Tech for Social Good on a visit to Somerville-based climate tech
incubator Greentown Labs for Green Justice: A Climate Crisis Conversation.
This is a panel discussion that will feature Massachusetts‚Äô newly appointed
Climate Chief Melissa Hoffer, Fire River Films Producer Daniel Bennett, and
Beacon Climate Innovations Principal Moneer Azzam. The event will discuss
ways to involve disadvantaged communities in the development of climate
tech solutions, and will be followed by a screening of Mossville: When
Great Trees Fall, a documentary about a centuries-old Black community
uprooted by petrochemical plants. Spots are limited and available on a
first-come-first-serve basis, so RSVP now to secure your spot. Don't miss
out on this opportunity to learn more about this cause and meet founders at
the forefront of the climate tech space.


*Green Justice: A Climate Crisis Conversation*

*Thursday, April 27 4:30-7:30pm*

*444 Somerville Ave (we‚Äôll meet at the Harvard T station)*

** RSVP here ** <https://forms.gle/JdiTWGEPadBTvm6P7>

Only fifteen spots are available, RSVP soon!

HCS Tech for Social Good

Join Our Mailing List <https://groups.google.com/g/harvard-tech4good> @
groups.google.com/g/harvard-tech4good

_______________________________________________

-1550110947.subject: [ADAMS] Wind Ensemble Concert this Friday (4/21) at 8 pm

Hi Schmooze,

-1719357522.subject: [hcs-d] Join T4SG and Greentown Labs for Green Justice on 4/27!
-1719357522.text:
TL;DR: RSVP <https://forms.gle/JdiTWGEPadBTvm6P7> for Green Justice: A
Climate Crisis Conversation on 4/27!


Join HCS Tech for Social Good on a visit to Somerville-based climate tech
incubator Greentown Labs for Green Justice: A Climate Crisis Conversation.
This is a panel discussion that will feature Massachusetts‚Äô newly appointed
Climate Chief Melissa Hoffer, Fire River Films Producer Daniel Bennett, and
Beacon Climate Innovations Principal Moneer Azzam. The event will discuss
ways to involve disadvantaged communities in the development of climate
tech solutions, and will be followed by a screening of Mossville: When
Great Trees Fall, a documentary about a centuries-old Black community
uprooted by petrochemical plants. Spots are limited and available on a
first-come-first-serve basis, so RSVP now to secure your spot. Don't miss
out on this opportunity to learn more about this cause and meet founders at
the forefront of the climate tech space.


Green Justice: A Climate Crisis Conversation

Thursday, April 27 4:30-7:30pm

444 Somerville Ave (we‚Äôll meet at the Harvard T station)

* RSVP here * <https://forms.gle/JdiTWGEPadBTvm6P7>

Only fifteen spots are available, RSVP soon!

HCS Tech for Social Good

Join Our Mailing List <https://groups.google.com/g/harvard-tech4good> @
groups.google.com/g/harvard-tech4good

-696354833.subject: [ADAMS] Read our report requesting Harvard to Dename Winthrop House
-696354833.text:
[image: 67B74C7C-3372-4A6E-9D64-B43FF23BD66C_1_201_a.jpeg]


The product of a month‚Äôs worth of historical and archival investigation,
the Dename Winthrop House Report <http://tinyurl.com/winthropreport>
details the brutal history of the Winthrop family, from John Winthrop
signing the first law in North America legalizing slavery to his
descendants becoming slave trade profiteers throughout the West Indies.

This powerful and influential family was also deeply connected to the early
history of Harvard. The later John Winthrop, a professor and acting
president of Harvard, purchased an enslaved African boy and housed him on
campus. Students prepared defenses of slavery at Harvard‚Äôs Commencement.
The Winthrop name is a complex, bloody uniting of status, connections, and
wealth.

Denaming is an act of accountability. We've sparked a national conversation
<https://hyperallergic.com/816804/in-surprise-die-in-protesters-demand-harvard-take-down-sackler-name/>
about what it means to name our physical spaces.

Read and share the report, and join over 500 peers and sign the petition
<http://tinyurl.com/denamewinthrop>. Help hold Harvard accountable for
its legacy
of slavery. <http://legacyofslavery.harvard.edu>

Feel free to reach out with any questions.

Sincerely,

Clyve Lawrence

Read the report: https://tinyurl.com/winthropreport
Sign the petition: https://tinyurl.com/denamewinthrop

*BUY <http://bit.ly/Ganza2023> TICKETS FOR GANZA NOW! *
Eleganza is Harvard's premier fashion and dance showcase. Over 1600
students come every year to watch highly talented performers use fashion
and dance to amplify marginalized voices and raise thousands of dollars for
charity. Our charities for this year are *The New England Foundation for
the Arts (NEFA), The Advancement Project, *and* AgitArte*! This year's show
is on *SATURDAY, APRIL 22 at 7:30PM in BRIGHT-LANDRY HOCKEY CENTER*. Don't
miss the show of the year!

[image: Ganza.png]

Upgrade <http://bit.ly/Ganza2023> your experience with VIP and enjoy:
- floor access to dance the night away alongside the models
- 2 extra raffle ticket entries, with prizes including gift cards up to
$250, Kyle Cavan jewelry, a Glossier gift basket, and more!
- complimentary Red Bull
- other special in-show perks!

**ps SEF tickets can be upgraded out of pocket!*

-- 
*Jennifer Chu*
Harvard College
A.B. Degree Candidate in Psychology

By Melissa Kirsch
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/laoZmbmGdcGLA-GSM5yR7g~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJjVzP0S-aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvbWVsaXNzYS1raXJzY2g_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyMiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDgyMiZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMDc4JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkP3OwQ2Ttul4bUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]

Good morning. The Morning‚Äôs springtime playlist provides an ideal soundtrack for
a joyful season.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/22/multimedia/22-THE-MORNING-NL/22-THE-MORNING-NL-jumbo.jpg]Mar√≠a
Jes√∫s Contreras


MOOD MUSIC

On weekends in springtime, when the warmer weather has yet to click into place,
relaxing can be hard. It‚Äôs sunny, but for how long? Don‚Äôt ask questions, just
get out there and get into it. The day is a wave and you need to catch it. The
wools and downs, winter‚Äôs armor, are useless today. Today, when you‚Äôll learn to
get dressed again. The same thing every year, but every year it‚Äôs still a jolt.

Don‚Äôt overthink it. Here‚Äôs some music to help.
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/DsIcaB4rv_YORiU_YRE9_A~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJjVzP0ThaHR0cHM6Ly9vcGVuLnNwb3RpZnkuY29tL3BsYXlsaXN0LzF3RXJscmQ4UU9aNXk5bkpSTVlIeDY_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyMiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDgyMiZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMDc4JnNpPWIzZjQ0NGIwYTI2YTQ5ZTMmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWJhMmZmNjllZDZlOWZlYzZmMzFmMzIyY2U1MzRiZDE1VwNueXRCCmQ_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]

The playlist, a collaborative effort by readers of The Morning, is a big
sprawling thing. It has more than 1,000 songs that have been bringing readers
joy lately
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/NidSnCdCkXzKIenfRU6wDQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJjVzP0TWaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8wOC9icmllZmluZy9jdXJhdGVkLXBsYXlsaXN0Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyMiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDgyMiZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMDc4JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkP3OwQ2Ttul4bUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
more than 1,000 tracks that are ‚Äúthat song‚Äù for someone ‚Äî the one they put on
when they want to feel up, to feel better, to set the stage for a good day or to
turn their mood around.

The mix is multifarious, unpredictable, full of old favorites and new stuff you
might love or might skip. Jimi Hendrix. Harry Styles. Bob Seger. De La Soul. The
National. The Little River Band. Wet Leg. More than one Chumbawamba song. We
weren‚Äôt able to include every song submitted, but at over 24 hours, the playlist
is more than long enough to provide a soundtrack for your entire spring. Put it
on while you‚Äôre making breakfast, while you‚Äôre running errands, while you‚Äôre on
a long drive.

The other evening, I got a meeting time wrong and arrived an hour early. I sat
down in the sun. How long had it been since I found myself with a totally
unscheduled hour in a strange place? I challenged myself to just sit and look,
to resist the impulse to catch up on emails or distract myself with texting. The
sun started to set, it got chilly, I didn‚Äôt have a jacket. I stayed outside
anyway, appreciating that evening chill that is winter saying it‚Äôs not done with
us yet.


FOR MORE

 * Break down spring cleaning
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/A4734_eYl8ZQg7Sd1UK7iw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJjVzP0TcaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8xNC9yZWFsZXN0YXRlL3Nsb3ctc3ByaW5nLWNsZWFuaW5nLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyMiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDgyMiZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMDc4JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkP3OwQ2Ttul4bUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
   into manageable chunks.
 * Here are 22 works of fiction to read
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/W4s6SmIBnvVhJfEKkm_uJA~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
   this spring.
 * ‚ÄúA possible self can take you beyond daydreams, which are often fleeting and
   not necessarily grounded in reality.‚Äù If spring is a time of rebirth, why not
   a rebirth of your self
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/6rLyEwPLSzaA309gmZzy7Q~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]?

Continue reading the main story

Ad
[https://liveintent.newyorktimesinfo.com/imp?s=859187&li=NN&m=ba2ff69ed6e9fec6f31f322ce534bd15&p=NN_20230422]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/WTdKYN9KLS2kLe89olbK-g~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJjVzP0SWaHR0cHM6Ly9saXZlaW50ZW50Lm5ld3lvcmt0aW1lc2luZm8uY29tL2NsaWNrP3M9ODU5MTg3JmxpPU5OJm09YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTUmcD1OTl8yMDIzMDQyMiZ0ZT0xJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDIyVwNueXRCCmQ_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~


THE WEEK IN CULTURE

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/21/multimedia/22-THE-MORNING-rust-kflc-copy/21rust-kflc-jumbo.jpg]A
church set in Montana, where Alec Baldwin resumed filming ‚ÄúRust.‚ÄùTodd
Heisler/The New York Times

 * Alec Baldwin returned to the set of ‚ÄúRust‚Äù
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/SjLEHNVRt-JOKHNIFv53xA~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   as the charges he faced in the shooting death of a cinematographer were
   dropped.
 * Stars of the Netflix series ‚ÄúBeef‚Äù called a story of sexual assault by
   another actor on the show ‚Äúundeniably hurtful
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/vMA4zHNJPTCymv0FR_p7Cw~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].‚Äù
   He has said he made it up.
 * By settling a defamation lawsuit, Fox News made clear it would keep its
   audience in a bubble
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/wt6PoucakxtMBEVrXh36jg~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
   at all costs, The Times‚Äôs James Poniewozik writes.
 * After social media users panned Frank Ocean‚Äôs Coachella set and shared a fake
   hit from Drake and The Weeknd, The Ringer asked: What is artistry in the age
   of A.I.
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/AIF9rmqSYiDaHY6wOxU4mQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJjVzP0T__c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]?
 * Outside a stadium in Tampa, Fla., hundreds of Taylor Swift fans waited
   overnight in the rain
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/lQuZ6aajHf006UKxzTaeyw~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   for Eras Tour merch.
 * The choreographer Benjamin Millepied remade ‚ÄúCarmen‚Äù
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/rMSJ7inXe7dYwmn1Ey0h_Q~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
   to capture her essence and tell a modern story. (Read The Times‚Äôs review
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/_U9vP4fqx-QK-43e2TQ-8g~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].)
 * Naomi Watts and Elle Fanning: 40 female artists
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/9N7BUakRlXJg52i3N_7xgA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJjVzP0TxaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vaW50ZXJhY3RpdmUvMjAyMy8wNC8yMC90LW1hZ2F6aW5lL3dvbWVuLWFydGlzdHMtY3VsdHVyZS1tZW50b3JzLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyMiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MDgyMiZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMDc4JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkP3OwQ2Ttul4bUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
   share the younger women who inspire them.
 * A descendant of the painter Camille Pissarro teaches life drawing
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/j-4xpiZlWe6FP52bdXGVhw~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
   in New York.

 * The future of social media
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/yDy2y6dHDR0r0iQX4Dvnkg~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   is full of ads and influencers, Brian X. Chen writes.
 * Book bans are rising rapidly
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/8KmFWG2fWiiJZcYhFTbaWQ~~/AAAAAQA~~~]
   in U.S. schools, driven largely by organized efforts and new legislation.
 * A star of ‚ÄúKokomo City,‚Äù a documentary about Black transgender sex workers
   that won awards at the Sundance Film Festival, was shot to death
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/w8wE_VDDiXqXcjrIInWiUw~~/AAAAAQA~~~].
 * A former member of the boy band Menudo said he was sexually assaulted by Jose
   Menendez
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/gGpy-wrAPx8rmtCw9DwLGg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJjVzP0T-~~],
   whose sons gave a similar rationale before they were convicted of killing him
   in the 1990s.
 * The death of the singer Aaron Carter in November was ruled accidental: He
   drowned in his bathtub
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/0hwlLiAImp-SR3Q2IVjXwg~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   after taking sedatives and inhaling a spray cleaner, officials said.


THE LATEST NEWS

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/22/multimedia/22-THE-MORNING-NL-latest-mlvf/22-THE-MORNING-NL-latest-mlvf-jumbo.jpg]The
Supreme Court.Shuran Huang for The New York Times

 * The Supreme Court said that the abortion pill mifepristone would remain
   widely available
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/JponqMWxyinOzNPpA1O2OQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmJjVzP0T-~~]
   for now while an appeal of a lower-court ruling moves forward.
 * Here‚Äôs what to know
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/SXUWOeET5Nenso-qqW7Qog~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   about mifepristone and how it‚Äôs used.

YELLOW SHEET CAKE WITH CHOCOLATE FROSTING

It‚Äôs my birthday this week, so why not bake me a cake? Just kidding! But if you
are on the lookout for the perfect yellow sheet cake with chocolate frosting
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/cooking/UVrQknkIUhgIyD88hqhR2Q~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~],
you can‚Äôt go wrong with Erin Jeanne McDowell‚Äôs recipe. I especially love the
frosting, which somehow manages to be both deeply chocolaty and light. If you‚Äôd
prefer a more classic layer cake, you can bake the batter in two 8-inch pans,
and start checking them after 25 minutes. You can even bake and frost this cake
a day ahead. Just store it in the fridge until ready to serve. It‚Äôs excellent
both cold and at room temperature.

ADVICE FROM WIRECUTTER


DEEP-CLEANING DUST

If the spring bloom gives you watery eyes, itchy skin or other seasonal allergy
symptoms, a canister vacuum may bring some relief at home. Of all the options
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/zyb4I_KQHV8uZLatAdEhPw~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
Wirecutter experts have tested, Miele‚Äôs ‚Äî with tightly sealing bags and
high-quality filters ‚Äî were the strongest, deepest-cleaning and most reliable.
If you suffer from particularly bad allergies or asthma, you can add a HEPA
filter. Mine even helped capture dust mites
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/cFzq-KuqYC4q1W7E9yWdxA~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]

Sacramento Kings vs. Golden State Warriors, N.B.A. Playoffs: The Kings are in
the playoffs for the first time in 17 years, while the Warriors‚Äô stars ‚Äî Stephen
Curry, Klay Thompson, Draymond Green ‚Äî have won four titles together. But the
youthful Kings dominated the aging Warriors for the first two games. The
Warriors won Game 3, thanks to Curry‚Äôs 36 points. Game 4 is crucial: If the
Warriors lose, they face an elimination game on the road, where they have been
dreadful
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/cf4hMo39nh3gR6SUu6cPIw~~/AAAAAQA~_c7BDZO26XhtSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
all season. 3:30 p.m. Eastern tomorrow on ABC.
