-883515987.subject: "Lullaby" by John James
-883515987.text:
Algae pushes north / and further north.

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 22, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** Lullaby (http://poets.org/poem/lullaby-3?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
John James (https://poets.org/poet/john-james?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID)

^for Wendell

Algae pushes north
and further north.
The plankton follows,
and with it, a biome

of multifarious
sea creatures: microbes,
mollusks. Charismatic
megafauna. All of them

now breed at higher latitude,
which means the things
that bred at that higher latitude
now breed elsewhere

and elsewhere
eat. I linger at the end,
the edge of it. I tread
the precipice

of the abyss. It is Friday,
early, and my son
is newly born. In the dark
he coos and grunts. The slowing

stream of morning
news murmurs in his ear.
It cradles him
in a sound, like some

object of history.
Outside, berry brambles
glisten in an almost
absent wind, here

and there starting up
to toss pollen from a node.
The starlings, always
starlings, tighten

like fists along a strand
of telephone wire.
My son, he‚Äôs sucking
on my finger. He‚Äôs looking

up at me with two bulbous
slate gray eyes that hardly
let me scrawl these words.
I think of the beluga

whale stitched on his shirt, the fishy
taste of the milk it feeds
its own young, born in warmer
waters, which push them

toward the pole. Here, sun
pummels the windows
and the exposed planks of the house,
summons tiny seedlings

from the mud. It desiccates
the herbs left hanging
on the porch. My son
writhes in my arm, a single

muscle almost, slacking
and contracting as he throws
another wail. The end, it‚Äôs moving
toward us. His future‚Äôs set

in an unreadable script.
Through glass
I watch starlings shuffle
and drift, displace

grubworms from the dirt.
My neighbor shaves
a bristlecone pine toppled
in the morning heat. He drops

the limbs in piles
and soaks the wood in flame.
Somewhere in the distance
plankton colonies dissolve.

Whales go with them.
The oak trees
burn in Spain. My son
rolls his eyes over curtains

and patterned sheets, gazes
at the azure
light of the TV. At his lips,
a milky bubble. He moves

his tiny head. He dozes
to the changeless whir
of the machine, gogging, I presume,
at its slow and secret ministry.
Copyright ¬© 2023 by John James. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on April 22, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS8693404211.mp3?updated=1681507365&mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID

About the Treehouse Climate Action Poem Prize
John James‚Äôs ‚ÄúLullaby‚Äù is the first-place winner of the 2023 Treehouse Climate Action Poem Prize. Established in 2019 with generous support from Treehouse Investments, the prize is given to honor exceptional poems that help make real for readers the gravity of the vulnerable state of our environment at present. Beginning with Earth Day, Poem-a-Day will feature this year‚Äôs three winners on consecutive weekends.

‚Äú‚ÄòLullaby‚Äô skillfully captures the painful scale that is so characteristic of the climate emergency: the tension of trying to embrace the joys of an individual life, such as holding a newborn baby, while simultaneously being aware that this delight takes place against the large-scale backdrop of global catastrophe. This poem balances the dynamic of private versus public experience, local versus global, and internal versus external in a way that makes our current crisis feel both personal and intimate.‚Äù
‚ÄîDr. Peter Kalmus and Matthew Olzmann

‚ÄúI composed ‚ÄòLullaby‚Äô in the early hours in the weeks after my son Wendell was born. Sitting on an exercise ball, I bounced him to sleep, holding him in my left arm while with my right I typed and revised the poem. I thought, then, about the mysteries his future holds, as well as certain certainties, not least of all the increasing reality of anthropogenic climate change and our society‚Äôs inability to address this growing catastrophe. The poem ends with an allusion (https://poets.org/glossary/allusion?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID) to [Samuel Taylor] Coleridge (https://poets.org/poet/samuel-taylor-coleridge?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID) ‚Äôs ‚ÄòFrost at Midnight (https://poets.org/poem/frost-midnight?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID) ,‚Äô another poem written by a father for a son, against the weather.‚Äù
‚ÄîJohn James
http://poets.org/poet/john-james?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID

John James (http://poets.org/poet/john-james?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID) is the author of The Milk Hours (Milkweed, 2019). His work has been supported by fellowships and awards from the Bread Loaf Environmental Writers‚Äô Conference, the Academy of American Poets, and the Lannan Center for Poetics and Social Practice at Georgetown University. He is completing a PhD in English at the University of California, Berkeley.

http://poets.org/poet/john-james?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781571315366?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID

The Milk Hours (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781571315366?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID)
(Milkweed, 2019)
https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781571315366?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID


‚ÄúBlueberries for Cal‚Äù by Brenda Shaugnessy
read more (http://poets.org/poem/blueberries-cal?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID)
‚ÄúWhat We Set in Motion‚Äù by Geffrey Davis
read more (http://poets.org/poem/what-we-set-motion?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID)
http://pcm23.eventbrite.com?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID
Thanks to U.S. poet laureate Ada Lim√≥n (https://poets.org/poet/ada-limon?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID) , author of The Hurting Kind (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781639550494?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID)  (Milkweed Editions, 2022), who curated Poem-a-Day for this month‚Äôs weekdays. As of this year, the U.S. poet laureate guest editorship during National Poetry Month (https://poets.org/library-congress-and-poem-day?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a collaboration between the Academy and the Library of Congress. Read or listen to a Q&A (https://poets.org/April-2023-poem-a-day-editor-ada-limon?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID)  about Lim√≥n‚Äôs curatorial approach and find out more about our guest editors for the year (https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID) .


http://poets.org/donate/pad?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID
‚ÄúPoem-a-Day is brilliant because it makes space in the everyday racket for something as meaningful as a poem.‚Äù ‚ÄîTracy K. Smith

If this series is meaningful to you, join the community of Poem-a-Day supporters by making a gift today (https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=8a6cc2e524&mc_eid=UNIQID)  in honor of National Poetry Month. -2120840137.subject: [Fyre] Research for "Race in a Polarized America (Gen Ed 1052)"
-2120840137.text:
Hi! My name is Leah Yeshitila and I am researching the relationship
students have with "legacy status" and how it affects opportunities. All of
these answers are anonymous and will only be used for the course itself. We
are looking for the unique perspectives Black and Brown students on campus
have on this issue. Thank you for your time! My peers and I
greatly appreciate your contributions to our research. Here is the survey:

https://harvard.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_1QRCaOpt1i7Z19c

-- 
*Leah Yeshitila* (she/her/hers)
Harvard College | Class of 2026
A.B. Candidate in African American Studies and History and Literature
Mobile: 972-804-5018
Email*: *leahyeshitila@college.harvard.edu

-313617437.subject: [Fyre] PBHA Housing Awareness Month! Speaker Panel, this Friday!, + Community Organizing Training
-313617437.text:
[image: üì¢] It‚Äôs Housing Awareness Month! [image: üì¢]

HAM's Goals:

- raise awareness about housing justice on campus

- highlight the work of local housing organizations and the voices of
people impacted by homelessness and housing insecurity

- promote critical housing policy at the local, state, and federal level

This Friday, April 21st, we will be having a speaker panel
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScsJl897MuXEkn8nWTN1F-1-skylxpj1Rl9zNHwjGqGdKEPgg/viewform>
with
three incredible speakers from organizations working towards housing
justice (such as the Massachusetts Housing and Shelter Alliance and
CityLife Vida Urbana, an organization working against housing
discrimination). Sign up for the panel HERE
<https://forms.gle/7rkLY8DqFUnvnz6U6>.

Join us for a community organizing training from 5:30-7 pm on Thursday,
April 27th! We will discuss community organizing practices and principles
in the context of housing justice and will also go over current housing
justice movements in Massachusetts. The interest form is linked HERE
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfNucNxGkfUTSpN3l1zVF37Q6PcTOt65ynDDsaNaTY3-Wop1Q/viewform>
.

Here is our LinkTree <https://linktr.ee/housingawarenessmonth> with other
community events related to housing justice and quick action items you can
take to help push housing policy forward.

To learn more about housing in the US, Harvard's Joint Center for Housing
State of the Nation's Housing Report
<https://www.jchs.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/reports/files/Harvard_JCHS_State_Nations_Housing_2022.pdf>
and Citizens' Housing and Planning Association Report
<https://www.chapa.org/sites/default/files/2023-02/annual-report-2022-final_0.pdf>
are
great resources to check out!

If you have any questions or suggestions, feel free to reach out to Sophie
at advocacyhousing@pbha.org and Sophia at advocacy@y2yharvardsquare.org!



[image: üíó] The Housing Awareness Month Committee [image: üíó]


*With Kindness,*

*Byron Gonzalez*
He/Him/His
A.B. Candidate
Harvard College | Class of 2025

-1729660325.text:
*The HUA Inclusion Team Invites You to attend our *
*Financial Aid Fair*

*Are you having trouble filling out your Financial Aid Forms? *
*Do you need an accountability partner?*
*Are you craving Raising Canes? *
*The HUA Inclusion Team has your back! *

*Come to our Financial Aid Fair on April 20th (THIS THURSDAY) from *
*5 pm- 6:45 pm in Science Center Hall C to fill out your financial aid
forms. *

*Event Description*: The Financial Aid Fair is an opportunity for students
to get together and have a designated space and time to work on their
financial aid applications. As the due date for financial aid materials
approaches (May 1st), this fair will also be a time for students to get
support and assistance throughout this process. *There will be a financial
aid officer present to assist students in completing their applications.*

Raising Canes and refreshments will be provided!

*Financial Aid forms are due on MAY 1ST! *


[image: Financial Aid Fair-4 (1).png]

-527848768.subject: [hcs-d] Inclusion and Belonging in Mathematics Panel
-527848768.text:
Dear all,

We'd like to invite you to a panel on Inclusion and Belonging in
Mathematics on Monday, with dinner offered after.  Everyone is welcome to
attend, including students, faculty, and staff.  Please RSVP at this link
<https://streaklinks.com/BenbuoINzY3Xn3EreQE32XQp/https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSeuhC-Eyx1ggkhPJIaUcsjQwgqRZg8liS3u-8ma7gNxNaqOWQ%2Fviewform%3Ffbclid%3DIwAR3yLA2J4680pPKBMsaz0SSwvfKlTQcy_cW2nYDXIT75KqJdnBel-DKC03Q>
.

*Date:* Monday, April 24 from 4:15-5:30pm
*Title:* Inclusion and Belonging in Mathematics Panel
*Location: * Science Center Hall B
*Description: *The student group Harvard Gender Inclusivity in Mathematics
(GIIM) will be hosting a panel on inclusion in mathematics in our
department and beyond. The panelists will speak to the highlights and
challenges they've experienced in mathematics, especially as mathematicians
from underrepresented groups.  There will be some preset questions, but we
will also encourage the audience to ask questions throughout.

*List of panelists:*
- Robin Gottlieb (professor)
- Hakim Walker (preceptor)
- Theo McKenzie (postdoc)
- Isabel Longbottom (graduate student)
- Clair Xinle Dai (graduate student)
- Hana Lang (undergraduate student)
- S√≠lvia Casacuberta (undergraduate student)
- Moderators: Danielle Paulson and Dora Woodruff

-- 
You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups
"mathmindedundergrads" group.
To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an
email to mathmindedundergrads+unsubscribe@g.harvard.edu.

-1338205824.subject: Re: [ADAMS] Join T4SG and Greentown Labs for Green Justice on 4/27!
-1338205824.text:
TL;DR: RSVP <https://forms.gle/JdiTWGEPadBTvm6P7> for Green Justice: A
Climate Crisis Conversation on 4/27!


Join HCS Tech for Social Good on a visit to Somerville-based climate tech
incubator Greentown Labs for Green Justice: A Climate Crisis Conversation.
This is a panel discussion that will feature Massachusetts‚Äô newly appointed
Climate Chief Melissa Hoffer, Fire River Films Producer Daniel Bennett, and
Beacon Climate Innovations Principal Moneer Azzam. The event will discuss
ways to involve disadvantaged communities in the development of climate
tech solutions, and will be followed by a screening of Mossville: When
Great Trees Fall, a documentary about a centuries-old Black community
uprooted by petrochemical plants. Spots are limited and available on a
first-come-first-serve basis, so RSVP now to secure your spot. Don't miss
out on this opportunity to learn more about this cause and meet founders at
the forefront of the climate tech space.


*Green Justice: A Climate Crisis Conversation*

*Thursday, April 27 4:30-7:30pm*

*444 Somerville Ave (we‚Äôll meet at the Harvard T station)*

** RSVP here ** <https://forms.gle/JdiTWGEPadBTvm6P7>

Only fifteen spots are available, RSVP soon!

HCS Tech for Social Good
<https://groups.google.com/g/harvard-tech4good>Join Our Mailing List
<https://groups.google.com/g/harvard-tech4good> @

-1629176472.subject: WCFIA Events | Week of April 23, 2023
-1629176472.text:
This email contains the Weatherhead Center for International Affairs event schedule for the upcoming week.

This email contains the Weatherhead Center for International Affairs event schedule for the upcoming week.
View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/wcfia/wcfia-events-week-of-april-23-2023-main?e=99ae3eb787)

Please use the links below for up-to-date status information and full registration details on how to participate in individual events.

PLEASE NOTE: Hybrid or in-person events may still require masks. Please be prepared to wear a mask during in-person events if asked.


** MONDAY, APRIL 24
------------------------------------------------------------


** Canada Seminar (In Person) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/canada-seminar-04-24-23)
------------------------------------------------------------

‚ÄúThe Lives of Writers‚Äù
Speaker: Eleanor Wachtel, Writer and Broadcaster, CBC.
12:00pm to 1:30pm ET


** Science, Technology, and Society Seminar: STS Circle at Harvard (In Person) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/science-technology-and-society-seminar-sts-circle-04-24-23)
------------------------------------------------------------

‚ÄúTranslating the Plantationocene from the Prevolutionary Caribbean to Colonial Brazil‚Äù
Speaker: Neil Safier, Associate Professor, Department of History, Brown University.
12:15pm to 2:00pm ET


** Seminar in Economic Development (In Person) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/seminar-economic-development-04-24-23)
------------------------------------------------------------

‚ÄúTitle Pending‚Äù
Speaker: Chad Syverson, George C. Tiao Distinguished Service Professor of Economics, Booth School of Business, University of Chicago.
4:00pm to 5:30pm ET


** Seminar in International Trade Economics (In Person) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/seminar-international-trade-economics-04-24-23)
------------------------------------------------------------

‚ÄúCollusion and Innovation: The Case of LCD Cartel, 2001‚Äì2006‚Äù
Speaker: Mitsuru Igami, Associate Professor, Department of Economics, Yale University.
4:30pm to 5:45pm ET


** TUESDAY, APRIL 25
------------------------------------------------------------


** Culture and Social Analysis Workshop (Hybrid) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/culture-and-social-analysis-workshop-04-25-23)
------------------------------------------------------------

‚ÄúSocial Movements, Civil Society, and Political Change‚Äù
Presenters: Elizabeth McKenna, Assistant Professor of Public Policy, Harvard Kennedy School.
Stephanie Ternullo, Postdoctoral Fellow in Government, Harvard University.
12:00pm to 1:30pm ET


** Tuesday Seminar on Latin American Studies (Hybrid) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/tuesday-seminar-latin-american-studies-04-25-23)
------------------------------------------------------------

‚ÄúWhy Are Urban Services Still So Bad in Large Cities?‚Äù
Speakers: Alison Post, Associate Professor of Political Science and Global Metropolitan Studies, University of California, Berkeley.
Alice Xu, Postdoctoral Associate in Political Economy, Yale University.
Alyssa Huberts, Adjunct Professor, Georgetown University.
12:00pm to 1:20pm ET


** WEDNESDAY, APRIL 26
------------------------------------------------------------


** Canada Seminar (In Person) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/canada-seminar-04-26-23)
------------------------------------------------------------

‚ÄúAt a Remove: Re-storying Earthworks in Oklahoma‚Äù
Speaker: Chadwick Allen, Professor of English; Adjunct Professor of American Indian Studies, University of Washington Seattle.
9:00am to 10:30am ET


** Program on U.S.-Japan Relations Seminar (Hybrid) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/program-us-japan-relations-seminar-04-26-23)
------------------------------------------------------------

Distinguished Visitor Lecture: Glen S. Fukushima
‚ÄúThe Trade Controversy in U.S. Foreign Policy: Issues and Prospects‚Äù
Speaker: Glen S. Fukushima, Vice Chair, Securities Investor Protection Corporation (SIPC); Senior Fellow, Center for American Progress.
12:00pm to 1:00pm ET


** Book Talk (In Person) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/book-talk-states-and-nature-04-26-2023)
------------------------------------------------------------

States and Nature: The Effects of Climate Change on Security
Joshua Busby will talk about his new book States and Nature: The Effects of Climate Change on Security (Cambridge: 2022) and explore why climate change leads to negative security outcomes in some places and not others.
Speaker: Joshua Busby, Professor, LBJ School of Public Affairs, University of Texas at Austin.
Chair: Dustin Tingley, Chair, Weatherhead Research Cluster on Climate Change. Professor of Government, Department of Government, Harvard University.
4:00pm to 6:00pm ET


** HIGHS: Harvard International and Global History Seminar (Hybrid) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/highs-harvard-international-and-global-history-seminar-04-26-23)
------------------------------------------------------------

‚Äú‚ÄòFor Spain and for the World‚Äô: The Spanish Civil War, the Colonial Question and the Politics of Comparison‚Äù
Speaker: Zaib un Nisa Aziz, Assistant Professor, Department of History, University of South Florida.
Comment: Elisabeth Leake, Associate Professor of History, Tufts University.
Mahia Bashir, PhD Candidate, Department of History, Harvard University.
4:00pm to 6:00pm ET


** THURSDAY, APRIL 27
------------------------------------------------------------


** Nigeria in the World Seminar (Zoom) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/nigeria-world-seminar-04-27-23)
------------------------------------------------------------

‚ÄúNot Too Young To Win: Young People and the 2023 General Elections‚Äù
Speaker: Ibrahim Faruk, Programme Manager, Governance and Development, YIAGA Africa.
12:00pm to 1:30pm ET


** Middle East Seminar (In Person) (https://wcfia.harvard.edu/event/middle-east-seminar-04-27-23)
------------------------------------------------------------

‚ÄúDecolonizing Israel: The Potential Contribution of the Palestinian Citizens‚Äù
Speaker: Nadim Rouhana, Professor of International Negotiation and Conflict Studies, Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, Tufts University.
4:30pm to 6:00pm ET

ACCESSIBILITY STATEMENT: The Weatherhead Center for International Affairs welcomes individuals with disabilities to participate in its programs and activities. If you would like to request accommodations or have questions about the access provided, please get in touch with the person listed as the contact on the individual event listing in advance of your participation or visit. Requests for Sign Language interpreters and/or CART providers should be made at least two weeks in advance, if possible. Please note that the Weatherhead Center will make every effort to secure services, but that services are subject to availability.
http://wcfia.harvard.edu/

-1182142282.text:
For Harvard Undergraduate Maker's Collective last event of the semester, we
are throwing our biggest "Make Night" yet. With trays upon trays of Thai
food, come enjoy dinner at the Science & Engineering Complex (SEC) from *5:00
PM to 7:00 PM*. We are excited to announce that the dye sublimation printer
will be open during the event, where you can come in and print whatever
image or design you want on metal/canvas/fabric and take it back with you.

-1471179657.subject: [ADAMS] Fwd: Build long-lasting relationships at WorldMUN 2024!
-1471179657.text:
Fully funded spring break trip. No model UN experience necessary.

*Travel the world.*


*Find a family.No experience needed.*

*WorldMUN.*
APPLY NOW
<https://worldmun.us17.list-manage.com/track/click?u=12fa5cdffc49c7e4bef7f3cdb&id=3ba50f6cd2&e=48879ba95d>

Connect.


WorldMUN brings together more than 1,000 young leaders from around the
globe to engage in fruitful debate on pressing global issues, providing
participants with the opportunity to hone their diplomacy skills while
building long-lasting connections with peers from diverse backgrounds.
Travel.


WorldMUN 2024, the 32nd iteration of the conference, will take place
from *March
8 to 18*. Past locations have included Paris (2023), Madrid (2019), Panama
City (2018), Montreal (2017), Rome (2016), Seoul (2015), Brussels (2014),
Melbourne (2013), and Vancouver (2012).


Past WorldMUN conferences have seen: a diplomatic gala in the Louvre
(2023), an address from King Felipe VI of Spain (2019), and a speech from
Pope Francis (2016).
Annual application is open now.


Join the tight-knit WorldMUN community today! Visit our website,
worldmun.org
<https://worldmun.us17.list-manage.com/track/click?u=12fa5cdffc49c7e4bef7f3cdb&id=a6e2da9986&e=48879ba95d>,
for more information, and apply via tinyurl.com/wmun24
<https://worldmun.us17.list-manage.com/track/click?u=12fa5cdffc49c7e4bef7f3cdb&id=efcf94eb50&e=48879ba95d>
by 11:59 pm EDT on *Friday, April 28*.


*Please note that we do not have a preference for applicants with model UN
experience*. In fact, year after year, we find that many of our best chairs
join WorldMUN with no prior model UN experience. We will provide all the
training necessary to succeed at the conference.


Please email Davin Shi, the Secretary-General, at
davinshi@college.harvard.edu
<davinshi@college.harvard.edu?subject=null&body=null> or
secretarygeneral@worldmun.org
<secretarygeneral@worldmun.org?subject=null&body=null> if you have any
questions about the application process or the WorldMUN experience.
Apply Now
<https://worldmun.us17.list-manage.com/track/click?u=12fa5cdffc49c7e4bef7f3cdb&id=281aeb9f19&e=48879ba95d>

Cringe-inducing stories of failure from Neo CEO Ali Partovi. Join us
on *Thursday
at 6:30 - 7:30pm at Harvard Hall 104* as Ali Partovi shares his advice on
what to do (and what not to do) *when starting a company, as well as how to
prepare yourself for success when starting or joining an early stage
company.*

*About Ali and Neo:*

*Neo <http://neo.com/> is a diverse mentorship community, startup
accelerator, and VC. We help the top CS students become tomorrow's tech
leaders and help startups build legendary teams. Applications for our
premier undergrad Neo Scholar program
<https://www.notion.so/hr-neo-com-3964bd200285459d8ce282f5a42c2948> will
open in May, and applications for Neo Accelerator
<https://neo.com/accelerator> 2024 will open in Feb/March.*

*Ali Partovi <https://www.linkedin.com/in/apartovi/>**, CEO, Neo: **Ali
tries to make a career of investing in people smarter than himself. He has
backed Airbnb, Dropbox, Facebook, & Uber. He co-founded Code.org
<http://code.org/> (Hour of Code) to bring CS to classrooms. Ali grew up in
Tehran during the Iran-Iraq war, attended Harvard, and sold his first
startup, LinkExchange, in 1998. He's passionate about sustainable food and
loves climbing, snowboarding, guitar, puzzles, & family.*

Calling all Harvard undergraduates!

If you are interested in Latin America, promoting democracy, *and an
impactful trip during next spring break*, you should apply to staff the
XXIX Summit of the Americas happening during spring break 2024!

Harvard Association Cultivating Inter-American Democracy has officially
opened its applications for staff! It is the world‚Äôs largest simulation of
the Organization of American States (OAS) for high school students in Latin
America. The topics in committees range from politics to economics, health,
Indigenous and immigration rights, etc.!

*The conference will be in a yet-to-be disclosed Latin American country
during spring break, and following the conference, there is a
post-conference trip during spring break!*

You can speak either English, Spanish, or Portuguese. *No MUN experience
required and all identities welcome to apply!*

Apply now by 4/28!

-603357292.subject: The Slowdown for April 24, 2023
-603357292.text:
https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=1a940bc539373853ecf2316d3190e2e95920623d22e19b1a500c9f5e2f870dd5dd0c0b75ab3e202375f5bca0d881644998f81d9c20cf3025 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=1a940bc53937385346bb1c2c9b54b9218fece343a396c6baa173558dba908588f74184b6d699eea64df83fb3bedfdb9a0905a2478c9ae532 
Give Now 


https://click.connect.americanpublicmedia.org/?qs=1a940bc53937385320078b99c7452f7c22159b2ffaf22f6902094cb1b7442696e8b1ae1b0f619a910777509baec0921ebc8dd69a5fa5547b 
“I read the daily poems from The Slowdown with my morning coffee. These poems are a gift.” - Richarda E. 





 Today‚Äôs poem points out that sometimes that voice streaming in our heads isn‚Äôt even our own. Sometimes words directed back to ourselves as lack of worth, the self-critiques that we vocalize, though of our own making, are sentiments put there by someone else.       

   
— Major

Last Night I Had Such Good Dreams
 by Jennifer Perrine



I woke myself up laughing, and today I went down


           to the lake and sat for an hour listening to ice


shift and break into endless shards, its creaking ceaseless,


           and I did not think of you much, or of how I am 


not as good as you were at making French toast, or rice


           even, how I cooked a huge batch to last me the week


and remembered too late how you used to rinse the grains


           to keep them from sticking, so I wound up with eight cups


of thick goop, and said to myself some Asian you are, 


           and when I forgave myself for fucking up the rice,


I wondered whose voice that was—yours or mine or the great


           collective mouth that hums through the cloud and thinks it knows 


best how I should grieve, says get over it already,


           and just for a while this evening, after I came back


from that vast expanse of water, those brittle crystals


           splintering and coming to rest on the shore, I thought


I had—gotten over it, or you, as I gazed up


           at the full moon rising through the trees and wondered how


another month had passed, and I said out loud to that 


           satellite—that desolate rock that does nothing but


orbit and reflect light and drive the tides—-I said look

           how far I have come, I am still here, I have survived

the worst of it, I woke up laughing last night, when was 

           the last time that happened, and when the moon answered back 


with its wild silence I realized too late I was


           never talking to the moon at all, that when I speak 


to an empty place, I am always speaking to you.

"Last Night I Had Such Good Dreams" by Jennifer Perrine. Used by permission of the poet.

-1128196492.subject: [HUES] DUE TONIGHT: HUES EXEC BOARD APPS!!!!
-1128196492.text:
Hey Engineers!

With the end of the semester approaching, HUES will be
*running elections for board positions* for the coming school year
(2023-2024)! HUES always welcomes new board members no matter the
year/concentration as long as you're passionate about strengthening the
engineering community. You *do not need to have previous experience* being
on board for HUES in order to run for the positions, (*you technically
don't even need to be an engineer to run for the positions lol*), so we
hope to see you all run for the various openings!

HUES Board members direct and organize events for the engineering community
such as: SEAS Formal, Field Day, SEAS BBQ, Innovation Talks, Socials &
Happy Hours, Industry Tours, and much more!  If you've enjoyed any of these
events and want to take on a more active role in developing and organizing
these activities, please consider applying for a board position (*descriptions
attached*).

Feel free to reach out to me or Molly personally (
mwieczorek@college.harvard.edu or mollybosworth@college.harvard.edu) if you
have any questions or concerns.

Details below:

*Applications for HUES Board 2023-2024 are due April 24th AT 11:59PM EDT
at THIS FORM
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeQp_yI-Ib5ahelBwt2cSMCnLwjjWQiF1wMCAdZr4mgInDtYQ/viewform?usp=sf_link>.*

*Running for a position:*


   - *All members of the hues-open list are eligible to run for a position*
   - Candidates are eligible to run for up to 3 positions (i.e. you can
   give speeches for two additional roles if you do not get your top choice)
   - *All candidates must send a candidacy statement (300 words max)
   to this form
   <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeQp_yI-Ib5ahelBwt2cSMCnLwjjWQiF1wMCAdZr4mgInDtYQ/viewform?usp=sf_link>*
    *for each position of interest by** April 24th at 11:59PM EDT*
   - Candidacy statements will be distributed before the elections

*Voting/Election:*


   - *The election is open to all members of the hues-open list who would
   like to come for deliberations and voting.*
   - Because the meeting is relatively long, voters can come and go, but *if
   you're running for a position please try to stay the whole time (please let
   us know if you can only stay part of the time.)*
   -  Please keep speeches to under 3 minutes.
   - You may not take part in the deliberations for any position you are
   running for; you will be in a different room while deliberations happen
   among voters.
   - For each position, the candidate with the most votes will be elected -
   for positions with 2 chairs, the candidates with the top 2 most votes will
   be elected.

*The election will take place on **Friday, April 28th *from 1:00 PM - 4:00
PM EDT*, but will likely not take the entire allocated time.* If you would
like to be considered for certain positions but are unable to submit a
candidacy statement and/or attend the election deliberations, please let me
or Molly know.


Best,

Maycee Wieczorek, Molly Bosworth

*HUES Co-Presidents*

--

LTE (Long-Term Evolution) is a fourth-generation (4G) wireless standard that
provides increased network capacity and speed for cellphones and other cellular
devices compared with third-generation (3G) technology.

-794620766.subject: Monday at 5! India on the road to Universal Health Coverage
-794620766.text:
Private insurers as purchasing intermediaries in publicly financed health insurance: Lessons from India‚Äôs Ayushman Bharat ‚Äì Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana<https://mittalsouthasiainstitute.harvard.edu/event/private-insurers-as-purchasing-intermediaries-in-publicly-financed-health-insurance-lessons-from-indias-ayushman-bharat-pradhan-mantri-jan-arogya-yojana/>
RSVP here<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScUFpKNzOqzLqBMz4-kmsBeastYZsY_nNR1PMqkdCqFbe1YDg/viewform>

TODAY! Monday, Apr 24, 2023 at 05:00pm

Refreshments will be served.


India launched the Ayushman Bharat ‚Äì Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY) in 2018 to provide cashless healthcare coverage for hospitalization to the poorest 40 percent of the population. The scheme forms an important component of the country‚Äôs journey towards universal health coverage. In this presentation, the institutional structures associated with the organization of purchasing arrangements in the PMJAY will be examined, with a focus on comparing the performance of government trusts versus private insurance companies. The governance arrangements that underly this performance will be delineated to invite discussion around the potential future role of government and the market in purchasing care in the world‚Äôs largest government- funded insurance program.

[cid:cdd56798-9c97-4154-b867-96b698e4e003]<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScUFpKNzOqzLqBMz4-kmsBeastYZsY_nNR1PMqkdCqFbe1YDg/viewform>


Speaker: Kheya Melo Furtado, PhD
Mittal Institute Bajaj Fellow, Spring 2023

Kheya has been working as Faculty of the Healthcare Management programme at the Goa Institute of Management, India since 2018. Her areas of research, consultancy and teaching are Health Systems Financing and Public Health. She has secured research projects as Principal Investigator from the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Harvard School of Public Health. Her current research focusses on policy and implementation assessments of India‚Äôs national publicly financed insurance scheme, the Ayushman Bharat- Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana, as well as other state-level health protection schemes in India. She is interested in the issues of mixed health systems, particularly in the role of the private sector in achieving health system goals.

Prior to GIM, she served at the Health Division of the NITI Aayog, the policy think-tank of the Government of India, New Delhi, where she implemented key projects such as the NITI Health Index for ranking States & UTs on their performance in Health; the drafting of the Health Chapter of the Three- Year Action Agenda for Government of India 2017-18 to 2019-20 and the NITI District hospital index for monitoring the performance of public hospitals. She also contributed policy inputs on key national health schemes and initiatives.

Her doctoral research was carried out on the role of private sector engagement and participation in disease surveillance, under the INSPIRE Fellowship award of the Department of Science and Technology, Government of India.

Moderator: Winnie Yip
Professor of the Practice of Global Health Policy and Economics in the Department of Global Health and Population at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health

Dr. Yip holds a PhD in Economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Her research focuses on rigorous and policy-relevant health system evaluations and the design and testing of innovative health system interventions to improve equitable access to efficient and good quality health care. In particular, she integrates economics, organization theory, management, and political economy to examine the use of national and state-level policy levers‚Äîincluding financing, provider payment, strategic purchasing, governance, and regulation‚Äîto leverage delivery system change. She currently applies this approach to developing viable and effective models of population health based integrated delivery systems in China and India. She is also interested in the implications of China‚Äôs ageing population for the country‚Äôs health system and in designing and piloting innovative eldercare systems to support older adults in living meaningful lives.

-1296655974.subject: Invite to Prod Demo Day
-1296655974.text:
Hi!

I‚Äôm Anne, I'm a sophomore at Harvard and help run a Harvard/MIT startup
accelerator called Prod. I wanted to invite you to our upcoming Cohort 2.0
Demo Day on April 30th.

*About Prod:*

We‚Äôre a student-run nonprofit dedicated to helping Harvard and MIT students
build companies. Our first cohort (last year) had 12 teams go full-time,
raise >$25M, and generate millions of dollars of contracts. This year we‚Äôre
on track to do even better.

*About the Demo Day:*

Save the date for the afternoon of April 30th. It‚Äôll be an action-packed,
student-first event where you‚Äôll get to meet the founders, hear war stories
of how they built their companies while in college, and chat with other
future founders in the Harvard/MIT ecosystem.

*How to RSVP:*

If you‚Äôre interested in joining Prod, joining one of the cohort 2.0 teams,
or just checking out the demo day, *please RSVP by Friday
<https://forms.gle/HLsT6sPNRbNoe9yQA>* (takes <5 minutes). Let me know if
you have any questions.

See you soon!

Best,

Anne

PS: happy to chat sometime to share more info on what we do if you're
interested

-1203511877.text:
Hello!

We are two PhD students in bioinformatics interested in explainability in machine learning in the context of the clinic. We are investigating how students versus doctors interpret explanations for predictions of machine learning models. To help with our project, please fill out the questionnaire below (estimated time: 10-15min). Those who submit a response will be entered in a raffle to win a $25 dollar amazon gift card! We would be so grateful for your help. Thank you very much!

Questionnaire:
https://harvard.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_8hQHYjVKukljiGq

Thanks again!

-Yasha

-1736766878.subject: [ADAMS] Fwd: THIS FRIDAY: Calling all Pre-Meds and Pre-Dents!
-1736766878.text:
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Nicole Farkouh <nicolefarkouh@college.harvard.edu>
Date: Mon, Apr 24, 2023 at 11:35‚ÄØAM
Subject: THIS FRIDAY: Calling all Pre-Meds and Pre-Dents!
To:


Are you interested in the medical field? Are you interested in being
pre-med or pre-dental? Are you debating between the two? Hear from
several Medical
and Dental School Admissions Officers from Harvard, Tufts, and Boston
University dental and medical schools!


[image: image.png]

Time: Friday, April 28th at 3:30 pm

Location: Lowell Screening Room! (in the basement of Lowell House)


Register Here
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdAUBCZ5q_TMKOcS-5SS6fQ4SBDEZ7lv2YBIjxukXy1S_53QQ/viewform>
for the Q&A Panel!


Come hear from these four schools about medical school and dental school
education and the admissions process. Sponsored by the Dental Interest
Group of Harvard Undergraduate Premedical Society.


(Refreshments will be served!)




-- 
Grace O'Sullivan
A.B. Candidate in Government & History
Harvard College | Class of 2024
graceosullivan@college.harvard.edu | (774) 417- 4149

-1706148837.subject: [hcs-d] HBS Startup Seeking CTO/cofounder
-1706148837.text:
Forwarding for a friend:

My name is Cris Arnolds, and I am an MBA student at Harvard Business
School. I am currently working on an exciting venture, Evolve, which aims
to revolutionize the career coaching industry through AI-driven technology.



Evolve is designed to offer personalized guidance to individuals seeking
career growth and development by leveraging large language models and
emotional AI. Our platform will utilize the knowledge and research of
Harvard's top career coaches to provide users with tailored insights into
their personality, interests, and skills, ultimately matching them with
their ideal career paths.



As we progress on this ambitious journey, we are actively seeking a
CTO/cofounder with a strong background in computer science, AI and
blockchain to join our team. This is a unique opportunity to play a pivotal
role in a venture with significant growth potential, while also making a
meaningful impact on people's lives.



If you or your classmates are interested in learning more about Evolve and
discussing the possibilities of joining our team, please feel free to reach
out to me at carnolds@mba2023.hbs.edu. I would be more than happy to
provide further information and discuss the vision and future of this
venture.



Looking forward to hearing from you!



Best,

Cris

-655199506.subject: [hcs-d] Marketplace startup looking for a web app developer this summer
-655199506.text:
Hello,


My startup, TUKA, has deployed an MVP with the help of 8 developers. As we‚Äôre gathering feedback from our beta users, we‚Äôre looking for a full-stack developer with knowledge and experience in JavaScript and REACT framework to add new features and functionalities to the platform over the summer. Please email me at levikedowide@hks.harvard.edu if you‚Äôre interested or know someone who would be interested.


Background about TUKA, we‚Äôre a marketplace for professional services firms in Africa, connecting them with companies in and outside their local market. Our vision is to propel our users in a future of work where a Namibian marketing firm would be able to seamlessly sell their service to a Kenyan or American SME.


Levi Kedowide
Master in Public Administration Candidate, 2023
Harvard Kennedy School
857.284.3672

-1837414205.subject: [ADAMS] Support Gender-Affirming Care: Letter Writing Event
-1837414205.text:
* Letter Writing in Support of Gender-Affirming Care*
Tomorrow, *Tuesday, April 25 at 7pm*, we will write letters to Texas state
legislators asking that they oppose a harmful bill recently introduced into
the legislature which seeks to restrict access to gender-affirming care.

We will also ask that legislators affirm a commitment to protecting LGBTQ+
rights and denouncing similar legislation harming the community.

We will be in *Boylston 104.*

This event is sponsored by the Office of BGLTQ Student Life! We will be
providing Cane's!

[image: unnamed (4).png]

-404598532.subject: [hcs-d] HSRG: reading group on CUDA/WebGPU numerical performance optimization
-404598532.text:
Hello from the Harvard Systems Reading Group <https://notes.ekzhang.com/events/hsrg>!

Ôøº

We're having weekly reading group at 1 PM in the Science Center (Room 109) on Sunday, April 30. All are invited to join us, regardless of past background ‚Äî we believe that having diverse thoughts is important to learning together as a collective.

This week's topic is is performance optimization for numerical computing. We'll learn how to write and tune matrix multiplication kernels from scratch on CPU using vectorized intrinsics and parallelism, as well as on the GPU by writing our own optimized CUDA kernels and WebGPU shaders. You don't need an NVIDIA GPU or any other hardware to come; I'll attach a latest-generation datacenter GPU to the cloud computer we‚Äôre sharing in the group, which you can access through in-browser VS Code.

To get updates please join our GroupMe at the website linked here: https://notes.ekzhang.com/events/hsrg :D

Best,
Eric

-131626734.subject: [AAWA] Fwd: [ADAMS] Support Gender-Affirming Care: Letter Writing Event
-131626734.text:
* Letter Writing in Support of Gender-Affirming Care*
Tomorrow, *Tuesday, April 25 at 7pm*, we will write letters to Texas state
legislators asking that they oppose a harmful bill recently introduced into
the legislature which seeks to restrict access to gender-affirming care.

We will also ask that legislators affirm a commitment to protecting LGBTQ+
rights and denouncing similar legislation harming the community.

We will be in *Boylston 104.*

This event is sponsored by the Office of BGLTQ Student Life! We will be
providing Cane's!

-935639259.subject: [ADAMS] HUTT Symposium this Friday! (FREE FLOUR BAKERY PASTRIES)
-935639259.text:
Hi everyone!

Interested in foreign affairs? Climate change and the problem of
decarbonization? Interested in joining HUTT next fall?

*The Harvard Undergraduate Think Tank cordially invites you to attend our
inaugural symposium this Friday, April 28th in the Fong Auditorium in
Boylston Hall!* We will have two different session presented by two of our
advocacy teams:
*Session 1 (1:00-2:30pm)*
American Leadership Legitimacy: A Gen Z Perspective on Foreign Policy
{Session Break - Flour Bakery Catering (2:30pm)}
*Session 2 (2:45-4pm)*
The Future of Nuclear Energy in the United States

Both events will include presentations by our undergraduate research teams
as well as moderated discussions and Q&A sessions with experts in the
field. And there will be free Flour Bakery catering for all attendees!

See attached flyer for details.

We hope to see all who are interested this Friday!

Best,
HUTT Co-Presidents
Arjun Akwei and Shelby Tzung

[image: HUTT_symposium.png]

-- 
*Arjun Akwei*
Harvard College | A.B. Candidate in Government and Astrophysics
Co-President, Harvard Undergraduate Think Tank
arjunakwei@college.harvard.edu | 202.740.8894

-281534408.subject: The Morning: Tucker Carlson‚Äôs downfall
-281534408.text:
[https://nl.nytimes.com/q/UnZGAtK7AVaEf62UDMWxBA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjVGPVcDbnl0QgpkPkawR2T7XC80Uh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
Plus, President Biden‚Äôs campaign announcement.
View in browser
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/ZR0DMNv9_0DaFKxaNM1zZA~~/AAAAAQA~-RrBHZPtcLzRSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]|nytimes.com
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/7mroD5b7Oj0SyQt_vCKFUQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjVGP0StaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vP2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjUmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwMDMmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTI5MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD5GsEdk-1wvNFIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
[https://static.nytimes.com/email-images/N-TheMorning%402x.png]

April 25, 2023

Continue reading the main story

SUPPORTED BY GE Aerospace [ge.com]

Author Headshot
[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/01/13/reader-center/author-german-lopez/author-german-lopez-blogSmallThumb-v2.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/NpMXjP9Af7oNwNTFZVCDBw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjVGP0S8aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZ2VybWFuLWxvcGV6P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjUmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwMDMmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTI5MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD5GsEdk-1wvNFIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~

By German Lopez
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/NpMXjP9Af7oNwNTFZVCDBw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjVGP0S8aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZ2VybWFuLWxvcGV6P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA0MjUmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTEwMDMmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTI5MCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD5GsEdk-1wvNFIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]

Good morning. Tucker Carlson is out at Fox News. Plus, President Biden announced
his campaign for re-election.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/25/multimedia/25themorning-lede-carlson-vfqp/25themorning-lede-carlson-vfqp-jumbo.jpg]Tucker
CarlsonLeigh Vogel for The New York Times


CANCELED

For years, the Fox News host Tucker Carlson has faced criticisms of his
amplification of racist and anti-immigrant ideas. But those issues seemed to
have little to do with his demise.

Instead, a growing list of controversies related to Carlson‚Äôs conduct on and off
the air had begun to aggravate Fox News executives, and the network abruptly
announced his departure yesterday
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/sxQT_y_c7liaxxvSfNdyOw~~/AAAAAQA~-RrBHZPtcLzRSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].

Network leaders and contributors had complained, and some quit, over Carlson‚Äôs
misleading coverage of the Jan. 6 attacks, in which he depicted rioters as
‚Äúmostly peaceful‚Äù onlookers. His coverage of 2020 election conspiracy theories
was part of Dominion Voting Systems‚Äô lawsuit against Fox
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/R8pr1PCS6oL5F8Ic-h6Ekg~~/AAAAAQA~-1wvNFIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~],
which the network settled last week. Carlson had also privately denigrated Fox
executives, saying they had cost the network credibility by allowing it to call
President Biden‚Äôs election victory, as The Washington Post reported
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/wdll0ROPb3rrCLpyn0XsAQ~~/AAAAAQA~-RrBHZPtcLzRSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].

And a former producer recently accused Carlson in a lawsuit of overseeing a
misogynistic and discriminatory workplace. Fox has disputed her claims.

As one of the top hosts on the most watched cable news network, Carlson played
an outsize role in conservative politics. Today‚Äôs newsletter will look at
Carlson‚Äôs influence and what his exit means for Fox News.


A BIG AUDIENCE

Carlson took over Fox News‚Äôs prized 8 p.m. slot in 2017 and increased its
already-high ratings, quickly becoming a fixture on the right-wing network and
in conservative politics.

How? Carlson tapped into
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/GRZjk-kjG5wChgteE2WNLg~~/AAAAAQA~-RrBHZPtcLzRSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
white viewers‚Äô fears over the country‚Äôs changing racial demographics, which
fueled Donald Trump‚Äôs rise in the 2016 election. He would regularly focus on the
notion of the ‚Äúgreat replacement,‚Äù a racist conspiracy theory that claims elites
are importing supposedly obedient immigrants to disempower native-born
Americans. In 2018, Carlson argued that hordes of immigrants were making America
‚Äúpoorer and dirtier.‚Äù

Carlson often highlighted local news stories but twisted them to make broader
claims about Americans losing control of their country. In one segment in 2017,
he claimed ‚ÄúGypsies‚Äù were causing chaos in a small Pennsylvania town, urinating
and defecating in the streets.

‚ÄúThe message of these segments was always the same: You and your way of life are
under attack, and the people doing the attacking look different and have
different values than you do,‚Äù my colleague Nicholas Confessore, who covered
Carlson‚Äôs rise for The Times
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/GRZjk-kjG5wChgteE2WNLg~~/AAAAAQA~-RrBHZPtcLzRSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~],
told me yesterday. ‚ÄúCarlson reassured viewers that their discomfort was
reasonable ‚Äî that they didn‚Äôt have to feel bad about their fears and worries.‚Äù

Carlson did so by embracing Trumpism but not Trump himself. The approach was
partly personal. In private texts, Carlson said of Trump, ‚ÄúI hate him
passionately.‚Äù It also helped Carlson differentiate himself from other Fox News
hosts, Nicholas said. Because they aligned themselves closely with Trump, the
hosts Sean Hannity and Laura Ingraham would often have to come to his defense
when Trump said something outrageous. Carlson tried to avoid those pitfalls by
focusing on the underlying message instead of Trump as the public face of it.

Fox‚Äôs predominantly white audience embraced Carlson‚Äôs approach, and he drew more
than three million viewers a night, regularly making his show No. 1 or No. 2 at
the network. And although accusations of bigotry and falsehoods prompted
sponsors to flee Fox, Carlson‚Äôs show increased its ad revenue because its
audience was so large.

Carlson has not said what he‚Äôll do next. But without that big audience, he
probably won‚Äôt be as influential.


UNCERTAIN FUTURE

Fox News said it would rotate hosts in its 8 p.m. slot until it could find a
permanent replacement. At first glance, this seems bad for the network: Not only
did it lose one of its biggest stars, but it has no replacement lined up. And
the announcement comes at a time when Fox has already faced months of bad
publicity, and it just agreed to a $787.5 million settlement over Dominion‚Äôs
lawsuit.

But Fox has overcome similar challenges with its hosts before. Carlson himself
replaced Bill O‚ÄôReilly, who was once the network‚Äôs most popular host, and not
only maintained O‚ÄôReilly‚Äôs ratings but at times surpassed them. That experience
may have led Fox to believe that the network carries more sway over its viewers
than individual hosts do.

The former Fox executive Roger Ailes used to occasionally bench his prime time
stars for a night to show them that the ratings stayed high when they were gone
‚Äî demonstrating that it was Fox that made them big, Nicholas noted. ‚ÄúI suspect
the audience loyalty to Fox is probably greater than the audience loyalty to any
particular Fox star,‚Äù he added.


FOR MORE

 * A lack of premium advertisers in recent years had done little to hurt
   Carlson‚Äôs standing
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/3Q3er7iqoiO8WpH_WaUQ8w~~/AAAAAQA~-RrBHZPtcLzRSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   at Fox News.
 * Trump and Carlson patched up
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/G-xquwgxricvz8vOTuQK7Q~~/AAAAAQA~-RrBHZPtcLzRSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   their differences recently.
 * CNN fired the host Don Lemon
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/Ny5EtGuf1qtvTGrxmzJulw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjVGP0TZaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNC9idXNpbmVzcy9tZWRpYS9kb24tbGVtb24tY25uLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMjkwJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPkawR2T7XC80Uh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
   who lost executives‚Äô support after an uproar over a sexist comment he made on
   air.
 * The departures of Carlson and Lemon mark the end of an era in media
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/957pJafNBtmcsG4LGei5QQ~~/AAAAAQA~-1wvNFIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~],
   The Times‚Äôs Jim Rutenberg writes.
 * Jeff Shell, the chief executive of NBCUniversal, was fired after a news
   anchor
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ymqkRr18a3HTRvZfYy6a_Q~~/AAAAAQA~-1wvNFIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
   lodged a sexual harassment complaint against him.
 * Carlson‚Äôs departure is part of a Fox tradition in which abuse is tolerated
   until it‚Äôs inconvenient, Michelle Goldberg writes
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/2RdMyPiix5wxfiHaQ_TZGQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjVGP0TlaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNC9vcGluaW9uL3R1Y2tlci1jYXJsc29uLWZveC1uZXdzLWRvbWluaW9uLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMjkwJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPkawR2T7XC80Uh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
   in Times Opinion.
 * ‚ÄúNever put anything in an email‚Äù: Carlson‚Äôs dismissal represents a cautionary
   tale that Rupert Murdoch learned years ago, Bret Stephens writes
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/3HYP55hsRi1vwx3SgYSAFg~~/AAAAAQA~-RrBHZPtcLzRSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
   in Times Opinion.
 * Late night hosts joked about Carlson‚Äôs departure
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/VRkoWoI4rlDqF8XCbWLzFg~~/AAAAAQA~-1wvNFIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~].

Continue reading the main story


A MESSAGE FROM GE AEROSPACE

Invention is in the air

In 2022 alone, nearly 3 billion people flew with our technology under wing. But
the boundaries of more sustainable air travel exist to be pushed, and we‚Äôll
continue doing so with the mission to invent the future of flight, lift people
up, and bring them home safely.

Learn More

GE Aerospace Logo
[https://static01.nytimes.com/ads/email_logo/Morning_briefing/us/GE_Logo_150X150.png]
[ge.com]


THE LATEST NEWS

Politics

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/25/multimedia/25-THE-MORNING-NL-biden-pgqk/25-THE-MORNING-NL-biden-pgqk-jumbo.jpg]President
Biden.Doug Mills/The New York Times

 * Biden announced his re-election bid
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/aGbpREnndJyhkOUgC7pC_A~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjVGP0TlaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNS91cy9wb2xpdGljcy9iaWRlbi1ydW5uaW5nLTIwMjQtcHJlc2lkZW50Lmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMjkwJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPkawR2T7XC80Uh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA],
   setting up the possibility of a rematch with Donald Trump. Follow our updates
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/R6YbCgExQrzawcg4tiydJA~~/AAAAAQA~-RrBHZPtcLzRSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].
 * A jury will start hearing E. Jean Carroll‚Äôs allegation today that Trump raped
   her in a department store
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/_dcnlj1gpExFNLarumXKRQ~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjVGP0TlaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNS9ueXJlZ2lvbi90cnVtcC1yYXBlLXRyaWFsLWUtamVhbi1jYXJyb2xsLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMjkwJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPkawR2T7XC80Uh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
   dressing room more than two decades ago.

 * The North Dakota governor signed a bill banning abortion
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/AJthFb9Xe9_YyZkqdxKV_A~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjVGP0TZaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNC91cy9hYm9ydGlvbi1iYW4tbm9ydGgtZGFrb3RhLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMjkwJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPkawR2T7XC80Uh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
   after six weeks of pregnancy, even in cases of rape or incest.
 * The College Board will change its A.P. African American Studies course
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/Z76_-uU885dUdrlTn9zFaQ~~/AAAAAQA~-1wvNFIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
   after scholars accused it of bending to political pressure and omitting key
   concepts.

International

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/24/multimedia/25themorning-ukraine/25themorning-ukraine-jumbo-v2.jpg]Ukrainian

A POP SONG ON TRIAL

Did Ed Sheeran copy his Grammy-winning ballad ‚ÄúThinking Out Loud‚Äù from Marvin
Gaye‚Äôs soul classic ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Get It On‚Äù? The question is at the center of a
copyright trial
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/KtiM5kdhWRjJsMqpYw5CNA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjVGP0TuaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNC9hcnRzL211c2ljL2VkLXNoZWVyYW4tbWFydmluLWdheWUtY29weXJpZ2h0LXRyaWFsLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyNSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTAwMyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxMjkwJnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPkawR2T7XC80Uh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
that began yesterday in federal court in Manhattan.

Because of a quirk of music copyrights, the case rests primarily on the songs‚Äô
chord progressions, which are nearly identical, as this video comparison shows
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/1oJjrS5TNgHPiu-OcD8--A~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmKjVGP0SxaHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS96MVl4RmpRWGJYZz9jYW1wYWlnbl9pZD05JmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjMwNDI1Jmluc3RhbmNlX2lkPTkxMDAzJm5sPXRoZS1tb3JuaW5nJnJlZ2lfaWQ9OTgxMDkxNjgmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xMzEyOTAmdGU9MSZ1c2VyX2lkPWJhMmZmNjllZDZlOWZlYzZmMzFmMzIyY2U1MzRiZDE1VwNueXRCCmQ-RrBHZPtcLzRSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].
But Sheeran‚Äôs lawyers have argued that the chords are common in pop music ‚Äî
including in songs by artists who used them before Gaye and Ed Townsend, who
collaborated with him on ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Get It On,‚Äù did.

-1467147978.subject: [ADAMS] Want to make an easy $100?
-1467147978.text:
TLDR: Make $100 for dropping off my boxes to the HUA storage program on May
6, text 906 281 6989 if interested


DETAILS:

3 boxes (potentially 4) will be delivered to your location on *May 1*, you
choose the time. You will keep the boxes in your possession until May 6, when
anytime between 10:00am and 5:00pm you will drop the boxes off at the HUA
storage program located at Beren Hall (at the corner of Mill and Plympton
St by Winthrop). You will be given my proof of purchase for the storage
program to provide at drop-off.

Compensation will be $50 upon transfer of the boxes to you, and an
additional $50 upon completion of the boxes drop-off to the storage
program. Pay through Venmo, PayPal, or cash (if you insist, lol)

Send me a text at (906) 281-6989 if interested!

_______________________________________________

-729370402.subject: [cs-undergrads] Re: Build an (AI) Bot Workshop Sunday, 4/30/23 @ 3:30 pm
-729370402.text:
Hi all,

Based on demand, there's now a second session in the morning for the *Build
an (AI) Bot Workshop* this Sunday, April 30, if the afternoon time didn't
work for you. *These are now the two sessions:*

   - Morning (new time), with lunch dumplings: 11 AM to 3 PM. Sign up here
   <https://www.eventbrite.com/e/build-an-ai-bot-workshop-morning-session-new-tickets-623028403727>
   .
   - Afternoon (original time, still happening), with dinner dumplings:
   3:30 PM to 7:30 PM. Sign up here
   <https://www.eventbrite.com/e/build-an-ai-bot-workshop-afternoon-session-tickets-619793297437>.
   But no need to do so again if you already signed up earlier.

Location: Nieman Foundation's Lippman House @ Harvard 1 Francis Street
Cambridge, MA 02138

djm

--

-1470223931.subject: Vercel Ship starts in one week
-1470223931.text:
Vercel Ship is almost here
May 1st - 5th
Join us virtually for a special launch experience that will include updates on the future of Next.js and how Vercel is further integrating with popular frontend frameworks.
${btnText}    ${btnText} <[[${btnURL}]]>
Tune in to see what‚Äôs new + watch the main event‚Äîa keynote with Vercel CEO Guillermo Rauch‚Äîlive on May 4.

.

-1142530415.subject: [ADAMS] FROSHICAL
-1142530415.text:
THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT!!

Jk. Well it‚Äôs important to us. This coming week is the FROSHICAL. We took
some advice from the *Pfoho Emailer* and made this email extremely
engaging.

Our show is a musical called POST MORTEM. We have celebrities (Will from
Weld 16 and Alex Lim from all the KrokToks) and extremely attractive people
(everyone in the cast).

We have shows on Thursday 27th- Sunday 30th ‚Äì PLEASE COME IT‚ÄôS VERY SILLY.

The show at 7.30 on Thursday 27th is FREE with a HUID. All tickets are SEF
Eligible. Come to the show. I will give u a big kiss.

Thanks.
Love u.

-1804185655.subject: [hcs-d] [HCQCA] Last Call! Quantum @ NASA + Sushi TODAY!
-1804185655.text:
Last call to RSVP <https://forms.gle/trdetYbqg3ZWEB8m8> for HCQCA's Last
Event of the Year! There will be free sushi!

[image: NASA Poster.png]

Learn about NASA's research on quantum computing and distributed systems!

*There will be free sushi!*

RSVP here: https://forms.gle/trdetYbqg3ZWEB8m8
<https://soco.college.harvard.edu/click?email_links_id=446&member_id=11667280>


*Abstract*: The NASA Quantum Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (QuAIL)
performs research to assess the potential impact of quantum computers on
challenging computational problems relevant to NASA missions of the future,
with particular emphasis on discrete optimization. The talk will begin with
a brief overview of the QuAIL team and some general remarks on the status
of and prospects for quantum computing. The talk will then transition to a
discussion of distributed quantum computing, with an emphasis on recent
results in the quantum CONGEST-CLIQUE Model (qCCM). I‚Äôll introduce both the
classical and quantum CONGEST-CLIQUE Models of distributed computation, and
then outline two quantum algorithms that succeed with high probability; one
yields an approximately optimal Steiner Tree, and the other an exact
directed minimum spanning tree, each using asymptotically fewer rounds of
communication than any known algorithms in the classical CONGEST-CLIQUE
model. We achieve these results by combining classical algorithms with fast
quantum subroutines. Additionally, we characterize the constants and
logarithmic factors involved in our algorithms, as well as related prior
classical and quantum algorithms, revealing the importance of ‚Äúsmall‚Äù
factors and highlighting that advances are needed to render both practical.
The talk will conclude with some open questions.



*Bio*: Eleanor G. Rieffel leads the Quantum Artificial Intelligence
Laboratory at the NASA Ames Research Center, and is the NASA Senior
Researcher for Advance Computing and Data Analytics. She was one of two
2020 NASA Ames Associate Fellows. She joined NASA Ames Research Center in
2012 to work on their expanding quantum computing effort. Previously, she
performed research in diverse fields at FXPAL, including quantum
computation, applied cryptography, image-based geometric reconstruction of
3D scenes, bioinformatics, video surveillance, and automated control code
generation for modular robotics. Her current research focuses on quantum
algorithms, evaluation and utilization of near-term quantum hardware,
fundamental resources for quantum computation, quantum error
characterization and mitigation, distributed quantum computing, and
applications of quantum computing. She received her Ph.D. in mathematics
from the University of California, Los Angeles. She is best known for her
2011 book Quantum Computing: A Gentle Introduction with coauthor Wolfgang
Polak and published by MIT press.
--
Team HCQCA
Website & Interest Form: harvardquantum.com
Follow us on Instagram: @harvardquantumcomputing
<https://instagram.com/harvardquantumcomputing?igshid=YmMyMTA2M2Y=>

-1591831093.subject: [Legal Notice] Changes to Google Maps Platform Data Privacy Terms for US and UK users
-1591831093.text:
Hello Google Maps Customer,

We‚Äôre writing to let you know we updated our Controller-Controller Data Protection Terms for Google Maps Platform on January 23, 2023.

What do you need to know?

The updates to our Protection Terms are the result of the adoption by the UK of the International Data Transfer Agreement (IDTA) Addendum[1] and changes to several US state‚Äôs privacy laws. You can review the specific updates to each country below:

   - For the US:
     - We added a US State Privacy Laws Addendum[2] to the Controller-Controller Data Protection Terms[3] to support data protection laws in California, Colorado, Connecticut, Utah, and Virginia.
     - The US State Privacy Laws Addendum has replaced the previous CCPA Addendum (which only applied to California) as of January 1, 2023.
   - For the UK:
     - From March 2022, the UK International Data Transfer Agreement (IDTA) Addendum allows the EU Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) to be used for transfers of personal data under the UK GDPR.
     - We removed the previously required UK specific Standard Contractual Clauses as they are no longer necessary.
     - You can review Google Maps Platform‚Äôs SCCs[4].

These updates won‚Äôt affect your use of other Google products or services as they will only apply to Google Maps Platform.

What do you need to do?

No action is required on your part.

We‚Äôre here to help

If you have any questions or concerns about this update, please contact Google Maps Platform Support[5].

Thanks for choosing Google Maps Platform.

‚ÄìThe Google Maps Platform Team

[1] https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/guide-to-data-protection/guide-to-the-general-data-protection-regulation-gdpr/international-data-transfer-agreement-and-guidance/
[2] https://business.safety.google/controllerterms/us-state-laws/
[3] https://business.safety.google/controllerterms/
[4] https://business.safety.google/gdprcontrollerterms/sccs/eu-c2c/
[5] https://support.google.com/cloud/contact/maps_api_privacy

¬© 2023 Google LLC 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, CA 94043

You have received this mandatory service announcement to update you about important changes to Google Maps Platform or your account.

-1871391019.subject: New! Paid Internship: Climate Policy Summer Internship
-1871391019.text:
Dear Eelaaf,

The Salata Institute is piloting a Climate Policy Summer Internship Program in collaboration with the Massachusetts State House. The Institute will facilitate the placement of up to three Harvard students in legislative offices addressing climate, environmental, or sustainability issues in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.
Learn More and Apply (https://salatainstitute.harvard.edu/climate-policy-summer-internship/)
Program Funding:  The Salata Institute for Climate and Sustainability will compensate each Climate Policy Intern at a rate of $20.00 per hour for their work with participating legislative offices.

Program Duration: 8-12 weeks (flexible based on the legislative office)

Program Qualifications: Undergraduate or graduate student at Harvard University
Call for Student Volunteers:

Volunteer for The Harvard Climate Symposium (https://harvardclimatesymposium.cventevents.com/event/c2f2acd5-bd80-49de-b1d3-4206bc0c7c76/summary) , a convening of hundreds of climate leaders in government, business, and civil society on May 9th, 2023. Volunteers will join the Salata Institute team in directing and assisting Symposium participants and will be able to participate in this invitation-only event.
Application Deadline: April 27, 2023
Req. Volunteer Training: April 28, 2023
Learn more & apply. (https://hbs.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_6yPbvG71nbpvEOi)

The Salata Institute for Climate and Sustainability's mission is to develop and promote durable, effective, and equitable solutions to the climate-change challenges confronting humanity. In an effort to strengthen the connections among students dedicated to this issue, the Institute will act as a hub for the many existing climate-related programs and initiatives across Harvard University.

============================================================

-1378636954.subject: "Throwing Children" by Ross Gay
-1378636954.text:
It is really something when a kid who has a hard time becomes a kid who‚Äôs having a good time

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID


Poem-a-Day is reader-supported. In honor of National Poetry Month, please consider making a gift to help cover the costs of this important series.
https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID
April 26, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** Throwing Children (http://poets.org/poem/throwing-children?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
Ross Gay (https://poets.org/poet/ross-gay?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID)

It is really something when a kid who has a hard time becomes a kid who‚Äôs having a good time in no small part thanks to you throwing that kid in the air again and again on a mile long walk home from the Indian joint as her mom looks sideways at you like you don‚Äôt need to keep doing this because you‚Äôre pouring with sweat and breathing a little bit now you‚Äôre getting a good workout but because the kid laughs like a horse up there laughs like a kangaroo beating her wings against the light because she laughs like a happy little kid and when coming down and grabbing your forearm to brace herself for the time when you will drop her which you don‚Äôt and slides her hand into yours as she says for the fortieth time the fiftieth time inexhaustible her delight again again again and again and you say give me til the redbud tree or give me til the persimmon tree because she knows the trees and so quiet you almost can‚Äôt hear through her giggles she says ok til the next tree when she explodes howling
yanking your arm from the socket again again all the wolves and mourning doves flying from her tiny throat and you throw her so high she lives up there in the tree for a minute she notices the ants organizing on the bark and a bumblebee carousing the little unripe persimmon in its beret she laughs and laughs as she hovers up there like a bumblebee like a hummingbird up there giggling in the light like a giddy little girl up there the world knows how to love.

Copyright ¬© 2023 by Ross Gay. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on April 26, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS1880903134.mp3?updated=1682441550&mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID

‚Äú‚ÄòThrowing Children‚Äô is just what it is, a prose poem (https://poets.org/glossary/prose-poem?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID)  or maybe an essayette, but let‚Äôs call it a prose poem, recounting a sweet walk with my friends and chucking a little kid up in the air, a skill I have been honing for a long time. You know how nice it is to hear a kid hollering with delight, and how lucky it feels to chip in.‚Äù
‚ÄîRoss Gay
https://poets.org/poet/ross-gay?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID

Ross Gay (https://poets.org/poet/ross-gay?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID) is the author, most recently, of the book of poetry Be Holding (University of Pittsburgh Press, 2020) and the collection of essays Inciting Joy (Algonquin Books, 2022). ‚ÄúThrowing Children‚Äù is from The Book of (More) Delights, forthcoming in September from Algonquin Books.

https://poets.org/poet/ross-gay?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://bookshop.org/a/262/9780822966234?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID

Be Holding (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9780822966234?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID)
(University of Pittsburgh Press, 2020)
https://bookshop.org/a/262/9780822966234?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID


‚ÄúMy Eighteen-Month-Old Daughter Talks to the Rain as the Amazon Burns‚Äù by Dante Di Stefano
read more (https://poets.org/poem/my-eighteen-month-old-daughter-talks-rain-amazon-burns?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID)

‚ÄúNight at the Roller Palace‚Äù by January Gill O‚ÄôNeil
read more (https://poets.org/poem/night-roller-palace?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID)
http://pcm23.eventbrite.com?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID
Thanks to U.S. poet laureate Ada Lim√≥n (https://poets.org/poet/ada-limon?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID) , author of The Hurting Kind (https://bookshop.org/a/262/9781639550494?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID)  (Milkweed Editions, 2022), who curated Poem-a-Day for this month‚Äôs weekdays. As of this year, the U.S. poet laureate guest editorship during National Poetry Month (https://poets.org/library-congress-and-poem-day?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID) is a collaboration between the Academy and the Library of Congress. Read or listen to a Q&A (https://poets.org/April-2023-poem-a-day-editor-ada-limon?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID)  about Lim√≥n‚Äôs curatorial approach and find out more about our guest editors for the year (https://poets.org/poem-day-guest-editors-2023?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

‚ÄúPoem-a-Day is brilliant because it makes space in the everyday racket for something as meaningful as a poem.‚Äù ‚ÄîTracy K. Smith

If this series is meaningful to you, join the community of Poem-a-Day supporters by making a gift today (https://poets.org/donate/hfp/national-poetry-month?mc_cid=42c0ae6b37&mc_eid=UNIQID)  in honor of National Poetry Month.
