-1700821930.text:
April 2023 | MIT Sloan Admissions Newsletter

 ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå  ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå  ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå  ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå  ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå  ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå 
 
 
 
ADMISSIONS NEWSLETTER
April 2023
 

 

 
 
Hi Eelaaf, 

Your time at MIT Sloan not only will equip you to face the challenges of tomorrow, but also will support your career growth along the way. 

Today, we're sharing some great resources to help you map out how our graduate programs bolster your development well beyond graduation. Our 2022 Employment Reports <https://mitsloan.mit.edu/career-development-office/employment-reports?utm_source=slate&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=news-all&utm_term=022823> can help you analyze program outcomes, spot future career trends, and see the top hiring industries for recent graduates. Here's a snapshot:

	 The MBA Classes of 2022 and 2023 accepted opportunities at 330+ companies. Graduates pursued roles in Consulting (31.2%), Technology (22.6%), Finance (22.6%), and other high-growth industries.
 
	 98.3% of the MFin Class of 2022 accepted opportunities within six months of graduation at 107 companies and financial centers around the world.
 
	 100% of the MBAn Class of 2022 accepted offers within six months of graduation at over 30 data-focused companies in the U.S. and across the globe. 

How will you leverage your MIT Sloan degree to drive impact? We can't wait to find out!



Best,

MIT Sloan Admissions


 

 

 
 
April Highlights
 
This month, we're spotlighting feel-good stories of people, initiatives, and trends that are making a positive impact. Highlights range from Oatly's executive director paving a way toward "a radically better future" to MIT Sloan's new course on "Pursuing Happiness and a Meaningful Life" to how to land more job offers with the help of artificial intelligence.  


 
Oatly Exec: How to Lead with Purpose in an Imperfect World
 
 
Purpose-led work isn't black-and-white. Practicing bravery and self-care, and tapping into creativity, can help leaders navigate the gray areas.
 
READ THE FULL ARTICLE <https://mitsloan.mit.edu/ideas-made-to-matter/oatly-exec-how-to-lead-purpose-imperfect-world?utm_source=slate&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=news-all&utm_term=022823>

 
Can Happiness Be Taught? These Two MIT Sloan Business Experts Think So
 
 
Nurturing happiness takes work, but doing it right can lead to greater productivity and stronger relationships.
 
READ THE FULL ARTICLE <https://mitsloan.mit.edu/ideas-made-to-matter/can-happiness-be-taught-these-2-mit-sloan-business-experts-think-so?utm_source=slate&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=news-all&utm_term=022823>

 
Job Seekers with AI-Boosted R√©sum√©s More Likely to Be Hired
 
 
Algorithmic writing assistance can help new job seekers find and fix spelling, grammatical, and usage errors in their r√©sum√©s. Employers approve, research shows.
 
READ THE FULL ARTICLE <https://mitsloan.mit.edu/ideas-made-to-matter/job-seekers-ai-boosted-resumes-more-likely-to-be-hired?utm_source=slate&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=news-all&utm_term=022823>

 

 

 
 
VIEW EVENTS <https://mitsloan.mit.edu/events?f%5B0%5D=events_audience%3A1802&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=news-all&utm_term=022823&utm_source=slate>
VIRTUAL CAMPUS TOUR <https://mitsloan.mit.edu/explore-the-mit-sloan-campus?utm_term=022823&utm_source=slate&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=news-all>
 
 
MIT Sloan School of Management
Office of Admissions
50 Memorial Drive, Building E52-359
Cambridge, MA 02142
 
 
 
 

 
#MyMITSloan
Image by rawpixel.com on Freepik
 
You may have received this email because you took the GMAT or GRE.
 
Click here <https://applymitsloan.mit.edu/go?cmd=message&id=099e14ab-64de-4764-8c7c-ee6d70e7f7b0&utm_term=022823&utm_source=slate&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=news-all> to view this email in your browser.

-1290781130.text:
Join* Harvard Candela Latin Dance Troupe* on Sunday,* April 30* at 2pm for
an afternoon of latin culture, community, and excitement!Join us in
celebrating the work by Candela‚Äôs junior and senior choreographers as well
as the dozens of dancers who have been practicing for months, many of whom
are creating pieces and performing on stage for the very first time!Our
show‚Äôs diversity of participants, styles and sources of inspiration reflect
Candela‚Äôs overall mission of providing a space of communal learning about
latin artistic heritage by spotlighting traditional, modern and hybrid
styles of dance.Tickets are $10 for HUID holders ($15 for non-HUID holders)
and can be purchased at the Harvard Box Office
<https://www.boxoffice.harvard.edu/Online/default.asp?BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::permalink=candela&BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::context_id=>.
The show is SEF eligible.¬°Vamos a gozar!

By Melissa Kirsch
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/ovNW_wXxKdaZMnOqoAqLRA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmL3ZUP0S-aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvbWVsaXNzYS1raXJzY2g_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyOSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTM2NyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxNjc1JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPlTxTGT_Jl39Uh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]

Good morning. The books we read when we‚Äôre young help shape the adults we become
in ways we don‚Äôt always grasp.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/04/29/multimedia/29-THE-MORNING-NL/29-THE-MORNING-NL-jumbo.jpg]Mar√≠a
Jes√∫s Contreras


PRETEEN SENSATIONS

If you ask any kids who grew up reading Judy Blume, they‚Äôll tell you precisely
what they learned from each of Blume‚Äôs books; which taboo rites of passage each
book introduced; probably even where they were, physically and developmentally,
when they first stumbled on this information. They might very well remember the
precise page number of the paperback that was passed around middle school on
which the most eye-opening passages appeared.

I recently reread her classic, ‚ÄúAre You There God? It‚Äôs Me, Margaret,‚Äù in
advance of seeing the film adaptation
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/OR6bmufoK2nu-VKNAIkKaA~~/AAAAAQA~_yZd_VIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
that opens this week, 52 years after the book‚Äôs publication.

In my memory, ‚ÄúMargaret‚Äù was chiefly about puberty, specifically about getting
your period for the first time. I vividly remembered the famous scenes when
Margaret first encounters sanitary napkins and when she and her friends do
exercises in order to ‚Äúget out of those baby bras,‚Äù chanting, ‚ÄúWe must ‚Äî we must
‚Äî we must increase our bust!‚Äù

As I reread the book, though, I was struck not only by its Big Moments, but also
by the many small, almost trivial ones that I‚Äôd unwittingly assimilated into my
understanding of the world.

There‚Äôs an early scene in which Margaret‚Äôs father injures himself while mowing
the lawn and Margaret runs out into the yard ‚Äúto look for the limb,‚Äù in case the
doctor might be able to sew it back on.

I stopped short. This scene was as real to me as one of my own memories. When
I‚Äôd read the book as an adolescent, it was the first time I‚Äôd heard about such a
grisly surgical procedure. I didn‚Äôt actively think of it again, but ‚Äúyou should
always look for the limb‚Äù became part of my smart aleck‚Äôs understanding of the
world, a bit of wisdom, never questioned. I never tied this knowledge back to
the book or any source.

‚ÄúMargaret‚Äù also instilled in me the belief that wearing loafers with socks makes
one ‚Äúlook like a baby‚Äù and that it was possible to get a custom label made for a
homemade sweater that said ‚ÄúMade Expressly for You ‚Ä¶ by Grandma.‚Äù Small details,
certainly not the main themes of the book, not what I‚Äôd tell any adult at the
time that I ‚Äútook away‚Äù from reading it.

‚ÄúMargaret‚Äù the movie ‚Äî which you should see if you loved the book, or loved the
director Kelly Fremon Craig‚Äôs first film, ‚ÄúEdge of Seventeen‚Äù ‚Äî is full of these
details, moments that change a young reader quietly. Watching it, I felt little
electrical connections being made between my childhood brain and my adult brain,
between the data that was inputted decades ago and the coherent knowledge it‚Äôs
become.


FOR MORE

 * Blume, Fremon Craig and the film‚Äôs stars discussed the novel‚Äôs cultural
   impact
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/2YLBbATgkclz-x_X0IDXlg~~/AAAAAQA~-VPFMZP8mXf1SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~].
 * ‚ÄúSomebody used to say to me, ‚ÄòJust wait till all these kids who grew up with
   you get to those positions of power in Hollywood ‚Äî you will see.‚Äô‚Äù Blume on
   how the ‚ÄúMargaret‚Äù film finally came to be
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/-V7ugI7aHeI-WpmtKBQTFA~~/AAAAAQA~_yZd_VIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~].
 * ‚ÄúTo us, Margaret Simon wasn‚Äôt a character, she was a proxy ‚Äî for the girl who
   stuffed socks in her bra, who felt uncomfortable in her own skin; for the
   girl who was homesick for a friend who had matured overnight or moved away or
   turned mean; for the girl who struggled to make sense of the diagrams on the
   origami-folded instructions inside the tampon box.‚Äù The Times‚Äôs Elisabeth
   Egan on the book‚Äôs enduring appeal.
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/vF3N-jsMj9Q5jzyb6qatvw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmL3ZUP0TxaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNC8yNy9ib29rcy9qdWR5LWJsdW1lLWFyZS15b3UtdGhlcmUtaXRzLW1lLW1hcmdhcmV0LW1vdmllLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDQyOSZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTM2NyZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxNjc1JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkPlTxTGT_Jl39Uh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]

ARTICHOKE CARBONARA

Whether you‚Äôre planning a festive spring gathering or looking to make yourself
something extra special for dinner this weekend, Anna Francese Gass‚Äôs delightful
artichoke carbonara
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/cooking/SHhN8Bwb7RWGpBLrshcsJg~~/AAAAAQA~_yZd_VIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
might be just the thing. In her clever recipe, she levels up an easy weeknight
pasta by stirring in canned or frozen artichoke quarters, adding flavor and
texture without much effort. For a vegetarian version, skip the pancetta and
caramelize some onions or mushrooms in the pan instead. Then top each bowl with
a raw egg yolk for the silkiest carbonara sauce imaginable.

ADVICE FROM WIRECUTTER


MAKE YOUR COLD BREW

Unless you‚Äôre a year-round iced coffee hound, you may be making the annual
transition from hot drip to cold brew. At the coffee shop, that can be a
splurge, but at home, switching to cold brew might actually save you money. A
good cold brew maker, like Wirecutter‚Äôs pick from OXO
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/KJNyO-7g3qhcCcE5Hohb9Q~~/AAAAAQA~-VPFMZP8mXf1SH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~],
can smooth out the rough edges of inexpensive, mediocre beans, producing a
sweet, mellow concentrate that will last all week. I even like to brew the same
grounds twice ‚Äî coffee pros might disapprove, but the results are great,
especially with a splash of milk. ‚Äî Marguerite Preston

New Jersey Devils vs. New York Rangers, N.H.L. playoffs: These two teams are so
close that you could probably see one arena from the roof of the other without
the skyscrapers in the way. Maybe that‚Äôs why they have each looked so

in Newark, and then the Devils won two games in Manhattan. The Devils now lead
the series, 3-2, and can advance with a win tonight. Good news for them: The
game is in New York. 8 p.m. Eastern on ABC.

-1232533050.subject: [hcs-d] Fwd: Startery S23 Summer Cohort
-1232533050.text:
Forwarding for a friend! Startery <http://Startery.io> offers students
interested in startups the opportunity to both develop their own ventures
as well as consult for current startups. Check out the info for their
summer program.

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Tejas Ravindra <tejas@startery.io>
Date: Fri, Apr 28, 2023 at 10:28‚ÄØAM
Subject: Startery S23 Summer Cohort
To: <calebcapoccia@college.harvard.edu>


Hey Caleb,

Here are more details about the Startery Summer Intensive Program:

Our platform serves as an incubation and consulting resource for student
operators looking to complete bounties for startups. The summer program is
divided into two parts - the incubator, where students build an idea from
the ground up, and consulting, where students tackle specific business
challenges for startups. Our unique hybrid consulting/incubator approach
allows students to develop crucial skills that can be applied towards
starting their own companies or future careers. We work primarily with
early-stage startups and cover a wide range of industries, from healthcare,
robotics, and education to web3 and AI.

The incubator program culminates in a demo day, where student teams pitch
their ideas to a panel of investors, experts, and advisors. The winning
team receives a free client voucher, redeemable for free services from our
operators the following year.

For your reference, I‚Äôve also attached a flier you could share along with a
blurb to post around:

‚ÄúJoin the ultimate summer experience with Startery's Summer Intensive
Program. Develop in-demand skills by working on client projects and bring
your own startup ideas to life, all at the same time! Get hands-on guidance
from experienced entrepreneurs and a chance to compete for a free client
voucher. This is the perfect opportunity to equip yourself with skills that
will set you apart in the workforce and launch your own entrepreneurial
journey!‚Äù

Thanks you so much for your help!

Best,

Tejas

Tejas Ravindra
*Founding Partner at Startery LLP*
*tejas@startery.io <tejas@startery.io>*

-1178067583.subject: [ADAMS] COME TO RIVERBEND PARK RALLY TOMORROW
-1178067583.text:
Did you love weekend park access on Memorial Drive last year? Questioning
why that isn‚Äôt happening again?

We are too. The state agency overseeing the park refuses to acknowledge the
needs of our community ‚Äî 94% of residents want the park open to people and
closed to cars, and the Cambridge City Council passed several orders
supporting it as well.

What can we do? *We can rally.* Tomorrow at 1:00 PM at the Weeks
Footbridge, come join over 300 residents and elected officials (including
potentially Rep. Ayanna Pressley!) who are planning to urge the DCR to open
the park all weekend. Register at https://rallyatriverbend.eventbrite.com!

Thanks,
Clyve Lawrence

-290395087.subject: [hcs-d] Fwd: [HUMIC] Board Applications are Open! APPLY BY FRIDAY 5/5.
-290395087.text:
[image: humicblackbanner.png]
HUMIC Board/officer applications are open!!! *We are looking to recruit
highly motivated and committed board members for the 2023-24 school year.
Apply here
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSduHbSk3kRuC6gJpnK1XoV4_JwmNb4t_KXXrYSG6aqSwURbAw/viewform>
by Friday May 5th.*

The Harvard Undergraduate Machine Intelligence Community (HUMIC)
<http://harvardai.org> is Harvard's primary space for undergraduates
interested in *artificial intelligence and machine learning *to gather,
socialize, and learn from one another. We serve the unique role of hosting
completely undergraduate-run workshops and projects exploring
state-of-the-art developments. *We unlock the next generation of a liberal
arts education: liberal arts augmented by machine intelligence.*

We run lots of exciting events including the Future of Intelligence
Fellowship (FIF) and the AI Project Incubator. We invite AI luminaries for
talks and private dinners (e.g., Daniel Gross - founder of AI at
Y-Combinator - and Surya Bhupatiraju - research engineer at DeepMind). We
vibe out and build the community for all things machine learning - check
out the merch that we just unleashed (courtesy AnhPhu @
Maker's Collective). *What are you waiting for? Apply
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSduHbSk3kRuC6gJpnK1XoV4_JwmNb4t_KXXrYSG6aqSwURbAw/viewform>
to be a board member now!*

[image: IMG_2105.JPG]

-1782948818.subject: WICS Mentorships - End of Semester Special Outings Announcement
-1782948818.text:
Hi all,
Thanks for participating in the WICS Mentorships programs this semester!
As an end of semester treat, we'll be offering up *ONE SPECIALLY
FUNDED end-of-semester outing to ALL mentor-mentee pairs. YAY!*
If you go on an outing between now and the end of this semester with your
mentee(s), you'll be treated to *$30 in funding PER PERSON* (e.g. $60 per
mentor-mentee pair, $90 per mentor+2 mentees pair). This outing funding is
in addition to the normal funding for 5 outings per pair.

Happy reading period, and good luck with finals! All pending reimbursement
requests will be processed at the end of this semester. You have until EOD
May 14th to submit reimbursement requests :)

*Gentle reminder*: you cannot "stack" mentorship outings funding--e.g. you
can't combine funding for 5 outings all in one go for Omakase. If you spend
more than the per-person limit on one outing, no worries, we'll refund up
to $20/30 per person (depending on normal outing vs end-of-semester
outing). We want you to spend more time together, not just meet once!!

WiCS Love,
Katrina

-777844713.subject: [Fyre] $15 For Your Thoughts on How to Help Change Health Access
-777844713.text:
We want to hear your voice! üéâ

Youth to Youth is a youth-created survey that aims to better understand the
health needs and concerns of other youth of color in the Boston area. For 5
weeks, answer a set of short questions over text and earn money with each
response! We want to hear your opinions on COVID-19, mental health, and
more! Your voice can make meaningful change!

So, what does participating in the study look like?

   -

   Answer 5 short questions over text every week for 5 weeks
   -

   Get $$$ (up to $15) when you‚Äôre done ü§ëü§ëü§ë


Why should I join?

   -

   Your answers can help inform health policy and health programming in the
   Boston area
   -

   You can help increase the representation of minorities in research just
   by sharing your opinions!


Interested in joining? Fill out this form (link here
<https://redcap.bumc.bu.edu/surveys/?s=WCNDKYL9K8NTWWTX>) or scan the QR
code below!


[image: image.png]

For more information about this study, please contact the research team at
MACEAL@bmc.org.

Thank you!


Joelle Williams

A.B. in Human Developmental & Regenerative Biology | Faculty of Arts and
Sciences

-663047692.subject: HULS board elections
-663047692.text:
Hi everyone,

The voting form for HULS board positions is now open! Vote using this link
<https://forms.gle/PWNKgMuESHPhHMWG6> by 5pm on Tuesday, May 2. Candidate
statements are below:

---------------

*Jacob Fernandes (running for co-president):* When I first joined HULS, I
was a first year who knew that I loved linguistics and creating conlangs,
but knew literally nobody outside of a tiny reddit community who shared
this interest. As far as I knew, I just had some weird niche interest. But
at HULS, I found a community who welcomed me, nerded out with me and let me
indulge in my conlangery by teaching, learning, and collaborating. As a
HULS board member and longtime HULS member, I have gained a greater
appreciation for everyone in the club and what it means to run a student
organization. I have made an impact on the club already, like helping
organize and host HULS' first Halloween Party. But I want to be able to
lead HULS to a brighter future, where we can reach even more students,
whether they are casual linguistics, computer scientists, professional
researchers, or even semanticists.

*Blake Lopez (running for co-president):* While serving as your
Co-President this past year, I‚Äôve been lucky enough to get to know you all
and to learn how best to run our club, and I want to continue serving as
your Co-President this upcoming academic year in order to take advantage of
this knowledge and give you all the best experience possible. Together,
we‚Äôve landed high-level guest speakers like Barbara Partee and Gennaro
Chierchia‚Äîfor next year, why not try to get Noam Chomsky to make a long
awaited in-person appearance? Or to get anyone else you‚Äôd like to see? The
sky‚Äôs the limit! The sky‚Äôs also the limit for the hilarious new
developments we‚Äôve made in our conlang, which I hope to continue helping us
to innovate. It‚Äôs been my honor to serve as your Co-President, and I hope
to get the chance to make our next year, my last year here, a great one.

*Antara Bhattacharya (running for secretary): *Hi I'm Antara and I am
perpetually Very Excited about linguistics things! I've been in HULS since
I arrived on campus and I love the wonderful linguistics community and all
our weekly meeting chaos/increasingly cursed conlanging. I would like to
help make more of it happen! As secretary I want to do lots of fun stuff
like run meetings for constructing/solving linguistics olympiad problems (I
am very involved with running ling olympiads!), finally having the
linguistics meme meeting, and getting more students involved + getting more
guest speakers. You all are awesome I love HULS <3

*John Harrington (running for treasurer):* HULS is one of the highlights of
my week where I get to hang out and do wacky linguistics stuff with
like-minded peers. I've previously served as Logistics Manager, and have
helped out in an unofficial capacity this past semester after my time
abroad, and I would love to continue to help facilitate the activities and
operations of the club next year as Treasurer.

---------

It's been amazing working with all four of these people, who've all helped
out with Linguistics Society officially and unofficially this semester.
Thanks to everyone who came to meetings this last year! I'm sad to be
graduating and leaving you all :(

Warmly,
Joanna <3

-302570594.text:
*Applications due at Midnight!!!*

On Fri, Apr 21, 2023, 11:23 AM Harvard SEAS SHPE <harvardseasshpe@gmail.com>
wrote:

We are happy to announce that we have officially opened applications
> <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSf487v213B9i86NR8EU0JE_wy8vSrl7NXxGU24i-xRsfhYuXg/viewform?usp=sf_link>

>
> If you're interested in promoting the success of Hispanic communities in
> STEM this is the club for you!!!
> [image: Board App Pub.png]
> The Deadline to apply is *Sunday April 30th*
>
> We highly encourage everyone who is interested to apply!
> You don't have to be Hispanic and/or an Engineer, if this cause speaks to
> you, please apply!!!
>
> We look forward to reading your applications.
